PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Middle East
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned petitioners are appalled at the use of violence in an attempt to resolve international problems. Our concern is heightened when a peaceful resolution of the crisis in the Gulf was possible. Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should demand that the Australian Government:
(a) immediately withdraw from hostilities in the Gulf.
(b) bring our naval force home from the Gulf.
(c) initiate a peace process similar to that we have negotiated in the Cambodian conflict.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Middle East
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

* The hasty deployment of Australian military personnel to the Middle East at the request of the President of the United States has involved Australia in an undeclared war with potentially disastrous consequences for Australia and the people of the Middle East.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
* Immediately withdraw all Australian military personnel from the Middle East and pursue a foreign policy designed to secure justice and human rights for all of the people of the Middle East.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Colston (from 31 citizens) and Vallentine (from 250 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bushmead Rifle Range
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request the Senate to urge the Federal Government to retain the Bushmead Rifle Range in Western Australia;
That it remain in the hands of the Federal Government with a commitment to its ongoing use by the various rifle clubs of Western Australia.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Release From Custody of Yang Wei
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that:

Mr YANG Wei of Shanghai, People's Republic of China, formerly a PhD candidate student at the University of Arizona, USA, has been illegally jailed in the Shanghai No. 1 Detention House, without trial since July 14, 1989, following his public support of the Chinese Alliance for Democracy and his outspoken condemnation of the June 4, 1989 massacre. We fear for the physical and mental well-being of YANG Wei.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the government of the People's Republic of China to secure the immediate release from custody of YANG Wei.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to ensure that sections 59 and 60 of the Defence Act 1903 can not be applied to the conflict in the Persian Gulf. These sections
authorise the Government to call on Australian men between the ages of 18 and 60 years to serve in the Australian Defence forces for the duration of the war.

The Government has stated categorically that it will not revive the National Service Act of 1951 in order to conscript Australian men into the forces to serve in this war. The Australian Democrats understand those statements to be Government policy. We are introducing this Bill to ensure that that policy is adhered to for the duration of this conflict regardless of the demands or pressures which may be placed on the Government or any future Government to commit large numbers of land forces to the Gulf. As this measure is simply to place on the statute books Government policy with which the Australian Democrats fully agree, we can see no reason why the legislation should not gain a speedy passage through both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

This is perhaps the classic example of the Democrats in our perceived role of keeping them honest. It is our aim to firmly shut the door which currently leads to the option of re-introduction of conscription by the Government without reference to either Parliament or the people.

This move is of course not going to come as a surprise to any who have sat in this Chamber for any length of time. Some eight years ago, former Democrat Deputy Leader, Senator Colin Mason, introduced a Bill to require a referendum before conscription could ever again be implemented by an Australian Government. In 1987, his successor, Senator Paul McLean, introduced a similar measure, with the additional requirement that before Australian forces are ever again committed to overseas service a vote of both Houses of Parliament would be required. I therefore take grave exception to the mindless comments of some of the Hawke Government's Ministers who claim that this is an opportunistic and cheap publicity stunt.

An examination of Sections 59 and 60 of the Defence Act could lead to the view that if a Government wanted to re-introduce conscription to meet demands placed on us by our allies in relation to the Gulf War, it may be difficult to implement. None of the provisions of the National Service Act 1951 would be available to the Government as has already been established by the Minister for Defence Senator Ray in answer to a question by Senator McLean on 12th November.

However, while it could be argued that at best Sections 59 and 60 of the Defence Act provide a doorway to conscription which is cramped and mis-shapen the Australian Democrats would argue that any Government determined on such a course could still wriggle through it. The Proclamation of the call-up under Sections 59 and 60 of the Defence Act could detail procedures which the Government could in fact wholly draw from the now suspended National Service Act of 1951 to ensure that the call-up's validity and effectiveness was secured against any legal challenges by those seeking to resist the call-up.

This brings me to the substantive basis for the Bill. The Australian Democrats agree with the Government that conscription is an option which should only be available to a Government in order to meet a threat to Australian Security from a foreign power or powers. There is no suggestion that such a situation exists as part of the Gulf conflict nor that it could exist as a result of any future developments in the Middle East.

These views on the pre-conditions for the re-introduction of conscription have of course been a cause for historic debate in Australia in the past. The Labor Government which took Australia into the First World War collapsed over the issue of conscription being used to increase our commitment to a conflict which did not represent a threat to Australian security. The Liberal Government which took Australia to Vietnam was defeated largely over the issue of conscription being used to fight a United States sponsored war of intervention which did not represent a threat to Australian security.

Just as the ALP gained new members because of its opposition to our involvement in Vietnam and was able to gain the strength required to win office in 1972, Australian Democrat offices are now hearing about the massive number of resignations from the ALP and loss of public support because of their commitment of our forces in the Gulf. The people of Australia will ultimately make the decisive judgement on this horrific blunder by the Hawke Government. In the meantime the protests will continue and public opinion will continue to turn against the war.

During this period the Australian Democrats seek to limit this Government or any future Government to the level of commitment already made and to work towards the recall of our forces as soon as possible.

Mr President, Australian Democrats offices have received many calls from parents of sons over 18 years of age appealing to us to make sure they will not be called up and sent to the Gulf. There is a high level of anxiety in the community about the Government's commitment of our forces to the Gulf but that anxiety reaches grave proportions in the minds of those whose family members would be subject to conscription if a Commonwealth Government was persuaded to re-introduce it. No amount of assurances by the Prime Minister or the Minister for Defence can calm that anxiety more effectively than the speedy passage of this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that General Business notice of motion No. 154 standing in my name relating to the Baltic states be taken as formal.
—There is an objection to this motion being taken as formal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move, pursuant to contingent notice:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to General Business notice of motion No. 154, standing in the name of Senator Hill for this day, relating to Soviet military actions in the Baltic States.

Horrible things are occurring in the Baltic states today and this matter is therefore of great urgency. Today as we are assembled here Soviet troops are moving into Estonia and the democratically elected parliamentarians of Estonia and their supporters are having to put up barriers around their Parliament House.

Two days ago, at least five Latvians were killed when Soviet special beret troops attempted to storm the Interior Ministry building in that state. A few days earlier in Lithuania, as honourable senators are aware, Soviet troops stormed something like seven different institutions, killing some 14 persons, including innocent civilians, and injuring many others.

Again, as we stand here, there are rumours of presidential rule from the Soviet Union, which is the equivalent of martial law, and of the democratically elected leaders of the Baltic states being called to Moscow to be told this unfortunate news.

Huge rallies are occurring in Moscow in support of the Baltic states and those who are prepared to stand and defend their so dearly won and new freedom. It is so critically important that democracies around the world at this time of urgency give support for those within the Soviet Union and the Baltic states who are prepared to stand up against this horrible violence.

It is most regrettable that this seems to be occurring not simply by coincidence with the Gulf war, when the attention of the world community has been diverted to that occurrence. Therefore, to some degree the international community has been unable to focus on the type and extent of the violence that is occurring in the Baltic states. If it were not for the Gulf war, the events in Lithuania, where tanks in fact ran over civilians, would have been regarded as another Tiananmen Square incident; and we know the extent of the world community's reaction to that event. But it has not occurred because of the diversion of the Gulf war, which only increases our responsibility to take action today and at the very least to pass a motion which condemns the violence that is occurring and calls upon certain actions to be taken.

This Parliament is not the only body that is concerned about this matter. Democracies throughout the world-in Britain, the United States of America and the European Community-have been passing similar motions calling upon their governments to put pressure upon the Soviet Union to desist from the use of violence in this way and in fact to look at other possibilities. Honourable senators would be aware that today the European Community is considering its resolutions in respect of aid support to the Soviet Union and the big economic powers will also be looking at their economic packages to the Soviet Union.

So the matter is critically urgent. It is important that the Soviet Union is left in no doubt at all that the world's democracies simply will not tolerate this abuse and killing of innocent people who are simply wishing to stand up for the freedoms they had won at a price after decades of occupation. They will not be subjected to the restraints of dictatorship as they have been in the past and we must therefore offer our support. If this motion is passed and the Senate understands the urgency of this matter, I will seek to move:
That the Senate-
(1) deplores the brutality used against the citizens of Lithuania and the deaths of fourteen people arising from the use of force by Soviet troops on 13 January;
(2) condemns the assault by Soviet troops on the Interior Ministry in Riga, Latvia on 21 January in which at least four persons were killed and nine injured;
(3) is appalled by the additional threat of force against the democratically elected Parliaments of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania;
(4) demands that the Soviet Union in accordance with universally accepted principles of human rights desist from the use of military force and violence against the peoples of the Baltic states;
(5) calls upon the Australian Government in conjunction with other democratic states to protest such brutality to the Soviet authorities and in international human rights forums; and

(6) calls on the Soviet Government to facilitate the peaceful transition to independence of those Republics which have expressed through democratically elected parliaments a desire for self-determination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion was not called formal and many people opposite would realise why it was not. On many occasions one has had to negotiate in order that a motion can be declared formal. I think most members of the Opposition understand that we on this side of the chamber cannot support a motion which calls on the Government to do something being dealt with in this way-other processes have to be adopted. Senator Hill apparently-and I will withdraw this if it is not true-has shown no flexibility in modifying this motion so that we can all join him in respect of the principles that he has enunciated in his motion for the suspension of standing orders.
—No. I redrafted it last night to meet some concerns and your side came back with further requests today that I was not prepared to meet.

—All I can say-and I have not been involved in the process-is that I think it is a pity that we have not been able to resolve a motion to get the unanimous support of the Senate in a formal process. I think Senator Hill would concede that over the years we have never allowed a clause through that calls on the Government; it is usually phrased in another way which does not see the Senate as a formal chamber, with us being part of the chamber, calling on the Government to do something.

SPEECH.PARA: My first point is to explain why, in spite of most of the substance here, which I have no problem with, we could not agree to the motion being called formal. Now we face the secondary issue, which is whether we should suspend standing orders to debate this motion. It is an important issue; one cannot belittle that.

We also have another important issue to continue to debate this morning. Necessary arrangements have been made so that that debate is carried on national television and we are eroding that time at the moment. I believe it should have priority. That in no way denigrates this other issue-it is very important. But Parliament was specifically called back to debate the Gulf issue. I refer Senator Hill to Dr Hewson's press interview where he consistently said that we were coming back for two days to debate the Gulf issue and the Gulf issue alone.

If standing orders are suspended and we have a long and sustained debate on this matter, I think we will very much be treating the other debate as a second issue. Quite frankly, I think that would be putting the cart before the horse. I think it is a pity, given the fact that there is almost unanimity on the issues, that this matter could not have been sorted out so that we could have had a united resolution of the Parliament. I do not know whether there is any point in reopening the negotiations to see whether we can come to a motion with which we all agree and which will not require a large and long debate that intrudes into the Gulf debate. I think it would be a pity if it does.

Again, I recognise this other very important issue but life does go on. The Gulf cannot dominate everything; other issues need to be addressed and cannot be put into the background. But, I think that this morning, given the reason for the recall of Parliament and the arrangements that have been made, it would be a preferable course for this chamber to finish the Gulf debate and to consider the other matter over the next few hours to see whether we can, through negotiation, get a motion that not only this side and the other side of the chamber but also the Australian Democrats and the Independents can agree with and which can be put through in a formal sense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the suspension of standing orders. While Senator Ray pointed out that the Parliament has been recalled to debate a specific matter, the matters in Senator Hill's motion- matters which we have also raised by way of notice in this chamber, even today-are currently very urgent and important. They are matters which are related to the very debate which the Parliament has been recalled to undertake.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important for the Government and the people of Australia to get a clear view of where their parliamentary representatives stand on this matter. Bearing in mind that many members of the Senate have yet to speak, I understand it is intended that this should be a limited debate. We believe that this is a matter of urgency. We support the suspension of Standing Orders at this time. Senator Ray made the point that there should be negotiation of notices between the parties and the Independents in this place. This is only a two-day sitting. It does take time for negotiations particularly with Ministers, shadow Ministers and my portfolio holders, the same people engaged in the substantive debate during this non-sitting period.

By virtue of the statements we have already made, I think it is quite clear that we, along with members of the Opposition, consider this to be a very important and opportune time to discuss this particular issue and, therefore, we support the suspension of Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, support the suspension of Standing Orders. I will be very brief. I will make two points: firstly, newspapers have only one front page. If the Gulf war was not taking place at this time, splashed across every front page of every newspaper in every State of Australia-indeed the world-would have been the brutal treatment by the Soviet army of the peaceful demonstrators in Lithuania trying to protect the media; that is, free speech. Secondly, overnight we heard of the brutal killing of people in Latvia during the storming of the Interior Ministry.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Hill has said, this Parliament ought to understand that the parliaments of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia-the centres of democracy-have had to be barricaded, barbed wire has been put around them, tank traps have been put around them so as to prevent the Soviet armed forces from entering those citadels of democracy. We, as a parliament, have a very important task.

Senator Ray indicated that for the Government to agree to this, it ought to surely agree to what it is being called upon to do. In the motion as I see it the Government is being called upon to do one thing. Paragraph (e) states:
calls upon the Australian Government in conjunction with other democratic states to protest such brutality to the Soviet authorities and in international human rights fora;
The Government has already done the first part, but what about the international fora? What is wrong with protesting about the brutality in international fora? What is wrong with this motion?

I was consulted late last night on this motion. As far as I am concerned, it is not strong enough. Surely the Government is not being called upon to do very much other than what it has already done thus far. Therefore, I support the suspension of Standing Orders and believe that this motion ought to be carried unanimously by the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to support Senator Hill. I am very pleased to hear of the support he has from Senator Powell and Senator Harradine in moving the suspension of Standing Orders on this matter. I do regret the reasons, which may be explainable, that this matter has not been declared formal. This is a major issue indeed. As Senator Harradine has said, if we had not had the smokescreen from the Baltic states point of view of the Gulf war, it would be major headlines around the world; indeed, in many instances it is today. It is on the front page of the Australian and it has been on the front page of many other newspapers as well. I use the word `smokescreen' very deliberately because the world may not remember that the annexation of the Baltic states and the movement into the Baltic states by the Soviet Union in 1940 took place under the smokescreen of the day before the fall of Paris to the Nazi forces. I think that there is a very strong argument to be made that the timing of the Soviet action in relation to Lithuania, Latvia and now Estonia was very significantly influenced by the events in the Gulf.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a major issue. It is one of the two issues that have made a major setback to the cause of world peace and stability in the last 12 months. This issue, plus the Gulf crisis, are the two issues of paramount importance in determining the course of order, stability and peace, or no peace, in this world.

I must say to Senator Ray that there was no suggestion here that this matter ought to be given priority over the issues that we have been recalled to debate, but to suggest-I am sure Senator Ray did not mean to do this-that this was a matter of other than significant importance I think would be a mistake.

I did not find Senator Ray's comments convincing in relation to his opposition to declaring the motion formal on the basis that one paragraph of the six paragraph motion moved by Senator Hill calls upon the Australian Government to do something. Paragraph (e) calls upon the Australian Government in conjunction with other democratic states to protest such brutality, as is occurring in Lithuania, Latvia and now Estonia, to the Soviet authorities and in international human rights fora.
The key action paragraph of the motion is paragraph (f), which states:

calls on the Soviet Government to facilitate the peaceful transition to independence of those republics which have expressed through democratically elected parliaments a desire for self-determination.

That is really the key paragraph of this motion. I hope that not one member of this Parliament would be opposed to that paragraph. Indeed, if there were such opposition, then it makes a mockery of the stance that this nation has so proudly and rightly taken for 50 years virtually without exception on the question of the legality or illegality of the annexation of the Baltic states by the Soviet Union in 1940.

I believe that this is a very important motion indeed. I hope that the Government will have another chance to look at its position on it because I think that it would do great good to the cause that we are all striving for of peace, stability and order if we could have unanimous support for this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that, on the basis of the Opposition agreeing to make one very small amendment to the text of the motion, I am prepared to accept it and have it declared formal. There was never any basic problem with the substance of the motion. The difficulty was that as so often in these matters there had not been sufficient advance consultation to--
—Hang on, I gave it to you last night for that purpose.
—Yes, but not before the Opposition had given notice of it, as I understand it.
—We even varied it at your request before we gave notice of it.

—I am sorry, I had not been personally involved in that. I did not know about that until I got in this morning and was told that the motion as moved had two problems. One was in the formulation of the last paragraph. I had not had time obviously in the rough and tumble of events with the Gulf to focus on that. I looked at that a few minutes ago and decided that there is no problem in terms of the formulation of the last paragraph. The content and the flavour of it are clear and are entirely consistent with the position that this Government has taken. I am not prepared to quibble about the language in which that is expressed; I think that is okay.

SPEECH.PARA: The remaining problem we have, as so often with these motions, is the penultimate paragraph calling upon the Government to do various things-which conveys the implication that we have not been doing them. I want to say for the record that so far as the events in Lithuania are concerned, we have made very clear our position on that-publicly by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and in terms of direct representations to the Soviet Ambassador on 14 January. As far as the events in Latvia are concerned, yesterday afternoon the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Woolcott, made our concerns very clear indeed to the Soviet Ambassador and I am in the process of putting out a further Government statement re-enforcing that in an overt and public way.

It is something we have been doing in the course of events and, with the utmost respect, we do not need to be told that we should be doing it on matters of this kind. I can assure the Senate that we are very conscious of the issues concerned. Senator Hill, with his usual grace on these matters, has conceded that point and is prepared to amend slightly the language of that penultimate paragraph accordingly. In the sweet spirit which is thus prevailing, I hope that we can curtail what otherwise might have been a protracted debate and get on record a very firm parliamentary statement of a position that obviously in substance we all share.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply say that I support the suspension of Standing Orders, which I thought would have been clear from the motion I moved this morning which was in similar terms. I did so specifically because I returned, as did many other senators and members, from overseas having been away only three days. I was, at the time of returning, attending a meeting of the executive of the International Democrat Union. That executive meeting managed to discuss not only the Gulf itself and the questions that had to be dealt with but also the question of the Baltic crisis. I am pleased to see that the Government is now of the view that we are able to deal with both matters at the same time as well as meetings of an international nature and character.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel that with the importance of what is occurring in the Baltic nations if we did not place on record at the recalling of the Parliament our strong condemnation of the actions against the freely elected parliaments of the people of the Baltic states then we would be sadly remiss. I think the importance of the press conference called by Mr Yeltsin calling on Russia's troops not to fire upon the people of those Baltic nations has been very significant and if we had failed to deal with this matter in this Parliament we would have been most remiss. I am very pleased to see that the Government has capitulated and has seen fit to allow the Standing Orders to be suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly support the motion to suspend Standing Orders. I am delighted to hear that the Government has agreed that Senator Hill's motion is reasonable and should be passed by this Parliament. I have been totally appalled by the events that have been occurring in Eastern Europe, particularly in the Baltic states, and could not understand why the Prime Minister is not making as much fuss about this as he made about the Chinese tanks running over the citizens of China. This is a worse situation because these countries are not part of the Soviet Union. They have been independent countries and recognised as independent countries by all governments in this Parliament since Mr Whitlam made his incredible faux pas in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I see this as being very much akin to the Soviet attack on Hungary and Czechoslovakia. Surely that warrants this Government protesting very loudly about this matter. The only other thing I wanted to raise was the difference between this motion, No. 154, and my motion, No. 156, which I hope will be carried formally in a few minutes time. My motion was actually prepared before No. 154 and dealt with events before the recent attack by the Soviet troops on the citizens of Latvia, which is why I did not mention Latvia in my motion. Also, I went directly to the point of calling on the Government of the Soviet Union to act on this matter whereas Senator Hill, in addition to calling on the Soviet Government to do something, calls on the Australian Government to take some action. There are some fundamental differences between the two motions, but I believe that both should be carried by this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats would like to put on record our thanks to the Senate for having negotiated and allowed this matter to become formal; our support for the people of the Baltic states and for the motion; and, particularly, our abhorrence of the actions that have been taken by the Soviet Union, particularly in Lithuania. It now looks as though the Soviet Union is taking these actions in Latvia, and also, as Senator Michael Baume was saying this morning, in the Ukraine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I think the correct procedure now in view of the expressions in the Senate would be to withdraw that motion and put my motion in an amended form to the Senate. In view of the sentiments that have been expressed, I seek leave to withdraw the motion to suspend Standing Orders and to move my motion in an amended form.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is proper that I should respond to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) who indicated that he was concerned about a long debate. There was never an intention for a long debate on this matter. There was never an intention to divert from the principal reasons for which the Parliament has been called back. As I sought to explain in seeking the suspension, one of the great concerns about this issue is that it is not receiving the attention that it demands from the world community because the world's attention has been diverted to the Gulf issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point I make briefly is that we can always find some set of words to accommodate the Government's concern that if the motion is passed in this form it will mean Government senators calling upon their own Government to take certain action with which they are uncomfortable. But the real area of concern that could not be accommodated came this morning when I was told that the Government could not live with the word `independence' in the last paragraph. The Opposition believes that it is absolutely critical that the Soviet Government is called upon to facilitate the peaceful transition to independence of those republics which have expressed through democratically elected parliaments a desire for self-determination.

The Government has had a rethink, as Senator Evans indicated, and is prepared to accept paragraph (f) of our motion. We are pleased that it has reached that position. I seek to amend my motion by deleting paragraph (e) and substituting the words:

strongly believes that the Australian Government in conjunction with other democratic states should protest and continue to protest such brutality to the Soviet authorities and in international human rights fora; and

In moving the motion in that amended form I hope the Government will take that seriously. We on this side of the chamber would like to see it take the question of this brutality to the floor of the United Nations General Assembly. We would like to see it taking it to the Human Rights Commission using all the resources that are open to a country such as Australia to bring force upon the Soviet Union to desist from this brutality. I move:
That the Senate-
(a) deplores the brutality used against the citizens of Lithuania and the deaths of fourteen people arising from the use of force by Soviet troops on 13 January 1991;
(b) condemns the assault by Soviet troops on the Interior Ministry in Riga, Latvia on 21 January 1991 in which at least four persons were killed and nine injured;
(c) is appalled by the additional threat of force against the democratically elected parliaments of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania;
(d) demands that the Soviet Union, in accordance with universally accepted principles of human rights, desist from the use of military force and violence against the peoples of the Baltic States;

(e) strongly believes that the Australian Government in conjunction with other democratic states should protest and continue to protest such brutality to the Soviet authorities and in international human rights fora; and

(f) calls on the Soviet Government to facilitate the peaceful transition to independence of those republics which have expressed through democratically elected parliaments a desire for self-determination.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Lewis) agreed to:
That the Senate-
(a) condemns those in authority in the Soviet Union who have acted to resume by force military control over Lithuania;
(b) profoundly deplores the killing of innocent Lithuanian citizens and the use of Soviet troops and tanks at the front door of the Lithuanian Parliament;
(c) calls on the Government of the Soviet Union to bring this brutality to an end and to permit the fledgling moves towards democracy in the Baltic States to take their natural course; and
(d) conveys these sentiments to the Government of the Soviet Union.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATHS OF FORMER SENATOR EDWARD ALBERT ROBERTSON AND THE HON. GORDON MUNRO BRYANT, E.D.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT: It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the deaths of former Senator Edward Albert Robertson, Senator for the Northern Territory from 1975 to 1987, on 5 January 1991, and the Hon. Gordon Munro Bryant, E.D., a former member of the House of Representatives for the division of Wills from 1955 to 1980, on 14 January 1991.

I understand that it would accord with the wishes of the Senate if motions of condolence for the deceased were debated on 12 February 1991. I ask honourable senators to stand, in silence, as a mark of respect to the deceased.
Honourable senators standing in their places-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 January, on the motion by Senator Button:
That the Senate:

(a) reaffirms its support for an on-going role for the United Nations in promoting world peace and the self-determination of nations and in particular the resolutions of the Security Council directed to end the aggression of Iraq against Kuwait;
(b) affirms its support for Australia's positive response to the request made by the United Nations Security Council in Resolution 678 for support in implementing that Resolution;
(c) expresses its full confidence in, and support for, Australian Forces serving with the United Nations sanctioned multi-national forces in the Gulf;
(d) deplores Iraq's widening of the conflict by its unprovoked attack upon Israel; and

(e) recognises, as those with whom we are acting now in the Gulf have recognised, the need to intensify efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, including a just resolution of the Palestinian issue and the continuing security of Israel, once the crisis in the Gulf is resolved.
and on the amendment moved thereto by Senator Coulter:
Omit all words after ``That the Senate:'' substitute:

Reaffirms its support for an on-going role for the United Nations in promoting world peace and the self-determination of nations, and in particular the resolutions of the Security Council directed to end the aggression of Iraq against Kuwait by means of sanctions and diplomacy

Affirms its support for Australia's positive response to the request made by the United Nations Security Council in Resolution 661 for support in implementing comprehensive sanctions against Iraq until it leaves Kuwait.

Condemns the Australian Government's warlike interpretation of Resolution 678 of the United Nations Security Council, and calls for an immediate ceasefire, and the withdrawal of Australian warships from combat duty, which is consistent with that resolution.

Expresses its full confidence in, and support for, Australian forces in the Gulf, and places the burden of responsibility for the misguided decision to deploy them to the region solely on the Federal Government and Opposition.
Deplores Iraq's widening of the conflict by its unprovoked attack on Israel.
Recognises the need to intensify non-military efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, including a just resolution of the Palestinian issue and the continuing security of Israel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the motion moved by the Government regarding the Gulf crisis. In speaking, I indicate my total opposition to the circulated amendment from the Australian Democrats which, I understand, also has the support of Senator Vallentine. In supporting the motion, I want to bring to the attention of the Senate one aspect which I know some speakers have already drawn attention to, but which in its own way justifies the actions that the allies have taken in the Gulf; it is the appalling human rights record of the regime in Iraq, not just since Iraq's invasion and plundering of Kuwait over the last six months, but the regime of Saddam Hussein and the Baath Party over the last 20 years.

SPEECH.PARA: I am, like many members of this chamber, a member of Amnesty International and the Parliamentary Amnesty International Group. There is probably no country that has had more adverse reports in the last 20 years than Iraq regarding human rights abuses. I draw to the attention of the Senate some of these abuses to give a flavour of what has been going on in Iraq over the last 20 years.

I refer to a report of Amnesty International on Iraq's occupation of Kuwait which came out at the end of last year. It is called Human Rights Violations Since 2 August. It is quite a detailed report. I think other members of the Senate have seen copies of it and may have had the opportunity to read the full report.

I bring the attention of the Senate to some of the lists of human rights abuses and methods of torture that the Iraq regime has been using against the citizens of Kuwait. On pages 37, 38, 39, and 40 Amnesty International carefully lists, from interviews with people who have fled Kuwait, the types of tortures that have been used against the citizens in Kuwait. Thirty-eight accounts are given. I will not read them all but I will put on record a few of them to give a very unsavoury flavour of what has been going on. I have been disappointed that in the speeches I have heard in the Senate from the Australian Democrats and from Senator Vallentine there has been no recognition of this appalling record of human rights abuses. That has been quite disappointing. Some of the types of tortures reported by Amnesty International are as follows:

Beatings on all parts of the body, including punching, slapping, delivering Karate-style blows and kicking with heavy army boots. Implements used for beating include canes, metal rods, whips, steel cables, hose pipes, rubber truncheons and rifle butts.
Other methods of torture that are quite common are described as follows:
Falaqa: prolonged beating on the soles of the feet. Sometimes the detainee is then forced to walk or run.
Suspending the detainee by the feet, or by the arms which are tied behind the back.
Beating the detainee while suspended from a rotating fan in the ceiling.
Breaking of the arms, legs or ribs; dislocating elbow and shoulder joints.
Lifting the detainee high up in the air and then dropping him, sometimes resulting in the fracturing of bones.
Applying pressure to the fingers with a clamp-like instrument.
Slashing the face, arms or legs with knives.
Extracting finger and toenails.
Boring a hole in the leg, apparently with a type of drilling tool.
Cutting off of the tongue and ear.
Gouging out of the eyes.
Castration.
Hammering nails into the hands.
Piercing the skin with pins or staplers.
Shooting the detainee in the arm or leg at point-blank range, followed by deprivation of the necessary medical treatment.
Rape of women (including virgins) and young men.
Inserting bottlenecks, sometimes when broken, into the rectum.
Tying a string around the penis and pulling it tightly.
Pumping air using a pipe through the anus, particularly of young boys.

Applying electricity to sensitive parts of the body, including the ears, lips, tongue, fingers, toes and genitals. Sometimes the detainee is doused with water prior to the administration of electricity. The electrical instruments used include electric batons as well as wires fitted with clips (like those used to recharge car batteries but smaller in size).

It goes on through four pages listing the types of torture the Iraqi authorities have used in Kuwait in the last six months. But long before the invasion and occupation of Kuwait, there had been endless reports of the abuse of human rights by the present regime. In a report called Human Rights in Iraq, Middle East Watch from the middle 1980s, the conclusions and recommendations state:

Iraq is a well-organised police state and its government is one of the most brutal and repressive regimes in power today. With the exception of freedom of worship, the Iraqi government denies its citizens all fundamental rights and freedoms, and ruthlessly suppresses even the smallest gestures of dissent. Iraqi citizens enjoy neither freedom of expression nor freedom to form or join political parties or trade unions of their choice. Their government subjects them to forced relocation and deportation, arbitrary arrest and detention, torture, disappearance, and summary and political execution. There is no meaningful legal recourse in Iraq against these abuses.
The Iraqi government imposes its rule through:

the Baath party's monolithic organisation, which penetrates all elements of society and is responsible for enforcing political and social conformity; a pervasive system of informing-such that Iraq has become a nation of informers-which denies Iraqis the right to express their views candidly, even in private, and encourages friends and family members to report on one another;
a highly developed cult of personality for President Saddam Hussein, active participation in which has become a test of loyalty and a prerequisite for advancement;
secret-police agencies that are empowered to arrest, detain without trial, torture and kill.
That is a report from the mid-1980s.
Another report from Amnesty International is entitled IRAQ Evidence of Torture 1985. I will just quote briefly from some of the evidence of torture and abuse of human rights:

Five people said they had been totally or partially stripped: a women said she had been made to stand naked for a long time in front of her interrogators without being blindfolded; three people said their genitals had been pawed.
Eight people, including two women, said they had been threatened with rape, and two with having a bottle inserted into their rectum.
One man said both of these physical abuses had actually been carried out on him.
Eight people said their interrogators had threatened to arrest, torture or rape members of their family, including children.

That was in 1985, long before the invasion of Kuwait. That was the regime conducting its policies against its own people and not even against the Kuwaitis, who it may claim, of course, to be members of another country. It was against its own people.

So we have unlimited evidence that Iraq should stand condemned in the eyes of all civilised people and civilised societies for being one of the worst regimes in the post- Second World War period. There should be absolutely no doubt on the part of anybody in Australia in condemning this regime. In my view, if there is an argument for saying that a war is justified, that military action and intervention against a regime such of that of Saddam Hussein is justified, it is this one.

I am distressed by remarks made in this place by members of the Australian Democrats, and by Senator Vallentine last night in particular, which I find extraordinary. I do not doubt Senator Vallentine's sincerity about being opposed to war. Everybody is opposed to war. But it is a meaningless statement to say that one is opposed to war because, unfortunately, people like Saddam Hussein are not opposed to war. They see it as a logical instrument of international action. Unless we take action against those people, our being opposed to war means that they will always win.

Last night Senator Vallentine quoted the views of Martin Luther King, because two or three days ago in America it was the celebration of Martin Luther King's birthday. She said, `What would Martin Luther King be saying about the American involvement in Iraq'? I would like to quote from Martin Luther King in the 1960s:
He who passively accepts evil is as much involved in it as he who helps to perpetrate it.

Martin Luther King recognised evil. He recognised the evil of the racist policies of the southern states of America with the segregation and took action to overcome it. Obviously in the end he paid with his life for taking those actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was non-violent action.
—But he also recognised that when evil is taking place one has to oppose it. I remind Senator Bell that sometimes to oppose that evil one has to take even further action than passive non-violence.
—Don't misquote King.

—I am quoting what he said and I am saying that he recognised evil. I also want to quote something that has been said here so often in other debates and which was first of all said by Edmund Burke in April 1770. The original statement, which is often paraphrased today, was:

SPEECH.PARA: When bad men combine, the good men associate, else they will fall one by one, an unpitied sacrifice in a contemptible struggle.
That has often been paraphrased as follows:
The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing.

I remember many years ago as a student reading probably what is considered the greatest novel in modern times-Tolstoy's War and Peace. When one reads War and Peace, the theme that comes through consistently is that evil will triumph unless good people combine to oppose it and fight it. If they do not combine to fight it then it will triumph, and that has been the lesson of history.

Probably the greatest historical book written, which is probably the basis of modern historical research, is Edward Gibbon's The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire. If one reads the full unabridged version of that book one will find again that emphasis-that unless good people combine evil will triumph. I think too many people in the Democrats and Senator Vallentine have found themselves falling for the easy thing to say-`we are opposed to war'-without realising that sometimes unless we fight the evil people will win because we do nothing.

I must say that Senator Vallentine also further irritates me with the morality she puts forward-that she is the only one who wants the world to be good; she is the only one who knows how to explain why the world can achieve things through peaceful means. I do not disagree that we all want that, but I also point out to Senator Vallentine that she has no monopoly on virtue, no monopoly on those sorts of views. I point out to Senator Vallentine that, when I and my colleague Senator Walsh were demonstrating in the streets against our involvement in the Vietnam war, Senator Vallentine was a member of the Country Party in Western Australia-a party that supported overtly and strongly our involvement in sending young conscripts to Vietnam.

I understand that after a period of time she left the Country Party. She then joined the Australian Labor Party. She left the Labor Party and joined the Nuclear Disarmament Party. Then she left that and for a while was an independent nuclear disarmament politician, and she is now a member of some sort of Green organisation. I am reminded of a famous statement by Billy Hughes towards the end of his long parliamentary career. He was asked, `You have been a member of the Labor Party, the Nationalist Party, the Liberal Party and the United Australia Party. Why haven't you been a member of the Country Party?'. He said, `Good God man, you have to draw the line somewhere'. It is a line that Senator Vallentine chose not to draw from the very beginning. She has even beaten Billy Hughes's remarkable record of being a member of practically every party conceivable.

The next thing about Senator Vallentine which I find extraordinary is that she issued a press statement on 21 January and she made remarks last night further emphasising it. I want to quote from this part of her press release. She says:

A denial of information to Israel via Nurrungar which would be crucial for their use of Patriot missiles, as such a contribution negates Australia's official policy of even-handedness in the Palestine-Israel conflict.

She is criticising the fact that we are using information from Pine Gap and Nurrungar, but particularly Pine Gap, to warn civilians in Israel that they may be attacked by Scud missiles that not only have conventional warheads but also have, potentially, germ or chemical warheads.

She criticises us for trying to protect ordinary civilians who have made no attack on Iraq and who are not involved in the fighting but are a part of Saddam Hussein's policy of trying to draw Israel into the conflict in order to destroy the Arab coalition that supports the allies. She criticises the use of that information. I would have to say that, under any sort of civilised regime anywhere in the world, that is the most useful thing that Pine Gap can be used for-to warn civilians not only in Israel but in any country that they could be attacked by terror weapons of a mad dictator.

I think it is extraordinary that Senator Vallentine would criticise the Government and criticise the United States for allowing the joint facilities in Australia to provide that sort of warning to ordinary civilians in Israel, or any other country that may be attacked. Senator Vallentine makes the point, and so do the Democrats, that we should have given sanctions more time to work. What I find extraordinary is that when this debate started in August-September of last year, when we said that we would put our naval ships into the Gulf to ensure that the sanctions would be effective, the Democrats and Senator Vallentine opposed it. They said it was terrible to get our ships involved and ensure that the sanctions were effective. Now they are claiming that we should allow more time for the sanctions to be effective.

I find it extraordinary that they would shift their position so dramatically. Five months ago they complained that we were making the sanctions too effective by having our ships there and now they say that we did not give enough time. If we had taken their advice five months ago, the sanctions would not have been in any way effective because none of the allies would have had the ships in the Gulf, the Red Sea or anywhere else, stopping Saddam Hussein's ships getting through with supplies.

Senator Vallentine goes on at some length to say that Australia should not be involved in any war and that we should always use diplomacy. I want to ask Senator Vallentine and the Democrats a question about the negotiations in Cambodia, which is an area that I have had some interest in. I think I am the only member of this chamber who, since the early eighties, has visited Cambodia twice. Probably, and hopefully, some time this year a UN resolution will be carried that says that Cambodia will have a United Nations peacekeeping force, and that Australia will contribute part of its military forces to that peacekeeping force.

I say to Senator Vallentine: what happens if Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge refuse to accept a peace arrangement and start fighting? Are our soldiers supposed not to fight and protect ordinary Cambodian civilians? Are we to say that because we do not agree with any self-defence and with arming our soldiers to protect Cambodians, we are going to stand by and allow Pol Pot to carry out a second genocide? Of course that is absurd. We have to allow, in particular circumstances, the use of force to protect ordinary civilians and ordinary people against the evil that is Pol Pot. Yet if we take the view of Senator Vallentine and the Democrats to its logical conclusion, they say that we should not be in Cambodia using arms to protect the ordinary civilians against the homicidal, psychotic Pol Pot.

Another area where there has been a war for 30 years is Eritrea. I think I am the only member of this Parliament who has visited Eritrea. I support the Eritrean cause because the Eritreans have a just cause. They were illegally incorporated into Ethiopia. I say to Senator Vallentine: do the Eritreans have to lay down their arms and allow another maniac dictator called Mengistu to wipe them out? He has carpet bombed every town that the Eritreans have. He has killed hundreds of thousands of people. He spends 50 per cent of his domestic budget on weapons. Is Senator Vallentine going to say that they have no right to defend themselves? Go and tell the 15-year-old Eritreans I met who are going up to the front to defend themselves and their families that they should lay down their arms and not fight. It would be absurd. We cannot take the view of Senator Vallentine or of the Democrats. We cannot say, `You can't fight. You shouldn't fight to defend yourselves'. There are circumstances in the world where one has to fight, where people have every right to do so.

I want to conclude by putting my view about what has happened in the Gulf and about the future of the UN. For 30 years people, including the Democrats and Senator Vallentine, have been complaining about the ineffectiveness of the UN. They have argued that superpower rivalry has made the UN a useless debating chamber. Finally, at long last the UN is starting to act the way it was envisaged by people like Dr Evatt in 1945-to be the international mediator. Dr Evatt made it quite clear that it did have to have the power to intervene militarily to defend countries from aggression by a neighbour such as Iraq. I quote two parts of Dr Evatt's speech in 1945:
If economic or diplomatic sanctions: are deemed inappropriate to the situation or prove ineffective, the Security Council may take any military action necessary to suppress the aggressor.

It must be made crystal clear that the nations seeking representation in the world organisation must be prepared to contribute their share of physical force to restrain the action of proved aggressors.

That was Dr Evatt in 1945. He knew what powers the United Nations had to have: it had to have the ultimate sanction of military force to stop aggression. Senator Vallentine and the Democrats do not want to concede that point. In not conceding that point, they condemn the UN to endless irrelevancy and uselessness, because an aggressor will know that in the end it will not work.

I hope that as a result of the Gulf decisions in the UN, we have now established the precedents so that the superpowers, whether they be the United States (US), the Soviet Union, Great Britain, France, and the other permanent member of the Security Council, China, understand that from now on there is a new environment in the world, that we expect these sorts of conflicts to be resolved by debate and discussion and that the UN is the appropriate forum in which decisions will be reached. We do not accept unilateral action.

I think it is to be welcomed by those people who have been very critical of the United States, in particular, over not using the UN in past disputes, that the US has now committed itself and is going to find it very difficult in the future to go back on using the UN as the appropriate forum. It will destroy its own credibility in western Europe, with countries such as Australia and with people such as myself, as a member of the Australian Labor Party, if it intends in the future to ignore the UN as the appropriate body to settle international disputes. If it does so, it will suffer the consequences. I think it should be welcomed that in the long run this will mean the UN will triumph as the international body. This has been Labor Party policy for 40 years: it is what we have been seeking to achieve. I think that achievement is something to look forward to.

I have no doubt that from time to time in the future Australia will be required as a middle power in the UN to provide military forces to stop aggression or to be part of a peacekeeping force. I am not an isolationist: I am an internationalist. I believe that after those requests have been properly debated and decisions have been reached in the UN, we would, in our own context, meet those requirements. We cannot, in this world today, allow ourselves to become isolationists or allow ourselves to say that the rest of the world can look after itself but we are not going to be participating in it. That is no role for Australia.

The Democrats get up here and argue endlessly about international activity on environmental issues and trade issues. We cannot participate in those issues at the international level and then say, when the real crunch issue is on, when there is naked aggression, `Ah, we are going to wash our hands of it; let someone else do the dirty work of stopping aggression'. We cannot say that and still expect the rest of the world to take notice of Australia's views on international environmental issues, international trade issues, social issues, population problems and so on. We want to play a part in all those, but when it comes to the bottom line of stopping aggression, are we going to squib it? That is not the Australian way. It never has been and I hope it never will be.

Finally, let me say this about the future of the UN: there are many countries that do not have democratic forms of government. I think a UN, revitalised, knowing that it has the power and the status to impose and express strong views about human rights issues, about dictatorships, may in fact be able to use that new influence to encourage dictatorships to go by the way.

A country that I have a particular interest in is Burma. I would hope that in the next 12 months a revitalised UN can use its influence with its new standing to say to the military regime of Burma, `You must stand aside and allow the democratically elected Government, which was overwhelmingly supported by the Burmese people, to take office, because if you don't, the rest of the world, through the UN, will consider taking some firm action against you'. Ask 36 million Burmese people what they would think about that UN action. They would cheer it to the echo because they know it may be the only way that they can get a decent government that is going to be democratic and is going to provide them with a decent standard of living and a decent system of government.

Those people are not going to be worried too much about whether this is an interference in their internal affairs, because they have expressed their view. This terrible military government killed 4,000 people in 1988, has tens of thousands locked up already and is now torturing many in terrible human rights abuses. So I hope that the new United Nations-the new atmosphere that is being created-will enable us to say that there is a better chance in the 1990s and in the new century to ensure that the Saddam Husseins of the world are going to be taken on and defeated. I think in the long run all of us agree that that will be a major achievement for a better world.

I am terribly disappointed to hear the views of the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine. They have not been able to delineate the difference between the meaningless statement of saying, `We all oppose and abhor war' and pragmatically, properly and constructively doing something about it. How can one say to Saddam Hussein, `We all oppose war', and then let him get on with the job of doing what he wants to do-that is, invading other countries? Those honourable senators have put up a meaningless statement.

I am glad I have had the opportunity to take part in this debate and that the Parliament has been recalled to have it. I am very pleased that overwhelmingly the majority of Australian parliamentarians and the people understand a very basic principle-that is, naked aggression such as Saddam Hussein has shown cannot be allowed to go without forfeit. It has to be opposed. By opposing it, no matter that the cost in some cases will be terrible, in the long run the world will be a better place because the United Nations will have much more influence. I support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —These two days are very sombre days indeed. The Parliament is dealing with one of the most serious matters to come before it-that is, the involvement of our armed forces in armed conflict. No other war in history has generated so much public discussion and debate and no other war has received so much publicity after it has started. Prior to the commencement of this war there was considerable national and international debate. That is indicative of the fact that people worldwide, including Australians, consider it is their individual responsibility to come to a clear, informed and conscientious decision about this most grave matter and that it is very important to develop a view about it. That has been reflected in the debate in this chamber and in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate has been quite wide ranging. Many of the contributions have been incisive and all have been sincere. For my part, I have difficulty in coming to an informed, conscientious decision about this war and Australia's involvement in it. I might say that a few years ago I would not have had so much difficulty in arriving at an informed view based on a conscientious decision. Although I have had an interest in international affairs for many years, I am not in complete possession of all the strategic facts and circumstances, knowledge of which is rather vital to a final determinant of the issue. Whether or not to commit Australian defence forces to armed conflict is a decision for the Government to take under the Constitution. But I believe that Australian citizens have a responsibility, through members of parliament, to make their position clear to the Government and for the Government to follow that decision.

As I indicated, this war is probably one of the most publicised wars in history. I deplore the euphoria with which some of the media, particularly the television media, deal with some of the defence military actions taking place in the Gulf states. Everybody in this Parliament is against war. War and its aftermath are accompanied by much distress and evil. Indeed, history shows that sometimes the very principle in defence of which a nation has gone to war is later besmirched by those very nations which have become the victors under different guises.

One of the reasons that the West went to war against Hitler-the Nazi regime-was that regime had no respect for human life. Indeed, that regime had a philosophy which was dubbed by them Lebensunwertes leben-life unworthy of life. The Nazi doctors, under authority from that regime, were empowered to declare that certain individuals had a life unworthy of life. So many went to the gas chambers. There was a national card index established which would attempt to detect those with genetic disorders and have them sterilised. The Nuremberg trials were held after the war and the Declaration of Helsinki was made in order to attempt to uphold the principle of the worthiness and inherent value of each human life.

But now we see in some of the very countries which fought against that, including the United Kingdom, and to some extent Australia, attempts to establish that same vile principle of life unworthy of life-to attempt to detect the presence of genetic disorders in the unborn; not to cure the disorders but to eliminate the bearer. That is not to say, of course, that the action taken against Hitler and his regime was not required. Of course it was required. It was demanded and it should have taken place before it did.

As has been said in this debate, those of us who know a bit about history and have read about that period are aware that a number of people high up in the German Army were hoping that the allied powers would act against Hitler before they did. The allied powers had too much patience with Hitler, as has been said. Hitler was able to go into Sudetenland, Czechoslovakia and Austria. His expansion was met head-on after he invaded Poland. In a way, we have a possible similar situation today with Saddam Hussein.

It is not my intention to range over the very clear and thoughtful contributions that have been made in this debate in this chamber. I believe the motion needs to be restated, and I am going to restate it because it is my intention to vote for the motion, though I believe that it has some inadequacies. The motion is:
That the Senate

reaffirms its support for an on-going role for the United Nations in promoting world peace and self-determination of nations and in particular the resolutions of the Security Council directed to end the aggression of Iraq against Kuwait.

Surely no-one can argue against that paragraph. It is important that the United Nations has an ongoing role in promoting world peace and self-determination of nations. One of the problems of course with that is that there is a veto in the Security Council, and really in some of these areas it depends on whether China and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics agree. In my view that is not appropriate. However, if the United Nations is going to do any good at all, then I believe that the motion does indicate how this should occur. Clearly, that paragraph of the motion indicates to all concerned that the Senate agrees that the invasion by Iraq of Kuwait was simply robbery with violence. Iraq has not gone in and just taken everything out. That has happened, but it is occupying Kuwait. It is not only an invasion; it is an occupation. The attempts therefore of the Security Council decision and its call upon nations to support it were to try to get Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait, to withdraw his occupying forces from that country. The second part of the resolution says:
That the Senate . . .
affirms its support for Australia's positive response to the request made by the United Nations Security Council in Resolution 678 for support in implementing that resolution.

Of course our naval forces went to the Gulf area to participate in the blockade in support of sanctions against Saddam Hussein. The question has been raised in the debate as to whether the particular prerequisite before a country goes to war has been tried; that is, that all other measures have been tried, whether sanctions really have been tried, and whether diplomacy really has been tried. I am not going to go over the responses that have been given by those who have responded to these questions, but I have listened and I have considered that matter very carefully, as to whether sanctions have been given a chance.

It is clear that sanctions were working to the extent that the interdiction was successful-over 90 per cent-but that is not the test of whether the sanctions were working. Working means whether they were having an effect on the decisions that were being taken by Saddam Hussein. That is the test as to whether they were working or not. Clearly they were not working in that respect.

The next question arises as to whether we should have given them more time. It has been clearly stated that there were certain strategic reasons, as well as humanitarian reasons, for a time limit to be put on the sanctions. As we all know, that time limit was 15 January. Why put a time limit on it? That is a very good question. One of the reasons that have been advanced is that, if a time limit were not imposed, then strategically military action would have been most difficult to mount successfully because of geographical, meteorological and other factors, for a period of about four months. Secondly, in that time, what is happening to the people of Kuwait? Are we to stand back-in face of the evidence that has been provided to us by Amnesty International of the gross violations of human rights that have taken place in Kuwait by the Iraqi occupation forces? Thirdly, would the time that Saddam Hussein would have been given have enabled him to develop the biological weapons of warfare, the chemical weapons-he has already developed the chemical weapons but obviously has difficulty in achieving their launch-and also, perhaps, a nuclear capacity? As has been said, what effect would this have had on the coalition of forces in the Gulf? These are some of the humane as well as strategic considerations which are appropriate for us to reflect upon when coming to a decision.

Regarding diplomatic efforts, I do not know of any previous occasion in modern history where an aggressor has been given so many diplomatic chances to back off. As was indicated here by one of the speakers yesterday-I think it was the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans)-the United Nations Secretary General's efforts appeared to indicate that there was no hope that Saddam Hussein would change his mind.

The French, who know this area very well, even after the deadline had expired gave an opportunity to Saddam Hussein which any reasonable person, surely, would have accepted. It had benefits for Iraq, but it was not accepted. The motion goes on to state that the Senate:
expresses its full confidence in, and support for, Australian forces serving with the UN-sanctioned multi-national forces in the Gulf.

I certainly support what has been said about our naval personnel and other personnel in the area. They deserve our support and their families, friends and relations deserve our support. ``The penultimate paragraph of the motion says that the Senate:
deplores Iraq's widening of the conflict by its unprovoked attack upon Israel.

Whatever attitude Iraq may have about Israel, and whatever problems Israel itself has posed for the Arab nations and others, there is no justification whatsoever for the action of Iraq in widening the conflict. It is important to understand that this measure clearly appears to be an attempt to bring onside those Arab nations which are currently offside with Saddam Hussein. Finally, the motion states that the Senate:

recognises, as those with whom we are acting now in the Gulf have recognised, the need to intensify efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, including a just resolution of the Palestinian issue and the continuing security of Israel, once the crisis in the Gulf is resolved.

I will vote for that particular paragraph of the motion, but I believe that it is inadequate. The reason I believe it is inadequate is that establishing peace and stability in the Middle East may not provide protection for the human, political and civil rights of the peoples in the area. Much has been said about the concept of a new world order and collective security. It is important, when considering a new world order and collective security, that it is based on respect for the human, civil and political rights of people.

I assume that the Government agrees with that. I was in touch with the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about that particular matter. I suggested that that might go in, but it was too late at that time. The Prime Minister's office indicated that as far as it was concerned that was the basis upon which peace and stability in the Middle East should be established. The motion reads that the Senate:
recognises, as those with whom we are acting now in the Gulf have recognised, the need to intensify efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East . . .

I reckon some of the people with whom we are associated in the Middle East at the moment would not recognise the need to intensify efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East based on respect for human, civil and political rights. For example, President Assad of Syria is not well known for his support of human, civil and political rights. Indeed, one of the victims of this conflict is Lebanon.

To a certain extent, the policy of the United States of America in Lebanon has contributed to a betrayal of that country, and to a betrayal of human, civil and political rights in that country where Syrian armed invasion, other armed invasions, and civil strife have contributed over a period to 150,000 dead in that country. In recent times, since the Gulf war started, the 40,000 to 60,000 Lebanese who were in the Gulf area-in Kuwait and other countries-have had to get out, and are now unable to send financial support back to their homes, and Syria has extended its control over that country.

It is my view-and I believe and hope that it is the Government's view, because it has been stated to me by the Prime Minister's office-that the motion means that there is a need to intensify efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East based on respect for the human, civil and political rights of individuals, including a just resolution of the Palestinian issues and the continuing security of Israel once the Gulf crisis is resolved. That is very important because unless we get, and try to uphold, civil, political and basic human rights in the area, there will never be peace in that area.

I conclude by saying that, whilst it was important for this Parliament to be recalled for this very important debate, it is also important for all of us, individually and collectively, to pray for world peace; to pray for peace in our own hearts and minds, in the community within which we live, in our own homes and, in an extended way, peace for the world. My prayers and thoughts are with those people who are currently suffering in this Gulf crisis, and those people who are suffering because of the smokescreen, mentioned by Senator Short, which is being used by other dictators such as the Soviet Union to put down democracy in the Baltic states.

This has been a very difficult matter for me as it has been, I believe, for all Australians, but it is my intention, having made up my mind, to vote for the motion and to get out and strongly support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to compare the situation facing the world now with that facing us 12 months ago. Twelve months ago we saw the end of the Cold War; the collapse, we believed, of communism and of the repressive regimes in eastern Europe, and the rebirth of freedom and democracy in those nations. We had also seen the apparent and encouraging movement in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics towards greater freedoms and a hesitant start towards the establishment of democratic institutions and a democratically elected parliament. As a result, there was the flowering of hope that the world was on the verge of a new order: a new era of political freedom, of economic development and, above all, of peace and stability. Since then two disasters of great magnitude have occurred. The first was the commencement on 2 August 1990 of a new and terrible war with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The second was the brutal use of force by Moscow against the Baltic nations of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in recent days, weeks and months, about which the Senate unanimously adopted a condemnatory motion only an hour or so ago. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the Gulf crisis is concerned, I wish to add my voice to that of other Government, Liberal and National Party senators and Senator Harradine, and particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, in expressing my strong support for the motion before the Parliament.
