I echo Dr Hewson's sentiments that the Opposition stands united with the Government in condemning Iraq's brutal invasion and ruthless occupation of Kuwait; in our belief that the United Nations is upholding the principles of its charter; in supporting the current nature and extent of Australia's defence involvement in the Gulf crisis; and in strongly supporting the role of the United States of America, and particularly President Bush, throughout this crisis.

For the entire post-Second World War period, which now extends well into its fifth decade, the United States has been the torchbearer for freedom in a troubled and largely undemocratic world where basic human rights and values have been ignored or violated much more frequently than they have been respected. The United States has been supported in this role by many other nations at different times, notably Britain and, I am very proud to say, Australia. But the United States has carried the main burden. It has done so again on this occasion of the Gulf crisis, in the sense that it was the United States that initiated much of the activity within the United Nations that led to that organisation, for the first time in its history, playing a fundamental role for which it was established, namely, taking action to oppose the invasion and repression of one sovereign nation by another.

It cannot be stressed too often: the war that Iraq commenced on 2 August last has now been joined by the most diverse coalition of nations in modern history, nations whose participation is sanctioned by the moral authority of the United Nations, nations who have joined battle for only one reason-that over a 5 1/2 month period Iraq arrogantly and deliberately defied no less than 12 resolutions of the United Nations Security Council which, inter alia, condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and called for its withdrawal, called initially for economic sanctions and-in the final resolution, resolution 678-approved the use of force to evict Iraq from Kuwait.

Each of those 12 resolutions was passed by an overwhelming majority. On nine of the 12 resolutions the vote was unanimous. Virtually every member of the United Nations-Senator Gareth Evans in his contribution to this debate yesterday said 157 of the 160-supports the action being taken by the allied forces to eject Iraq from Kuwait and to restore sovereignty to that nation.

The world's condemnation of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is reflected in the extraordinary coalition of, as I said, no fewer than 28 nations who make up the United Nations sanctioned multinational force. It is not just America, Britain and Australia that are involved; it is 28 nations from all continents and of all political, social and cultural persuasions. No fewer than nine of those 28 nations are Arab nations. This war is not an Arab versus non-Arab war or a Muslim versus non-Muslim war. It is a war joined on the one hand by Iraq, led by a ruthless and brutal dictator and tyrant and, on the other hand, by a large and representative group of nations that believe that the rights of nations, particularly small nations, to preserve the integrity of their sovereignty and the freedom of their citizens are basic conditions not only worth fighting for but also without which there is no hope of individual, national or world peace, order or stability.

The 28 nations that make up the coalition ranged against Saddam Hussein are very diverse. As well as the United States, Britain and Australia, the coalition includes Canada, New Zealand, France, Denmark, Norway, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, the Netherlands, Argentina, Germany, Bangladesh--

TALK.START.PARA: —Sweden.

—Sweden is another, so that means all the Scandinavian nations are involved, as well as Italy, Morocco, Poland, Portugal, Pakistan and others-hardly a group of United States sycophants, as some of the protesters against the war would have us believe. I will come back to the protesters a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point that cannot be stressed too much is that the allied objective is not to invade or to subjugate Iraq; it is to liberate Kuwait, to restore its sovereignty and independence and the lives and freedom of its citizens. Since 2 August last, Kuwait has been pillaged, destroyed and raped by Iraq. Iraq installed a provisional government comprising Iraqi officers with whom even the Kuwaiti opposition members were not prepared to cooperate in the formation of a puppet government. Iraq has since annexed Kuwait and declared it to be its nineteenth province `forever'. The disputed Rumaila oilfield in Kuwait and the islands of Bubiyan and Waaba were renamed Saddamiyat al-Mitia and annexed to the Iraqi province of Basra.

Iraq has since based its refusal to withdraw from Kuwait in the first instance upon the unqualified proposition that Kuwait is a part of Iraq. The annexation of Kuwait in two parts shows clearly that Iraq regards the oilfield and the two islands as non-negotiable. Iraq has destroyed and looted Kuwait. Kuwaiti assets have been seized, stripped and transported to Iraq. Internal resistance has been suppressed with the use of systematic terror. According to Kuwaiti sources, an estimated 7,000 Kuwaitis were killed in the first three months of the invasion; of the 800,000 Kuwaitis, 400,000 have fled to Saudi Arabia or have remained abroad; whilst of its total population of two million, many non-Kuwaitis have fled the country through Jordan. There are now more Iraqi troops in Kuwait than there are Kuwaitis.

Iraq is led by a man who cannot accurately be described in any way other than evil. Saddam Hussein's record of ruthlessness and brutality, not just against other nations but even more so against his own people, has few parallels in modern history. His drive towards nuclear weapons a decade or more ago, which was confronted successfully by Israel when it destroyed Iraq's nuclear reactor, is just one example of his military intention. Enthusiasm for unconventional warfare is only one of the characteristics of Hussein which should excite the outrage of peace demonstrators. As was outlined in the Weekend Australian of last week:

When Saddam seized the leadership of the Iraqi Ba'athist Party in 1979 he moved against five of his closest supporters, had them tortured, staged public confessions, and then took part himself in their execution, apparently by machinegun. Torture and execution of supposed dissidents became routine and most probably has intensified since the annexation of Kuwait. Religious and tribal dissent has been met with particular ferocity. Hussein butchered the dissident Muslim leaders of the Dawa. He used mustard gas and cyanide, on a scale . . . not witnessed since the German gassing of Ypres in 1917, against the Kurds of Halabje-men, women and children-and then renamed the town after himself.
No class of people was immune from his poison gas: not the Iranian troops fighting the original Gulf war; not the Iraqi deserters who perished in the southern marshes of their homeland.

In April last year he promised that his binary chemical weapons would lay waste to half of Israel should he be attacked. Following the invasion of Kuwait, he used innocent hostages from different nations of the world as a human shield to defend his defence installations. Today it is reported that Saddam proposes to use captured allied prisoners of war as human shields at strategic positions. Not only is such action obscene in itself but it also constitutes a total violation of international conventions on the treatment of prisoners of war.

Last month Amnesty International produced an 80 page report on the widespread abuses of human rights that have been perpetrated by Iraqi forces following the invasion of Kuwait. The report says that violations reported since 2 August 1990 are entirely consistent with the abuses known to have been committed in Iraq over many years. The report of Amnesty International goes on to say that Iraq's policy of the brutal suppression of all forms of internal dissent continues to be implemented and the people of Iraq remain its victims.
The report lists some of the methods of torture that are carried out by the Iraqis under Hussein's direction. Scores of them are listed in the report--

TALK.START.PARA: —As there is torture and violence in all wars.

—No-one is disagreeing with that, Senator Vallentine. If Senator Vallentine is proposing that two wrongs make a right, I would be very surprised. Let me give some examples of the sorts of tortures involved: beatings on all part of the body, involving punching, slapping, delivering karate-style blows and kicking with heavy army boots. Implements used for beating include canes, metal rods, whips, steel cables, hosepipes, rubber truncheons and rifle butts. Torture also included falaqa, which is prolonged beating on the soles of the feet; breaking of the arms, legs or ribs; dislocating elbow and shoulder joints; slashing the face, arms or legs with knives; extracting finger and toenails; boring a hole in the leg; cutting off the tongue and ear; gouging out the eyes; castration; hammering nails into the hands; rape of women and young men; inserting bottle necks, sometimes when broken, into the rectum; applying electricity to sensitive parts of the body, including the ears, lips, tongue, fingers, toes and genitals; burning various parts of the body; pouring caustic substances onto the eyes causing blindness; raping or torturing the detainee's relatives in his or her presence and threatening the detainee with such acts.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now say something about the peace protests that are occurring and some of the comments made during this debate by the peace group spokespersons, in particular Senators Powell and Vallentine. No-one denies protesters on any cause the right to protest. Indeed, in Australia and other Western nations like the United States and Britain, it is a basic right. They would not be able to do the same thing in Iraq, as the Amnesty International report illustrates so graphically and horrifically.

While fully accepting the right of protest, I share the profound disagreement of my Liberal and National Party colleagues, and of most, though not all, members of the Government with what the peace protesters are saying. I would like to ask a few questions of them. Why do the protesters seem to protest only when the stance of the United Nations and other like-minded nations are involved? Why did the protesters protest only once the United Nations sanctioned multinational force had been deployed? Why did they not protest between 2 August 1990 and 15 January 1991 at Saddam Hussein's plundering of Kuwait, his raping of Kuwaiti women and his killing of their children? Why did they not protest that it is Saddam Hussein alone who has refused to give peace a chance? It is Saddam who, to use the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), is shedding blood for oil.

Let us be clear on this fundamental point: the full weight and authority of the conscience of the world-the United Nations-called on Iraq for peace no less than 12 times following its invasion of Kuwait. Twelve times the United Nations was denied; 12 times its plea was met with a deafening silence by Saddam or by arrogant rejection. Peace was given every chance by the United Nations and its member nations. The only denial of peace or any prospect of it came from Saddam Hussein. Every action he took, every signal he gave, showed beyond any doubt that he had no intention of withdrawing from Kuwait or of providing the peace that the rest of the world so desperately and patiently sought.

Senator Powell, Senator Vallentine and the peace protesters argue that the economic sanctions were not given sufficient time to work. The evidence is overwhelming that the sanctions were not having sufficient impact on Iraq to force it to withdraw from Kuwait. Western intelligence sources estimated that the sanctions would not have the necessary impact even if they were continued for another 12 months or possibly much longer.

In the meantime, what happens to Kuwait? What does the rest of the world do? Sit on its hands? Sit by and watch impassively while the pillaging, the raping and the killing of innocent men, women and babies continues remorselessly and without cause. If that is what seeking peace at all costs is all about, I do not want-and I do not believe many Australians would want-any part of such non-existent, mythical peace. As the Prime Minister said last week, when confirming Australia's involvement in the coalition force:
We all of us wish for peace . . . But we cannot have peace just by wishing for it or just by talking about it.
We have to work for it and sometimes, tragically, we have to fight for it.
I agree with that. In his address to the United States people last week, President Bush said:
While the world waited, Saddam Hussein systematically raped, pillaged and plundered a tiny nation no threat to its own.
He subjected the people of Kuwait to unspeakable atrocities.
And among those maimed and murdered-innocent children.
While the world waited, Saddam sought to add to the chemical weapons arsenal he now possesses, an infinitely more dangerous weapon of mass destruction: a nuclear weapon.
And while the world waited, while the world talked peace and withdrawal, Saddam Hussein dug in and moved massive forces into Kuwait.

President Bush is right. No-one doubts the sincerity of many of the peace protesters. We all share their fierce desire for peace. I do not know anyone who does not want peace. But what the protesters need to come up with are concrete, practical proposals as to what they would do. It is not enough merely to mindlessly chant, `Give peace a chance'. I have heard of no concrete, practical solutions or proposals from the protesters that would in any way have influenced Saddam Hussein's brutal, murderous, repressive, tyrannical actions.

If Saddam were permitted to take Kuwait without resistance, does anyone doubt that he would move to take control of the Saudi oilfields or to pursue his development of nuclear weapons to add to his armoury of chemical weapons? Does anyone believe that this would lead to peace in the Middle East or elsewhere? I put it to the Senate that anyone who believes that is gravely misguided.

Saddam Hussein is clearly and unequivocally opposed to withdrawal from Kuwait under any circumstances. He has and continues to violate the rule of law in international relations, let alone basic rules for human rights. For this reason alone, opposition to Australia's role in the multinational force is opposition to the rule of law in international relations.

This morning we heard on radio Iraq's senior representative in Europe, the Iraqi Ambassador to Paris, ask what are Australia's interests in the Gulf that were affected by what Iraq was doing. He clearly believes that we have no interest there. The Iraqi Ambassador is wrong for many reasons. As Dr Hewson said in the House of Representatives yesterday, Australia's interests in the Gulf and what is happening there are real and they are vital.

Let me repeat here some of those interests. We do have an interest in helping to build a new international order where the strong are just, the weak are secure, and the peace is preserved; we do have an interest in making the United Nations an effective means of establishing such an international order; we do have an interest in resisting Saddam Hussein's threat to regional stability and security, particularly that of Israel; we do have an interest in deterring or preventing the use of chemical warfare and other weapons of mass destruction; we do have an interest in helping to ensure that the international oil market is not held to blackmail as a result of Iraq's aggression; and we do have an interest in helping to end the brutalisation of Kuwait's citizens and the appalling violation of their basic human rights over the past 5 1/2 months. No civilised country can ignore those appalling facts. So our interests in the Gulf crisis are real and they are vital.

I was going to comment in some depth on Senator Vallentine's contribution to this debate last night and refer to what I regard as her quite disgraceful and disreputable behaviour in both the Senate and the House of Representatives yesterday. On reflection, I think it is better to leave her to be judged by her own words and actions.

However, Senator Vallentine made two or three points in her remarks last night on which I must comment. One comment was that it is the coalition forces' invasion of Kuwait that will destroy Kuwait. That, surely, has to be the theatre of the absurd. Kuwait is being ruthlessly destroyed hour by hour and has been for the last five months by Iraq.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we are going to add to the destruction by bombing it.
—Another comment she made was that the attack on Israel would not have happened if the multinational force had not moved in on Iraq.
—If Palestine was on the agenda.
—Can anyone explain to me the logic of that?
—Order! Senator Short has only a short time remaining. Senator Vallentine has interjected on a number of occasions. Will she please give the speaker the opportunity to be heard.

—Thank you very much, Mr Acting Deputy President. As I say, another point that Senator Vallentine made was that the attack on Israel would not have happened if the multinational force had not moved in on Iraq. The attack on Israel was a deliberate ploy by Iraq to try to divide the coalition. Israel is to be congratulated in the strongest terms for the moderation that it has exercised in non-response to that attack. Israel is the innocent victim of that attack; it is not part of this aspect of the Gulf crisis. So Senator Vallentine's argument to me just turns logic completely on its head.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point that Senator Vallentine made was: why is there a difference between action on UN resolution 242-and I think probably resolution 338-in relation to Israel and resolution 678 on Iraq? There are totally different circumstances between the two. Resolutions 242 and 338 set out provisions to be met by both sides of the conflict and requiring negotiation between them. One of those issues was the settlement of boundaries between the then warring parties of 1967 and 1973-boundaries which had never been determined, whereas in the case of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, established and recognised international boundaries were being, and are being, blatantly violated. The onus for the implementation of resolutions 242 and 338 has thus never rested exclusively with Israel; indeed, the Arab side, which had lost territory in both wars, was for several years ambivalent about the resolutions mainly because they implied recognition of the state of Israel. I just repeat that the circumstances between the two are totally different.

Finally, Senator Vallentine outlined various alternative courses for action-I accept what she said-in a speech she made in the Senate last year. She advocated negotiation and mediation. As I understand it, all the proposals she made in that speech have either been rejected out of hand by Hussein directly or indirectly.

I want to make two final points which I regard as very important. Firstly, I add my thanks, my congratulations and my prayers for our service men and women who are serving with the multinational force in the Gulf-those now serving, those who have served, and those who will serve. I say to them, `We are all very proud of you. We are eternally grateful to you, as will be all peoples who believe in true lasting peace, freedom and security'.

Finally, I want to say to the Australian public-which is now very heavily supportive, with support running at 75 per cent for and 18 per cent against the action in the Gulf, and with Australia's involvement supported by 69 per cent and opposed by 24 per cent-that it is essential that we all hang in there with our support.

The war could be protracted. The British Foreign Secretary the other day talked of it taking months. We saw how support for the war in Vietnam eroded as it dragged on. This will not be another Vietnam, of course, but it is very important indeed that the Government, the Opposition and all like-minded people continue to do all possible to keep public support by explaining the continuing reasons for Australian involvement. The cause of freedom, stability, security and world order demand it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Is leave granted?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I think that this is unprecedented. I have never heard a senator being denied leave to make a personal explanation in this place.

—Order! Senator Vallentine, will you resume your seat. You requested leave to make a personal explanation on the grounds that you were misrepresented. Leave was not granted. Therefore you may at some other time reapply. It is in the hands of the Senate to make a decision about that particular matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support the motion before this chamber. The decision to go to war is never an easy one, nor should it be. It is not easy for the world community, it is not easy for individual nations and it is not easy for individuals within those nations. (Quorum formed) The human cost of any war is monumental. The financial costs are immense. Resources and the environment are eroded. These considerations must weigh heavily on all of us.

SPEECH.PARA: To me, as an individual who has campaigned for peace for over 26 years, this decision was not an easy one. As a long time member of Australia's peace movement, as an individual with a deep commitment to human rights, and as a person who believes in the peaceful co-existence of peoples and nations, I have thought deeply and seriously about my attitude to the current situation. As a member of Australia's Left movement, I have taken into consideration the views and beliefs of all my friends in that progressive movement-both in Australia and internationally. The decision I have taken to support this resolution is one that I deeply believe in. It is consistent with my principles. It is, I believe, consistent with a sustainable Left position.

There are four basic, long held principles which have guided me in supporting our current commitment in this conflict. They also underlie the Government's decisions. These four principles are basic to the philosophy of the Left, in this country as well as internationally. First is the Government's and my personal opposition to war and our commitment to world peace. We have pursued both global and regional initiatives for peace. Our work at the United Nations (UN) on disarmament issues, on confidence building measures for peace and on regional security issues is acclaimed worldwide. Our initiatives for a nuclear free zone treaty in our region and for a resolution of the Cambodian issue are honourable ones. Peace does not come easily-it has to be worked at and worked for. Unfortunately, at times it has to be fought for.

The second principle is a belief in the independence of nations and the self-determination of their people. We have opposed, and we must oppose, foreign intervention in and aggression against nations. The third and increasingly important consideration relates to the role of the United Nations. The Australian Labor Party has long cherished the concept of the United Nations as an influential and effective forum and mechanism for the resolution of international conflict. The current crisis demonstrates the potential for the UN in this role. The fourth belief is one that goes directly to the immediate issue. That is, the quest for a just resolution to the Middle East conflict, to the Palestinian homeland issue and the security of Israel.

As I have stated, these four principles are and should be basic to the position of progressive political movements both in this country and internationally. It is a fact that the Left in Australia has not been exclusively a pacifist movement. It has consistently supported armed struggle. It has consistently argued for intervention to protect the independence of nations and the self-determination of people. As a movement, we have supported armed struggle in countries both far from and near to our shores. In the last half of this century, we have had many examples of this. We should not forget them and for the record some need to be mentioned.

We committed ourselves to the struggle against fascism in Spain in the 1930s and 1940s. We committed funds, we committed arms. Australians went to Spain to fight against fascism. The Communist Party in Australia was at the forefront of these initiatives, but it was not alone. Workers and other individuals, unions and other groups joined that struggle. The Spanish struggle was not in our region. Our commitment to fight for peace and freedom was recognised internationally.
The Abbot at the Benedictine Monastery of Montserrat, which protected democrats during the civil war, said to partisan veterans in 1986:

In you are demonstrated the values which are necessary for the future of humanity; the capacity to find common cause with people of other nations, the fact of giving your own lives to defend the peace and freedom of other people; the fact that you came over here by yourselves without obligation. That is why I am thankful to you and grateful that you have come to meet me here at Montserrat.

The Europeans said Australia and Australians were so remote from Spain that we could have been forgiven for not wanting to take part in the struggle. But we, the Left, did so. There have been many instances since where the progressive movement in this country has endorsed armed struggle in pursuance of the aims of freedom, equality and independence of nations. We endorsed the war against Hitler and fascism. We supported the struggle of the Vietnamese people against the imperialists. For years, the Left has supported the Fretilin movement's armed struggle in its quest for self-determination. We have supported the majority of black peoples of South Africa, particularly the African National Congress.

In Central America, the Left supported the Sandinistas in their struggle and now continues to support guerilla movements in El Salvador and neighbouring countries. Support for armed struggle, therefore, is not alien to the Left. As I have said, the Left is not, and has not been, exclusively a pacifist movement although we hold the quest for peace as one of our most basic political tenets. We have supported in principle the whole post-World War II decolonisation process. This has been characterised by wars of liberation against European powers with liberation movements supported by the communist bloc and opposed by the United States and colonial powers. Rhetoric that we hear now has generated from that period. The world, however, has moved past that decolonisation era, beyond wars of liberation against European powers and the Cold War is now over.

The issue, therefore, is whether the use of force in this instance can be justified and whether it can be morally sustained in the current Gulf crisis. On 15 January, UN Secretary-General Perez de Cuellar made one final plea to Saddam Hussein. He said:

I most sincerely appeal to President Saddam Hussein to turn the cause of events away from catastrophe and towards a new era of justice and harmony based on the principles of the United Nations charter.

This plea had been made before. It had been made by all sectors of the international community consistently over the almost five months of Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. It was a plea that had been made by the West, by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR), by non-aligned countries, by the European Community, by Pacific countries and by the Arab League. Most importantly, it was a plea that had been made a dozen times by the world community by way of UN Security Council resolutions. It was a plea that had been rejected as often as it had been made.

All attempts at peace through diplomatic means and at negotiations to prevent war had failed. In Hussein we are being haunted by a monster the world helped to create. He has been supplied with arms when he should not have been. He has been able to develop chemical weapons and he should not have been. He has been able to develop political support around the world out of the world's failure to apply itself to resolving the Palestinian issue. On 2 August 1990 he took a brazen and unjustifiable step in annexing Kuwait. I do not need to go in great depth into the situation in Kuwait since the invasion of 2 August 1990. We need to remember that Kuwait has been taken over by Iraq and that there are over 300,000 Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait outnumbering the 200,000 Kuwaitis who remain.

We also need to recognise that on 19 December Amnesty International documented a very comprehensive picture of human rights violations including detention, torture and summary executions. We should acknowledge that Iraq's looting of Kuwait has also been well documented. It amounts not to casual heat of the moment looting but to the deliberate, systematic pillage by one country of another.

Iraq has stated many times that Kuwait is its nineteenth province. The world cannot tolerate this sort of annexation. So, Mr President, the world is confronted with a situation of intransigence which, if not addressed, condones the takeover and destruction of Kuwait. We are also confronted by a person who now threatens to destroy another state which has UN support, the state of Israel. But we are confronted with more than this: we are confronted with a person whose potential resources and power are a threat to us all.

How we respond to Hussein is at issue. This particular crisis arises at an important moment in world affairs. It arises at a time when there is a major change in the world power balance. It arises at a time when there are changes in the structure of world power. Cold War and detente are over. We now have to meet the challenge that this recently created and fluid situation presents. It is my firm belief that this challenge can be met by the United Nations and the increasing role that body is playing, and has to play, in world affairs.

Before I go to that, let me tackle three issues that have been raised over recent weeks in respect of Australia's response to this crisis. We have been accused of acting in haste. Let the record speak for itself. This matter has been progressing since August 1990. During that time we have had 12 UN resolutions directed at the Gulf crisis. We have had more than 100 countries supporting decisions made at the United Nations level. In fact, at the Security Council we had six co-sponsors of the vital resolution, and those co-sponsors include both the US and the USSR.

Consultation has not only proceeded at that level. In the last week preceding the deadline date of 15 January, Hussein entertained negotiating offers from a wide and diverse group of nations. The USSR, France and the Arab League as well as the Secretary General of the United Nations himself were amongst those who went to him with propositions for a settlement of the crisis. We all know full well the representations made by the Secretary General of the United Nations, Perez de Cuellar, and the way in which he was treated by Saddam Hussein. One can say that the world community tried in a relentless effort to bring about a negotiated peace to this particular issue. One can also very fairly say that at every turn they were met by intransigence and resistance by Saddam Hussein.

It is apparent that he was and is in no way concerned about achieving a negotiated settlement to the problem. A negotiated settlement for Hussein could not have been a victory that he could have presented to his people. It is also claimed that sanctions were not given long enough to work. I am one of those who have believed from the outset that sanctions could not work in respect of Iraq. I also believe that, as time went by, and goes by, Saddam Hussein was using and is using the opportunity to increase his armoury and his capacity for retaliation.

Claims have also been made that the Australian Government has been too closely linked to the United States in pursuing our role in this crisis. One cannot deny that the United States is at the forefront of international endeavours. But one must also not deny that there are more than 100 countries involved in and supporting the decision making processes at the United Nations and that 28 countries are involved in intervening in the Gulf.

One must ask that, if we were not committed, if we were not involved, if we were not supportive of both the United States and the United Nations in their role in this conflict, then who would we be aligned with? The answer is clear. We would be aligned with no other countries but Cuba, Yemen, North Korea and Jordan. We must remember in addressing this claim that we no longer live in a Cold War era where both superpowers take directly opposite positions. We must remember that both superpowers are now on the same side in this issue. This time, linkage with the United States of America (USA) is also linkage with the USSR, as well as linkage with the non-aligned countries of the world.

As I have already mentioned, we do have an evolving world situation and it is one that is very much at a definitional stage. It is one that presents a test for the world community; it is one that presents a test for the United Nations. The old days of nuclear deterrents are over. The old days when superpowers could, amongst themselves, achieve stability and order are over. We now have to evolve a mechanism to ensure the continuation of world peace and the protection of sovereign states, and we must do this quickly. The body that is most suited for that role is, of course, the United Nations. This crisis presents a fundamental test for the United Nations. If it passes it, then world peace, security and good order are the major beneficiaries.

For a moment, let us go back to the genesis of the United Nations. Let us go back to our role in that and let us go back to some of the considerations put forward at that particular time. Dr Evatt, of course, played a leading role in establishing the United Nations. In 1945, in the House of Representatives, he said that if economic or diplomatic sanctions `are deemed inappropriate to the situation or prove ineffective, the Security Council may take any military action necessary to suppress the aggressor'. The use of force in bringing about adherence to UN resolutions was obviously contemplated at the time. Dr Evatt also said in 1945:
It must be made crystal clear that nations seeking representation in the world organisation must be prepared to contribute their share of physical force to restrain the action of proved aggressors.

Since its inception, therefore, it has been contemplated that the UN could marshal force to ensure its decisions could be implemented. We should recognise that. We should particularly recognise that when we talk about the increased and enhanced role for the United Nations.

In this particular process, the UN has a series of resolutions that have been endorsed by an overwhelming majority of its member countries. If the UN could not bring about enforcement of a resolution or a series of resolutions in this context, then it can never be effective. If it cannot bring about the enforcement of resolutions that it has adopted with co-sponsorship with countries such as the US, the USSR and France, then it has no hope of bringing about any effective resolution to conflict in the future.

There is, at this time in history, an opportunity to evolve a new world order, an effective mechanism for the good conduct of nations. It is an opportunity that cannot be lost. The alternative is that of world disorder. If the world does not stand up to Hussein, then he is the victor. There is no alternative to that. Hussein represents the politics of tyranny, of repression, of terror. His victory now would be a victory for his politics and for his values. Let us not underestimate the potential destruction which would arise from this. Hussein possesses chemical weapons. He is near to or does possess nuclear weapons. If he defeats this challenge to his authority, if he is not curtailed by the world, then by this example the world would be open to domination by any aggressor. So there is a clear choice for us and for the world, and that choice goes very much to the heart of the issue of peace and the heart of the future role of the United Nations.

Some argue that we in Australia should withdraw our commitment at this particular stage. But how irresponsible would that be? We have supported UN resolutions; we have supported UN initiatives. These resolutions clearly contemplate the use of force. Not to lend physical support, at this stage, when we have travelled so far down the road in the UN process on this particular issue, would be an act of grand treachery to the United Nations. It would undermine forever the future role of the UN and our role within it. What we have here is international action taken under the auspices of the United Nations with the consent of all permanent members of the Security Council for the first time in that body's history. We have an obligation to this action and to the United Nations.

In closing, there are two pleas that I would like to make. Firstly, there is a plea to the Australian community, one that I make as a member of that community as well as the Minister representing ethnic affairs in this chamber. We are a diverse, multicultural society made rich through the many, varied cultures, attitudes, religions and people who have made Australia their sanctuary and their home. My plea is one for tolerance, for understanding, and for a commitment to our community as a whole. Reports of racism, violence arising from that racism as well as religious intolerance, are sickening, and they are abhorrent. There is no room in Australia for such behaviour.

Muslim men, women and children, wherever they have come from, whether they have come from India, Turkey, Iraq, Palestine or elsewhere, as well as Arabs of all religions, deserve respect, not racism; they deserve understanding, not hatred. I therefore call on all Australians to live up to the notion that ours is a nation for all people to live in, to express their views freely, to hear one another, and together determine a future based on bringing together the best of all cultures.

My second plea is one to my friends in the Left, to the peace movement, and to all those marching in the streets-people with whom I have marched for the last 26 years of my 40-year life. It is a plea based on the obligation we all have to truth. Let us get some balance into this debate. Let us address the issues honestly. Let us acknowledge and condemn Saddam Hussein's role, as all world leaders, including Gaddafi, have done. Let us acknowledge Hussein's intransigence.

Let us acknowledge that there is no moral equivalence between Hussein and the rest of the world community. Let us acknowledge the potential that this issue has for world peace, for the UN and for a new world order, and let us acknowledge the need for consistency in our arguments. How can we support armed struggle in so many instances and then object to it in this particular case?

Let us also encourage the peace movement to think creatively, to debate the new world order and its implications for peace and international social and economic justice. We have objectives which all of us in this chamber share. The most fundamental one, however, is to achieve peace. It is a peace that we need to win, not only for the Middle East but also for the rest of the world. I must say in conclusion that this war cannot be allowed to go on for too long. The cost will be too great.
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —If any people in the gallery make comments like that and interrupt the proceedings of the Senate, I will have no alternative but to ask the attendants to force them to leave.

INTERJECT.PARA: An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the attendants to take that woman out of the gallery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to state at the start that I oppose the brutal, barbaric dictator Saddam Hussein. His inhumanity seems to know no bounds. As Senator Harradine said earlier, the invasion was indeed robbery with violence. We condemn him and all his forces, who have been responsible for the pillaging and the rape of Kuwait and its people. Yes, Saddam is a fanatical, cruel dictator. He is, as Senator Tate outlined yesterday, responsible for the torture and the killing of many innocent civilians. It is very pleasing to note that at last an Amnesty International report is getting a proper and thorough airing in this place. It is very pleasing to note that a large number of speakers have indeed quoted from that report.

SPEECH.PARA: I must emphasise here that in the debate that has gone on so far-in listening to those from the Liberal and Labor parties who support the war, and listening to the many excellent speakers who have made some very valid points-Senator Tate is the only speaker from either side who has come even close to justifying the involvement of this country, of this Government, in this war. Where I differ from Senator Tate is that war is not now the option, not now the solution.

I do not agree that the only proper means we now have to stop aggression is more aggression. I cannot agree that the only way to stop the killing of innocent civilians is by killing more innocent civilians-and, make no mistake, the volume of explosives being dropped now on Iraq and Kuwait is killing millions of innocent people. By the time this is over, one only wonders what the total cost will be. Tens of thousands of people could have already lost their lives in this war. The destruction of property will be massive-not that that should be one of our major considerations.

The sanctions, which have been discussed by many people so far, were working. As Senator Gareth Evans acknowledged, some 95 to 97 per cent of Iraq's external trade had been cut off. Industrial production had dropped sharply and non-subsidised food prices had soared. Indeed, the sanctions had in fact exceeded the United Nations' stated objectives because, despite the exemptions, medical supplies were running short, and that was one of the items that was supposed to be still getting in.

The question, I believe, is one of timing. Now is not the time. War should be an absolute last resort and not rushed into before all else has failed. To those who compare this war with World War II, I say that they are ignoring the fact that in this case we had united, well-organised sanctions that were working. We did have an alternative. The issue of timing is of critical importance. Why must we rush into war just as the sanctions begin to have their intended effect on resources? To take time means that we must be patient, and we must encourage other nations to be patient. To take time means that we must be prepared to discuss at length and discuss again. We must give time to those within Iraq to protest directly and indirectly, as much as they are able, at the lack of resources that they are beginning to experience, in order to put pressure on Saddam Hussein from within his own country. This means that we should have kept-indeed, could keep if the hostilities were to stop-the sanctions in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Noting that a number of Western nations have downgraded the Iraqi diplomatic representation in their respective countries by expelling non-essential diplomatic staff and those seen as security risks, I ask: Why has not the Australian Government taken such action? Can we assume that the Government is, therefore, satisfied that there are no Iraqi diplomatic or service personnel who pose any danger to Australian interests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that a number of governments have recently taken action on security grounds, as Senator Hill says, to reduce the numbers or expel whole missions of Iraqis in their countries. These include the United States, British, Netherlands, Belgian, Greek, Canadian and Philippines governments.

ANSWER.PARA: As is the case with other members of the United Nations force in the Gulf, Australia is, nonetheless, maintaining diplomatic relations with Iraq. That is essentially because we do consider it important to ensure that this channel of communication is kept open, not least for the kinds of communications that we were able to make to the Iraqis this morning, for example, in the context of the prisoner of war issue and the targeting of civilian populations.

On the outbreak of hostilities with Iraq, the Australian Government imposed a 50-kilometre travel restriction on members of the Iraqi Embassy in Canberra. It is only a small mission, with only something like six people there. That restriction was imposed on security grounds. We would of course be concerned about any activities by diplomats of Iraq or of any country that posed any more specific threat to Australian security. We would take appropriate action to deal with such a situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald under the title `Australia dragging feet over UN appeal' which claims that Australia is one of only three countries to have failed to respond to a United Nations appeal for funding to assist victims of the war in Iraq, apparently because the appeal is already oversubscribed. I ask the Minister for his assurance that the Government will demonstrate that its commitment to UN initiatives in the Middle East is not selective by, as a matter of urgency, reconsidering its decision to not contribute. I also seek his assurance that Australia will make a significant contribution to the Joint International Committee of Red Cross-League of Red Cross Societies appeal for victims of the war.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has not been dragging its feet in this matter as has been alleged in that article. The facts are as follows: Prior to the outbreak of hostilities, the UN did prepare a plan to handle a potentially large exodus of people from Iraq and Kuwait. For planning purposes, the UN worked with a figure of 400,000 evacuees; that is to say, 100,000 in each of Jordan, Syria, Turkey and Iran. It estimated that to care for this number of people for three months would cost around $US175m. The UN then launched, on the basis of that assessment, an international appeal for a portion of this amount or start-up funds of some $US38m so that it would be in a position to react speedily if required. That appeal was quickly met, principally through the generosity of the Government of Japan, which pledged, in fact, the full $US38m figure. There were also contributions from some others of the 15 countries, and there were only 15 countries that were specifically asked to contribute to this. Those additional contributions amounted to something like another $US18m.

ANSWER.PARA: In those circumstances, and not least because of the huge budgetary constraints we are facing in the humanitarian relief area, we made the judgment that it was unnecessary for Australia to make a contribution to that start-up fund at this time. That is not to say that we will not be prepared to consider a contribution and to find the funds to do so should some further appeal be made in due course through UN channels for some additional support in that area.

Subsequent to the UN appeal, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) launched an appeal for approximately $US140m. The ICRC has, of course, a crucial role to play in providing protection and assistance to civilians caught up in the conflict, in caring, if required, for the wounded and in protecting and assisting those captured or detained. Along with the UN, the ICRC also has a role in assisting those fleeing across international boundaries.

Again, the Government is considering how we might best contribute to the relief of suffering in the Gulf region generally. I have before me at the moment a number of proposals, including for further contributions both to the UN, as I have already said, and to the ICRC. A decision will be made shortly and I will be making an announcement at an appropriately early time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to the following words used by the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives on 6 December last concerning the Australian commitment in the Gulf:

QUESTION.PARA: We do not propose any further commitment. We do not expect any further request. But, in the unlikely event that one came forward, we would consider it.
On the Sunday program the other day, the Minister made the following unequivocal statement:
I am here to say I am not going to escalate our commitment.
I ask the Minister when that decision was made; on what basis it was made; and whether this decision has been communicated to our allies in the multinational force and the United Nations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of Senator Durack's question about whether we have communicated any decision, the answer is no. Our commitment to the Gulf area was very carefully thought through in the first week of December. It is based primarily on what we regard as our role as a world power-that is, a middle power. We anticipated, if there was to be a conflict, the nature of that conflict, and we therefore crafted our decision to be commensurate with our position as a world power.

ANSWER.PARA: I might say that we very carefully looked at what the best sort of contribution was that we could make to the coalition forces. Admiral Maus made it very clear when General Gration visited the region that that contribution of escort vessels, of which the coalition was short, would be the most appropriate contribution. His reasoning for that is fairly well known: that is, our ships have integrated air defence systems with the layer defence of the carrier group. Secondly, the communication systems between our ships and the coalition ships, especially the United States (US) ships, is highly compatible and they are the latest state-of-the-art technology. Finally, Australian ships have been exercising with US, Canadian and British ships, especially in Rimpac, for many years. That is why Admiral Maus in particular was very pleased that Australia's contribution would be along the line of escort ships.

Similarly, a view was expressed to the Australian contingent then that there was a shortage of medical teams. It is true that Australia could make a greater contribution, and so could many countries, but each country judges its contribution according to the role it sees itself playing in the world and the most appropriate contribution it regards as possible. As for any future escalation, we see absolutely no cause to re-evaluate our decision not to contribute anything more because all these factors were taken into account at the time.

The final point I make is that at no stage in my visit to Washington in October, or in the various discussions that Senator Evans held in the US, Canada, Europe and the Middle East-and he has had a whole range of discussions-has there been any request for a further contribution because most of those countries recognise our contribution as an excellent one, a valuable one and one where there is an area of shortage. So the question of a further escalation simply does not come up.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Prime Minister said on 6 December:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . in the unlikely event that one came forward, we would consider it.
In view of the development of events since 6 December, can we take it that that statement now does stand?

TALK.START.PARA: —That statement was made in the context of other factors at the time. What I am saying is that as of now, and as this has developed over that period, we do not intend to make any further contribution to this area because we have well and truly subscribed to the coalition forces in a very adequate way.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to press reports on potential terrorist threats to Australia? What action has the Government taken to protect Australians from terrorism, and how serious is that threat?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the start of this latest phase in the war that was initiated by Saddam Hussein on 2 August last year against the people of Kuwait, we have taken special measures, and indeed the national anti-terrorist plan has been activated, so that the contingencies which are foreseen can be adequately dealt with. There is a very high state of preparedness among Federal agencies, in cooperation with State police forces, to deal with any such contingencies as they might arise.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite clearly, special security measures have been taken in relation to particular persons and buildings, but naturally I would not outline those. However, everyone who passes through our airports will be aware of the enhanced security at those airports. I do not think anybody has vented any anger or frustration at the delay that has been occasioned by the necessary extra checking that has taken place both of individuals and their baggage and cargo being handled.

I am briefed constantly on the situation in relation to threats which are credible or turn out to be hoaxes. I can assure the people of Australia that those security measures are being undertaken against the threat of violence, which has added credibility since Iraqi Radio broadcast its request that terrorism be activated around the world against those who have contributed to the multinational forces operating in the Gulf region at the moment.

Whilst actions of violence by terrorists may have the most colourful aspect as far as the public imagination is concerned, perhaps more worrying are those politically motivated violent acts that might take place within the Australian community as a result of the tensions generated by this conflict. Last night there was a Jewish rally in Melbourne and some incidents occurred. I understand that a person has appeared in the Melbourne courts this morning as a result of actions taken in relation to that rally.

I know from the comments by my colleague Senator Bolkus during his splendid contribution to the debate this morning that what we need to emphasise is the social cohesion of the Australian community. We have to ensure that those who have a particular point of view can express their view non-violently and peaceably and, in particular, that those in the Arab and Muslim communities are not stereotyped and subject to harassment or intimidation during this time of tension.

I had the honour of attending Friday prayers at the Lakemba mosque a couple of Fridays ago at which time the spiritual and community leaders of the Muslim community in Sydney gave a very clear undertaking that their community would never engage in acts of violence in relation to this conflict. On behalf of the Prime Minister, and I think the whole Australian community, I assured that community of our tolerance and the fact that we would not tolerate actions of harassment, intimidation or violence directed against that community during these times.

I believe that all contingencies in regard to acts of violence that might affect Australians as a result of this conflict have been foreseen and are well prepared for. The Australian people can take comfort from the fact that we have, as I say, reached a high state of preparedness to deal with any contingency that might arise.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Firstly, does the Government have access to the most accurate United States intelligence assessments of military and civilian casualties arising from the Middle East war in the following countries: Saudi Arabia, Israel, Kuwait and Iraq? Secondly, for each of those countries, what is the best estimate available to the Government of military and civilian casualties? Thirdly, can the Government confirm the reported estimate of the European representative of the Kurdistan Socialist Party that allied bombing of the city of Kirkuk in northern Iraq has killed several hundred civilians?

—We do have access to updated information on military and civilian casualties as it becomes available to the United States. I am not, however, prepared to undertake, now or at any specific time in the future, to release the details of those casualties. Information will be given from time to time as appropriate but, in conditions of war such as we are engaged in at the moment, security considerations are associated with such information and I do not propose to add anything further to the public record at this stage. I have no specific information about the particular allegation made in response to the city of Kirkuk, which Senator Powell mentioned. I will seek information about that specifically and see what it might be possible to put on the public record.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. Can the Foreign Minister indicate which particular security considerations are an impediment to the Australian public's right to know about casualties in this war?

—Sometimes the public's right to know in our own country is a less immediately relevant consideration than knowledge becoming available to Saddam Hussein. In the circumstances, I am sure it would be appreciated that that is a consideration that needs to be taken into account. I repeat: It is the Government's approach on these matters to make as much information available as possibly can be made available, but I simply cannot give any open-ended undertaking to make available information in that or any other category as it comes to hand from the sources available to us. There are considerations of a security kind that have to be weighed and balanced along the way.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Now that world crude oil prices have fallen to the levels that existed before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, when can Australian motorists expect to see retail petrol prices returning to pre-invasion levels?

QUESTION.PARA: An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, I must say that the vast number of people in the gallery today have come to listen to Question Time. Those people who are interjecting will be removed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oil prices have fallen dramatically in the wake of the commencement of hostilities in the Gulf to around $20 per barrel now, which is about the same as the prevailing rate at the end of July 1990, just prior to the invasion of Kuwait. But prices remain extremely volatile and our dollar is slightly lower than it was in August last year. It is down by about three to four cents.

ANSWER.PARA: On 19 January the Chairman of the Prices Surveillance Authority, Professor Allan Fels, announced that the wholesale price of petrol would fall by 0.52c per litre today-22 January-and that further cuts could be expected in the coming week if there was no reversal in the oil price drops recorded since the outbreak of hostilities. An additional 0.52c per litre fall in wholesale prices will be effective from tomorrow-Wednesday, 23 January. In total, today's and tomorrow's drops amount to 1.04c per litre.

Wholesale petrol prices are currently around 7c per litre higher than at the end of the 21-day price freeze imposed by the Treasurer in response to the Middle East crisis but around 12c per litre below their peak of 76c per litre on 19 October 1990.

The Prices Surveillance Authority is basing its wholesale petrol price movements on a mix of crude oil and Singapore petrol prices using a seven-day moving average of prices. This has insulated the motorist from the worst effects of oil market volatility while still ensuring that market movements are reflected in Australian petrol prices.

It is important to note that the Prices Surveillance Authority determines the wholesale price. The Government has no control over retail prices. It is possible that distributors' and resellers' margins may not settle back to their previous levels, although I urge consumer pressure to encourage that to be the case. It is also possible that the States would take some interest in this area if there were to be any considered refusal to pass on those wholesale price reductions.

The current Middle East situation brings home once more the need for Australia to continue its efforts to improve energy efficiency and conservation to minimise the impact of increases in petroleum prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. What additional funds, over and above the Budget allocation, have been provided to the Royal Australian Navy for its involvement in operation Desert Storm? Will the Minister assure the Parliament that adequate funds will be available to the Department of Defence to minimise any reduction in Australia's defence capabilities elsewhere?
—That question is peculiarly within the province of the Minister for Defence who has responsibility for those Budget allocations. I will ask Senator Ray to answer the question.

—At the time at which our ships and other defence personnel were committed to the Gulf, it was made clear by the Government that the additional costs would be supplemented by Government. I have approved a figure, but it still has to go through the normal government processes-be contested and either added to or subtracted from. The honourable senator will understand that is why I do not put a figure on it now, even though I might like to get the jump on the Department of Finance. The Government has given an assurance that the overall defence budget will not be affected by the additional costs of the Gulf deployment. It is a complex formula because one can not only take the Gulf costs into account, but also one must subtract the normal operational costs that those ships and other personnel will be dealing with. Given the current atmosphere, given indications in government, I think those costs will be fully supplemented.

—Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce inform the Senate about the level of response to his requests in October for companies to register interest in future stages of the Cape York spaceport development? Is the level of response sufficient to give the Minister confidence that the project will come to fruition?

—I can indicate in outline that following the request for expressions of interest there were 23 expressions of interest from various companies lodged with the space office. Those expressions of interest came from Europe, Japan, North America and Australia, including some significant Australian engineering firms. In so far as assessment of those expressions of interest is necessary, that has not been dealt with at this stage. I should say that if an adequate protagonist is found from those expressions of interest, the next stage in relation to the spaceport would be the environmental impact studies which have to be completed, and also consultations with the Aboriginal community on Cape York. Those two matters will be dealt with after the protagonist is chosen from the expressions of interest which have been lodged with the spaceport office.

—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer inform the Senate of the likely impact of the Gulf war on the Australian economy, and in particular its implications for the length of the current recession in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short will recall that following the August Budget last year there was some discussion about the likely price of oil, long before the Gulf war was even mooted as a possibility. A figure was fixed in the Budget projections which was the subject of some discussion. The essential point was that the Government at that time was not prepared to provide a firm figure in relation to oil prices. At this stage of course it is too early to say what the implications of the Gulf war are likely to be in terms of the recession from which Australia is currently suffering.

ANSWER.PARA: I should say that since the Senate last met there has been some moderation of the unemployment consequences of the recession. I think there has been a considerable improvement in the level of inflation-its having fallen to 6 per cent over the past year-and it is anticipated that it will fall below this level in 1991. There has been an improvement in the balance of payments deficit, and of course there has been a continuing period of declining interest rates for the last 12 months. Of course, the Government is hopeful to be able to consolidate these gains and improvements in the economic situation. Government expenditure will of course continue to be restrained, and the structural Budget surplus will, as far as possible, be kept high. In so far as the impact of the Gulf war is concerned, I believe it is too early to say what detriment that will cause to the projections of the Government in respect of the economy in 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs whether Iraq's actions in invading and occupying Kuwait are contrary to international law. Further, will the Minister also inform the Senate whether the Iraqi treatment of alleged prisoners of war is in accord with its international obligations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Iraqi actions from the time of the invasion to the present have been characterised by a flagrant disregard of the various principles of international law embodied in the United Nations Charter or in the Geneva conventions which are meant to be some civilising restraint on the conduct of the horrific war that is being undertaken. The initial Iraqi invasion of Kuwait contravened a fundamental obligation under article 2(4) of the United Nations Charter not to threaten or use force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any state.

ANSWER.PARA: Iraq's refusal to comply with numerous resolutions of the United Nations Security Council calling upon it to withdraw from Kuwait is also in clear breach of article 25 of the United Nations Charter, and as we know from Daniel Ortega's remarks to Craxi, the leader of the Italian socialists, `withdraw' is one word which Saddam Hussein would not utter, but, in not uttering it, he is in complete breach of his obligations under the United Nations Charter.

Iraq's action in holding foreign nationals as hostages and using them to render strategic areas immune from potential attack was certainly contrary to the fourth Geneva Convention dealing with civilians. The torture, the rape, and the summary executions without trial which have been well documented by Amnesty International in Kuwait under the occupying forces are themselves certainly breaches of the fourth Geneva Convention. Under article 147 of that Convention, grave breaches-which have been so well documented by Amnesty International-include the emptying of the humidicribs in the maternity hospital so that 300 premature babies were left to die on the cold tiles of the floor, the Red Crescent doctor himself testifying to the fact that he had buried 72 of those babies. Those horrific crimes against civilians-the brutal tortures, the summary executions-are all such grave breaches that those individually responsible and their superior officers will be held responsible at the conclusion of this conflict.

The treatment of prisoners of war by Iraq reported today-their parading and display-is itself contrary to the third Geneva Convention dealing with prisoners of war which stresses how humanely they must be treated. In particular, the use of prisoners of war as human shields by placing them at educational and scientific and other establishments, as has been threatened, is very clearly in breach of article 23 of the third Geneva Convention dealing with prisoners of war. That article reads:

No prisoner of war may at any time be sent to, or detained in areas where he may be exposed to the fire of the combat zone, nor may his presence be used to render certain points or areas immune from military operations.

There can be no more clear statement of the international law and the treatment of prisoners of war, and it is very clear that if the threats against prisoners of war taken by Saddam Hussein's forces are carried out in the way that he has alleged they will be, then Iraq is once again in clear breach of its international law obligations. This is only a catalogue of the most apparent breaches of international law, the clearest breaches. I believe it is totally in harmony with what one would expect of a regime which is nurtured on war, which has as its lifeblood the killing of others-as in the conflict with Iran where over a million died for no territorial gain whatsoever.

We know of his treatment of the Kurds, the horrific gassing of the civilian populations; we saw the huddled bodies of Kurdish villagers in the streets and alleyways of their various places of what should be peaceful habitation. These particular cruel treatments of the population of Kuwait and, now, of prisoners of war put Iraq in clear breach of international law and, at the end of this conflict, those responsible will be brought to justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. The Minister will be aware that Radio Australia has refused to broadcast personal messages from their families to our defence personnel in the Gulf, even though such messages were broadcast to Australian hostages in Iraq until Christmas. Can the Minister advise whether this decision was due to lack of funds, as claimed by Mr David Hill; to a belief that by doing so it would be part of a Government propaganda machine, as resolved by members of the Australian Journalists Association (AJA) at Radio Australia; or was it because the Acting Manager of Radio Australia, Mr Geoff Heriot, judged that by doing so it would be giving overt support to the Government's political military endeavour? Does the Government support this decision by Radio Australia and, if not, what action has the Government taken to ensure that loving family messages can be broadcast to our young servicemen and women at war. as was provided to their predecessors in World War II, Korea and Vietnam?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a very large skirmish over this in mid- January between members of my office, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and Radio Australia. Senator Newman asks what were the reasons: all the ones that she has given, but given at different times. That is, the first indication given to Admiral MacDougall, I think, was that Radio Australia could not do it because of costs. Later reasons given were that this was not a priority area of operation of Radio Australia; it was not within its charter. The AJA made the point that it did not want to become a propaganda arm of the Government; and other similar statements have been made.

ANSWER.PARA: It is disappointing that Radio Australia has taken this attitude. It was able to broadcast messages to the hostages, and it did a splendid job in this regard. We are now in the position where our ships are deployed and it is much harder than it was before to get mail through, and much more difficult for the crews to be able to make phone calls home because the opportunities are very limited.

I urge Mr Hill to change his decision. The Government does not support it. The Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, sent me a message a few minutes ago saying that he did not support that particular action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you written to Mr Hill?

—Mr Hill has said in a letter to me-I was anticipating Senator Alston's question-that he would like to meet me on this subject, and I have been trying to arrange that as soon as possible. Some people may like the right to sell tickets to that particular meeting. Nevertheless, I will be taking up the matter on its substance and its merits. It is not true to say that families sending messages to their loved ones in the Gulf can in any way be construed as militaristic or propagandising.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, the Senate will know what a tolerant person I am and I do not issue threats or admonitions very often, but I cannot understand why, if Radio Australia cannot serve its country in this way, it should continue to deserve its current level of funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. There have been misinformed allegations that the Government is considering conscription as part of its response to the Gulf crisis. Will the Minister inform the Senate what provisions exist in Australian law with regard to conscription and clarify the Labor Government's rejection of this option?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing to be said absolutely emphatically is that in relation to this conflict there will not be any conscription of any Australian to serve in the armed forces. That has been clearly stated by the Prime Minister; it had been stated in this chamber in answer to a question asked by Senate McLean before Christmas. The fact is that we have an absolutely unadulterated, unadorned, emphatic no to the question of conscription. That is the clear political stance of this Government and totally in accord with everything that has been said by the Minister for Defence and the Prime Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: Further, there is no legal basis which would enable conscription to be undertaken. In that respect I simply wish to emphasise that sections 59 and 60 of the Defence Act provide the framework for conscription in time of war. Because of the definition of `in time of war', there is an opinion of the Attorney-General's Department that nothing occurring at the moment in the Gulf, or by way of threatened terrorism activity within Australia, would qualify as an invasion, or apprehended invasion, of Australia which is what is required under the Defence Act to qualify as time of war.

The effect of the National Service Act 1951, of course, was terminated by section 4 of the National Service Termination Act 1973, an early activity of the newly elected Whitlam Government. That provides that no person is liable to register or render service under the National Service Act. Therefore, it follows that there is no legal capacity whatsoever for any Australian Government to conscript any Australian into its armed forces and, of course, there is no political will to do so.

There have been some interjections from the Australian Democrats as I have been answering this question. The Democrats have abandoned devotion to truth. There is no doubt that honesty and truthfulness have been a casualty of this particular war, and they have engaged in propaganda in this instance. The propaganda is not only coming from the Gulf; it is also coming from the Democrats in this regard. It has caused grave anxiety to many Australian households.

Senator Robert Ray interjecting-- Senator TATE-Senator Bell has just been mentioned by Senator Robert Ray. In fact, Senator Bell went on radio talkback in Hobart last Thursday or Friday in order to state that Senator Robert Ray had refused to give an answer, yes or no, in the Senate to the question of whether there would be conscription. The Hansard clearly reveals that in answer to a question asked by Senator McLean on 12 November 1990, Senator Robert Ray said:
As to the question: Will we reintroduce conscription?, the answer is no.

That is the answer given on 12 November, recorded in Hansard, publicly available, and known to Senator Bell; yet he has aroused these misgivings in the Tasmanian community. I know from telephone calls to my office that there have been real apprehensions and fears in the households and among the parents and young men of Tasmania as a result of his scaremongering in that regard. There is no legislative power and no political will whatsoever to introduce conscription into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Will Australian vessels be made available to undertake shore bombardment in support of allied amphibious operations? Are the Australian vessels free to do this now under the existing rules of engagement, or would it require a separate Cabinet decision for this to be undertaken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have made it clear in this chamber on a few occasions that I will not be tabling or releasing the rules of engagement. What I have said for the public record is that the rules of engagement allow a multi-faceted approach to the tasks of our ships. When a direct question is asked: will they be able to do this or that?, I decline to answer. I do say, though, that those rules of engagement and operational guidelines have been made available to Dr Hewson and Senator Durack.

ANSWER.PARA: I say quite clearly, because I have said this on the public record, that one of the operational guidelines is to minimise civilian casualties. In general, the ships will not just be on escort duty; they will have other tasks to do consistent with what the coalition is doing. I do not want to go further than that and be too specific, but they have a multi-faceted role.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to his statement made yesterday in the Senate in which he said that the Middle East war started on 2 August when Iraq invaded Kuwait. I ask the Minister: Given that we apparently have been at war for five months now, what effect has this had on the staff of the Australian Embassy in Iraq, the Iraqi Embassy staff in Australia and Australians in Iraq during that period? What has been the status, during the whole period, of Australian service personnel who were sent to the Gulf of Oman to enforce sanctions, given that they must actually been serving in a war zone? What has been, and is now, the status of Australian and United States of America personnel at North West Cape, Nurrungar and Pine Gap given that they too are providing intelligence and communications support for a war effort? Are they on active service in a war zone? How was the war zone defined over this full five-month period, and who defined it?

—I said that the Middle East war started on 2 August when Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. I have no reason to retract that. Our involvement in that conflict started on 16 January.
