If Senator Coulter cannot understand the subtlety in the difference in that, then I am sorry for him. He has gone on therefore to base a number of other questions on a false premise.
—Can the Minister for Defence inform the Senate of the success of the Gulf information service being run by the Royal Australian Navy? Has the service received many calls to date? How is it working?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Navy has set up a 008 hot line for inquiries made by any relatives of servicemen in the Gulf. The service operates on a 24-hour basis and is staffed by Navy personnel, both uniformed and civilian. So far over 1,000 calls have been taken since its inception. No matters of an operational nature are discussed, nor are details of individual personnel serving in the Gulf or those of their families divulged. The facility is a very important link between the Navy and family members and friends and will greatly assist in reducing the potential for unnecessary stress generated by unintended information or ill-founded rumours. For instance, for several hours last Friday night a television station carried a story about a collision between two Australian ships. That story was never substantiated by that television station and was denied by us consistently. That would have promoted a number of anxious calls-I believe hundreds-from family members worrying about the safety of their relatives. At least they were able to be reassured that there was no absolutely no basis for that story.

ANSWER.PARA: I visited that facility on Sunday morning and talked to the people working there. Obviously, they got the odd crank call to begin with, but now that the hot line has settled down mostly only genuine people ring. It is a very valuable service provided to the relatives of personnel in the Gulf.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY SECRETARY TO MINISTER FOR TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Prime Minister reflecting the position of the Government in his criticism of the anti-Gulf war peace movement as mouthing mindless slogans and falling into the trap of appeasement? Has the Prime Minister noted that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications and member of the Executive Council, the Hon. Warren Snowdon, has sponsored the Darwin `War is not the answer' rally on Saturday, 19 January, used office facsimile facilities for the anti-Pine Gap stance of the Alice Springs peace group, and made subsequent media comments acknowledging that he is in a personally uncomfortable position relating to Government policy? Does the Minister agree that these actions have the effect of weakening national unity because of the breach in Cabinet solidarity and that Mr Snowdon should be dismissed from his ministerial position?

—I am sure that anything that the Prime Minister said about mouthing mindless slogans was said with discretion. There are plenty of people in this country who are not happy about this country being involved in war who are not necessarily utterers of mindless slogans. But there are some who are utterers of mindless slogans, and those are the people to whom the Prime Minister would have been referring. As far as Mr Snowdon's position is concerned, he is not, as Senator Tambling's question implies, a member of the Cabinet. I understand that Mr Snowdon has made a statement about this particular issue in the House of Representatives today supporting the motion that is before the Senate and the House of Representatives, and I refer Senator Tambling to that statement.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given that the proponents of the war in the Gulf have repeatedly said that sanctions have proved ineffective after five months-an assessment with which I disagree-how does the Government now justify taking Australia into a war which could last many more months than five and cause the deaths of many, possibly hundreds of thousands, of innocent civilians-a subject which the Minister obviously finds too embarrassing to talk about? Why is the war option considered viable when sanctions were not? Can the Minister guarantee that war will dislodge Iraq's forces from Kuwait any more quickly than sanctions would have done and leave Kuwait intact and viable as a nation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —None of us, here or in the international community, preferred the war option to the sanctions option as a way of achieving the objective. We did not prefer it but we were forced into making the decision--
—You weren't forced.
—Order! Senator Vallentine, you have asked your question.

—We were forced into making the decision that there was no alternative but to go down the war route simply because of the rapidly accumulating evidence in the latter part of last year that, despite all our hopes and expectations, sanctions were simply not going to produce the result we wanted within a realistic time frame. I explained in considerable detail in my speech in this place yesterday-and I will not again today-just what the basis of that reasoning is. In short, it implies not just the necessity for an effective net to be maintained, which has been effective, but for that to be accompanied by very real and actual hurt within the country and, furthermore, for that to be accompanied by a willingness on the part of the Government to respond to that hurt by changing its policy course. In short, the judgment has been made that we could not reasonably expect anything of the kind to happen in under a period of another 12 to 18 months, and perhaps not even then, because of the particular nature of the society.

ANSWER.PARA: In the meantime, while we would be waiting around for this unspecified long run to work itself out, the following things would be happening-I repeat, would be happening: the murdering, the raping, the brutalisation and the looting of Kuwait and the people of Kuwait would continue unabated. We have available to us all the atrocities recorded and detailed by Amnesty International to give us plenty of evidence of that. Furthermore, we faced a situation in which Iraq would have taken advantage of that ongoing time period to rapidly increase its chemical weapons stocks. It would have taken the opportunity to further develop the technology making it possible for those chemical weapons to be attached to missiles in the form of warheads-technology which it is presently uncertain that the Iraqis actually have. It would have enabled another period of 12 or 18 months or two years for the development of biological weapons, which is very much in Iraq's potential capacity. Whether it is in its actual capacity here and now again remains a matter of some doubt. It would have enabled the capacity of Iraq to develop-which it unquestionably wants to do within the shortest possible time frame-a nuclear capacity together with an appropriate delivery system to go with it. The best available estimates are that, should Iraq be prepared to utilise the material available in its existing safeguarded nuclear reactor, it would be possible for it to produce at least a crude nuclear device within a period of just 12 months from now.

The point of the matter is that, quite apart from the political considerations, which have their own importance, and the capacity of Saddam Hussein to manipulate the environment and to undermine the coalition working against him, in terms of both the application of sanctions and the potential coalition available against him in the event that sanctions broke down, the reality, from the point of view of the very people in the region and in the world that Senator Vallentine is saying she wants to protect, we would have been gravely and massively adding to the risk. That is the reason why the rest of the world simply could not afford to take the risks associated with adherence to an open-ended sanctions policy, the ultimate success of which, even over a time frame of the length I have described, we simply could not guarantee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Does the Minister not give any credence at all to the reports, which have come from various agencies, that over 90 per cent of imports and exports into and out of Iraq had already stopped, that the sanctions were already showing their effectiveness and that only 40 per cent of the manufacturing industry was still able to produce after only 4 1/2 months? Does the Minister give no credibility to these figures whatsoever? I repeat my question: Can the Minister guarantee that war will dislodge Iraq any quicker than the sanctions would have done? The Minister has to come clean and state what the objective is: Was it removing Iraq from Kuwait or was it to completely damage Iraq's military capability?
—Order! Senator Vallentine, you have asked your supplementary question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do give credibility to the statistic-it comes in fact from the Central Intelligence Agency, and I am glad that Senator Vallentine on occasion shares the same sources-that 90 to 95 per cent of the flow of goods coming in and going out of Iraq have in fact been stopped as a result of sanctions pressure.
—There you are!

—I tap the mat-I really do. However, I made the point-I hope in stark terms-that the mere effectiveness of the net cannot by itself secure the effectiveness of the sanctions policy. It has to be accompanied by real hurt within the country and not some other compensating activity which in fact reduces the impact of that hurt. There has been a lot of such activity, not least the looting of Kuwait. The application of all the machinery, spare parts and food stocks from Kuwait has been a big compensating factor. The hurt has not been that great.

ANSWER.PARA: On some estimates, manufacturing capacity may have been reduced by up to 40 per cent as a result of the sanctions that have been applied. But the truth of that matter is that that has been pretty well wholly focused within non-essential, light industrial manufacturing areas that are simply not important or not necessary for the future viability of the Iraqi economy.

There has been no measurable impact at all on the Iraqi military machine as a result of the application of sanctions for the reason that we are talking about a dictatorship which gives ultimate priority to its military machine. There has been no significant impact, so far as we can tell, on infrastructure like energy and water supply, despite some earlier belief that that might be so. The truth of the matter is that although gross domestic product has been reduced, it has only been of the order of 10 per cent as a result of the inability of Iraq to sell oil and refined fuel. In all the other ways that I have mentioned, the impact of sanctions has so far been at best marginal. It would take an awfully much longer time than the world, the region or the people of Kuwait can afford for the impact to become more than that and maybe an even greater time for that impact to be translated into a decision by the Iraqi Government to actually change policy course.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Have all the holders of visas issued illegally by the Australian High Commission in Lagos to unidentified foreign nationals, particularly from the Middle East, who entered Australia been accounted for? If not, how many people are currently unaccounted for?
—I do not have a brief from the Minister on this, but I do undertake during the day, given the urgency which obviously Senator Olsen places on this question, to provide an answer for him.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What has been the Government's response to the totally unacceptable crackdown by Soviet troops in the Baltic states? Has the Government protested in the strongest terms to the Soviet Union?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The renewed resort to force by the Soviet authorities in the Baltic states-most recently now in Latvia-is a very deeply troubling development. Latest reports indicate that at least four people died when Soviet Interior Ministry troops stormed the Latvian police headquarters in Riga on 20 January. That follows, of course, the even more horrific events in Lithuania a few days earlier, in which some 15 people died, with many additional reported injuries.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has already before today forthrightly condemned the action of Soviet troops in Lithuania. On 14 January, Dr Blewett personally conveyed the Government's concern to the Soviet Ambassador. The Prime Minister also publicly deplored that Soviet action, noting that resort to force ignored the fundamental democratic mandate of the Lithuanian Government and Parliament.

In relation to the more recent events, yesterday the Secretary to my Department, Mr Woolcott, underlined the Government's concerns about the situation in the Baltic states generally and Latvia in particular in a meeting with the Soviet Ambassador. Today I have issued a public statement condemning the use of force in Latvia and instructed my Secretary again to call in the Soviet Ambassador to reinforce the strength of the Government's views. The Senate today also passed a motion in bipartisan terms strongly expressing our concern and distaste for those recent events.

As I said in my own statement today, we in Australia share the view of other Western nations that the use of force to resolve the future of the Baltic area is not only undermining the reform process in the Soviet Union itself but it also has a very substantial capacity to affect the whole future course of cooperation between the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the West, including Australia. It really would be a tragedy if the recent course of events in the Soviet Union were to amount to a retreat from the political and economic reforms of recent years, which have been absolutely integral to the emergence of a cooperative and constructive climate for East-West relations. Unfortunately, the situation in all three Baltic republics remains tense with Soviet troops still maintaining a very threatening stance.

On behalf of the Australian Government, I take this opportunity to strongly urge the Soviet Union to return to a path of peaceful negotiations with the freely elected representatives of the Baltic states in an atmosphere free of intimidation or the use of threat of force.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Can the Minister confirm or deny reports from a memo circulated by the Insurance Council of Australia that the Federal Government may be called on to cover the cost of personal injury and property damage in the event of a terrorist attack in Australia if the attack is thought to be tied to the Gulf war?
—I am not aware of such a memorandum. I will undertake to have it examined to see what implications it might have in regard to questions of insurance contracts.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. In view of the value of Australians having access to first-hand accounts of events in the Gulf, can the Minister inform the Senate as to progress being made towards having Australian journalists located on our ships in the area? Does the Minister believe that having additional Australian coverage of events may serve to balance the evaluations of the conflict currently being made from the perspective of American network television?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said on a number of occasions that accredited journalists would be given access to the Gulf ships, subject to operational and crew safety requirements. I can now confirm that there is a television crew in the region on stand-by for embarkation onto one or two of our ships for a period of two or three days. I am hopeful that that will occur in the next few days.

ANSWER.PARA: The film footage and copy produced by that team will be made available on a pool basis-that means that all stations will get it, subject, of course, to the normal security vetting requirements. I should point out that no facilities exist on our ships for the electronic transmission of television film ashore and other means of delivery will be infrequent as helicopter resources are required for higher priority tasks.

I believe that this will help in the coverage of Australia's involvement in the Gulf area. It is quite clear that the United States networks-Cable News Network in particular-concentrate on American topics. They are also very pro-American, which is at least something we could never accuse our own national broadcaster of being. Therefore, I think it is important as much as possible to give coverage to our involvement there. But I have to put this point: We must have our own priorities in these matters. I know how incestuous these issues are with the press and how self-important they seem, but our operational requirements must at all times take priority over the needs of the press, no matter how self-important some of those people think they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Will the Minister advise what medals will be struck for the service men and women who have served Australia in the Gulf?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those servicemen who served on HMAS Darwin and HMAS Adelaide were given the Australian Service Medal. In times of conflict, different sorts of medals apply.

ANSWER.PARA: This matter is normally dealt with in more detail by my associate Minister, Mr Bilney, but I have the following information which may be of assistance to the honourable senator: On 20 November 1990, the Governor-General approved the determination for the Australian Service Medal with the clasp `Kuwait'. Eligible personnel have been awarded the medal, which is for service in a non-warlike operation. With the recent announcement by the Prime Minister that Her Majesty the Queen has approved the Australian series of gallantry and distinguished service awards for individuals and units in warlike situations the full range of Australian military awards is now available.

With the outbreak of hostilities in the Persian Gulf it is now appropriate that personnel serving in the operational area become eligible for the award of the Australian Active Service Medal and the new awards for gallantry and for distinguished service, including the Nursing Service Cross.

A detailed determination developed for the circumstances and approved by the Governor-General is required for all awards. If the honourable senator requires any further information on that matter, I will get it. As I say, my colleague Mr Bilney has been dealing with this in more detail than I have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. When the Minister is ascertaining that information for me, will he include whether or not there is likely to be a specific medal designated for the Gulf itself?

—I believe that there will be, but as I say I will follow that up. If there is any other additional information, I promise to get it to the honourable senator. I am not asserting that there is additional information at this stage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 December 1990, Senator Watson asked me a question relating to the Australian Taxation Office, directed to me in my capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer. I have obtained an answer to that question. If Senator Watson is agreeable, I will have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The Australian Taxation Office is not anticipating an early election and is continuing to use the 1990 Budget tax rates for calculation of provisional tax through fiscal 1990-91 because they are the legislated rates. Last year the ATO was castigated for anticipating legislation; this year it is standing by existing law and is being questioned for that action as well.

There has been considerable pressure from many sectors of the taxpayer community for the ATO to issue provisional assessments as early as possible. That process had already started when the Treasurer announced the new tax rates (Royal Assent of Budget Bills granted on 6 November 1990). Further, the amending bill (Bill No. 6) which prescribes the new rates of tax will be debated in this session of parliament. For the ATO to wait for the passage of that legislation through both houses would have caused considerable delays in the issuing of assessments.

The action of the ATO to issue provisional assessments at the legislated rates is justified as the amending bill will contain a provision which will divorce the new tax rates from those to be applied in the calculation of 1991 provisional tax. The impact of continuing to apply the existing rates of tax as opposed to the announced new rates of tax is minimal, given the variation in the tax rates and the impact that variation would have on the determination of provisional tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering Senator Hill at the outset of Question Time I slightly misread the brief in front of me, intimations of mortality without my glasses, I am afraid. I think I said that in some cases whole missions had been expelled as distinct from reducing the number of diplomats. I think I used that expression. I just want to clarify for the record that there is no case of which we are aware in which a whole Iraqi mission has been expelled, but there are a number of cases, though-the ones that I indicated-where the numbers have been reduced on security grounds.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Newman)-by leave-agreed to:
That the Senate condemns the ABC for its refusal to send messages through Radio Australia to Australian servicemen in the Gulf and calls upon it to immediately reverse its policy decision.
Debate resumed.
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing that will not happen is that the Parliament will be stopped.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to go over what I have already said about the timing. I believe that the important point in the way in which I certainly differ with what Senator Tate had to say earlier was that I do believe that we have not yet reached the point at which we should be considering war. We should have given time for the sanctions to have their full effect. As has already been said and agreed to in this chamber, sanctions were indeed affecting the imports and exports from the country. We should have kept that pressure tight. The Australian Democrats have always supported sanctions as long as they were under United Nations command.

SPEECH.PARA: We totally agree that international law after international law has been broken by Saddam. We believe that given time the sanctions would have had their desired effect. Time means that we could have begun to discuss the other issues that must be put back on the table after this is all over. My colleagues have already dealt very thoroughly with a number of these issues.

Senator Ray and others have said that time would have given Iraq further opportunity to plunder Kuwait and indeed this may well have happened, but I believe that it was by far the lesser of two evils. What will be left now of Kuwait once this is all over? What will be left to liberate? If this war drags on for yet another week and another week after that, perhaps months or more, what will be left if saturation bombing continues? It is not correct to insist, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and I have noted a number of others have done, that the only choice was between war that we have now and appeasement. Between those two extremes there were a wide variety of options, but they would have taken time.

To move from time to another issue-money. If we look back through recent events around the world, current occupations in other parts of the world, we see many invasions of a smaller, weaker country by a larger, aggressive neighbour. Again, my colleagues have outlined a number of these. I want to deal briefly with only one today; that is, East Timor.

Where were we and what did our Government do when Indonesia invaded East Timor? Senator Tate talked yesterday about the torture, rape, killing and brutalities that were going on in Kuwait. All of these atrocities have been going on for years, not months, in East Timor. A third of the population has died, but this Government and the Opposition are silent on this issue. Why? Not only is there no call to war-and one must be very grateful for that-but there is no call for sanctions, there are no discussions even with the Indonesian military, with the Indonesian Government, asking the military to leave-there is silence. The answer again I believe involves money or oil. The answer to this is oil-the access to it, the control of it and how much it will cost.

As well as the direct reward of access to this resource the answer is also unfortunately found in the enormous financial commitment the United States has to its military program, the enormous amount of money tied up in military hardware and technology. The other group which stands to reap enormous financial rewards, one group of financial beneficiaries, will be the actual producers of that hardware, the military weapons, the bombs and the missiles, the builders of the planes and the ships, the ammunition suppliers, those who outfit the two armies and more that are now facing each other across the sands. Also the beneficiaries will be those who will-indeed it seems they are already jostling-get contracts to rebuild the cities, to rebuild the oil terminals, to rebuild the factories and the other installations now being destroyed.

What will the final cost be? It is estimated now that the minimum daily expenditures by the United States alone is some $A645m per day. It has been estimated that the United States alone has $170 billion worth of weapons at the ready stationed in the Gulf.

This brings me to an issue that makes this war even more obscene if that is possible; that is, the human cost, the direct and the indirect cost. I mentioned millions of lives earlier and I notice that obviously some people do not agree; but when we start looking at the indirect cost to all of the world I believe this is very realistic indeed. While we encourage the spending of billions of dollars maiming and killing innocent civilians in order to protect innocent civilians, millions of people in this world do not have enough to eat on a regular basis. They are not adequately fed, not because there is not enough food to go around in the world-plenty is produced-but because of a lack of political will, because of supply difficulties and because they or their governments do not have the money to purchase the minimal food that is available to them.

The billions spent on this war should have been directed to meet such urgent needs as feeding, housing and clothing this world's population. Every year the development aid budget for the whole world is some $50 billion. The Americans spent the equivalent of three-fifths of this even before the war was actually declared. In the State of the World's Children 1991 project, launched by the United Nations Children's Fund before Christmas, it asked for $20 billion a year each year until the year 2000. It said that with that it could do the following four things:
reduce child mortality levels to a third of 1990 levels and halve maternal mortality
reduce severe and moderate malnutrition in children under five
provide universal access to safe drinking water and `proper removal of excreta' ie sanitation
provide universal access to primary education for children and reduce adult illiteracy by half, particularly in women.

This is where the money could have been spent. Now, to add to the plight of the many poor nations of this world and indeed the poor in the industrialised countries that are fighting this war, the relief effort, the social services, will be directed away from them. It will be directed away from such areas as the Horn of Africa. I read in today's press that most of the aid workers have already had to leave the Sudan. They have had to move away from those areas to the refugees who are now beginning to pour out of Iraq. Eventually an enormous effort will be needed for Kuwait and Iraq and perhaps many more countries if this war drags on.

Already, hundreds of thousands of guest workers have fled the Middle East. Yes, this would have still occurred had sanctions been in place. However, we are exacerbating those problems. Some 122,000 guest workers were forced back to Bangladesh. Those 122,000 people were supporting a million people in Bangladesh. This is a further burden placed on a poor nation. Then, of course, there is the personal cost to those who are directly involved, their families and their communities-the cost to a generation of Iraqi and Kuwaiti people, and this is immeasurable.

I wish to stress that Australia had a choice. Our Government, with the support of the Opposition, chose war-one of the two extremes. War was chosen because, at the time, it seemed to be a quick and easy solution to this complicated problem. The initial problem is to remove Saddam but there are also problems related to the control of oil resources. We now have to stop and look and ask: will this really be a quick solution?'. Will it all be over in a week or two? Will it take another month? Will it indeed be over before that summer deadline that the Americans were so anxious to avoid? What will be left to liberate? What will the total damage bill be? What will be the total impact on the world in human terms and environmental terms? What will it be now that we have literally let the cat out of the bag? What will the end result be?

We read in the newspapers today of further atrocities being committed by Saddam Hussein in his treatment of prisoners of war. Where will it stop? We knew, America told us, our newspapers told us, how unpredictable this man was, how ruthless. We should now be absolutely horrified. (Quorum formed) I believe that war was chosen by others because of the attraction it offers to some powers and we followed along. It offers a great chance to test weaponry previously untested and untried because it is so new and so expensive. It gives an opportunity to demonstrate that brute force is really what is important to the powers of this world.

War was chosen by Australia because we did not want to be out of step with the United States and we made no extra public calls for sanctions to be given time to work. We followed along. We took what seemed to be at the time the easiest political route-the wimps' way out, to use someone else's words. Our leaders chose not to take the path that would have at least given peace some chance.

Finally, I wish to go through the amendments that the Australian Democrats will be moving to the motion that we have before us. We have some seven amendments. They involve either adding or subtracting a word, phrase or sentence. It would make a lot more sense for those listening if I simply read out the new motion that would be carried if the amendments were successful. It would state:
That the Senate-

(a) reaffirms its support for an on-going role for the United Nations in promoting world peace and the self-determination of nations and in particular the resolutions of the Security Council directed to end the aggression of Iraq against Kuwait by means of sanctions and diplomacy;

(b) affirms its support for Australia's positive response to the request made by the United Nations Security Council in Resolution 661 for support in implementing comprehensive sanctions against Iraq until it leaves Kuwait;

(c) condemns the Australian Government's warlike interpretation of Resolution 678 of the United Nations Security Council, and calls for an immediate ceasefire, and the withdrawal of Australian warships from combat duty, which is consistent with that resolution;

(d) expresses its full confidence in, and support for, Australian forces in the Gulf, and places the burden of responsibility for the misguided decision to deploy them to that region solely on the Federal Government and the Opposition;
(e) Iraq's widening of the conflict by its unprovoked attack on Israel; and

(f) recognises the need to intensify non- military efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, including a just resolution of the Palestinian issue and the continuing security of Israel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion. I do this despite the fact that the process of accepting this position has involved considerable personal anguish. I have been involved for a long time with the peace movement. In 1964 I was one of the first to demonstrate against the Vietnam War, I had come to an intellectual position, after having felt strongly that the war was wrong, that that was what I should do.

SPEECH.PARA: So I sympathise with those who feel strongly about this issue and find it difficult to support the actions taken or proposed. Furthermore, I do not think it is wrong, as some have suggested, to act on strong feelings without rational justification, to be spurred into action by the heart rather than the mind. This was how, as a younger man, I approached the question of capital punishment, for example. I had a strong feeling of revulsion at the act as I saw it-and still see it-of institutionalised murder from which my active opposition to that issue of capital punishment sprang. But, having felt this, it was incumbent upon me to rationalise this feeling, to develop an intellectual justification for my position. This was important for two reasons, not only to clarify my own thinking but also to be able to explain to other people why I felt that way, and to gain further adherents to that cause.

So it is with the issue of war. It is natural to feel revulsion to war; it is natural to feel revulsion at the senseless killing of the young combatants or, in modern wars, at the killing of innocent civilians of all ages. It is natural to feel revulsion at the tragic misallocation of resources into weapons with an awesome capacity to kill and to maim. It is natural to be concerned about the irrationality of the whole process of war; it is natural to feel all of these things. It is natural to feel this revulsion but, as with the analogy of capital punishment, it is incumbent on all of us to rationalise our position.

So many of the opponents of this motion, and to Australia's involvement in the Gulf war, have failed to do this. They have failed in particular to understand the significance of not curbing the excesses of Saddam Hussein. They have failed to explain--
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —They have failed to explain how the whole question might be resolved-if people would listen instead of joining the cheer squad that the Australian Democrats have engendered, they might learn something about it. They have failed to explain how the whole question might be resolved without the concerted action currently being taken. They have failed, in short, to provide any intellectual support in this particular area for what I understand are genuinely held feelings about involvement in war in general.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not enough to make invidious comparisons, as Senator Lees has, with East Timor, or with Panama, or with Grenada. Apart from the speciousness of such comparisons-for a whole range of reasons. If the international community did not act then, there is no reason at all why it should not act now. It is not enough either to talk about earlier errors in Middle East politics by the British, the French, the United States or the Soviet Union, nor is there any point giving support to Iraq's invasion in terms of the undemocratic nature of Kuwait. Kuwait is not the only autocratic fiefdom in the region, and Iraq is hardly in a position to be critical.

The fact is that Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait has upset a delicate balance within the region and a set of borders which, while not ideal, were accepted by all of the nations within the region and also those without. Any change to these borders must be the result of negotiations involving all those potentially affected. It cannot be by the annexation by force of an area. It is not enough either to demonise the United States of America, as is popular with the Democrats and Senator Vallentine. It needs to be remembered that only four of the United Nations 159 members have rejected the United Nations resolutions sanctioning the actions in the Gulf. It needs also to be remembered that 28 countries have committed forces in support of the United Nations Security Council resolutions, and that this includes nine Arab countries which have a lot more to lose than we do.

It is not enough either to argue by reference to claimed similarities between Vietnam and the Gulf. Such arguments, as many other speakers have pointed out, are also specious. Firstly, Australia's response in the Gulf was defined by and made in response to successive resolutions by the United Nations; that was not the case in Vietnam. Secondly, the Vietnam war was borne of anti-colonial nationalism and developed into a civil war; that is manifestly not the case in the Gulf.

Thirdly, our commitment to the Gulf, unlike Vietnam, is a modest, limited and practical one. It is a commitment that is proportionate to our national resources. Finally, our involvement in Vietnam was based upon a mistaken belief that an alien ideology was creeping southwards through Asia and would eventually engulf Australia-the so-called domino theory which history has proved to be a nonsense.

The reasons, by contrast, for our involvement in the Gulf are much clearer and much more logical than this. Firstly, Saddam Hussein's invasion and annexation of Kuwait, if unchecked, would give him a strategic power, in an already volatile and difficult region, out of all proportion to the size of Iraq. Does anybody seriously believe, given his track record, that Saddam would have stopped at Kuwait?

Secondly, the suggestion that it is somehow immoral or illegitimate to be concerned about oil is fanciful and naive, and might suit the cheer squad politics of the Democrats but does not suit anybody who wants to make a proper and rational analysis of the problem. It is not a question of morality, nor is it a question of Western greed. The whole world must be concerned about the strategic power offered by control over one of the world's most basic resources by a dictator who has armed Iraq-a country with a population about the same size as Australia-with a million troops and a formidable arsenal, including chemical and biological weapons, ballistic missiles and a developing nuclear capacity.

Senator Lees says that this will affect Third World countries which are struggling to survive. I ask her to consider how control of the oil resources of the world or a good proportion of the oil resources of the world by somebody of Saddam Hussein's nature would affect those same people.

The argument that we should have given sanctions longer to work has already been thoroughly dealt with by Senator Evans and by others, but it demonstrates a basic misunderstanding about what sanctions were meant to do. Put simply, sanctions were designed to bring Iraq to its senses, not to its knees--
An incident having occurred in the gallery-
Senator Vallentine interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Vallentine.

—This is precisely what I was talking about. It is the difference between cheer squad politics where people look for a cheap cheer rather than trying to analyse rationally a situation and come to a realistic solution.
—You cannot rationally analyse going to war; there is no rationalisation.
—Order! I ask Senator Vallentine not to continue with any interjections.

—Put in simple terms, sanctions were designed to bring Iraq to its senses, not to its knees. The fact is that in all the attempts at diplomacy and non-military coercion, Saddam has made no response. He has clearly never been interested in peace. He is a dictator whose whole ethos is bound up in military power. There seems to be a belief by those opposing the United Nations action that somehow we are in a perfect world where people act rationally, with honesty and with principle on all matters. The world is not like that. This is unfortunate, but true. The United Nations has always recognised this. As a result, it has sanctioned the use of force as a necessary part of its armoury of weapons to use at its disposal as each case arises.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Schacht in an earlier speech referred to one of the speeches of Dr Evatt on the formation of the United Nations in 1945. I will repeat what Dr Evatt said because it is worth repeating:

It must be made crystal clear that the nations making representation in the world organisation must be prepared to contribute their share of physical force to restrain the action of proved aggressors.

The Democrats in their amendment talk about reasserting a role for the United Nations, and yet what they want to do is to totally undermine the United Nations so that it cannot have a role. Force is a legitimate part of the armoury of the United Nations and suddenly the Democrats want to change all that. It was Thucydides who at the time of the Peloponnesian war said:
If you give in, you will immediately be confronted with some greater demand, since they will think you only gave way . . . through fear.
It is an unfortunate comment on mankind 2 1/2 millennia later and, despite remarkable advances in so many areas, that this comment is as valid now as it was then.

The fact is that Saddam Hussein is not about to be influenced except by force. It is this unavoidable fact which has led me, despite considerable personal anguish, to support a small but appropriate contribution to the world effort to force Saddam out of Kuwait. I welcome the Government's acceptance of the need to intensify efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, including a just resolution of the Palestinian question. I welcome also the Government's assurance that there will be no commitment of additional Australian forces to the Gulf. It is with deep personal regret that I believe the action proposed by the Government to be necessary. I urge support of the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my first speech in this place, I promised to bring to the Senate the attitudes of my family and to represent the people who had helped me grow from a boy into a man. I bring to this place the attitude that my mother had to wear since the minute I was born, when the midwife held me up by the heels-a long, stringy, very thin, weak-looking affair I was-and said, `More cannon fodder'. I was born during the Korean war. My mother was horrified by that and has had to carry that for some years. I bring her attitude to this place and I speak on behalf of her, my family, my peer group, my supporters and my friends and, I hope, for a growing number of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: On my way to this chamber today, I was handed a petition which had been gathered in my absence in Hobart between Saturday night and some time yesterday. While my office was manned by people working out of hours without me present and without a campaign to gather a petition, almost 1,000 people signed a petition, which I will table and ask to have dealt with in the normal way later this afternoon. But the amazing thing to me was that this petition arrived without my exhortations or campaigning and about 1,000 people saw fit to sign it, mostly late on Saturday and during Sunday.

I wanted to mention that before I started because it amazed me so much. That petition, of course, came from Hobart and, knowing Hobart people fairly well, I flicked through it and looked for some names that I might recognise. I can see in that list recognisable names of architects, doctors, teachers, film producers, bus drivers and butchers. I cannot identify the 1,000 names but I can see a broad spectrum of citizens of Hobart and also, quite interestingly, some people from mainland Australia who were tourists in Hobart signed it because they felt that this was a way that they could get a message across to their Government immediately.

During this lengthy debate so far, I have been disappointed, mostly by what I have seen as well-measured, carefully read statements, mostly delivered without passion and mostly delivered without commitment and without conviction. It seems that all we have heard is the party piece; all we have heard is what has been sanctioned by the Party, to use a word in another way. It is almost as if most of the people who have spoken so far have been afraid of showing passion, afraid of admitting that Australia has reached this shameful position.

In attempting to justify this position, Senator Gareth Evans said in part that wars have to be fought. I am afraid that I was not convinced. Part of Senator Hill's justification for the position that we have reached included his concern that a power balance must be preserved in the Middle East and, as I understand it, Senator Beahan was saying something of the same just recently. Senator Hill was also concerned about the possibility of a power vacuum when hostilities cease. I suggest that that vacuum would have been ideally filled from within Iraq by those who would have achieved Hussein's overthrow after his failure was apparent. And that failure would have become apparent, if sufficient time was given for sanctions to work.

A suggestion made earlier on in this debate via the interjections of several Liberal senators was that Iraqi citizens would starve during the enforcement of sanctions. Those interjections reveal how little those people know of the geography of the area. We are talking about the fertile crescent. It is highly unlikely that Iraqi citizens will starve-although they will not be eating caviar-as a result of sanctions, as a result of the actions which keep trade away from their country.

Sanctions will destroy trade and sanctions will destroy military capacity, but for Liberal senators glibly to suggest from their ignorance of the geography of the area that people will starve illustrates their depth of understanding of what is involved here. Sanctions will destroy the military capacity of the area. They will force that country, if applied long enough of course, to become something more like an agrarian society, incapable of sustaining the megalomania of military dictators such as Saddam. Surely that is the agreed purpose of sanctions-to reduce the capacity of a leader to provide for his external ambitions.

After listening to some of this debate yesterday, I took refuge in watching the television late last night. Two experts, Marvin Feuerwerger and Edward Luttwak, were interviewed on a Cable News Network program at 1.30 this morning. Marvin Feuerwerger was from the Washington Institute for Near East Policy and Edward Luttwak was from the Washington Centre for Strategic and International Studies. These experts were introduced by the interviewer and the interviewer's questions generally took the trend of, `What is the next phase in the war?' and, `What should we do next?'. I think the expectations of the interviewer were that we would be told what the next phase was. Instead, Luttwak replied, `Sanctions were working. We should not proceed beyond the air war. We could starve the troops out. They need truckloads of food each day'. The other speaker suggested that we should not engage Iraq in a ground war because it would be solely a waste of lives. Both those strategists appeared on American television last night and were not witnesses being led by the prosecution; they were witnesses brought to argue, I think, another phase of the war. However, without assistance from the interviewer, they came up with that analysis.

Returning to the debate-not the television debate-several speakers so far have invoked their personal understanding of history in their attempts to justify the actions of this Government. Many honourable senators have read out lists of past tyrants and have described the past responses of Western civilisations to these tyrants. If we really want to learn the lessons of history, we should not be interested in imitating the failures of history, nor should we be interested in any new world order which depends upon American superiority of armaments.

Senator Schacht spoke at length about this new order. There is nothing new about trying to bludgeon dissenters into compliance, nor is there anything new about using military superiority to enforce peace. The Romans tried that. It is not a real, lasting peace. History teaches us that such peace only lasts as long as it takes for a new weapon to emerge or for a new tyrant to develop his power. We are obliged to be interested in the lessons of history.

Perhaps the mightiest lesson of all is provided to us by the Great War-the war to end all wars. It did not. Instead, new weapons and new violent strategies gave promise to new violent warriors who wanted to avenge the memory of their forefathers. The same, or even a greater effect, was obvious from the Second World War-a war that was caused by the first. What whirlwind will we reap from the seeds of today's destruction?

Other honourable senators spoke of more recent history: the atrocities committed by the Iraqis in Kuwait. Senator Tate asked us directly for a quantification of the level of atrocities required before violent reaction could be provoked. My personal and genuine answer to Senator Tate-and I am very pleased that he is in the chamber at the moment-is that a nation has vastly different capacities and vastly different responsibilities to those of an individual.

TALK.START.PARA: —Duck the question.

—I do not duck the question. If Senator Kemp will listen, I will provide him with my personal answer. As an individual, I could tolerate very little violence on my children before being provoked into a physical response. I even try not to allow them to be jostled within a crowd. I suppose that all fathers wrestle with difficulties in this regard. But nations have a responsibility to do more than make brief, instinctive physical reactions. They have a responsibility also to go through more than esoteric mental recreation; they have to face the aggression and decide what to do about it. It is the responsibility of nations to respond in a considered, timely, just and responsible manner, with due regard for the future consequences of their reaction.

SPEECH.PARA: As a father, I am afraid that I would not have the capacity to think too much about the future consequences of any reaction that I might have if my child was threatened. But as a nation we have the responsibility to think of the future because we are acting not on our own behalf, and not on the behalf of the individuals under our control-we are acting as representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —So it is okay to let Kuwaiti children be murdered while we stand by?

—I did not say that. If Senator Macdonald does not have the capacity to understand what I say, I suggest that he stop using his mouth and use his other ear. I cannot endorse nations behaving like vigilantes. Those who do suffer the consequences and history has taught us what happens.
—What would you do about the murderers of children in Kuwait?
—I have told Senator Macdonald. Did he not understand?
—You are very difficult to understand at the best of times, but what would you do with the murderers of children in Kuwait?
—Order! Interjections are disorderly. I ask all honourable senators not to interject. Senator Bell has the floor.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I cannot help but think that the response which is now occurring in the Gulf may well bring about destruction and suffering vastly in excess of anything that has occurred in Kuwait. The present violence is certainly the seed of future violence. Thus, that is not an appropriate response, regardless of the sophistication of the ordnance being used and regardless of the precision of its delivery, the decision to use military force was a primitive decision.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell suggested in his contribution that the leader of Iraq is probably irrational and inconsistent to the extent that he cannot maintain meaningful negotiations. These are probably not Senator Boswell's exact words but I think I have the sense of it. I agree with his instinctive psychoanalysis. However, we should consider what is possible in terms of negotiations in this region. In effect, we are negotiating with the Iraqi people and not just their leader. Surely our aim is to place that evil leader in such a position that his own people will recognise his folly and stupidity and, therefore, remove his authority or at least remove their support of his regime. Such a course would resolve much of what is not resolved by warfare.

The Iraqi people would not then be harbouring a smouldering hatred of those who they now see as aggressors. Such hatreds have always eventually given rise to vengeance. If any interjector suggests that such a theory is naive, I say again that that person should look at history. Such hatreds always give rise to vengeance, with the avengers claiming the status of heroes. Such hatreds have always perpetuated warfare.

In passing, I must say that I am particularly disappointed that so much of the negotiating that we saw reported in Australia was conducted by people other than those with the United Nations mandate. It was only at the very end that the United Nations Secretary-General was expected to achieve an impossible, last minute resolution after the military minds had painted all of us into an impossible corner.

Senator Tate, Senator McMullan and others reported the statements made by the world leaders such as Mitterrand and Craxi. Quotes from those people suggest that Hussein would never say the word `withdrawal' and that he has not given us any sign that he would comply with the United Nations requests. Have these people not been anywhere? Do they not know anything? That is what bullies talk about. That is what they are all about. That is the language of bullyism. They never, ever admit fault. They never submit.

What did these wise people do? They gave a deadline; a time to aim for. Of course the leader of Iraq waited until the deadline. Of course he maintained his position until then. Without that line to aim for, with uncertainty, with no indication of when international patience will run out, stress and pressure would mount from within. The Iraqi people would then put pressure on the person who is leading them into a vague situation without a deadline, without a goal and without any sense of achievement. It is then that the uncertainties would arise from within the administration of Iraq.

Senator Newman suggested that our civilisation has a history of dealing with tyrants. The history of our treatment of previous tyrants has not rid the world of new tyrants. We have one now. If we meet violence with violence, and if we meet the tyrants with violence, there will always be one who believes he is stronger. That is the fundamental law of violence. There will be one who believes he is more terrible, more fear-inspiring than all who have been defeated before with violence.

We must not repeat the follies of history. We need to recognise that what Senator McLean was saying yesterday was, in fact, where we are. Senator McLean spoke about our opportunity to move from the mentality of war to the mentality of peace. We are, in our society now, at a threshold. I am sorry to say that we went over the brink a couple of days ago. We have reached a stage in our society where we have the technology, the social skills and the communications networks which we had never had before. We almost had the will to bring about a real new world order, a world order of strong, persistent, international cohesion to ostracise the warmongers and to make their program impossible to embark upon.

Senator MacGibbon, with his keen vision, noticed that all those concerned about the use of violence in this conflict are those who were concerned about the use of violence to solve Vietnam's problems. He was wrong: there are many missing. His eyesight has failed him. Those who are missing are sitting on the Labor front bench. What has happened to their courage, their commitment and their faith in the future and the progress of our civilisation? By that I mean the progress towards non-military solutions to international problems. Those aspirations are constrained within the stultifying blanket of the party system.

I am pleased to note that there are perhaps some who may not feel the constraint as tightly as others, but that system has denied parliamentarians an opportunity to vote publicly in the same direction as their conscience. I blame that system for the frustration which has been expressed by so many Australians. They are frustrated because they have not seen sufficient public debate and public exposure, through debate, of the concerns that my colleagues have expressed both yesterday and today.

As I listened to Senator Schacht's contribution I hoped for some departure from the party line. Senator Schacht gave us a lot of information. He described how Iraq's Government has abused its own people over the last 20 years and he placed particular emphasis on evidence from 1985. All Senator Schacht's evidence shows us is Australia's inaction over those years. Although he has been outspoken on human rights issues over a number of years, it does not seem to have achieved the results which he and many others would hope for.

Senator Schacht also confused not fighting with inaction. It takes great courage to resist the primitive urge to lash out, to strike rather than negotiate. I was astounded to hear Senator Schacht attempting to misquote Martin Luther King's thoughts about how evils should be met. Of course King challenged all peaceful people to meet evil and to take action. He did not propose violent reaction against it. Senator Schacht's problem is that he knows of only one action-the primitive action of violence. I was astounded that he attempted to endorse that by referring to Martin Luther King.

I had a great problem with Senator Schacht's repeated and misguided assertion that the Australian Democrats first opposed sanctions. We certainly did not. What we did oppose was the placing of Australian vessels under United States command in a role which at that time was not endorsed by the United Nations. The Democrats contend that there could still be a role for Australian ships to play as part of a United Nations sanction enforcement team.

Speaking of being unconvincing, Senator Aulich was one who drove me to write down what he was saying. He suggested that until now we have been unable to implement collective security through the United Nations. Perhaps he is correct. We do know that we now have the opportunity to exercise collective security. Real security comes from the opportunity to reduce the imbalance between the haves and the have-nots. But to suggest that collective security needs as its foundation the destructiveness of this military action is to remove the best opportunity we have to establish, through consensus, non-military actions as the restraints which are necessary for the preservation of peace. Restraints built in that way are restraints which are not easily broken. Restraints based on violence are those which can be overcome by any other violence.

The military actions are really like mass capital punishment. Just as the prospect of capital punishment does not deter the crazed murderer, mass capital punishment cannot deter the power-hungry dictator, the sort of person who always adopts the mentality of the schoolyard bully- `If I am violent enough I can overcome all comers'; the `I am the greatest' mentality. As we all know, such a mentality is always surpassed eventually, usually by a more violent person.

I do not know about honourable senators in the chamber, but I have seen enough of life: I have had to deal with enough tough guys to know the basic laws of the street. I know that if such a person is ostracised he is met with complete isolation from his community. If nobody challenges him, if he is unable to function in the community, his violence is irrelevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes or no-would it have worked with Hitler?

—For the benefit of the cloth ears here, I will start again. I have given a recipe because we now have the technological capacity, the social skills, the communication network and the social development which, for the first time in history, give us the opportunity to bring to bear on bullies the sorts of actions which we have learnt surpass the primitive actions taken in the past which have failed. What is being proposed, by way of interjection, is that we return to the primitive notions of the past and try to learn them all over again. That is just garbage. There is a lesson we need to learn so we can eventually rid the world of the likes of this despicable tyrant that has been given to us. If we are too thick to learn it, in centuries to come we will realise that we had an opportunity in the 1990s and, because of intransigence and primitive thought, we did not take it. That will be to our disadvantage.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of what we have heard from Government speakers about collective security and the strength of acting in unity is quite correct. The important thing is what we do when we are in unison, how we enforce peace when we act together. That is why my petitioners and correspondents ask the question of this Government. We know that violence does not work. Why do we not look at the alternative measures? That is why we are so upset about the action taken by the Government. We are upset because we know that there are alternative means. We know that the world and the world's peoples understand that. Why do the world's leaders not understand it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion before the Senate. Senator Bell gave us a summary of all the reasons why the Australian people will, in the end, totally reject the view which has been put forward by Senator Powell and her colleagues. Anyone listening to Senator Bell would have assumed that the Gulf crisis was the fault of Mr Bush and Mr Hawke. He barely mentioned this evil dictator, this slaughterer of his own people, this man who has plunged the world into this terrible bloodbath. We heard virtually nothing from Senator Bell about Saddam Hussein.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bell urged us to learn the lessons of history and he referred to World War II. The lesson of history is this: at the end of the day, peace-loving people have to stand up to bloodthirsty dictators. People have to say, `Thus far and no further', and be prepared to enforce their will. Standing up to the Nazis and the Japanese did not create 40 or 50 years of violence: it created a long period of peace in Europe. It is clear that the Australian Democrats have learnt nothing from history.

It is unlikely that during our period as senators we will have to consider a motion of greater moment than one which commits the men and women of our armed forces to war. Dr Hewson has stated the position of the coalition very clearly. He said yesterday, and I quote:
We share with the Government a fundamental unity of purpose concerning Australia's commitment to the Gulf war.

The arguments regarding our commitment to the Gulf have been extensively canvassed in this chamber. Today I wish to direct myself to two particular matters. Firstly, I believe there is not a person in the Senate or in the House of Representatives who is not for peace. I reject the assertions from Senator Powell and her colleagues that they are the ones who offer the best chance for long term peace in this world. Indeed, the policy advocated by Senator Powell and the Senator Vallentines of this world would, I believe, given time, lead to international disaster.

The second issue I wish to discuss relates to the responsibility of the Government to ensure that our service men and women receive the Government and community support that they are entitled to expect. All of us in this chamber seek peace. The debate is between those who say the best way to maintain peace in the long term is to avoid confronting the aggressor, to give him time, concessions-indeed anything-in the hope of persuading him to cease his illegal occupation of his neighbour. On the other hand, there are those-and I am pleased to say the vast majority of senators-who argue that naked aggression must now be resisted as all reasonable diplomatic steps to secure peace have been exhausted.

It is clear that the Democrats, under the leadership of Senator Powell, have adopted a policy of appeasement. Dr Hewson, and Senator Evans in this chamber, were quite correct in drawing our attention to the lessons of the 1930s. Appeasing the aggressor in the 1930s did not lead to peace but resulted in the deaths of tens of millions of men, women and children. Appeasement was the policy that was tried by the British Prime Ministers Baldwin and Chamberlain, and it was a policy which almost led to world Nazi domination. This is how the historian, William Manchester, describes the great appeasers, Baldwin and Chamberlain, who now, as he says, wear the sackcloth of history. He wrote:
So, with their eyes open they sought accommodation with a criminal regime, turned a blind eye to its iniquities, ignored its frequent resort to murder and torture . . .

Senator Powell, Senator Vallentine and indeed most of the Democrat speakers in their contributions to this debate largely ignored the criminal regime of Saddam Hussein and spent much of their time, as I have said, attacking the policies of the United States of America and the Australian Government in their attempt to give meaning and substance to the resolution of the United Nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did their former leader say?

—Senator Chipp, I understand, has dumped on them. Senator Chipp has made it very clear, I understand, that he does not support the policies that Senator Powell and her colleagues are now pursuing. We believe that the policy represented by the motion before this chamber is the international community's best chance to secure a new world order based on peaceful relations between sovereign states. Saddam's invasion and annexation of Kuwait, a member state of the United Nations, was a flagrant violation of the United Nations Charter, yet Senator Powell urges us to show him more understanding and to give him more time.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been many attempts over the past five months to get a negotiated settlement-all frustrated by Iraq's refusal to withdraw. What evidence is there that Saddam Hussein is prepared to negotiate peace? Senator Powell has not brought forward any evidence today. Saddam Hussein has a record of making war on his neighbours and slaughtering his own citizens who have the misfortune to belong to a minority group or who are his political opponents. What chance is there to negotiate a rational peace with this man? How do we deal with an evil leader such as Saddam Hussein, who has no respect for human rights and civilised behaviour? Senator Powell, Senator Vallentine and, as we have just heard, Senator Bell, offer no solution.

Senator Evans has outlined in some detail why the policy to impose sanctions was not in the end going to bring about a resolution of the conflict. It is interesting that none of the Democrat speakers have seen fit to carefully address and weigh the arguments that Senator Evans put forward. In calling for sanctions to be given what amounts to unlimited time-and I repeat that the Democrats are effectively calling for sanctions to be given absolutely unlimited time-Senator Powell, Senator Vallentine and their colleagues might reflect on this matter: Saddam Hussein has never had a weapon he has not used, or indeed is prepared to use.

Senator Edward Kennedy informed the United States Senate armed services committee hearings that in eight or nine months time Saddam will have some type of nuclear weapon. Senator Vallentine in her speech said that Iraq is developing a nuclear capability. How does Senator Vallentine deal with this fact? Within a brief period of time Iraq may be able to deliver a nuclear bomb. Did she offer a sound practical policy to deal with what would be an immense crisis for the world community? What did Senator Vallentine do? She attacked Israel. She offered nothing practical, nothing to deal with the real substance of the issues which are before this chamber. Is there any doubt that Saddam would be prepared to use a nuclear bomb as an offensive weapon to dominate his neighbours? A war he would wage with a nuclear capacity would cause far greater confusion and casualties than may be inflicted by the present crisis. We also know that with additional time Saddam Hussein will be able to upgrade his delivery systems for chemical and biological weapons. All the evidence points to the fact that Saddam Hussein is more than prepared to use these terrible weapons.

It is worth considering the horrendous implications for the future of the world if Saddam Hussein possesses an effective arsenal of nuclear bombs and upgraded chemical and biological weapons. Providing additional time for sanctions, as argued by Senator Powell and her colleagues, would not produce peace. It may produce a holocaust. Senator Powell warns us of another Vietnam. In some ways Senator Powell, in raising this issue, is raising an apt point. The failure to defeat an aggressor in Vietnam condemned the people of South Vietnam to be governed by one of the world's most backward regimes, a regime that instituted a gulag to re-educate its political opponents, a regime which has created such terror that hundreds of thousands of its citizens thought it preferable to face the risks of rape, torture from pirates, and possible death in the open sea, than to stay under a totalitarian dictatorship.

In his speech supporting the Government's position Senator Bolkus, to his undying discredit, seemed to forget these real lessons of Vietnam. Indeed, it has to be said that Senator Bolkus hardly bolstered the Government's case for supporting the United States-led coalition forces by recalling that the Left had supported the Vietnamese-by that he means, of course, the communist Vietnamese-against imperialist forces. Who were the imperialist forces? I suspect the imperialist forces he was referring to-and he would attempt to argue-were the US and Australian forces. It hardly bolsters the Government's policy to have a Minister stand up and utter such nonsense, in my view. Senator Schacht also undermined his own well-argued case by mentioning the Vietnam experience.

The second point I wish to address is the need to ensure that the Government's Gulf policy is effectively communicated to the Australian public. Our service men and women need to be confident that the nation is united behind them. The bipartisanship which has been offered by the Opposition means that there is almost a unique opportunity to build and maintain national unity and purpose on the Gulf commitment.

Indeed, the divisions between the two major parties which have so often marked Australian foreign policy since World War II are not present in this crisis. How different it is from the time when the Fraser Government sought bipartisan support from the Labor Party for the Australian commitment to the multilateral Sinai peace force following the Camp David agreement. I can tell Senator Tate that the Labor Party has come a long way since the debates in 1981-82.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his senior Ministers have been criticised in the press for failing to communicate effectively the Government's Gulf policy. It is a policy which I and my colleagues all support, as we have stated. Regrettably, there is some substance to these criticisms. For example, the Government was notably unenthusiastic about recalling Parliament to enable this vital national debate to take place which will demonstrate, above all, the strong support that this Parliament will give to our Gulf commitment. That is the message which will go out from this Parliament when this motion comes to the vote.

Regrettably, some Australian Labor Party members and senators have already attempted to undermine the Government's policies. Senator Tambling drew attention previously and, indeed, in this chamber today to the fact that a Government office-holder, Mr Snowdon, the honourable member for the Northern Territory, has given his strong support to a rally opposing the Government's policy. Mr Hawke must show that his Government speaks with one voice on this vital national issue. It is one thing for Labor Party backbenchers to dissent from Government policy; it is intolerable that a Government office-holder should be free to attack our national commitment. In my view, Mr Snowdon must either resign or be sacked by the Prime Minister.

There is some irony in the fact that yesterday Senator Evans was subjected to considerable abuse from so-called peace activists when he attempted to explain to this Parliament why, in some cases, military action is the only moral course. It would be interesting to calculate how much money this Government has funnelled into so-called peace groups. The Government recently announced the establishment of a peace study centre in Perth. I wonder whether Senator Tate, who is in this chamber, can let us know whether this centre will join with some other so-called peace centres in attacking the Gulf commitment.

Can Senator Tate tell us how much the Government gave to radical peace groups in 1986, the International Year of Peace? How many of these groups are supporting the moral commitment the Government has made to support the UN resolutions on the Gulf? Do their publications make it clear that at times this nation must go to war if we are to establish a workable long time peace? I think not.

This is not point scoring. The Government, through its own shortsightedness and weakness, has helped the Left build its influence in the education system and given it resources which have increased its capacity to attack the national commitment to the Gulf. As a result, the onus is now on Senator Tate and his colleagues to make special efforts to communicate the Gulf policy, to effectively answer the concerns that will be raised and to expose the false arguments of the Senator Vallentines and their supporters.

Other difficulties will have to be faced by the Government if it is to communicate its policy with a strong voice. The fact that our forces are committed to the Gulf raises particular dilemmas for the media. It is a concern that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) itself has become a matter of controversy in relation to the coverage of the war. It has been accused of anti-Americanism and pro-pacifist bias in the press, and today Senator Robert Ray gave some credence to these views by saying that no-one could argue that the ABC is pro-American. I hope the ABC is pro-Australian.

I have not had the opportunity to analyse the validity of the arguments which have been made against the ABC in the press but I have noted that David Hill, not surprisingly, rejects these criticisms. Nevertheless, the ABC does have a tradition of left wing bias. What procedures does the ABC have in place to ensure that its current affairs programs do not excessively promote minority views? The public would be interested to hear from David Hill what these procedures are and how they are being observed. Does the Government have a view on the performance of the national broadcaster in relation to its reporting of the Gulf crisis?

The Government has now asked men and women to put their lives at stake for the national good. There can be no twotrack foreign policy. The national interest must not be compromised by any Labor Party internal problems and, indeed, the frequently perceived need by the Labor Party leadership to placate its left wing.

For example, two years ago the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) leader, Yasser Arafat, mouthed the renunciation of terrorism and the recognition of Israel's right to exist. Events have proved he clearly did not mean these words. Why, then, we ask, is the Government still considering a request by the PLO office in Canberra for visas to enable overseas PLO representatives to come here? The request should have been rejected as soon as the PLO made clear its support for Baghdad's invasion of Kuwait, and it should certainly be rejected now.

How can Australia take resolute action against Saddam Hussein and, at the same time, consider appeasing some of his most enthusiastic supporters by upgrading further the PLO status and representation in Canberra? I can tell Senator Tate that action on this front will help communicate the determination of the Government to support its own policy.

As I have said, Australians will not tolerate a two-track foreign policy. There is some evidence to date that the Government does not have a well thought out policy, as I have said, to communicate clearly and forcefully the reasons for our Gulf commitment. In my view, every family in Australia should be informed of the reasons this Parliament has made its bipartisan commitment to the Gulf.

Recognising the bipartisan approach which has been offered by the coalition, I would certainly like to see a letter jointly signed by Mr Hawke and Dr Hewson posted to every adult in Australia, which encloses information and sets out in straightforward language the reasons why we have made this national commitment. With this information at hand, all Australians will understand why this Parliament will pass the motion before us with a huge majority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Peace in our time-those words have been uttered many times in this century with optimism and hope by people who reflect the world's desire to live in peace, to live without conflict. And 1990 promised to be just that-a year in which we had peace, when Russia changed its spots, when the Berlin Wall fell, when the problem of Namibia was solved, and when South African people were given some hope. While there was still some conflict in the world, the world basically started off as a better place at the beginning of 1990. It was a place in which peace and disarmament meant that a civilised world could concentrate on such matters as poverty, starvation and the environment and look after those in the world who deserved a better life.

SPEECH.PARA: But what happened to that promising start of 1990? That madman, Saddam Hussein, came upon the scene. Without reason, cause or logic, he ruthlessly and brutally invaded and occupied an adjoining sovereign state and proceeded to rape and pillage a nation and its people. He imposed a regime of summary execution, arrest and incarceration without trial and often without cause; a regime where accidentally spilling a cup of coffee over his photograph in a newspaper meant instant arrest; a regime where turning off his broadcast on a radio in a public place meant imprisonment.
