So the issue of sanctions is the key issue. I have come to the conclusion that sanctions were not going to succeed. We are left then with the one option, and that is the military option.

I mentioned earlier that for me it was a particularly difficult personal decision to come to, given that I never believed it would be a short war. No war is ever clean, war is horrific. I know a medical practitioner who spent some time in Iran during the conflict. He was a surgeon asked to go there in order to treat the victims of the Iran-Iraq conflict. He showed me some photographs of the victims of gas warfare. They were certainly the most horrific photos I have ever seen of human beings and the way that they are affected by war. Those sorts of images weighed in my mind when considering this issue.

In terms of the future-I would like to examine this briefly before I conclude-I hope that out of this conflict and out of the reorganisation of world affairs that we have witnessed over the last year and with the end of the Cold War we have an emerging international system where justice, fairness and equity can be resolved without the necessity of warfare.

I hope that the United Nations can take the leading pivotal role in this new conduct of world affairs. I have to say that I hesitate to use the term that has been used quite frequently-the new world order. I have heard that term used before, incidentally, by Adolf Hitler. I am afraid the images it conjures up are not particularly pleasant. I give one word of warning. I certainly do not believe that the United States can be expected, if this new international system emerges, to pay the economic and military price for enforcing the sorts of actions that are necessary in Kuwait. We are going to have to evolve very quickly some way of the international community sharing that burden. If that means the United Nations developing its own effective military force, then so be it. But I am fairly sceptical that that sort of international organisation will emerge because I believe that when it is put to the test on other occasions, when we cannot obtain the almost unanimous world opinion that we have on this occasion, we will not be able to police effectively the United Nations resolutions and sanctions if we have to.

But certainly, the United States cannot be expected to bear the brunt and the price of being the world's policeman. I believe that after this dispute is over there is a real danger that the United States may well retreat back into isolationism in a way similar to the way in which the Soviet Union has been forced to, particularly given that the European Community and the Japanese economy are, without doubt, emerging as the great economic forces in the world and seem loath to pay their share of the price.

Another point about the United Nations-again, it is a point that has been made by the Australian Democrats; it is a legitimate point but it does not excuse the fact that they are not supporting the action in the Middle East-is the behaviour of countries that sell arms to both sides as occurred in the Iran-Iraq conflict. It went on and again I personally hope that with the emergence of a new international system, the United Nations can take effective control of the arms trade by restricting and reducing it and, hopefully, eliminating it, so that we do not have the massive billions of dollars spent on armaments that could otherwise be spent on more effective causes that have been outlined.

As I have said, I reject the linkage of the Palestinian problem and other problems in the Middle East. I believe that it should be rejected but I sincerely hope that there will be an international conference on those issues and that they will be seriously addressed. If there is one thing to be learnt, and it is a sad way that Israel has had to learn it, it is that the argument that Israel needs defensible borders has largely disappeared with the advent of missile attacks because there are no defensible borders against missile attack.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Patriot missiles?

—They are not particularly effective. In conclusion, I would like to make some comments about the protesters. I protested against the Vietnam war. Again, I reject the analogy between the Vietnam war and this situation. I can understand how people feel, particularly young people who have been in the galleries, the people who are outside and the persons who have rung me about this issue. I discussed this matter with the mother of one of the naval personnel last week. She came to see me in my office. We talked about the issues for some two hours in a fairly rational manner. At the end of the conversation, when we had gone through the sorts of issues that I have talked about in the Senate today, she looked at me and said, `Senator Sherry, I have come to the conclusion that there really is no other way'. There is no other way. That is the conclusion I have come to and that is the reason why I support my Government. I support the motion before the Senate. I will be supporting that position publicly and I will be supporting that position in my Party. I also thank the Liberal Party and the National Party for being bipartisan in that support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly this evening to join with my colleagues in supporting the motion moved by the Government on the Gulf war. At this stage of the debate it could be said that with 40-odd speakers who have spoken ahead of me, I could add very little to the debate that has not already been said. I may even agree with such observations, but I do not agree with the observation made by Paul Lyneham on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program yesterday morning in Western Australia when he suggested the speakers could be limited. He asked the question, `Who would be interested in what the member for Timbuktu thought of the Gulf war?'. I believe that members or senators from remote areas have something to contribute to the debate on the Gulf war. I know they contribute plenty to other debates, but they can also contribute to the debate on the Gulf war.

SPEECH.PARA: First, may I record my disappointment that Parliament was not recalled last week before the deadline expired. I know that putting this nation into a state of war is a function of executive government, but senators and members could have been briefed at first hand rather than relying on the biased opinions of the media. The United States Congress had a special sitting; the German parliament sat; and the Italian parliament definitely sat because three or four speakers from the Government side have quoted from the great speech of Craxi, the Italian Prime Minister. I agree with most of what he had to say, although I do not agree with everything his Government does. The French and British parliaments had their sittings, but we did not, so there will not be any of our famous speeches quoted, as the other speeches such as Craxi's was here.

Since the beginning of the Gulf dispute, the Opposition has supported the Government in all the moves it has made, so the Government did not face any problems from us in sitting last week. However, with the way the Australian Democrats have carried on, it would not matter whether we sat last week or this week; they perform the same.

I believe the way that the Gulf war has been shown on television is an utter disgrace. I know that we have to have up to date reports, but I do not believe in glorifying war. It has been run as a live show, interspersed with American advertisements. It is something that we can do without and the television media should be looked at. War is a serious matter and should be treated as such. It should not be glorified that way. War, of course, was the final solution after everything else had been tried in this matter. Honourable senators may have read the reports in the media this morning of the effect that that type of reporting has had on families and children.

I want to make a short comment-as other speakers have-on the behaviour of the peace movement. I do not deny the right of any movement to express its views, but there is a right and wrong way to do it. The behaviour that we have seen in the galleries of this chamber was disgraceful and was mainly led and stirred by Senator Vallentine. She interjected when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was speaking in the House of Representatives. She was sitting in the Senators Gallery and, when an attempt was made to eject her, she pulled rank, told the attendants she was a senator and could not be ejected. If she was prepared to interject she should have been prepared to accept the consequences and not to have pulled rank. Her action leaves a lot to be desired.

What will happen next time there is something controversial being debated in this Parliament? Will people in the gallery be allowed to carry on in the same way? In the next few months the rural voice will get stronger over the recession. Will we condone farmers carrying on in the same way or will they be ejected?
Senator Boswell interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If they do, I will be the first to call for their ejection, Senator Boswell. However, my main point concerns the sanctions that have been applied by the United Nations. This was the main thrust of the Democrats' argument. They believe the sanctions have not been given enough time. Senator Powell and others told us that the sanctions were the only way to go and should have been allowed to continue, but how long is enough time? Is it six months? Is it a year? Is it two years? Is it five years or whatever? No one has told us.
—How long will it take with South Africa?

—Senator Boswell has mentioned South Africa. The sanctions there have been proved to be a failure. If honourable senators do not believe me they should ask the black population there whether the sanctions have worked. The only ones who have suffered in South Africa have been the black population. Sanctions hurt only the weakest, not the strongest. It has been mentioned already by Government and Opposition senators that, as the sanctions continued, Hussein became stronger and stronger. In South Africa sanctions were applied in 1963, a lot longer ago than I imagined, on the supply of arms.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1970 a sports ban was placed on South Africa by the Olympic Committee. That would be the only successful sanction. It caused the elimination of South Africa from the Olympics and caused the elimination from competition of the best cricket team in the world at the time. That is the only one that has worked. The sanctions of 1980, 1985 and the United Nations Security Council suspension of investment in 1986 all failed to work and South Africa became stronger and stronger. South Africa is independent in fuel even though it has only two oil wells; it has been able to extract fuel from coal. So in those 28 years the sanctions have failed.

I will move away from South Africa; I was distracted by Senator Boswell. Do the Democrats know who will pay for the sanctions? If five months have not been long enough, how long will it take for the sanctions to work? It could take five years. Who will pay for them? In the final analysis, trade sanctions fall most heavily on rural industries. That is of no concern to the Democrats, of course. Senator Bell, who has been the latter day saint of the defence of the rural industry, has failed to think how sanctions would affect those industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Farmers do not prosper from war.

—They do not; they lose, but we are all in together. Primary industry is still being affected by those failed sanctions against South Africa. We have a large amount of trade with the Middle East that has been affected. That leaves aside the trade we have lost with Iraq, the country we are at war with. Iraq was our second biggest wheat customer, taking about 1.3 million tonnes. We have lost that market and we have to look for others. We had a good trade in live sheep to Kuwait. There has been no trade with Iraq during the last two years in live sheep, but during the 1980s Kuwait was our second most important market. In recent years it took about 1.6 million sheep annually, somewhat below the peak of 2.1 million in 1984. The embargo means that the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) forecast for total live sheep exports of 5.8 million is very unlikely to be achieved. I have said that we should forget the trade with Iraq because we are at war with it and we will probably replace that market, but Iraq caused us to lose our trade with Kuwait by its illegal invasion of Kuwait in August.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the Democrats' view on oil and the slogan which is around which says `No blood for oil.' The Democrats have said that time and time again, but I quote the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson):

Success in seizing Kuwait's oil assets would encourage Saddam Hussein to repeat the strategy against other neighbours. His growing oil power would fund a further arsenal and adversely affect inflation, growth and interest rates not just in Western economies but in Third World ones as well.
These are the countries that the Democrats purport to care for all the time. He continued:

Saddam's aggression has come at a critical time for the global economy, with the onset of recession in many countries, the severe difficulties confronting eastern European countries and the threatened breakdown of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade system. It also comes at a particularly critical time for our own economy-
in case Senator Coulter does not know-

which is very vulnerable to any downturn in the international economy. To prevent world oil supplies being illegally acquired and manipulated by a ruthless and aggressive dictator is not a goal about which Australia or the rest of the international community need feel any embarrassment.
I feel no embarrassment tonight in agreeing with that claim.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before the dinner break I quoted from the speech delivered by my Leader, Dr Hewson, to the House of Representatives in which he pointed out that he is not ashamed-and I believe that we should not be ashamed-to admit that we do not want 65 per cent of the world's oil to finish up in a mad dictator's hands. I stand by that statement. I have said before that the sanctions have failed, and all the senators, from both the Opposition and the Government sides, who have spoken in this debate have said that the sanctions have failed.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that five months was long enough: five months in which Hussein did not give one inch, or 2.54 centimetres; five months in which Kuwait suffered more and more and was plundered more and more with infrastructure being dismantled and removed to Iraq; five months in which oil prices around the world rose because of the effect of the occupation; and five months in which nothing was achieved.

If the United Nations had achieved half of what it was aiming to achieve in that time, we could have said that something was achieved, but absolutely nothing was achieved in those five months. It was five months in which Iraq dug in in Kuwait, and that is the only thing that was achieved. Hussein achieved that; we achieved nothing. D day was 16 January, just as 6 June 1944 was D day. That day, 6 June 1944, was the day that the liberation of Europe commenced. Not five months after sanctions had been imposed or anything like that, but five years plus after the appeasement of Hitler-Baghdad Rose keeps denying that that went on but that is what happened-the Allies set out on the liberation of Europe. To that date the Second World War had been under way with occupation and digging in. That is when the liberation of Europe started, and it took another 12 months after that, with a lot of slaughter, finally to achieve what was done. If in 1938 things had been played differently and played as they are played now, things would have been a lot different. When the United Nations with the Allies acted on 16 January, the time had most certainly come to remove the invaders of Kuwait. The sanctions had failed, as I have already said.

I know that this two-day special sitting of Parliament is not to debate the deepening recession that affects this country, but the sanctions have had a special effect on the rural areas that I represent with the loss of the grain and live sheep trades, and I have told the Senate of that on other occasions. I hope that it will not be too long before the Prime Minister makes good the promise he made when he said that he did not want the sanctions that we have imposed on Iraq to be carried by only certain sectors of Australia. I hope that it will not be very long before he puts those words into action to relieve the problems the sanctions have caused in the country areas of Australia.
I come briefly to the call by Senator Powell from the Australian Democrats for us to vote on our consciences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have a conscience?

—Yes, I most certainly have a conscience. I use it at all times and not only when it suits me. Senator McLean ought to know what I am talking about. Senator Powell urges us to vote according to our consciences. I am certainly voting according to my conscience and I will leave the rest of the Parliament to vote according to their consciences. The Democrats consider that they have a mortgage on peace in this world, amongst the environment and all the other things that they think they have a mortgage on.
—All the trendy things that will give them a cheap vote.

—Yes, anything that will get the Democrats the cheap vote, like the peanut gallery that they had yesterday. They think they have a mortgage on peace. Senator Powell stated that the Democrats, who make up 4 per cent of this Parliament, speak for 50 per cent of the population. Has anyone had a look at the polls lately? There was a Newspoll and a Westpoll the other day. I do not know of any country in this world amongst the coalition or non-coalition that has not had 80 per cent support for the United Nations on these measures. Yet the Democrats have the gall to stand up here and go to the newspaper-in this case the Canberra Times-and the heading is `Powell urges MPs to vote with consciences', saying that they have 50 per cent of the backing in Australia. What a load of rubbish. If they have never told the truth before, it is time that they start telling it now.
—More fool the Canberra Times for reporting it, too.

—Yes, that is a good point. I come to the next point I wish briefly to mention. I commend the Government on one issue in this case, and that is its intention not to needlessly intern Iraqis who are in Australia and who are good residents of Australia. The Government has taken a wise decision in this case. Honourable senators may remember my speaking in this Parliament before on the rounding up in the last war of Italians and Germans who were true Australians and locking them up needlessly. I hope that in 50 years time a senator of Arab descent does not have to stand up and move a motion of reconciliation. However, we hope that, when all this is over and Kuwait is once again free, no time is wasted in addressing the final paragraph of the motion.
—It will be a heap of rubble.

—Senator McLean has spoken a heap of rubbish all day today and has been doing so continually in the last five months in that, for some unknown reason, he has taken a certain dislike to certain banking organisations around Australia. I move on from that point to read the last paragraph of the motion before us:

SPEECH.PARA: Recognises, as those with whom we are acting now in the Gulf have recognised, the need to intensify efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, including a just resolution of the Palestinian issue-
and I honestly believe that Arabs to a certain extent have been treated as subhumans and that it is time to do something in that direction-
and the continuing security of Israel, once the crisis in the Gulf is resolved.
Mr Acting Deputy President, then and only then will we have a chance of lasting peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion before this Parliament. I think its terms are well understood by people in this chamber and by people listening. In brief, and this is not a definitive and complete reading of the motion, it supports the ongoing role for the United Nations in promoting world peace and the self-determination of nations; it affirms support for Australia's response to the request from the United Nations Security Council; it expresses confidence in the Australian forces serving in the United Nations multinational force; it deplores Iraq's widening of the conflict by attacking Israel; and, finally, it:

SPEECH.PARA: Recognises, as those with whom we are acting now in the Gulf have recognised, the need to intensify efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, including a just resolution of the Palestinian issue and the continuing security of Israel, once the crisis in the Gulf is resolved.

That is the motion I stand to speak to tonight. I do so with a heavy heart and a great regret. This is the sentiment of all those supporting this motion. A decision has been made not to pursue sanctions but to exercise the military option-in short, war. I say again that I do so with a heavy heart and considerable regret. But the time has come and I believe the decision that has been made deserves our support.

I do not wish, in the time available to me, to canvass the issues which so many people have very eloquently run through in this place and in the other place. We have heard the detailed arguments about the failure of sanctions. We have heard the argument that sanctions, if persisted with, were not going to be a sufficient restriction against Saddam Hussein. Nor do I wish to canvass extensively the very exhaustive exercise of diplomacy that was carried out by the United Nations and any number of diplomats concluding, I think, with the last effort by the Secretary General of the United Nations, Perez de Cuellar. I do not wish to run through that. I think it has been spelt out in great detail and I believe the arguments put about that are persuasive.

I support the comments that were made in the world television coverage of Secretary General de Cuellar's return from his final down-to-the-wire mission to try to see whether peace could not be achieved or the military option averted. People have commented that the look on his face said it all. The man was tired and exhausted and his depression and despondency were very obvious. I think that conveyed the sentiments of so many of us.

Before I spell out those issues, I would briefly like to make the comment it is horrible to have to resort to the military option, to war, in the name of peace, but with the greatest regret, I believe that it has come to that. Saddam Hussein has embarked upon a dangerous and wicked course. In particular, I refer to his flagrant disregard of civil rights and cruelty perpetrated against the people of Kuwait, as documented by Amnesty International in its report of December 1990. Others have quoted extensively from that document. I simply join in supporting the sentiments of horror and outrage that anyone quoting from that document has evidenced in this place. They are entirely my sentiments too.

I want to make a few comments before talking about some differences between this war and others. I want to put on the record my support for the recalling of Parliament. I am pleased that we have the opportunity to be in Parliament to debate this significant motion. I want to convey to the people of Australia that we in this Parliament appreciate that this is a significant and very grave matter. It is appropriate for Parliament, on behalf of the people of this country, to seriously address the issues at this time.

I think it is also important for the Australian people to know that their Parliament and, indeed, their representatives want to tackle this issue and put the arguments on the record, not only to make a case in this place but also to inform the Australian people of the questions at issue here and the reasons that so many of us in this place have felt justified supporting this motion and affirming the Government's decision.

I think it is also important to say something about the young men and women of Australia who by, I suppose, a very arbitrary piece of history and action find themselves the ones called to serve in the Middle East in this multinational force. Not only did one have to be in the military forces in Australia at that time, not only did one have to be in the Navy but also one had to be serving on one of the ships that were called upon to go.

So, for those men and women who are on active duty carrying out this country's commitment, I think it is very important that this Parliament acknowledges their contribution from the outset and makes it clear that we are proud of them. We congratulate them and acknowledge their courage.

I also think that it is important that this Parliament should be sitting at this time. I can stand and say that we support their families. We must not forget mainly the generosity of their families-as well as the anxiety and concern-and the need to support and care for those families. They must know that they are not forgotten by the people of Australia and certainly not by their parliamentarians.

I say, as many have said in this debate one way or another, that there are differences between this war and the war in Vietnam. I do not wish to canvass the war issue, but I would say that one big difference between this war and the war in Vietnam is the way the forces, the men and women serving Australia, have been acknowledged from the time they have gone and, quite clearly, on the occasion of their return. There will be no wait, when they return, to acknowledge their contribution. That is one of the differences between this war and the Vietnam war.

There were considerable and increasing divisions in Australia during the Vietnam war, as more and more people came to realise that it was an unjust war and it was improper for people to be there. What happened, though, was that much of that antagonism, that enmity, was actually directed at the volunteer and conscripted men and women serving in Vietnam on behalf of Australia. Many of them were not acknowledged as having served in Vietnam or as Vietnam veterans for years after their return. That was not only the case in this country; it was also the case in America. I think it was wrong that the enmity and objection to that war should have been directed at the service people. It should have been sheeted home to the politicians, not to the service men and women.

I have said before that the men and women who are in the Middle East on behalf of Australia at the moment will not have to wait, on their return, for their country to acknowledge their contribution. I do not believe that any of us have any doubt about the courage and the properness of them being there. But I support the recall of Parliament because in this debate we are saying to the people of Australia that ultimately it is this Parliament's responsibility; it is the politicians' responsibility. If people wish to take issue with the decision, if they wish to dispute what Australia is doing, they should not direct that fight at the service men and women who are bound by their obligations under the service force commitment to be there. They should take it up with us. They should bring their fight to the politicians. They should bring to us disputes, their anger, and their unhappiness. We have made that decision and we wear that responsibility. I think that is one of the distinctions between now and Vietnam. It is not that I am cheerfully making this decision. As I have said before, it is done with a heavy heart. But I accept, as a parliamentarian in this place, that I am in part one of the wearers of that responsibility.

As a consequence, I want to reinforce, stress and support those who have said in this place that it is important that everybody respects the views of people in this matter. There is a need to respect those who hold a different view. I object to those who leapt to judgment on their fellow Australians.

Senator Kemp suggested that those of a different view from him were compromising national security. My view is that the value and significance of the debate and the bipartisan commitment of support for the motion is lessened by political point scoring. The position of some people-for example, the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine-is quite clear. It is quite clear that different points of view will not jeopardise national security. I think it behoves us to respect their point of view-they also have a duty to respect mine.

One of the things that we support in this country, too, is the right of people to hold and speak different views. In fact, we would probably say that we would fight to protect that right. I have no objection to people supporting peace in demonstrations around this country, although I must say that I heard one demonstrator in the Senate gallery yesterday lean over and shout, `Kill all politicians'. I think this is simply a reflection only on one individual. It is a measure of her anger and her lack of logic and ought not to be held against all the peace movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Peace demon- strations?

—The irony of it is not lost on us, Senator, but I appreciate that it is not for us to sit in judgment. Those people are doing sufficient for themselves. I do not believe it does us any good to discredit the peace movement when so many of its members, as I understand it, are people of passionate goodwill and commitment. The peace movement would have even more credibility if it was demonstrating outside the Iraqi Embassy in this town. I do not know whether it has done so; it may have. If it has not, that gives me some reserve in support for the movement because quite clearly there is as much a case for demonstrating outside there, if one is committed to peace, as there is for demonstrating in this Parliament. I hope that peace activists respect the fact that parliamentarians in support of this motion are supporters of peace. The issue is not whether or not we are committed to peace. Indeed, I am and I think I speak for most other people who say they are. Our dispute is about the way to achieve it.

SPEECH.PARA: I join Senator Tate-his was an excellent speech and one of the best in this place in a long time-in claiming that it is our responsibility to come to the assistance of the most vulnerable and the weak. The murdered babies in Kuwait that he quoted are only one example of the many human rights violations under Saddam Hussein that must be stopped. As I have said, the arguments about sanctions and diplomacy have been canvassed extensively. The people who have put them did so very persuasively and I will not run over them again.

I turn now to the role of the United Nations in which Australia has had a long history. Dr Evatt was one of the principal players in the foundation of the United Nations. The Labor Government, the Australian Labor Party and, I think, Australian governments of all flavours have continued to support and work through the committees of the United Nations.

With the end of the Cold War hostilities, there has been significant change in the role, position and effectiveness of the United Nations. That is something I cele- brate and support. I would have thought that that has been the view of most people around the world-that, as the Cold War ceased, so the divisive posturing of both sides ceased, enabling the prospect of decent and constructive debate and implementation of resolutions from the United Nations.

As I understand it-I could stand corrected on this-the decision of the United Nations to support in particular resolution 678, to exercise a military option after the deadline of 15 January, was unprecedented in terms of the support it got there. I want that United Nations role only strengthened. I believe that Aus- tralia's credibility in future debates and decisions in the United Nations will be the stronger for our commitment at this time.

What questions might the United Nations address? What might be the new agenda that Australia can initiate or contribute to in the United Nations? Certainly, with the cessation of hostilities and the ceasefire-and only after that ceasefire and cessation of hostilities-the United Nations will have a critical role.

I have spelt out the fifth point in the motion, but I think it is important to read it again. It states that this Parliament recognises, as those with whom we are acting now in the Gulf have recognised, the need to intensify efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, including a just resolution of the Palestinian issue and the continuing security of Israel, once the crisis in the Gulf is resolved. That would have to be very high on the priority list for the United Nations at the end of the hostilities.

No longer can the world ignore the need for a solution to the questions dividing the Middle East. I have had the opportunity to visit the Middle East and have seen at first hand the camps in which many Palestinian people have not only lived over the last 20 years or more but also have been born in and grown up in. They have known no other world. That is the way they understand the world and that is what home means to them-eight or 10 people in a 10-foot by 10-foot square concrete room. That is what the poverty of those camps has been like for more than a generation of Palestinian people.

There is a lack of health services, a lack of education, impossibly insufficient housing, in many cases a dangerous insufficiency of potable or drinkable water, insufficient food supplies, and in many cases sewage running in the streets. The playgrounds of the children of Palestine growing up in those camps are sewage-infested streets and piles of refuse insufficiently and inadequately collected. Disease and threats to health of all sorts are the playground for those children and families.

In the midst of all this children are trying to learn to read, to grow up informed in any kind of way. That quite remarkable achievement, in the face of such adversity, by the Palestinian people that I have met and spoken to in those camps must be acknowledged. One of the things that I could say-without, I hope, any misunderstanding-is that the poverty of the Palestinian camps is clean poverty. But that is simply a measure of the endless commitment by the Palestinian people to maintaining at least that modicum of cleanliness in the face of sewage in the streets and so on.

To me the overwhelming impossibility of the Palestinian camps, the great offence against human rights, is the loss of citizenship. People in the occupied territories are citizens of nowhere. In some ways one would have to ask what greater invasion or denial of human rights there could be.

Any resolution to the Palestinian question, and to other issues dividing the Middle East, must also ensure the security of Israel. It is sometimes overlooked that Israel's position in this is not a unanimous one either. Many Israelis have chosen to go to gaol rather than do their national service by serving the occupied territories. Many Israelis are passionate for peace. I am not saying that they are right and that Israelis that have exercised their military option are wrong. I do not believe it is for me to sit in judgment. But it is important for us to recognise that there are dreadfully deep divisions in those communities between different peoples and within peoples.

It was reported to me that yesterday there was a demonstration by Jewish people in Melbourne. I understand that that demonstration opened with a prayer by the rabbi in Arabic-a prayer praising Allah-which was translated for others there. One of the messages was that it is a perversion at the moment that Islam is at war with Judaism. Many times in history Islamic and Judaic religions have not only lived peaceably but also been in support of each other and we should not regard the current divisions in history as the natural state of things. They are what the state is now. But those people calling for peace yesterday were making it clear that, firstly, they have a passionate desire for peace and, secondly, they do not see that it is necessary for Islam and Judaism-two great religions-to be seen or used as a justification for continuing warring. We know that while these injustices continue in the Middle East there will always be that unrest: there will also be a guarantee of continuing prospects of war and certainly a guarantee that there will be no resolution for peace. So that has to be one of the items high on the agenda of the United Nations.

Today in the Senate I asked a question about the unacceptable military crackdown by the Soviet Union in the Baltic states. I would like to see that military force cease as soon as possible-indeed, I would say immediately. Further, I ask: Is this something that the United Nations could and should address? I want to see a United Nations that can find ways of tackling these hard issues-not only country to country disputes but also disputes within countries, particularly where those disputes involve contraventions of basic human rights. It is no longer acceptable that the world turn a blind eye to tyrannies within country borders of the sorts that we know-for example, Cambodia and Uganda. However, I make it quite clear that those are but two examples.

Increasingly the question of numbers of refugees around the world must deserve our attention, and we should not just think about them or talk about them-we should proceed to some resolution of their invidious circumstances. I would have to say that I would like to see a United Nations where of course the overriding concern of all its actions was human rights. I appreciate that my remarks just now may well mean hours of debate, hours of defining what are countries, what are borders, what are acts of aggression, what sort of level of denial of human rights becomes justifiable for United Nations intervention. I know they are probably rather heroic by way of challenge but I would like to try to look at what the United Nations might address than admit that we cannot do very much. I would have to say, though, that history sometimes could leave you feeling very depressed.

I was asked last week, curiously enough, after the war started, `Are you the mother of sons and does this make a difference to your view?'. Actually I am the mother of sons and no, I would hope it does not make a difference to my view. Possibly it does, but I would certainly want to say that those of us who have sons and those of us who have daughters probably have a special understanding, particularly if those sons and daughters are somewhere between 15 and 45, or maybe 60, but my view is that you do not have to be the mother of sons to have a passionate commitment to peace. You do not have to be the mother of sons to abhor this awful behaviour by Saddam Hussein. I would hope that we do not restrict compassion to only the mothers of sons. Please understand that because I am the mother of sons I do not wish to belittle or diminish my commitment to compassion.

Senator Tate also said in his speech that peace is not simply the absence of war but a situation where justice prevails. I think that is the final issue that I wish to speak to that must have the attention of governments and the United Nations. It is not good enough to say that we will stop the military option, stop the war, and then there will be peace. There will probably only be quiet, and then only for a time. What we have to address is what is meant by justice, what is the balance of opportunity for education, for literacy, for health services, for clean water and adequate food, for jobs and income security for people which constitutes the sort of fair justice we are arguing for. It is the absence of those circumstances, it is the absence of that justice that leads to tyranny, that allows the emergence of tyrannical leaders, and in particular may lead to one country claiming to demand the services and the provision of goods in another country that might even justify them in their territorial ambitions due to the clear needs of some of their people. Until we address those questions of justice, not only in our country but around the world, through the United Nations, I think the prospects of war may hang over us forever. They are the sorts of questions we have to tackle. That is the sort of commitment, I believe, in talking to this motion, I would like to be affirming.

I have said in this place on a number of occasions in different speeches that those appalling figures from the United Nations Children's Fund-something like 14 million children die each year from easily preventable causes around the world, and over 500,000 women die in childbirth and related diseases-indicate the sorts of perpetual injustices that I think ought to be the passionate question for all of us involved in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why spend so much money on armaments?

—It is not enough to talk about just finishing the military option; it is about our commitment to peace and what sort of justice is necessary to maintain that peace. I did not hear the honourable senator's interjection.
—Just commenting on the amount of money spent on armaments.

—I appreciate exactly what the honourable senator is saying about armaments. I have to say that one of the things I have on her is a few more years in this place, and a few more opportunities to have said it. I guess there is not one person in this chamber who would not prefer to spend his dollars on food, education or health services than on armaments. Certainly I have said it often, and I mean it, but I must say I do not find myself in the position where I can direct, for example, the military defence expenditure of most countries. I would prefer by a mile that we did not have those weapons of war. In fact, I would prefer that if anybody wanted to have a war, we should draw a patch on the ground and let the generals or heads of state go out and do it and stop taking the people with them. That is not the nature of war. I have to be a realist. In the end we have to confront the issue of whether or not Saddam Hussein's actions should be allowed to continue or whether they have to be stopped. The price we pay for stopping them is appalling. I understand that and everybody else in this place understands that, but that is the choice we make on balance at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: I do believe that we must have that commitment to a United Nations world justice-and that does include reduction in arms, and passionately would I vote for that at any time. Can you have a passionate vote? I would make a passionate speech before I voted, but certainly for a reduction in arms. I have been a long-time member of a number of organisations which have opposed nuclear arms and the threat of nuclear war. I do not believe I need to justify my case with my own personal history, but certainly I do not mind saying that I am a person who has campaigned against nuclear arms and would like to see not only their reduction but their total abolition. I would like to see no arms at all, but I guess that is an unrealistic ambition in my lifetime. I would certainly like to see that. I would like to see that we had international trade which meant countries did not have to fight and kick and scream for trading justice, although the last round of the general agreement on tariffs and trade talks means we will have to continue to think about that too. I would like to see a world free of dirty air and pollution. As somebody said in our debate in Caucus yesterday, it is important to recognise that boundaries on the ground do not stop missiles. They are the sorts of issues that we have to confront.

In this decision I think Australia actually does take its place in that world decision to oppose this act of aggression. I think it does draw credit to itself for its contribution. I believe Australia will have a continuing role in ongoing debates in the United Nations, I hope in regard to all the sorts of things I listed. I support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the five-part motion moved by Senator Button supporting Australia's role in the United Nations backed force in the Gulf, the motion which has been supported by the Liberal and National parties and, clearly, the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this debate, which has now gone on for some 13 1/2 hours, is unique. It is unique to think that so many members and senators can rise to discuss the one motion with so many differing perspectives on the same subject matter. We have had perspectives from the Liberal Party from a range of senators and members with varying backgrounds, and from Labor Party members and senators. I am sure that when Senator Reynolds rises to her feet we will hear another perspective. We have heard varying perspectives from the Australian Democrats and from Senator Vallentine. I think that in this debate, be it from a pacifist point of view or from the point of view of former pacifists, from peace activists and from all the other perspectives, as my colleague Senator Crowley said, we find all valid points of view.

This is not the sort of debate where we should enter into political point scoring. It is a debate where this chamber, and those members in the other place, would ideally seek as much unanimity as possible to show the greatest support for this motion. That is not to detract from the stance that has been taken by the Democrats or by Senator Vallentine or by anyone else who chooses to oppose this motion or who chooses to amend it. The point I am making is that it is a unique debate, and it is a debate to which I have listened with great interest.

However, there have been some sections of the debate which have detracted from it. I am sure that all of us would agree that the behaviour of some of the people in the gallery in the last couple of days has not helped the debate. The behaviour of Senator Vallentine in going across to the other place yesterday and in disrupting that place, using her privileges as an honourable senator to disrupt the proceedings of the House of Representatives--

TALK.START.PARA: —She is a disgrace to this Parliament.

—It was certainly, as Senator Knowles said, a disgrace to this Parliament, and brings no merit to Senator Vallentine who, I am sure, feels deeply in her heart about this issue, as I am sure we all do. But there are ways to represent those views without abusing the forums of this Parliament, as have many of her supporters. I think it is fair to say, having watched Senator Vallentine parade around this place in the last couple of days, that she has been personally involved in conspiring to disrupt this place by organising various protests in the galleries and outside, as she has done in the Western Australian Parliament previously where I was present one day when she was kicked out for disrupting that place.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that it is necessary for any Australian citizen, be they a member of parliament or a citizen, to resort to the sorts of tactics we have seen here in the last couple of days to express what are very valid views. I think it does no good for the cause of the passionate people in the peace movement. There are plenty of opportunities in Australia these days to have one's views aired and made public, and to express those views without disrupting this place. This is, I guess, the greatest of all debating chambers and public forums where the views of the elected representatives of the people of Australia can be expressed. That is why we are here for this two-day sitting.

I think it is also a great shame that some of the Democrat senators, particularly Senator McLean, and Senator Vallentine, have described some of the contributions made by the Government party and the coalition Opposition parties as `set piece speeches', to quote Senator Vallentine. They describe some members of the coalition and the Government as not being able to vote with their consciences, as their votes have been organised. It was Senator McLean who, only half an hour ago, accused my colleague from Western Australia, Senator Panizza, of saying that our Party would not allow him to vote with his conscience.

All of those people on this side of the Senate know that we can vote with our conscience whenever we want to. It quite often happens. The Democrats will remember that it was not so long ago that a number of senators crossed the floor to vote in support of a Democrat amendment on a recent piece of legislation. I do not think that is a fair insult to be levelled--
Senator Bell interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean did say it. It is not a fair insult to be levelled, particularly at this side of the House. Again, I guess that these are times when passions show through, and it is not unusual for a few gratuitous insults to be thrown around the chamber, but it is not helpful and I will certainly try to restrain myself during the debate this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: A point which has been made time and time again-I guess, coming on to the speakers list after 25 or 30 other senators, with another 20 to go, most of the points have been made-which has angered me while I have been sitting quietly in my seat, is that so many of the Democrat senators and Senator Vallentine tend to have this self-righteous approach, this so-called mortgage or monopoly on the virtue of trying to stop war and being in favour of peace.

I really would ask the Democrats and Senator Vallentine to try to search their consciences-to search their morals-to try to understand where some of their Senate colleagues are really coming from. One thing that has permeated the entire debate, and the entire period of time leading up to the start of hostilities in the Gulf, is that for all of us who represent people in this place it has been a time of some sombreness and some soberness.

I do feel for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke); for Senator Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade; for Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Defence; and for the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). They are the people at the forefront of these hard decisions. They feel these decisions personally. One can see the toll it takes on them physically, mentally and personally.

I think there is a degree of what I call sombreness and soberness which overcomes us all because we are here today and were here yesterday putting our names on the line, and supporting or opposing this course of action taken by the Government. The insult towards Labor senators and members, and coalition senators and members, that we are warmongers and not really in favour of peace-either by implication or by direct assertion-is not fair and certainly should not to be continued.
The mood of this sombreness and soberness, and the constructive broad ranging nature of this debate has, in part, been hurt by Senator Vallentine and her peace movement supporters.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Democrats.
—I have mentioned the Democrats, but I am trying to be as reasonable as I can.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem that we have here is that the people who advocate negotiation, sanctions and the use of discussion to solve this crisis in the Middle East; the very people who suggest these tools for solving the problem-for stopping the war and the use of military force-come in here and disrupt this place. They use force, they use tactics, they use foul language, they use-as we saw up in the gallery here this afternoon-violence against the officers of this Parliament to get their message across.

Senator Vallentine has the right and the opportunity to take part in this debate, and I would have thought that this is the sort of discussion, negotiation and intellectual approach to problem solving that she advocates, but Senator Vallentine has been in this chamber for less than two hours out of something like 14 hours of debate at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought she cared about the subject.

—That is right. She might be caring somewhere else. She might be out consorting and conspiring with some of her peacenik colleagues. The fact of the matter is that Senator Vallentine does not care to come into this chamber and listen to this most important debate-the very issue for which she was elected to this chamber in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: Her peace movement colleagues who have disrupted proceedings in these galleries, choose to come in when the television cameras are on at Question Time, or when Ministers are speaking, but they are not prepared to listen. They are happy to disrupt things, cause a stir and use violence and foul language to make their point to get on television in prime time, but they are not prepared to do what they suggest the world leaders should do, which is listen and talk and negotiate and try to understand some of the arguments.

I suggest that in their interests, and in the interests of all Australians, all of us should try to reflect upon the position that this Government has taken, supported by the Opposition, opposed by the Democrats, in a sober and intellectual frame of mind. It is fair to say that the most warlike people in this country at the moment are the very people who have surrounded this building and filled these galleries in the last couple of days.

One of the issues I want to raise in the short time remaining for me is the effect of this war on young Australians. By virtue of my birth date I am a young Australian, and I have not really witnessed a war of this sort. I was still only in primary school when Vietnam was coming to a close. I know that Senator McMullan and many other senators on the other side, and even on this side, have showed their credentials as peace activists in their younger days-when they had more hair and were wearing bandannas and tie dyed t-shirts. They must have felt twinges of anxiety when they saw these people come into the galleries in the last couple of days.

I think back to my own past. At that stage I was at Ironside State School in Brisbane. The most I did as a peace activist was to draw a massive `Ban the bomb' sign on what was, and probably still is, a gravel oval there. I think I was suspended from Ironside State School for the afternoon for doing that. I also remember writing, to my mother's and father's horror, `Make love not war' on the side of my `port'-I think we called them in Queensland-long before I knew what making love was all about. I did not realise why my mother was so horrified.

My recollections of war, as for so many of my generation, the younger generation, have been formed through movies such as Apocalypse Now, Vietnam, Born on the Fourth of July and The Deer Hunter, which is very hard to get in video shops. My generation and other young Australians generally are no different from everyone else in this country, but I think the way that we approach war, the way that young Australians form views about war-and I refer to many generations of young Australians-will be formed during these trying and very sad days for Australia. They will be looking at the images coming across on the cable network virtually every minute and forming their views of war. They will be looking at the protesters around this Parliament at the moment and forming their views from their behaviour. Many of the people opposed to the Australian involvement in the war will come to the view that war and killing is bad and that peace is good. These are very similar views to the concept of motherhood and apple pie because they are easy concepts to grasp.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of them are achievable, too.

—Certainly, we hope they are achievable. Many of us here today are grappling with the problem of whether war is good or peace is good. Clearly, peace is better than war, and I guess it is a bit of a contradiction to have to make war to make peace and very hard for younger people to understand and for any of us to come to grips with.

SPEECH.PARA: One good thing to come out of this debate is that so many young Australians will be concerning themselves with these very hefty issues of war and peace. I think it is good because for many years I have been asking for young Australians to be far more interested in the way we are governed-not only on issues such as war and peace or global environmental problems but also as to how we are governed generally. Many of us around this place are concerned at the moment about the level of involvement in politics by the population. Many articles have been written about the level of political party membership in Australia having fallen to disgracefully low levels. I guess this very hefty, important debate today, in so far as it involves young Australians in thinking about the global issues, can do some good in the long run.

I urge those young Australians not simply to take on the slogans of the peace movement nor the slogans of President Bush or the slogans taken on by our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or our Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). I say to young Australians: listen to the rhetoric, but question it. Do not believe the rhetoric of either Senator Vallentine or Senator Robert Ray. Challenge their thoughts, ideas and prejudices, as Senator Tate has done, I think more than most senators have done, in what I thought was a very moving speech yesterday. Senator Tate in putting his argument tried to come to grips with why, in some circumstances, a nation or a person has to use lethal force to try to stop a foe. He said:

. . . I have come to the conclusion that, whereas I may resist, I hope, the urge to kill an assailant or an aggressor who is attacking me personally, when I hear the plea of the innocent, vulnerable and the especially weak I realise that I must stand between that person and the aggressor. But, further, with the greatest sadness if one has to kill the assailant or the aggressor, having exhausted every type of negotiation and diplomacy then I believe that is where we must stand as a nation in concert with other nations around the world.

That is a tremendous analogy which young Australians should pay great heed to. It cuts across a lot of the rhetoric of both the hawks and the doves in this debate. As I said earlier in this address tonight, I invite the people in the galleries, the people in the peace movement generally, and all young Australians, to not just pay heed to the one-minute grabs on the radio and television stations but to listen to all of the arguments put in this debate tonight.

One of the other influences on young people in Australia and worldwide is, of course, the culture of the rock and roll era, which has taken over since the 1960s. Particularly, my rock idols of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, Neil Young and Bob Dylan, are both still going strong today. But now I guess we have far more rock bands. We have people such as Midnight Oil and so forth in Australia who raise the consciousness of younger generations about political problems.

I refer to some of the thoughts of Neil Young, a great rock-folk musician, who in the 1960s wrote a song entitled `Ohio', which described and painted in lyrical terms a very devastating and chilling picture of the Kent State peace rally killings. Neil Young affects the views of many young people right across the globe. It is fair to say that in the 1960s and 1970s he was a legend. I am sure that Senator McMullan would have many of Neil's records in his collection. After going to a Neil Young concert in 1985-I went again last year because I am a great fan of Mr Young's-I was surprised that, in an interview he did with Mr Richard Guilliatt from the Melbourne Age and reported in the West Australian on 8 March 1984, Neil Young came through with some very strident views in favour of a free enterprise society and what we would call in cliches `the American way' and, indeed, against the ideals of the peace movement and generally in favour of the concepts of peace through security or nuclear deterrence. I quote from the article:
Freedom-the catch-cry of the 1960s ethos-is a word he--
that is, Neil Young-
uses now to explain why he won't be involved in the peace movement.
I quote Neil Young:
I just feel that the free system had made it possible to do what I am doing . . . that's how I view it today with all of the feeling about nuclear war and power through idealistic demonstrations.
Idealistically I wish there were no weapons in the world (but) I think there is another side, and another way of thinking, and it's aggressive, as it is in Afghanistan.
I think you have to watch the other guy, because he's playing hard ball.

That is really what Senator Schacht said earlier today: idealistically we would all like peace and would like there to be no weapons, but there are other guys out there, as Neil Young calls them, and they are playing hard ball. We have to decide sooner or later how we will go out onto that ball park. Will we lay down arms or will we play hard ball back? Neil Young sums up by saying:
I mean I think war is wrong and I think killing is wrong, but I think survival of a free society is right.

That is what we are talking about here tonight. I was going to go on to discuss some of the arguments of the peace movement. Because time is short and many other senators want to make contributions tonight, I will sum up simply by saying that the arguments put, the slogans and some of the dishonest claims made by the peace movement, which I have asked Australians, and young Australians in particular, to challenge-the slogan of `blood for oil'; the comparisons with Panama, Grenada and East Timor; the need for further negotiations; and the use of sanctions-have all been debunked.

One claim which needs to be refuted has not been refuted adequately. The comparisons with Panama, Grenada and East Timor have been refuted a number of times. That has not stopped our Democrat colleagues from regurgitating them, but that is their right, which I admit. A number of honourable senators have quoted the figures provided by the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) on the effects of the sanctions. It has not been stated in the debate so far, but Stephen Solarz, a Democrat from New York and a House of Representatives member, in a 12 January debate in the United States Congress, when talking about Judge Webster, the head of the CIA, said:

Judge Webster, the head of the CIA, does not believe the sanctions will be sufficient to get Iraq out of Kuwait. Nor do the British, nor the French, nor the Egyptians, nor the Saudis. Not one of our coalition partners believes that sanctions will be sufficient to get Iraq out of Kuwait.

I think it is clear that one could quote all the CIA figures on the effect of the sanctions, but the head of the CIA himself knows that no matter what the effects are, they will not be effective. I quote Representative Stephen Solarz further:

The reason they do not believe sanctions will be sufficient is because they know that Saddam Hussein does not give a whit for the welfare of his own people. All he cares about is the maximization of his own power. However great the economic impact of the sanctions may be, they know, as we know, that Saddam Hussein does not have to run for reelection in 1992. He does not have to worry about a contentious Congress or a critical press. He will hunker down. He will wait. And while he waits, there is a very real possibility that this inherently fractious and fragile coalition will begin to unravel, and the sanctions will erode, and he will prevail.

In conclusion, I am pleased to support this motion. I am pleased with the broad bipartisan support that this motion has drawn. I think we must all hope and pray for the safety of our armed service men and women in the Gulf and the medical team on the USS Comfort. Our thoughts and prayers are with them. I respect the views put forward by the honourable senators opposing and seeking to amend this resolution but I call upon them to be very careful in the tactics they use when showing their opposition. Some of the tactics, particularly the Democrat tactic of moving the motion about conscription, could be construed as political point scoring at a time when it is not necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Reynolds, I note that Senator Campbell in his remarks said that at least 25 senators have preceded him in this debate. In fact he was the thirty-ninth senator to speak in this debate and there are 20 speakers still listed in the time that remains for this evening and tomorrow morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I get the distinct impression, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you are trying to tell me something.
—No, I am not.

—In considering the motion before the Parliament tonight, I would like to make my position absolutely clear. Firstly, I wholeheartedly endorse support for the United Nations (UN) in promoting world peace and the self-determination of nations. I support the Australian forces already serving in the Gulf.

SPEECH.PARA: I deplore Iraq's widening of the conflict by its unprovoked attack on Israel and its gross breaches of international obligations in the treatment of prisoners of war. I certainly believe adamantly in the need to intensify efforts to bring peace and stability to the Middle East, including a just resolution of the Palestinian issue and the continuing security of Israel. However, I am opposed to a war as a means of resolving international conflict.

This is not a new position for me. Senator Campbell indicated that he was still at school when the Vietnam conflict erupted. In those days I was a very apolitical young woman, I am sorry to say, and that, I believe, was responsible for my politicisation. All I can say in regard to Senator Campbell's comments about young people is that for many years in this place we have been concerned about the apathy of young people. Young people do not have any faith in the system. They not believe in getting involved in politics and they do not trust the political process.

If young people are prepared to make a commitment to the fight for peace-and there I have used a word I should not have in regard to peace, I suppose-if they are prepared to work for peace and join political parties to ensure that we find other methods, I believe that something will have come out of the debate in the Australian community at the moment.

Since August, I have had strong reservations about Australia sending ships to the Gulf. But like many people, I rationalised this decision because I hoped that the United Nations' sanctions, supported around the world, would bring about a negotiated settlement and withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait.

In December, with eight senior Queensland Australian Labor Party (ALP) members, including the President, Ian McLean, I made a public call for mediation in the Gulf crisis to address the following issues: withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait; demilitarisation of the Middle East region and replacement of a UN peacekeeping force; negotiated rights of passage for Iraq; democratisation of Kuwait; world oil pricing which does not favour wealthy nations' monopoly of this resource; and a peace conference to require negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians.

I am now opposed to Australia changing its role from enforcement of sanctions to military support for attack. I believe that sanctions could ultimately have brought about a negotiated settlement of this crisis. I accept the UN resolution which allowed `necessary force'. We could debate what we mean by `necessary force'. It is this aspect of the debate where differences of opinion arise.

Everyone in this Parliament wants peace but we disagree on the means to ensure it. I do not believe that a new international order can be enforced militarily. If we are to have a new international world order, we have to be able to find a way to resolve conflict. What a horrendous precedent this establishes if every time there is a dispute between nations we automatically assume that the only way to resolve it is through force and through bombing a nation into submission.

I am firmly convinced that sanctions should have been pursued despite the absolute intransigence of Saddam Hussein. There is evidence that sanctions had started to impact severely on Iraq's economy and its opportunity to continue to build its horrific array of weaponry.

I know that a number of people from both sides have quoted material in this debate but I would like to take the time of the Senate to quote from three sources, one Australian, one American and one British. The head of the Peace Research Centre, Andrew Mack, said in an article in the Canberra Times of 1 November 1990:

The war camp is almost certainly wrong about sanctions too. While sanctions regimes have failed more often than not in the past, UN-mandated sanctions against Iraq are the exception which will prove the rule.
Iraq is unique among states which have had sanctions applied to them. Ninety-five percent of Iraqi export revenues come from a single commodity.

Sanctions are having their most important effect on the technical infrastructure of Iraq-on power stations, hydroelectric stations, communications . . . , transportation . . . and factories. All these systems are dependent on spare parts which can no longer be imported. Sanctions also mean that the military capability of Iraq is slowly deteriorating as spare parts run out.

TALK.START.PARA: —It never worked in South Africa, though.

—We gave South Africa much longer, as I think Senator Macdonald will agree. My second quote is from Paul Nitze, a special adviser on arms to the Reagan Administration, who put his support for sanctions in a recent article called `War, Whether Its Needed or Not?' in the Washington Post. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: First, successful sanctions would be most likely to produce a stable world order. Critical to this outcome is that a substantially lower level of violence would be more likely to result in continued public support for an active U.S. international role.

Second, this option would likely be less disruptive to regional stability. But any approach that left much of Iraq's military capability intact would produce a need to retain a peacekeeping force on the front lines, either in Kuwait or Saudi Arabia, and perhaps elsewhere. While internal destabilisation in other countries of the region would remain a concern, this threat would be lower than that produced by all-out war, especially if the peacekeeping force were primarily Arab.''
In the Guardian Weekly, Paul Wilkinson, Director of the Research Institute for the Study of Conflict and Terrorism, wrote:

A combination of sanctions continuing containment and deterrence along with the construction of an effective Arab regional security system will provide an effective long haul method of obtaining the objectives of the international community as expressed in the U.N. Security Council resolutions.
It is true that this strategy requires patience and stamina-
patience and stamina; I am not sure whether patience and stamina are something that many of the world leaders making decisions in relation to this crisis are prepared to offer-
and arguably greater moral courage than the easy policy of reducing Iraq to rubble.

Honourable senators may not agree with his assessment, but the point that I agree with is the strategy requiring patience and stamina. Surely, patience and stamina are worth it when we are looking at human life. He continued:
Much has been made by the proponents of war about maintaining the authority of the United Nations . . .
We all are absolutely committed to the United Nations. I continue:

Is it really going to do anything for the U.N.'s moral authority and leadership if the Security Council is seen to condone war in which possibly hundreds of thousands of innocent Arab civilians are injured and killed?

Paul Wilkinson goes on to say that the UN Security Council must be aware of its moral responsibilities to the international community as a whole and asks how it can possibly approve an immediate resort to a war of mass destruction when we have not given sufficient time for sanctions and diplomatic pressure which might yet achieve the UN's objectives without the tragic loss of life.

Scientists have warned of the horrendous environmental consequences in the Gulf war. Even the most conservative estimates from Basil Butler, one of British Petroleum's four managing directors, said that 300 to 400 wells could burn out of control for up to nine months after the war ended. He does not say how long he thinks the war could last. A worst case scenario would be fires burning for five years, triggering a nuclear winter disaster and causing the failure of the Asian monsoons which would destroy harvests on which over one thousand million people rely.
An engineer with experience in the Gulf oil industry said:
No surgical military strike against Iraq can possibly prevent the Kuwaiti installations being mined, exploded and fires taking place.

A huge increase in acid rain is predicted, having a wide spread effect on Middle East food supplies. In Australia I call, as several of my colleagues have done tonight, for tolerance in what is already a very divisive debate and the longer the war continues the more divisive it will be. As members of a multicultural nation, we all want the Gulf war brought to an end. No single individual has a monopoly on peace. I think it is important that we acknowledge that to each other because different people will be making different stands. Some of us will be involved in the peace movement and others will be condemning the peace movement.

Basically, I do not believe there is anyone in this Parliament or anyone in Australia who does not want to see the end to this horrific war. The important thing is to recognise that our differences are based on how we see that the war can be stopped. Some of us have the view that we can solve conflict militarily. Others of us believe there have to be other ways and it is time for genuine conflict resolution and more creative ways to be found.

We are unified in wanting to see an end to the horrific scenes shown nightly on our television screens, but we disagree on how to halt quickly that military conflict. A group of women opposed to war in the Gulf sent me this message today which I think highlights the need for peaceful resolution. They said:

We believe that only through recognising our common needs and seeking to explore ways of settling our differences can we live in peace. We know that conflict will always exist between individuals and between nations but believe that we can work to minimise this and to find creative solutions which do not involve death and violence. War is neither natural or necessary but an archaic and dangerous way of solving disputes.

Although I do not want to be accused in what is a very serious debate of throwaway lines and sexism, I think it would be irresponsible of me not to point out that it is women and children who are bearing a considerable brunt of this horrendous war. When we know the absolute terror that those women and children must face while men on the other side of the world are making decisions, it is only honest to say that men have to seriously question why we believe that a military option is the only way out.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the women and children who suffered most at the hands of the madman Hussein.
—That is true.
—We have to stop it.

—We certainly do but we do not match it. We do not match one hostility and one horrendous act for another. The other issue that I think has to be addressed-I am not a psychologist, I do not know whether we have any psychologists in parliament-is that we are not using much psychology in our dealings with Hussein. We know he is capable of anything. We know he is capable of turning chemical weapons on his own people. We know how ruthless he is and yet we seem to believe that somehow we can bomb him into submission. It is clear from that that we are not thinking through the best possible way of dealing with such a ruthless man who is capable of anything.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my view that even in the midst of this terrible crisis it is still possible for the United Nations to negotiate a cease-fire conditional on the withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait but enabling independent assessment of border issues by a UN commission to be set up by the Security Council and the establishment of an international conference to address the need for a Palestinian homeland.
I urge the Australian Government to assert its independence and to maintain its international reputation by offering its skills in diplomacy and arbitration to bring about an immediate cease-fire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time is running out for this debate in many respects but there are some things many of us still want to say. I am glad to see that Senator Vallentine has come into the chamber this evening because it enables me to refer to one of the things she said last night when she accused those whose views differed from hers as, I think she said, lacking sincerity, and that their speeches were set piece speeches. I was very disappointed at this. I thought it was ungracious and unworthy and not a very tolerant approach to this debate, which is very important.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is necessary for all of us to recognise that there are people with different views on how to solve the problem of the inexcusable attack on Kuwait and of the inhumane way it was done. No leader, no nation, no politician or parliament commits its sons and daughters to war lightly, but there are times I believe when there is no choice but to pursue the matter in the way it has been done in this instance. No nation can be safe unless it knows that others will come to its aid in these sorts of circumstances. I quote from Cicero who 2,000 years ago said, `The only excuse for war is that we may live in peace unharmed'. I thought it better perhaps in the English than in the Latin version.

Colleagues have pointed out tonight-I shall not go over a lot of the history and many of the things that have been said-that the conflict did not begin on 17 January this year, but on 2 August 1990 when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Where were the demonstrators then? I live not far from the Iraqi Embassy. I did not see them there when there were unspeakable atrocities going on in Kuwait.

Perhaps it was inevitable that this would occur eventually. As early as 1961 Iraq had been threatening to take over Kuwait. But whatever reason Saddam Hussein had for doing it-and many reasons have been advanced-I think that is somewhat irrelevant when one looks at the documented brutality in the report of Amnesty International that has been mentioned here today by several honourable senators; it speaks of the brutality with which his army invaded and took over Kuwait. The same sort of brutality in a different way has been exhibited towards the hostages, the pilots, and prior to this we know what happened to the Kurds in his own country.

Tonight, as again last night, the environmental damage was referred to from oil fires being set, the oil wells of Kuwait being mentioned. My question then is: Who would set them alight?
