I think we all know who would set them alight if it suited his purpose. It was an unprovoked and brutal act of aggression on a sovereign nation and we should pledge ourselves not to let the strong do this to the weak. We should be a participant in the force which is seeking to free Kuwait.

Senator Newman quoted from the then Field Marshal William Slim who said, `Only those deserve freedom who are prepared to defend it'. I think that also should apply to us. There has been universal condemnation. Something has been attempted to be made of the fact that 28 nations are taking part in the allied forces. I think that is an enormous number. There are many other nations which would like to be taking part which do not have the resources to be there but support what the United Nations is doing and the 12 resolutions that have been passed. I am enormously impressed that there are 28 nations working together in this force. I do not see it as something to say that there are only 28 nations, as some would seek to do.

They also seek to say that the sanctions were working and seek to give examples that they are or were. In some instances sanctions may have been cutting back in places but not in ways that were significantly bringing Iraq to see that it had to withdraw from Kuwait. There was no way of enforcing sanctions that were going to hurt Iraq so that it would bring it to this position, and that was very clear. The dictator of Kuwait used the sanctions to strengthen his position there.

The Australian Democrats in their amendment say that they want the naval presence withdrawn. There would be even less opportunity to support sanctions if that were to be the case. The fact is that the sanctions were not working. While I concede that they may have been hurting some parts of the Iraqi economy, there was no sign of them working in a way which was going to bring such discomfort as to cause Iraq to withdraw.

The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in his speech, and others, have outlined the important issues from Australia's point of view. I shall not take the time of the Senate to repeat that here tonight, but there are a couple of areas that I wish to refer to. One of them is the coverage of this war by the media. There is no doubt that it is different from ever before. When we look at the way that technology and satellites are able to bring it to us, we realise that we have not seen anything like it. It is the first time any war has been covered so intensely, so immediately, so intimately with the live coverage that we have had.

No-one would deny that it is essential in any democracy that there be free access to all the relevant information and we be as accurately informed as possible. For the most part, I believe the media has accepted its role of reporting responsibly on what has been going on. There have been some cases where the reporting has strayed from the simple provision of information to becoming something almost like a sporting commentary. I felt quite sickened at some of the things I have seen and heard on television; I have not appreciated the way in which it has been presented. Perhaps I am alone in that, but I feel I should express my views about it.

The Australian reported yesterday, 21 January, `The Gulf war has become a blur of briefings and repeated television footage spinning further away from any perspective with each passing day'. There was the same day a very graphic cartoon in the Canberra Times which likened the presentation to that of a sporting event. One of the Sunday papers commented that the report on the Gulf war was interrupted by a race broadcast at the conclusion of which the television station commented, `And now, back to the war'. Perhaps it was not intended quite that way but it was said in that way. It has helped to create an unreal environment of something very horrible which is going on.

From the outset we have seen the first shots of the war, live eyewitness accounts, updates, unconfirmed reports-too many of them-human interest stories, and replay after replay. There is the technology to do this. Many people though, I think, have found some of it distasteful, the likening of it to a sporting event. We seem to be filled with commentators providing the innermost thoughts and workings as though every player were there on a cricket field and the participants were presumed to be doing this and doing that, with the expert commentaries, the guesses, and the speculations.

I emphasise that proper and independent information should be available to all the democracies participating in the action, but I do protest at this grand final approach. The Canberra Times editorial this morning asks, `Is it not better to verge on voyeurism than on ignorance?' I do not believe that it is a black and white choice between accuracy and immediacy, between sensitivity or news at all costs, between voyeurism or ignorance. I suggest that the modern media has an increased duty precisely because of the technology available to them to report responsibly and with accuracy. The difficulty, as the same editorial in the Canberra Times points out, is that the Gulf war so far has been largely electronic, somewhat remote, and to an extent bodyless even though so immediate. `Bodyless' was the word the Canberra Times used, and we all know that war is not bodyless; it is a bit like a video game.

I am not suggesting control of the press or anything like that. I am not suggesting censorship. Freedom is one of the things that this war is being fought over. My concern is that we do not lose sight of or be insensitive to the real and crushing human suffering, the fear and the anguish, the injury and the loss that is involved in the war and in the way it is presented to us.

I should like also to comment that I have been very disappointed indeed with our own Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) coverage. It seems to me to have been very insensitive. I cite as an example the story which I think the ABC ran three times, that one of the Australian ships had crashed, which was not the case. Should the ABC not have checked with the Navy to see whether that was correct before it ran such a story? The ABC seems to me to have presented a very pro-Hussein coverage of this event, giving him very good coverage and exposure in a way that I do not believe was good reporting. War is a tragedy and should be presented in that way.

It seems to have been a remote control war with the horrors of it kept somewhat at a distance-a war where bombs are fired by computers and missiles are fired from afar, but every time a Scud or a Tomahawk missile falls to earth it may destroy one, a hundred or many more people. In the broader scheme of things it does not matter whether the people who are killed or maimed are Iraqi women and children, elite soldiers, US troops or Israeli children. No matter how one examines it, war is a tragedy of unmeasurable proportions, a triumph of force over reason. But we have then to think back to what we are dealing with, to this man who inhumanely took over Kuwait, having done some of the other things that we know he is capable of doing. We must also not forget our serving personnel or their families in this time of tragedy.

One of the few positive things that have come out of the situation is the bipartisanship that has marked the Australian response to the Gulf crisis. Not only has it enabled Australia to act decisively and confidently within the international community but also, and even more importantly, this national unity has sent a clear and vital message to our serving men and women and their families that they have the support and prayers of their nation with them.

There have been demonstrations by, I think, a small minority who are against the war no matter what. I find it strange that they seem to think that they have a lien on a desire for peace. I too have a very strong desire for peace. I regard their actions as giving succour to a man who is a murderer; a man who would crush Kuwait at any cost. As I said earlier, why were they not demonstrating against him from 2 August to 17 January? Why were not they outside the Iraqi Embassy in the same numbers that they are now prepared to go out into the streets and condemn the United States, who are part of the United Nations network in this activity?

Why were they not outside the embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) on 14 January when I was there with people from Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia protesting the crushing at that time of Lithuania and since, of course, of Latvia? I knew the people who were there. They were Lithuanians, Latvians, Estonians and their friends that I have seen previously outside the same embassy of the USSR. The other protesters were not there, and I ask them why they were not there. Why are they not prepared to demonstrate against those who killed and shot at the Kuwaitis? Do they not appreciate how lucky they are to live in a free country where they can express their opinion without fear of being silenced or shot at and killed, as their counterparts in Kuwait were?

The Australian nation does not want this war. I think that is obvious. Similarly, there is no doubt that Australians are anxious and worried about the war. However, there is no doubt that by far the majority of Australians recognise our responsibility as part of the international community; that they support the men and women who are fighting for us and representing us and the allied forces; and that they recognise the role of the families of those who remain at home while the men of their family are away. We think, of course, about the innocent victims of this war. But a man like Saddam Hussein cannot be allowed to crush Kuwait and behave as he has. No small country is safe if he is allowed to get away with this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a debate that I really do not want to take part in; that I did not want to see happen; that I wished and hoped would not happen. I had hoped that this great nation of Australia would never enter into an international armed conflict. But unfortunately we are there in the Gulf, and we are here in the two chambers of the Australian Parliament debating it.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague Senator Collins has just said to me that there have been some very fine speeches made on all sides of the Parliament on this crucially important issue. They are speeches which will be quoted and requoted over many years, probably for generations to come. Hopefully this war will not last too long but, if this conflict that we as a nation are currently involved in continues or even escalates, we could be faced with a Third World war in this the twentieth century. It is something that we must endeavour to do everything possible to avoid.

It has been said many times in the debate in both chambers that there are no winners in war but many losers. The losers are children, women and, of course, men. It has also been said, and I say this as an aside, that wars are run by men. Well, it was only in the last decade on the other side of the world that a certain female leader found that she could do it equally as badly as any man.

This is not an easy debate for anybody to take part in and I do not believe that any member of either House of this Parliament really wanted to take part in it. It is certainly not an easy debate for a member of the peace movement to take part in. I am and will continue to be a member of the peace movement of Australia. The peace movement of Australia is not a homogeneous organisation made up of single entities with one common ideal. There are disparate groups in that movement, as I well know because of my involvement, because of my assistance to the movement in my current occupation and because of my previous assistance and my association with members of the movement.

There are, as I said, very large and widespread interest groups represented in the peace movement. In all of the peace demonstrations that I have taken part in in this country since I arrived 21 years ago, a very high level of anti-United States feeling has been projected. That is justifiably so, because the United States of America has been no saint in international fora. It has been an aggressor. It has gone in and taken over smaller nations, and it has sought to justify its actions in the past. I am not certain that that is the case in the current conflict that we are involved in, but unfortunately-and I admit that I have not taken part in any of the current demonstrations-it would appear from the media coverage of the various demonstrations right around Australia that there are only two nations involved: Australia and the United States. The Australian Government is getting bagged and the United States Government is getting bagged, when there are 28 nations taking part in the allied forces. But the aspect that grieves me the most is the distinct absence of condemnation of Iraq.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true; Iraq has been denounced.
—And I do not think only about Saddam Hussein. I include with him his generals and his other military forces, because they are equally culpable.
—Iraq has been condemned.
—Why don't you shut up. You've had your go. You shut your face now or you'll cop the biggest serve of your bloody life.

—Order! Senator McKiernan, take a seat please. I just remind all honourable senators that interjecting, first of all, is completely disorderly. I have warned Senator Vallentine before. Secondly, I ask all speakers to direct their remarks through the Chair. That established precedent allows the debate to continue in a way that people can be heard without interruption. So far, on the whole, that has been the case in this Senate all today. Senator McKiernan, please continue.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I apologise and I withdraw the words, even though it has not been asked of me. Perhaps my language was a little bit strong. I withdraw that. I was making the statement that the lack of condemnation of Iraq has been very absent from the banners and slogans that I have witnessed. Maybe that is a fault of the media, and I make no accusations about that. But maybe it is also very well organised.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the peace movement is a very disparate movement. It includes all sorts of people. And they are not all pacifists, as indeed we have witnessed in this very chamber in the last two days. We witnessed it in respect of two interjections yesterday. The first was, `We should kill members of the Labor Party.' The second interjection was, `Kill the members of the Government'.

We witnessed today an individual kicking the attendants. I think that the attendants have worked in this place under very difficult circumstances in the past couple of days and they ought to be commended. I take my hat off to them for the restraint that they have exercised under provocation.

I am against war. I do not want this war to continue. I want it stopped tomorrow. I particularly want it stopped before a ground assault starts. When a ground assault really gets going, that is when we are going to see the carnage-carnage not only of the troops that will be involved but also of all of the innocent civilians in the surrounding and immediate districts. It will run into thousands as all the military experts, usually with American accents, have told us over the past months. I do not want that to happen and I would like to see it stopped.

But I am not willing to fold my arms, stand back and let Saddam Hussein and his forces exercise the brutality, the killing, the maiming and the raping of the people of Kuwait-innocent individuals who have been forcibly occupied and taken over. I think as Australians we cannot afford to allow that to continue, so we have to take some stand.

It has been said on many occasions that perhaps we should have given sanctions more time to work. I really do wish that we had the liberty to do that. But we witnessed and knew when we were debating this issue in December of last year that, really, the sanctions were not working and it required something else. At that point in time I was very hopeful that the threat of international action would avert the threat of war. Unfortunately, it did not.

In that period of 5 1/2 months since that naked, innocent nation was forcibly taken over by its neighbour, that dictator has entrenched himself. He has not suffered from the sanctions, although maybe the people of Iraq have. He fortified Kuwait and he has taken steps to make certain that it is the nineteenth province of Iraq. The longer we continued with the sanctions, the stronger it seemed, militarily, Saddam and his Government became. Of course, the stronger he became, the harder it was going to be to remove him.

I honestly do not know the answers. I have been searching, not only as an individual, a human being, but also as a member of parliament, for the answers to this situation that we are in at the moment. And I have got no way out. The war has not gone away because we wished it to go away. Indeed, we all wished it to go away. Large sections of the population prayed for it to go away and it has not gone away.

What do we do? Do we fold our arms and let the aggression continue? There are times when we can do that no more. We have to stop it. We have to take action to ensure it stops, because if we do not, what nation will be next? Remember that the next time around Iraq, which will then incorporate Kuwait, will be that much stronger because of what it has taken over in terms of oil. The next threat on the horizon was said to be Saudi Arabia-maybe it was; maybe it was not.

Mr Acting Deputy President and members of the Senate, as a member of the peace movement, I am not prepared to take that risk. I am not prepared to have to live with my conscience 20 years down the track or have my children live with the conscience like others had to do when they did not stop Hitler in time. We had to act.

I do not want the responsibility, as a member of parliament, of bringing this nation into war. I do not want that responsibility as a parent of children, and the parent of one particular child who is now 22 years old and who would be of the conscription age if we had conscription. I honestly cannot say anything too kindly about the Democrats and the scare tactics they have put in the minds of young people in Australia over this particular issue.
Senator McLean interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I say that, Senator McLean, as a father of not only one son but another son who is 16 and, indeed, a daughter.
—I've got conscriptable children too.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, it is an emotional debate. It is a very serious debate and it is not surprising that people do get upset. It is unfortunate, though, in the circumstances like this that for our own cheap point scoring reasons we would stretch the truth to chase a few bloody votes. I do not care if I never get a vote because of the stand--
—Order! Senator McKiernan, I think you had better withdraw that word.
—I am sorry. What did I say?
—The use of the word `bloody' is unparliamentary.

—I withdraw it. I am sorry. I did not intend to say it and I withdraw it immediately. I do not care if I never get another vote on this. I wish that I did not have to stand here and take the actions that I have had to take not only in this place but within my Party and within my faction. That is another matter which, unfortunately, causes me great distress because, as people would know, there are some different points of view on this issue. That is not something that I condemn. I welcome the different points of view. Those different points of view have strengthened the great Australian Labor Party over the close on 100 years of its existence. We have spanned the globe in terms of our points of view. It is something that I welcome.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not welcome the fact that some of my colleagues, some of my friends, may not be voting with me in support of a Government motion that is before both Houses. However, I respect their right to do it and I respect the right that they have in this very important and very serious debate to exercise their views. I would make a plea for people within the Party not only to respect the views of those individuals whom I have just mentioned but not named, but also all of the views of people within the Party and from all sides of the Parliament.

The television coverage of this war has been mentioned. I cannot say too much about that. After watching the television earlier last Thursday in a state of some shock, I was virtually glued to the television set for the rest of the day. Such was my disgust that I have watched very little television since then. The disgust sank in only after a period. Since then I have tuned into radio. When people make noises about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation they should not in their condemnation include the coverage of ABC radio because I find that to be very informative and factual. I do not think that it is biased in any way. However, as a person deeply involved and interested in this issue, I confess to having bias. Therefore, it is easy for me to allege that bias has occurred in other areas.

I have gone on much longer than I had intended to. I had intended to say something about the efforts made by people to bring about a peaceful resolution to this conflict. I do not want to go into each and every one of them at this stage. In many of the fine speeches we have heard to date they have been put on the record. However, I refer to one in particular-that is, the last speech by the then Secretary General of the United Nations, Mr Perez de Cuellar, on 15 January 1991. Rather than delaying the Senate further, I will seek leave at a later time to incorporate that speech.

Before sitting down I make a final comment in regard to my Party-the Australian Labor Party; the Party that I am proud to belong to. Resolution 10 of our foreign affairs platform states that we, the Australian Labor Party, take an active part in the United Nations and its agencies and will work towards improving the United Nations as an effective instrument of peace, justice, security, human rights, decolonisation, and cultural and technical exchange. I will not read the rest of the section: it is out in the open.

We have finally reached the stage where many members of the Labor Party and the Australian community believe that the United Nations is finally fulfilling the role that it was created for. Those of us in the left wing of the Labor Party have carried many motions calling for the United Nations to be more proactive in international disputes and we have been very disappointed in the past. I am very disappointed now that on the death knock, the eleventh hour-when we can show that we can take action to perhaps stop the actions of somebody that history may judge to be worse than Hitler was-the United Nations might be nullified in its steps. I hope that it continues.

I hope that this conflict concludes very shortly and that it does not reach a ground assault stage. I certainly hope that those Australians who are currently serving on our three ships in the area return to their loved ones in Australia without any harm coming to them. I hope that there will be no more killing in the region of anybody, be they allied forces or Iraqi forces. I seek leave to incorporate the statement to which I referred earlier.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Statement by the Secretary-General on 15 January 1991

As 15 January advances, and the world stands poised between peace and war, I most sincerely appeal to President Saddam Hussein to turn the course of events away from catastrophe and towards a new era of justice and harmony based on the principles of the United Nations Charter.
All of our efforts in this direction will fall unless Iraq can signify its readiness to comply with the relevant resolutions of the Security Council, beginning with resolution 660.

If this commitment is made, and clear and substantial steps taken to implement these resolutions, a just peace, with all of the benefits, will follow. I therefore urge President Saddam Hussein to commence, without delay, the total withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait.

Once this process is well underway, I wish to assure him, on the basis of understandings that I have received from governments at the highest level, that neither Iraq nor its forces will be attacked by those arrayed in the international coalition against his country.

Further, with the commencement of withdrawal, as Secretary-General of the United Nations, I would, with the consent of the parties concerned, and the agreement of the Security Council, be prepared immediately to deploy United Nations observers and, if necessary, United Nations forces to certify the withdrawal and to ensure that hostilities do not erupt on the ground.
In addition, with compliance of the resolutions, I would urge the Security Council to review its decisions imposing sanctions against Iraq.
I would also encourage a process whereby foreign forces deployed in the area would be phased out.
Peace in the region requires that all of its problems be resolved justly and equitably, in accordance with the principles of the Charter of the United Nations.

I have every assurance, once again from the highest levels of government, that with the resolution of the present crisis, every effort will be made to address, in a comprehensive manner, the Arab-Israeli conflict, including the Palestinian question. I pledge my every effort to this end.

As I stated to the Council last night, all of us are aware of the extreme gravity of the decisions to be made in the period ahead. No-one and no nation can-except with a heavy heart-resort to the other ``necessary means'' implied by resolution 678, knowing in advance that tragic and unpredictable consequences can follow.

I trust, in the circumstances, that wisdom and statesmanship will prevail in all quarters in order to move decisively away from conflict. In appealing to President Saddam Hussein today, I wish him to know that I will readily devote my every capacity to working with him, and with all others concerned, to this end.

In the tenth and final year of my tenure as Secretary-General of the United Nations, no cause would give me greater satisfaction than to set the Middle East as a whole on the road to just and lasting peace. And no disappointment would be greater and more tragic than to find the nations of the world engaging in a conflict that none of their peoples want.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: Mr Acting Deputy President, I will not detain the Senate for very long. I have asked one of the attendants to go to the top gallery where members of the public are to advise them of this matter. I must say that it worried me yesterday--
—Me, too.

—I am sure Senator Walters knows what I am going to say. For the benefit of their own safety and that of others, I advise members of the public who are in the top glassed-in gallery that two panes of glass have already fallen from the glassed-in galleries onto the floor of this chamber, including one from directly above the President's chair. If members of the public would like to look, they will see that a third has just gone also. I draw their attention to the fact that if they do displace one of the panes of glass that they are thumping, the first person that it will flatten will be Senator Vallentine.

—I cannot uphold the point of order, but I take the Minister's advice and indicate to the people in the glassed-in gallery that the gallery was not made for expressions of physical interest in debate. If they want to bash the glass they should leave because it is extremely dangerous for that glass to be hit. I will have to clear those glassed-in galleries if there is any attempt to hit the glass again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in favour of the motion. I have listened to a variety of speeches, including the impassioned speech by Senator McKiernan, and also have watched and heard hysterical behaviour both on the floor of this chamber and in the galleries above. I am drawn to the conclusion that there are similarities to be drawn between the attitude of Senator Powell and the Australian Democrats, and, shall I say, Senator Vallentine playing Little Miss Echo, and the attitude of Neville Chamberlain who was described by Professor Fuchser in his book Neville Chamberlain and Appeasement as a weak and ineffectual old man, feebly waving his umbrella promising `peace in our time' while the Wehrmacht marched into the Rhineland, Austria and Czechoslovakia. I find the comparison irresistible.

SPEECH.PARA: Chamberlain was obsessed with World War I and not repeating it, but he failed to distinguish-and indeed was unable to distinguish-between the circumstances and the nature of the events leading to each conflict and indeed the very nature of the dictator who was determined to conquer. This is analogous to the latter-day appeasers-the Democrats and others on the left who are obsessed with Vietnam and are likewise unable to distinguish between the events surrounding the Vietnam war and the conflict now under way in the Gulf.

The rhetoric of Senators Powell, Coulter, et al is all about the destruction that war causes. Never once do they address the question of the price that has to be paid for appeasement or avoiding that conflict. To say that they are simplistic or naive is to be kind. To say that they are obsessive and fearful is more realistic. To say that they are prepared to give a piece of this country and a piece of that country to buy a quiet life, which for them is peace, is more accurate as it is to call them the appeasers.

Again, Professor Fuchser wrote of Chamberlain that he believed that the alternative to coming to terms with Hitler would be another world war, infinitely more devastating than the last, and therefore almost any act of political accommodation was fully justified-not only justified but also the only conceivable course of moral action. Did that ring a bell in the speech that we heard today from Senator Coulter?

Professor Fuchser also wrote that Chamberlain did not sign an agreement which meant the end of Czechoslovak sovereignty because he wanted to buy time or because he felt Britain was too weak militarily to do otherwise, but because he believed that the dismemberment of Czechoslovakia was the price that had to be paid if another world war was to be avoided. Is Kuwait the price to be paid this time? Is that the price that the Democrats demand?

Neville Chamberlain was the arch promoter of the policy of appeasement in the 1930s. The Democrats and their ilk are the arch promoters in the 1990s. Let us look at some of the quotes of the 1930s and then at some of those of the 1990s. In July 1937, Neville Chamberlain said:
If only we could sit down at a table with the Germans and run through all their complaints and claims with a pencil, this would greatly relieve all tension.
How many speeches and pleas have we heard over here to say, `Stop the war and let us sit down and talk.'? On 27 September 1938 Neville Chamberlain said in a radio broadcast:
How horrible, fantastic, incredible it is that we should be trying on gas-masks here because of a quarrel in a far-away country between people of whom we know nothing.

Is that a statement worthy of Senator Vallentine, perhaps? No, it was Neville Chamberlain speaking about the German annexation of the Sudetenland. On 28 September Neville Chamberlain wrote to Adolf Hitler:

I am ready to come to Berlin myself at once to discuss arrangements for transfer with you and representations of the Czechoslovak Government together with representations of France and Italy if you so desire. I feel convinced we could reach an agreement in a week.
Again, on 28 September 1938 he said:

There can be no honourable member of this House who did not feel his heart leap that the crisis had been once more postponed to give us once more an opportunity to try what reason and good will and discussion will do to settle a problem which is already within sight of settlement.
He signed the Munich Agreement on 30 September. On 3 October Neville Chamberlain further said:

Ever since I assumed my present office my main purpose has been to work for the removal of those suspicions and animosities which have so long poisoned the air. The path which leads to appeasement is long and bristles with obstacles.

On 3 September 1939 war was declared. There were opportunities during all the period that that policy of appeasement was pursued to prevent or curtail the horrors that followed with World War II. The time that elapsed allowed Germany to build, to implement its guns before butter policy, to be able to fight a war that brought us near to defeat. The comparisons between the period from 1936 to 1939 are too vivid and too close for us not to learn from them. The plea and the cry that say we must not have war at any price overlook the fact that there is always a price to pay.

Let us look at some of the important facts which are on the record. Firstly, world leaders tried and strove to attain a just peace. The United Nations worked and implored Saddam Hussein to withdraw from his conquered lands. The United Nations showed this time that it was not like the League of Nations; it showed that it had the strength to act and to reinforce its decisions, and Australia, to its credit, chose to shoulder its share of the burden of responsibility by sending Australian forces to serve with the coalition force of nations assembled to achieve the withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait. I say that Australia-and I say it with pride-chose to shoulder its share of the burden because Australia is not a nation which says, `We want to have our voice heard, we want to be part of the world of nations, we want to be listened to when we speak about the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, we want to be listened to when we think there is an injustice on a trade issue or when there are other international issues to be discussed', but then say, when the going gets really rough, `Sorry, I'm all right, Jack; it is not our bit of the territory so we are going to stay out and let the rest of the world carry our share of the burden'. Australians are not like that. But yesterday Senator Janet Powell said in the Senate:

It is of deep regret that only 4 per cent of the parliamentarians in this place are prepared to oppose the action taken by our Government and by the United States. That 4 per cent clearly represents at least a majority of Australian citizens.

She is clearly having herself on. Australians are a brave and a courageous people who share the path of world responsibility to bring to an end the aggression, the torture, the occupation and the dismemberment of a small country. As I said before, it was Chamberlain who said, `Peace in our time'. Of course, he meant, a `p-i-e-c-e'-a piece of this country and a piece of that country-just as it would seem the Democrats are prepared to pay in the 1990s.

The claim that the continuation of sanctions alone will solve the problem is a statement of appeasement, and appeasement is no answer. The Australian Democrats bring no answers. To hear Senator Powell speak of Saddam Hussein and justice in the same breath underlines her total misunderstanding of the reality of the nature of Saddam Hussein. How can she misunderstand the nature of a man who would use chemical weapons on his own countrymen simply because they were guilty of being an ethnic minority, of being Kurds. Again, it is reminiscent of World War II when the Jews were persecuted simply because they were that-Jews. This is a man who has inflicted torture, rape and destruction on those whom he invaded. He is not a man who understands the concept of justice. He is a shrewd, calculating, committed enemy.

Senator Powell spoke of the right of Australians to dissent. It is a right I will defend, but there is no such right in Iraq, as many people have pointed out in this chamber already. We enjoy that right to dissent, the Democrats enjoy that right to dissent, and the people behind the glass enjoy that right to dissent, because it was the people of my parents' generation who fought to ensure that my generation and I should enjoy that freedom. The appeasers, be they in this chamber, in the public gallery or in the streets, are again like the 40,000 supporters of Neville Chamberlain who wrote effusively congratulating him upon the Munich Agreement. Among those who wrote congratulatory letters were leading academic, intellectual and political figures of their day-people who find their counterparts in this society today, people who have signed the `Do not commit Australia to war!' advertisement placed in the Australian on 11 January 1991.

A former Cabinet secretary of Chamberlain's day, one Maurice Hankey, wrote that he had never questioned that Chamberlain would find a way to avoid going to war with Germany. Is this the mirror image of the view of Iraq that is held by the latter day appeasers-Senator Childs from the Labor Left; Democrats Senator Vicki Bourne, Senator Janet Powell and Senator McLean; Labor Left members of parliament Frank Walker, Jeannette McHugh, Stewart West; and of course the ubiquitous Manning Clark and Professor Ted Wheelwright? Are these the same people who thought as the intellectuals and academics and politicians who congratulated Chamberlain upon his success at Munich?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no.
—Are these the people who say peace at any price?
—The people are different; the times are different; the circumstances are different.

—Order! Senator McLean, you have been fairly noisy in your interjections and fairly persistent. Can I ask you to desist so the honourable senator who has the floor is allowed to finish her speech in relative silence?
—She is misleading.
—The honourable senator is entitled to her view. You cannot interject any more in that manner.

—Thank you. I find that the interjection is not one that surprises me because I have said that the people who are the appeasers of the 1990s are as obsessive about the conclusions they draw from the Vietnam war as Neville Chamberlain was about World War I. But the United Nations will not suffer the fate of the League of Nations. There has been the establishment of the coalition force of 28 nations, given the strong leadership of the United States, a nation that it has become fashionable to insult because it upholds the sorts of things that a very large proportion of the world believes in. Because that coalition force has been established the resolutions passed by the United Nations are going to be enforced and then we will see that the United Nations will not suffer that fate.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, Australians are a courageous people. They are a courageous people who are not fearful of taking their share of international burdens. They will, indeed, tolerate the views of the dissenters-the noisy but small minority-but they will disavow the sort of people whom Chamberlain would have embraced as soul mates.

Both Government and Opposition leaders have commended our forces, and I mean the forces who are serving this nation, as distinct from the people whom Senator Powell-or, indeed, was it Senator Vallentine; they are like an echo of each other-chose to congratulate, and that is the international Gulf peace team. I would like to commend our forces who serve with courage and distinction but, more than just commend them, I would like to thank them. I would like to thank them for serving and for their commitment to achieving a just peace.

I join with others who pray that this war and this conflict will come to an early and successful conclusion, and we will see that the aggressor, the torturer, the man who seeks conquest above all, will not be able to enjoy what he believes are the fruits of his conquest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent days the Australian media has carried video footage and print articles featuring rallies of what could be called the peace movement. By and large those who have attended these rallies, and those who have supported them, are genuine in the beliefs that they are expressing. In general, they have put forward two related proposals. Firstly, we should live in a world of peace and, in particular, Australia should not be a party to belligerent activity in the Middle East. Secondly, the proposal is that we should withdraw our naval contingent which is deployed in the Persian Gulf.

SPEECH.PARA: With a public debate of this nature there are certain to be some emotive words used, but most of those do little credit to those who have two opposing points of view. What we need in a situation like the one which faces us so starkly at the moment is clear, reasoned debate. Empty slogans are of no help. They may give protesters on both sides of the argument a great feeling, but an inner glow is not going to help the nation arrive at a considered conclusion to what has become a divisive national issue.

As one who supports Australia's involvement in the current conflict with Iraq-my reasons for which I shall outline later-I would stress to those who rally for peace, pray for peace and silently hope for peace, that an overwhelming desire for peace is not their sole preserve. I, too, if not all of those who support Australia's current military involvement, then at least the vast majority of them, have the same deep abiding desire for a peaceful world.

In relation to the conflict with Iraq we have the same wish to see a peaceful resolution to these hostilities. In other words, the population of Australia is not divided into two groups: those who advocate peace and those who do not. The difference is how we should attain that goal of peace for which we both strive. Those, like me, who believe that conflict is necessary in this particular case do so in the belief that it is the best way of bringing peace to this area of the world, and of maintaining peace in the future.
The Senate is debating a motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). That motion states that the Senate:

reaffirms its support for an on-going role for the United Nations in promoting world peace and the self-determination of nations and in particular the Resolutions of the Security Council directed to end the aggression of Iraq against Kuwait.
affirms its support for Australia's positive response to the request made by the United Nations Security Council in Resolution 678 for support in implementing that Resolution.
expresses its full confidence in, and support for, Australian forces serving with the UN-sanctioned multi-national forces in the Gulf.
deplores Iraq's widening of the conflict by its unprovoked attack upon Israel.

recognises, as those with whom we are acting now in the Gulf have recognised, the need to intensify efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, including a just resolution of the Palestinian issue and the continuing security of Israel, once the crisis in the Gulf is resolved.

I would like to remind honourable senators that last week the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) noted that the decision to be involved in the Gulf was based on five special considerations. These are worth noting by those who are unsure of whether Australia should be militarily involved in the Gulf.

The first consideration is that there is a fundamental principle without which there can be neither peace nor freedom, and that is the right of every independent nation not to be invaded, not to be the victim of aggression and not to be destroyed.

Secondly, Australia acts with the commanding moral authority of the United Nations. Never, in the United Nations 45-year history, has it worked so effectively and with such unity to fulfil its Charter and the principles of peace and security it embodies.

The third consideration is that Australia and the coalition of forces has reached this decision only at the end of a process without precedent in history. There is no parallel for the restraint, the patience and the caution with which the world alliance against Saddam Hussein has sought, by peaceful means, to resolve this conflict.
Fourthly, Australia's decision has a clear and achievable goal: to end Iraq's aggression as a necessary step towards establishing the conditions for peace and stability in the Middle East.

The fifth consideration is to further the great quest for a new world order of peace, security and freedom, especially in the light of the end of confrontation between the United States of America and the Soviet Union. In this regard, the Prime Minister remarked:

Indeed, I believe that, at the bar of history, there will be no greater condemnation of Saddam Hussein, than that his aggression has plunged the world into a terrible and needless crisis which threatens the world stability on which those splendid hopes depend.

The Prime Minister also commented in his speech on 17 January that the great lesson of this century is that appeasement of aggression is too high a price to pay for peace. The conflicts of the 1930s bear this out. The fascist expansion which occurred throughout that decade was made possible because of the lack of decisive action by the wider world community, at that time operating through the League of Nations.

The attempted annexation of Kuwait by Iraq is a frightening reminder of similar events of the thirties. It is possible to quote a long list of such annexations at the hand of militaristic, totalitarian regimes that took place during that decade. Austria and Czechoslovakia were annexed by Germany, as was Abyssinia-now Ethiopia-by Italy and Manchuria by Japan. In the case of the two European fascist nations, particularly Italy, it has been widely acknowledged that their expansion could have been thwarted if significant counter measures had been taken by the League.

Just as the United Nations has struggled to deal with Iraq's aggression so, too, did the League of Nations face similar problems. The League was burdened by a number of member nations which chose to ignore normal international responsibilities and sensibilities in order to further their own political, military and imperial goals. The failure of the League of Nations in stemming the fascist movement of the 1930s must be taken into account in dealing with Iraq's present aggression.

As the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, indicated yesterday, we are not dealing with another Vietnam. We must cast our minds back to the 1930s to see a parallel-a parallel which indicates the tragic consequences of appeasing aggression. In the 1930s a number of opportunities existed for the European powers to prevent the spread of fascism. A vital opportunity existed during the Spanish Civil War. The legitimate government of Spain was overturned by a military coup led by the totalitarian General Franco, and Spain was plunged into civil war.

From the outset of the coup, Franco had been heavily supported by the German and Italian military. The legitimate representatives of the Spanish people, however, were reduced to begging for assistance from the international community. The majority of responses forthcoming from the European powers were ones of pity and weak messages of condolence. Russia, however, not only gave assistance to the Government forces but also lobbied a combined European opposition to the fascist movement in Spain and indeed Europe. The western European powers, notably England and France, however, rejected the Russian approaches.

In opposition to their governments' positions on the Spanish issue, a considerable number of private citizens volunteered as members of the Spanish Government forces. Notable among those were the volunteers who formed the International Brigade. They realised, as did the Russian Government, that peace and stability could not be assured just through hope or debate, but that unjust actions must at times be opposed in the strongest way. At times world peace, tragically, must be achieved through conflict.

The ultimate victory of Franco's forces and the accelerated fascist expansion that followed, precipitating World War II, was made possible by the inability of the western European powers to form an effective coalition with the Russian forces. Many historians have acknowledged that a coalition defence of Spain was the last chance for European peace prior to the outbreak of the World War.

At present the world has the opportunity to learn from the mistakes of the European powers of the 1930s. The response of the United Nations to the Gulf crisis should be applauded in the shadow of the experiences of the 1930s. Following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the world body applied considerable economic sanctions to force a withdrawal from the Gulf state. Despite applying the strongest possible economic pressure, the Iraqi presence in Kuwait remained. There is no doubt that Iraq was using the time during which sanctions were applied to develop further its war machine, including the development of a nuclear capacity. When even the most strenuous diplomatic efforts failed to move Iraq's forces from Kuwait, the United Nations resolved that the Iraqi aggression must not be allowed to stand.

The United Nations' decision to become militarily involved was not taken lightly. It should again be mentioned that the appeasement of aggression is not the road to peace. In line with that lesson of the past and the need for a combined response, the United Nations resolved that a multinational military response to Iraq's aggression was required.

To the credit of the world community, a multitude of countries have contributed resources to the multinational force. Again, to the credit of those nations involved, Arab, Asian and African Muslim states are involved in the force. Those nations involved have recognised that the opposition to international aggression, as demonstrated by Iraq in its invasion of Kuwait, is a collective responsibility. It is in fact the responsibility of all the people of the world to oppose that type of aggression through all possible means so as to ensure world peace. In line with that collective responsibility, Australian involvement in the multinational force should be supported.

It is worth while to examine what the consequences could be if the world decided to ignore the Iraqi aggression. Nations throughout the world would believe that we live on a planet where might is right. Many nations would thus build a military machine and others would do the same to protect their borders. This would lead to a massive misuse of resources which could be better applied for the betterment of humankind. We cannot allow that situation to develop, but we will do so if we appease Iraq's unbridled aggression.

What would we do in the future if our nation, with its relatively small population, became subject to the aggression of a foreign power? We would hope to receive the collective support of others to fight to retain our freedom. If we expect that support, it would ill behove us to shirk our responsibility now to take a stand against Iraq's aggression.

Those of us who support the Government's positive response to the United Nations Security Council resolution do so in the belief that this is the only way to achieve an acceptable solution which will lead to future world peace. It is not an easy decision to make. But those who support the Government's response should not be regarded as anti-peace. That is definitely not so; in fact, the opposite is the case.

One reason why it is not an easy decision to commit troops to conflict is that it is inevitable that in war lives are lost. That has already occurred, although none of the casualties have yet been among the Australian forces. Some of us know personally members of the Australian forces already in the Gulf. We know what we are asking these young men and women to do on behalf of world peace. It is not an easy task to ask our forces to move into a danger area.

In all the time in which I served in the Army Reserve I was either a psychologist in training or a psychologist. At one stage I worked virtually full time with young men who were conscripted, my main task being to identify those who could undergo officer training. I am certain that some of those whom I interviewed did not return from Vietnam. I am thus not unmindful of the possible consequences of asking our troops to go into a war zone. Nevertheless, I support the Government's action. I do so because we cannot allow unbridled aggression to be rewarded and become a role model for other nations in the future.

In supporting the motion moved by my Leader, I acknowledge the debt that we owe to our 884 serving men and women in the Gulf. We have three ships there-HMAS Sydney, HMAS Brisbane and HMAS Success. I trust that, when the crews of these three ships return, the Australian people will display their enthusiastic appreciation for a job well done. These fine service men and women deserve such a display, indicating that this nation understands what they have done for future world peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the motion before the Senate as part of a demonstration of national unity at a time of world crisis. I say at the outset that war is a costly experience-costly in terms of human lives, human resources and a country's material resources. It is an experience that should be avoided wherever possible. But it is also often the only way to avoid an even greater cost of human lives, human resources and a country's material resources. At times action is needed to avoid what is clearly to be seen as an even greater future cost. This is how I see the present situation. If we believe in the philosophy of the brotherhood of man and the concept of this world as a global village, there is a responsibility for those who are in less fortunate circumstances and those who are overrun by an aggressor.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it is appropriate to take this opportunity, here and now, as a Tasmanian senator, to express my sympathies to the relatives and friends, particularly the 41 Tasmanian families, of those members serving in this area. My thoughts, together with those of my fellow colleagues from Tasmania, are indeed with them on this occasion as members of the Australian forces serve in the Gulf area.

We hope desperately and sincerely that this war will be resolved quickly. A parent's heart is often torn between the conflict of the need to stop an aggressor before more sons and daughters of others are harmed and the need to keep one's own offspring safe. Therefore, we know how those families whose children are serving in this crisis must be feeling during this time of great anxiety and great distress.

During my recent readings of local newspapers in Tasmania I have become greatly concerned about the nature of some of the calls for peace. Peace is necessary, but not the implied peace in so many of these articles-peace at any cost. There appears to be a number of well-intentioned people who, separated by a vast distance from what is actually happening in Kuwait and Iraq today, and mollycoddled by the security of their own nation, appear to be quite oblivious to the long term intentions and the past atrocities of Saddam Hussein.

Saddam Hussein, apart from seeking to advance Iraq's historic, political and strategic interests, aspires to be a present day Nebuchadnezzar, Saladin and Nasser of the Arab world. Saddam has modelled himself on previous great aggressors of this world, aggressors who stopped at nothing to achieve their aims; men who viewed human life as cheap and as a means to an end; men who, to adopted an oft-used historic expression, used human life as cannon fodder.

Saddam Hussein has little respect for the quality of human life, especially the human life of his own countrymen, women and children. His indiscriminate use of chemical weapons on the Kurds is but one of hundreds of examples. Thousands of men, women and children were gassed without any prior knowledge or warning for no other reason than that he feared their resistance to his regime and wanted their land for other purposes.

Saddam Hussein was the aggressor in 1980 in the Iraq-Iran conflict, a war that lasted for eight ghastly years and resulted in over a million casualties. Saddam Hussein has personally helped in the execution of his political opponents. Amnesty International has documented evidence of atrocities committed against Kuwaitis since the takeover of Kuwait. Its report of 19 December gives a chilling and comprehensive picture of the terrible human rights violations, detention, torture and summary execution.

The Iraqi Government has ignored United Nations resolutions condemning its mistreatment of the Kuwaiti people and its unlawful destruction and seizure of their property. This refusal to recognise the existence of the Kuwaitis is further shown by the Iraqi refusal to allow access by the International Committee of the Red Cross to provide protection and assistance. People who call for peace at any cost are ignoring the sadistic nature of this man. Saddam has his objectives. He wishes to be the master of the Arab world and in the process he will annihilate anyone who stands in his way.

I do not believe that we can trust this man. His past actions verify the dangerous nature of his psyche. He has double-crossed national leaders who previously assisted Iraq in its long war again Iran-that is, the leaders of Kuwait. I refer also to King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and President Mubarak of Egypt. Saddam Hussein sought to assure those Arab leaders that the dispute with Kuwait could be resolved by amicable means; if not, certainly through the Arab League. He has betrayed their confidence--
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. The consequences of allowing Saddam to go unchecked are uncertain and very frightening. If he were allowed to devour Kuwait, where would he turn his attention next? This week we have seen Iraq's missile attack on Israel. This unprovoked attack violates both international law and the accepted standards of international behaviour. In fact, Saddam Hussein has turned his back on the Islamic principles of ruling, of brotherhood, of mercy and of cooperation. We must not ignore the lessons of history.

SPEECH.PARA: The events of the 1930s in Europe remind us starkly of the need to curb an aggressor's desire for more territory. The failure of the international community to respond adequately to the invasions of Manchuria, Abyssinia and Czechoslovakia eroded confidence in the League of Nations and contributed to the collapse of the world as it was then known.

Appeasement of aggression risks only greater problems later on. However, this is first and foremost a test of the United Nations' ability to keep world peace and security. The conflict is the result of the Security Council taking its responsibilities seriously.

The resolutions against Iraq are supported by representative forces from over 28 nations. The conflict is not with the United States but with the Security Council of the United Nations. To have the Security Council back off and not carry through its resolutions would put the United Nations in the same category as the now defunct and useless League of Nations in keeping world peace. It is my sincere hope that the United Nations will not become another League of Nations. Since 2 August the United Nations has passed 12 resolutions on the Kuwaiti situation. Saddam Hussein has had a number of opportunities to pursue a peaceful resolution. In fact, leaders of the Arab world pleaded with this Iraqi dictator but those calls have been constantly ignored. It is important to note that when an aggressor nation simply chooses to opt out of its normal international responsibilities, it is difficult for any government to engage it in any meaningful discussion.

The Australian Government has made appropriate efforts to see the crisis resolved by diplomatic and peaceful means. The Opposition coalition places great importance on the need for national unity in dealing with such crises. For this reason we support the motion before the Senate. All the intensive efforts for a peaceful solution to this crisis have foundered on Saddam Hussein's flat refusal to consider any withdrawal from Kuwait. His cynical manipulation of the linkage between the crises and other issues and his continued massive build-up in Kuwait are quite frightening to world order.

Thirdly, the United Nations, by attempting a peaceful solution, gave Iraq an extra five months to build up its ever-increasing and growing arsenal of conventional and other weapons. The Central Intelligence Agency has ascertained that another 12 months of sanctions would not shift Hussein's position in Kuwait.

An extremely frightening consequence is that if he is not stopped now, and with control of greater oil resources, he could be expected to develop a significant nuclear capability. Given Saddam's track record, his readiness to use these weapons cannot be doubted. One has only to read of the disastrous results of Chernobyl to realise that the results of nuclear explosions continue for many years. Nuclear warfare is to be avoided at any cost. This is one means of avoiding what would certainly be a catastrophe. As I read the situation, continuing only with sanctions would allow Saddam to build up his weapons arsenal, including nuclear and chemical weapons, and give him an even greater opportunity and possibility for using those sorts of weapons.

Therefore, I support the Government in its involvement in this issue and hope and pray that this aggression will be quickly stopped and that world peace will ensue. May I take the opportunity in this debate of congratulating the Israelis for their forbearance in not seeking an immediate revenge against those missile attacks launched against the populated areas of Haifa and Tel Aviv. Equally, I would like to take this opportunity of congratulating the restraint of Syria and Egypt because I believe that both of those countries have shown great statesmanship at a time of great trial for their nations, being neighbours of Iraq and with long term difficulties for Israel.
Further, I hope and pray most fervently, as the Bishop of Tasmania stated so emphatically at the weekend, that we:

unite with compassion for the lives of those caught up in the crisis (that) we are united in our concern for the people of Kuwait overwhelmed by the aggressor (that) we are united in our preference for a non-violent solution, . . . but since this has not been achieved we are united in our heartfelt concern for (those) at home awaiting news, and praying for a safe and speedy homecoming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage in the debate-I think I am the forty-third senator to speak-there may be little left to say except to express my support for the motion before Parliament endorsing the actions of the Government and expressing solid support for the United Nations. However, as a founding member of the World Women Parliamentarians for Peace, and as the immediate past president and as a committed internationalist and peace activist, I feel impelled to put a view, not at variance, but perhaps supplementary to that of the very many thoughtful and informative speakers who have preceded me. The Hansards of these last two days deserve to be widely read, especially by the many people who have shown genuine concern yet clearly lack the information upon which to base informed opinions.

SPEECH.PARA: The basis of effective political action is surely to know one's subject. A preparedness to listen and learn has been conspicuously absent among many of the most vociferous of those who are most critical of the Government, even among elected representatives of the Australian people. Mr Deputy President, in order to ensure that the record is as complete as possible, I seek leave to have incorporated the 12 resolutions of the United Nations, the French peace plan and Security Council resolutions relating to Palestine and the occupied territories.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
RESOLUTION 660
2 August 1990
The Security Council,
Alarmed by the invasion of Kuwait on 2 August 1990 by the military forces of Iraq,
Determining that there exists a breach of international peace and security as regards the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait,
Acting under Articles 39 and 40 of the Charter of the United Nations,
1. Condemns the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait;
2. Demands that Iraq withdraw immediately and unconditionally all its forces to the positions in which they were located on 1 August 1990;

3. Calls upon Iraq and Kuwait to begin immediately intensive negotiations for the resolution of their differences and supports all efforts in this regard, and especially those of the League of Arab States;
4. Decides to meet again as necessary to consider further steps to ensure compliance with the present resolution.
RESOLUTION 661
6 August 1990
The Security Council
Reaffirming its resolution 660 (1990) of 2 August 1990,
Deeply concerned that that resolution has not been implemented and that the invasion by Iraq of Kuwait continues with further loss of human life and material destruction,
Determined to bring the invasion and occupation of Kuwait by Iraq to an end and to restore the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Kuwait,
Noting that the legitimate Government of Kuwait has expressed its readiness to comply with resolution 660 (1990),
Mindful of its responsibilities under the Charter of the United Nations for the maintenance of international peace and security,
Affirming the inherent right of individual or collective self-defence, in response to the armed attack by Iraq against Kuwait, in accordance with Article 51 of the Charter,
Acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations,
1. Determines that Iraq so far has failed to comply with paragraph 2 of resolution 660 (1990) and has usurped the authority of the legitimate Government of Kuwait;

2. Decides, as a consequence, to take the following measures to secure compliance of Iraq with paragraph 2 of resolution 660 (1990) and to restore the authority of the legitimate Government of Kuwait;
3. Decides that all States shall prevent:
(a) The import into their territories of all commodities and products originating in Iraq or Kuwait exported therefrom after the date of the present resolution;

(b) Any activities by their nationals or in their territories which would promote or are calculated to promote the export or trans-shipment of any commodities or products from Iraq or Kuwait; and any dealings by their nationals or their flag vessels or in their territories in any commodities or products originating in Iraq or Kuwait and exported therefrom after the date of the present resolution, including in particular any transfer of funds to Iraq or Kuwait for the purposes of such activities or dealings;

(c) The sale or supply by their nationals or from their territories or using their flag vessels of any commodities or products, including weapons or any other military equipment, whether or not originating in their territories but not including supplies intended strictly for medical purposes, and, in humanitarian circumstances, foodstuffs, to any person or body in Iraq or Kuwait or to any person or body for the purposes of any business carried on in or operated from Iraq or Kuwait, and any activities by their nationals or in their territories which promote or are calculated to promote such sale or supply of such commodities or products;

4. Decides that all States shall not make available to the Government of Iraq or to any commercial, industrial or public utility undertaking in Iraq or Kuwait, any funds or any other financial or economic resources and shall prevent their nationals and any persons within their territories from removing from their territories or otherwise making available to that Government or to any such undertaking any such funds or resources and from remitting any other funds to persons or bodies within Iraq or Kuwait, except payments exclusively for strictly medical or humanitarian purposes and, in humanitarian circumstances, foodstuffs;

5. Calls upon all States, including States non-members of the United Nations, to act strictly in accordance with the provisions of the present resolution notwithstanding any contract entered into or licence granted before the date of the present resolution;

6. Decides to establish, in accordance with rule 28 of the provisional rules of procedure of the Security Council, a Committee of the Security Council consisting of all the members of the Council, to undertake the following tasks and to report on its work to the Council with its observations and recommendations:
(a) To examine the reports on the progress of the implementation of the present resolution which will be submitted by the Secretary-General;
(b) To seek from all States further information regarding the action taken by them concerning the effective implementation of the provisions laid down in the present resolution;

7. Calls upon all States to co-operate fully with the Committee in the fulfilment of its task, including supplying such information as may be sought by the Committee in pursuance of the present resolution;
8. Requests the Secretary-General to provide all necessary assistance to the Committee and to make the necessary arrangements in the Secretariat for the purpose;
9. Decides that, notwithstanding paragraphs 4 through 8 above, nothing in the present resolution shall prohibit assistance to the legitimate Government of Kuwait, and calls upon all States:
(a) To take appropriate measures to protect assets of the legitimate Government of Kuwait and its agencies;
(b) Not to recognize any regime set up by the occupying Power;
10. Requests the Secretary-General to report to the Council on the progress of the implementation of the present resolution, the first report to be submitted within thirty days;
11. Decides to keep this item on its agenda and to continue its efforts to put an early end to the invasion by Iraq.
RESOLUTION 662
9 August 1990
The Security Council,
Recalling its resolutions 660 (1990) and 661 (1990),
Gravely alarmed by the declaration by Iraq of a ``comprehensive and eternal merger'' with Kuwait,
Demanding, once again, that Iraq withdraw immediately and unconditionally all its forces to the positions in which they were located on 1 August 1990,
Determined to bring the occupation of Kuwait by Iraq to an end and to restore the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Kuwait,
Determined also to restore the authority of the legitimate Government of Kuwait,
1. Decides that annexation of Kuwait by Iraq under any form and whatever pretext has no legal validity, and is considered null and void;

2. Calls upon all States, international organizations and specialized agencies not to recognize that annexation, and to refrain from any action or dealing that might be interpreted as an indirect recognition of the annexation;
3. Further demands that Iraq rescind its actions purporting to annex Kuwait;
4. Decides to keep this item on its agenda and to continue its efforts to put an early end to the occupation.
RESOLUTION 664
18 August 1990
The Security Council,
Recalling the Iraqi invasion and purported annexation of Kuwait and resolutions 660, 661 and 662,
Deeply concerned for the safety and well being of third state nationals in Iraq and Kuwait,
Recalling the obligations of Iraq in this regard under international law,
Welcoming the efforts of the Secretary-General to pursue urgent consultations with the Government of Iraq following the concern and anxiety expressed by the members of the Council on 17 August 1990,
Acting under Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter,

1. Demands that Iraq permit and facilitate the immediate departure from Kuwait and Iraq of the nationals of third countries and grant immediate and continuing access of consular officials to such nationals;
2. Further demands that Iraq take no action to jeopardize the safety, security or health of such nationals;

3. Reaffirms its decision in resolution 662 (1990) that annexation of Kuwait by Iraq is null and void, and therefore demands that the government of Iraq rescind its orders for the closure of diplomatic and consular missions in Kuwait and the withdrawal of the immunity of their personnel, and refrain from any such actions in the future;
4. Requests the Secretary-General to report to the Council on compliance with this resolution at the earliest possible time.
RESOLUTION 665
25 August 1990
The Security Council,
Recalling its resolutions 660 (1990), 661 (1990), 662 (1990) and 664 (1990) and demanding their full and immediate implementation,
Having decided in resolution 661 (1990) to impose economic sanctions under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations,

Determined to bring an end to the occupation of Kuwait by Iraq which imperils the existence of a Member State and to restore the legitimate authority, and the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Kuwait which requires the speedy implementation of the above resolutions,
Deploring the loss of innocent life stemming from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and determined to prevent further such losses,

Gravely alarmed that Iraq continues to refuse to comply with resolutions 660 (1990), 661 (1990), 662 (1990) and 664 (1990) and in particular at the conduct of the Government of Iraq in using Iraqi flag vessels to export oil,

1. Calls upon those Member States co-operating with the Government of Kuwait which are deploying maritime forces to the area to use such measures commensurate to the specific circumstances as may be necessary under the authority of the Security Council to halt all inward and outward maritime shipping in order to inspect and verify their cargoes and destinations and to ensure strict implementation of the provisions related to such shipping laid down in resolution 661 (1990);

2. Invites Member States accordingly to co-operate as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of resolution 661 (1990) with maximum use of political and diplomatic measures, in accordance with paragraph 1 above;
3. Requests all States to provide in accordance with the Charter such assistance as may be required by the States referred to in paragraph 1 of this resolution;

4. Further requests the States concerned to coordinate their actions in pursuit of the above paragraphs of this resolution using as appropriate mechanisms of the Military Staff Committee and after consultation with the Secretary-General to submit reports to the Security Council and its Committee established under resolution 661 (1990) to facilitate the monitoring of the implementation of this resolution;
5. Decides to remain actively seized of the matter.
RESOLUTION 666
13 September 1990
The Security Council,
Recalling its resolution 661 (1990), paragraphs 3 (c) and 4 of which apply, except in humanitarian circumstances, to foodstuffs,
Recognizing that circumstances may arise in which it will be necessary for foodstuffs to be supplied to the civilian population in Iraq or Kuwait in order to relieve human suffering,
Noting that in this respect the Committee established under paragraph 6 of that resolution has received communications from several Member States,
Emphasizing that it is for the Security Council, alone or acting through the Committee, to determine whether humanitarian circumstances have arisen,

Deeply concerned that Iraq has failed to comply with its obligations under Security Council resolution 664 (1990) in respect of the safety and well-being of third State nationals, and reaffirming that Iraq retains full responsibility in this regard under international humanitarian law including, where applicable, the Fourth Geneva Convention,
Acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations,

1. Decides that in order to make the necessary determination whether or not for the purposes of paragraph 3 (c) and paragraph 4 of resolution 661 (1990) humanitarian circumstances have arisen, the Committee shall keep the situation regarding foodstuffs in Iraq and Kuwait under constant review;

2. Expects Iraq to comply with its obligations under Security Council resolution 664 (1990) in respect of third State nationals and reaffirms that Iraq remains fully responsible for their safety and well-being in accordance with international humanitarian law including, where applicable, the Fourth Geneva Convention;

3. Requests, for the purposes of paragraphs 1 and 2 of this resolution, that the Secretary-General seek urgently, and on a continuing basis, information from relevant United Nations and other appropriate humanitarian agencies and all other sources on the availability of food in Iraq and Kuwait, such information to be communicated by the Secretary-General to the Committee regularly;

4. Requests further that in seeking and supplying such information particular attention will be paid to such categories of persons who might suffer specially, such as children under 15 years of age, expectant mothers, maternity cases, the sick and the elderly;

5. Decides that if the Committee, after receiving the reports from the Secretary-General, determines that circumstances have arisen in which there is an urgent humanitarian need to supply foodstuffs to Iraq or Kuwait in order to relieve human suffering, it will report promptly to the Council its decision as to how such need should be met;

6. Directs the Committee that in formulating its decisions it should bear in mind that foodstuffs should be provided through the United Nations in co-operation with the International Committee of the Red Cross or other appropriate humanitarian agencies and distributed by them or under their supervision in order to ensure that they reach the intended beneficiaries;

7. Requests the Secretary-General to use his good offices to facilitate the delivery and distribution of foodstuffs to Kuwait and Iraq in accordance with the provisions of this and other relevant resolutions;

8. Recalls that resolution 661 (1990) does not apply to supplies intended strictly for medical purposes, but in this connection recommends that medical supplies should be exported under the strict supervision of the Government of the exporting State or by appropriate humanitarian agencies.
RESOLUTION 667
16 September 1990
The Security Council,
Recalling the Vienna Conventions of 18 April 1961 on diplomatic relations and of 24 April 1963 on consular relations, to both of which Iraq is a party,

Considering that the decision of Iraq to order the closure of diplomatic and consular missions in Kuwait and to withdraw the immunity and privileges of these missions and their personnel is contrary to the decisions of the Security Council, the international Conventions mentioned above and international law,

Deeply concerned that Iraq, notwithstanding the decisions of the Security Council and the provisions of the Conventions mentioned above, has committed acts of violence against diplomatic missions and their personnel in Kuwait,
