Outraged at recent violations by Iraq of diplomatic premises in Kuwait and at the abduction of personnel enjoying diplomatic immunity and foreign nationals who were present in these premises,

Considering that the above actions by Iraq constitute aggressive acts and a flagrant violation of its international obligations which strike at the root of the conduct of international relations in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations,
Recalling that Iraq is fully responsible for any use of violence against foreign nationals or against any diplomatic or consular mission in Kuwait or its personnel,
Determined to ensure respect for its decisions and for Article 25 of the Charter of the United Nations,

Further considering that the grave nature of Iraq's actions, which constitute a new escalation of its violations of international law, obliges the Council not only to express its immediate reaction but also to consult urgently to take further concrete measures to ensure Iraq's compliance with the Council's resolutions,
Acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations,
1. Strongly condemns aggressive acts perpetrated by Iraq against diplomatic premises and personnel in Kuwait, including the abduction of foreign nationals who were present in those premises;
2. Demands the immediate release of those foreign nationals as well as all nationals mentioned in resolution 664 (1990);

3. Further demands that Iraq immediately and fully comply with its international obligations under resolutions 660 (1990), 662 (1990) and 664 (1990) of the Security Council, the Vienna Conventions on diplomatic and consular relations and international law;

4. Further demands that Iraq immediately protect the safety and well-being of diplomatic and consular personnel and premises in Kuwait and in Iraq and take no action to hinder the diplomatic and consular missions in the performance of their functions, including access to their nationals and the protection of their person and interests;
5. Reminds all States that they are obliged to observe strictly resolutions 661 (1990), 662 (1990), 664 (1990), 665 (1990) and 666 ( 1990);

6. Decides to consult urgently to take further concrete measures as soon as possible, under Chapter VII of the Charter, in response to Iraq's continued violation of the Charter, of resolutions of the Council and of international law.
RESOLUTION 669
24 September 1990
The Security Council,
Recalling its resolution 661 (1990) of 6 August 1990,
Recalling also Article 50 of the Charter of the United Nations,
Conscious of the fact that an increasing number of requests for assistance have been received under the provisions of Article 50 of the Charter of the United Nations,

Entrusts the Committee established under resolution 661 (1990) concerning the situation between Iraq and Kuwait with the task of examining requests for assistance under the provisions of Article 50 of the Charter of the United Nations and making recommendations to the President of the Security Council for appropriate action.
RESOLUTION 670
25 September 1990
The Security Council,

Condemning Iraq's continued occupation of Kuwait, its failure to rescind its actions and end its purported annexation and its holding of third State nationals against their will, in flagrant violation of resolutions 660 (1990), 662 (1990), 664 (1990) and 667 (1990) and of international humanitarian law,

Condemning further the treatment by Iraqi forces of Kuwaiti nationals, including measures to force them to leave their own country and mistreatment of persons and property in Kuwait in violation of international law,
Noting with grave concern the persistent attempts to evade the measures laid down in resolution 661 (1990),
Further noting that a number of States have limited the number of Iraqi diplomatic and consular officials in their countries and that others are planning to do so,
Determined to ensure by all necessary means the strict and complete application of the measures laid down in resolution 661 (1990),
Determined to ensure respect for its decisions and the provisions of Articles 25 and 48 of the Charter of the United Nations,

Affirming that any acts of the Government of Iraq which are contrary to the abovementioned resolutions or to Articles 25 or 48 of the Charter of the United Nations, such as Decree No. 377 of the Revolution Command Council of Iraq of 16 September 1990, are null and void,
Reaffirming its determination to ensure compliance with Security Council resolutions by maximum use of political and diplomatic means,

Welcoming the Secretary-General's use of his good offices to advance a peaceful solution based on the relevant Security Council resolutions and noting with appreciation his continuing efforts to this end,

Underlining to the Government of Iraq that its continued failure to comply with the terms of resolutions 660 (1990), 661 (1990), 662 (1990), 664 (1990), 666 (1990) and 667 (1990) could lead to further serious action by the Council under the Charter of the United Nations, including under Chapter VII,
Recalling the provisions of Article 103 of the Charter of the United Nations, Acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations,
1. Calls upon all States to carry out their obligations to ensure strict and complete compliance with resolution 661 (1990) and in particular paragraphs 3, 4 and 5 thereof;
2. Confirms that resolution 661 (1990) applies to all means of transport, including aircraft;

3. Decides that all States, notwithstanding the existence of any rights or obligations conferred or imposed by any international agreement or any contract entered into or any licence or permit granted before the date of the present resolution, shall deny permission to any aircraft to take off from their territory if the aircraft would carry any cargo to or from Iraq or Kuwait other than food in humanitarian circumstances, subject to authorization by the Council or the Committee established by resolution 661 (1990) and in accordance with resolution 666 (1990), or supplies intended strictly for medical purposes or solely for UNIIMOG;
4. Decides further that all States shall deny permission to any aircraft destined to land in Iraq or Kuwait, whatever its State of registration, to overfly its territory unless

(a) The aircraft lands at an airfield designated by that State outside Iraq or Kuwait in order to permit its inspection to ensure that there is no cargo on board in violation of resolution 661 (1990) or the present resolution, and for this purpose the aircraft may be detained for as long as necessary; or
(b) the particular flight has been approved by the Committee established by resolution 661 (1990); or
(c) The flight is certified by the United Nations as solely for the purposes of UNIIMOG;

5. Decides that each State shall take all necessary measures to ensure that any aircraft registered in its territory or operated by an operator who has his principal place of business or permanent residence in its territory complies with the provisions of resolution 661 (1990) and the present resolution;

6. Decides further that all States shall notify in a timely fashion the Committee established by resolution 661 (1990) of any flight between its territory and Iraq or Kuwait to which the requirement to land in paragraph 4 above does not apply, and the purpose for such a flight;

7. Calls upon all States to co-operate in taking such measures as may be necessary, consistent with international law, including the Chicago Convention, to ensure the effective implementation of the provisions of resolution 66l (1990) or the present resolution;

8. Calls upon all States to detain any ships of Iraqi registry which enter their ports and which are being or have been used in violation of resolution 661 (1990), or to deny such ships entrance to their ports except in circumstances recognized under international law as necessary to safeguard human life;

9. Reminds all States of their obligations under resolution 661 (1990) with regard to the freezing of Iraqi assets, and the protection of the assets of the legitimate Government of Kuwait and its agencies, located within their territory and to report to the Committee established under resolution 661 (1990) regarding those assets;

10. Calls upon all States to provide to the Committee established by resolution 661 (1990) information regarding the action taken by them to implement the provisions laid down in the present resolution;

11. Affirms that the United Nations Organization, the specialized agencies and other international organizations in the United Nations system are required to take such measures as may be necessary to give effect to the terms of resolution 661 (1990) and this resolution;

12. Decides to consider, in the event of evasion of the provisions of resolution 661 (1990) or of the present resolution by a State or its nationals or through its territory, measures directed at the State in question to prevent such evasion;

13. Reaffirms that the Fourth Geneva Convention applies to Kuwait and that as a High Contracting Party to the Convention Iraq is bound to comply fully with all its terms and in particular is liable under the Convention in respect of the grave breaches committed by it, as are individuals who commit or order the commission of grave breaches.
RESOLUTION 674
29 October 1990
The Security Council,

Stressing the urgent need for the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of all Iraqi forces from Kuwait, for the restoration of Kuwait's sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity and of the authority of its legitimate government,

Condemning the actions by the Iraqi authorities and occupying forces to take third-State nationals hostage and to mistreat and oppress Kuwaiti and third-State nationals, and the other actions reported to the Security Council, such as the destruction of Kuwaiti demographic records, the forced departure of Kuwaitis, the relocation of population in Kuwait and the unlawful destruction and seizure of public and private property in Kuwait, including hospital supplies and equipment, in violation of the decisions of the Council, the Charter of the United Nations, the Fourth Geneva Convention, the Vienna Conventions on Diplomatic and Consular Relations and international law,
Expressing grave alarm over the situation of nationals of third States in Kuwait and Iraq, including the personnel of the diplomatic and consular missions of such States,

Reaffirming that the Fourth Geneva Convention applies to Kuwait and that as a High Contracting Party to the Convention Iraq is bound to comply fully with all its terms and in particular is liable under the Convention in respect of the grave breaches committed by it, as are individuals who commit or order the commission of grave breaches,
Recalling the efforts of the Secretary-General concerning the safety and well-being of third State nationals in Iraq and Kuwait,
Deeply concerned at the economic cost and at the loss and suffering caused to individuals in Kuwait and Iraq as a result of the invasion and occupation of Kuwait by Iraq,
Acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations,
Reaffirming the goal of the international community of maintaining international peace and security by seeking to resolve international disputes and conflicts through peaceful means,
Recalling the important role that the United Nations and its Secretary-General have played in the peaceful solution of disputes and conflicts in conformity with the provisions of the Charter,

Alarmed by the dangers of the present crisis caused by the Iraqi invasion and occupation of Kuwait, which directly threaten international peace and security, and seeking to avoid any further worsening of the situation,
Calling upon Iraq to comply with the relevant resolutions of the Security Council, in particular its resolutions 660 (1990), 662 (1990) and 664 (1990),
Reaffirming its determination to ensure compliance by Iraq with the Security Council resolutions by maximum use of political and diplomatic means,
A.

1. Demands that the Iraqi authorities and occupying forces immediately cease and desist from taking third-State nationals hostage, mistreating and oppressing Kuwaiti and third-State nationals and any other actions, such as those reported to the Security Council and described above, that violate the decisions of this Council, the Charter of the United Nations, the Fourth Geneva Convention, the Vienna Conventions on Diplomatic and Consular Relations and international law;

2. Invites States to collate substantiated information in their possession or submitted to them on the grave breaches by Iraq as per paragraph 1 above and to make this information available to the Security Council;

3. Reaffirms its demand that Iraq immediately fulfil its obligations to third-State nationals in Kuwait and Iraq, including the personnel of diplomatic and consular missions, under the Charter, the Fourth Geneva Convention, the Vienna Conventions on Diplomatic and Consular Relations, general principles of international law and the relevant resolutions of the Council;

4. Also reaffirms its demand that Iraq permit and facilitate the immediate departure from Kuwait and Iraq of those third-State nationals, including diplomatic and consular personnel, who wish to leave;

5. Demands that Iraq ensure the immediate access to food, water and basic services necessary to the protection and well-being of Kuwaiti nationals and of nationals of third States in Kuwait and Iraq, including the personnel of diplomatic and consular missions in Kuwait;

6. Reaffirms its demand that Iraq immediately protect the safety and well-being of diplomatic and consular personnel and premises in Kuwait and in Iraq, take no action to hinder these diplomatic and consular missions in the performance of their functions, including access to their nationals and the protection of their person and interests and rescind its orders for the closure of diplomatic and consular missions in Kuwait and the withdrawal of the immunity of their personnel;

7. Requests the Secretary-General, in the context of the continued exercise of his good offices concerning the safety and well-being of third-State nationals in Iraq and Kuwait, to seek to achieve the objectives of paragraphs 4, 5 and 6 above and in particular the provision of food, water and basic services to Kuwaiti nationals and to the diplomatic and consular missions in Kuwait and the evacuation of third-State nationals;

8. Reminds Iraq that under international law it is liable for any loss, damage or injury arising in regard to Kuwait and third States, and their nationals and corporations, as a result of the invasion and illegal occupation of Kuwait by Iraq;

9. Invites States to collect relevant information regarding their claims, and those of their nationals and corporations, for restitution or financial compensation by Iraq with a view to such arrangements as may be established in accordance with international law;
10. Requires that Iraq comply with the provisions of the present resolution and its previous resolutions, failing which the Security Council will need to take further measures under the Charter;

11. Decides to remain actively and permanently seized of the matter until Kuwait has regained its independence and peace has been restored in conformity with the relevant resolutions of the Security Council.
B.

12. Reposes its trust in the Secretary-General to make available his good offices and, as he considers appropriate, to pursue them and to undertake diplomatic efforts in order to reach a peaceful solution to the crisis caused by the Iraqi invasion and occupation of Kuwait on the basis of Security Council resolutions 660 (1990), 662 (1990) and 664 (1990), and calls upon all States, both those in the region and others, to pursue on this basis their efforts to this end, in conformity with the Charter, in order to improve the situation and restore peace, security and stability;
13. Requests the Secretary-General to report to the Security Council on the results of his good offices and diplomatic efforts.
THE FRENCH PEACE PLAN
1. The Security Council invites the Iraqis to announce without delay their intention to withdraw from Iraq on a timetable and to begin a rapid and massive retreat;
2. The Secretary General will propose a plan to monitor and verify the Iraqi retreat by international observers and will put in place a peacekeeping force named by the Arab nations;
3. There will be a guarantee of non-aggression against Iraq;
4. Among other necessary measures to be taken, a meeting will be held with the Arab nations to promote the peace process;

5. This meeting will respect the Security Council resolutions, the members of which will assist the meeting to solve the problems of the region, in particular the Arab-Israeli conflict and the Palestinian problem, at the appropriate time (and under an appropriate structure) conforming to the statement of the Security Council president on December 20, to assure the security, stability and development of that part of the world.

The Security Council,

Canada, Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and United States of America, Romania and France : draft resolution
The Security Council,

Noting that, despite all efforts by the United Nations, Iraq refuses to comply with its obligation to implement resolution 660 (1990) and the above subsequent relevant resolutions, in flagrant contempt of the Council,
Mindful of its duties and responsibilities under the Charter of the United Nations for the maintenance and preservation of international peace and security,
Determined to secure full compliance with its decisions,
Acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations,

SECURITY COUNCIL RESOLUTIONS
RELATING TO PALESTINE AND THE
OCCUPIED TERRITORIES

The Security Council this afternoon resumes its consideration of the action of Palestinian civilians in the occupied territories following yesterday's suspension of the meeting to allow for further consultations.
(For details of yesterday's action and background, see Press Release 45246, issued 19 December.)
Shortly before resumption of the meeting, a new draft resolution, proposed in the course of consultations, was circulated (document S/22022). It reads as follows:
``The Security Council,
``Reaffirming the obligations of Member States under the United Nations Charter,
``Reaffirming further the principle of the inadmissibility of the acquisition of territory by war set forth in Security Council resolution 242 (1967),

``Having received the report of the Secretary-General submitted in accordance with Security Council resolution 672 (1990) on ways and means for ensuring the safety and protection of the Palestinian civilians under Israeli occupation and in particular taking note of paragraphs 20-26 therein (S/21919),

``Taking note of the interest of the Secretary-General to visit and send his envoy to pursue his initiative with the Israeli authorities, as indicated in paragraph 22 of the report of the Secretary-General (S/21919), and of their recent invitation extended to him,

``Gravely concerned at the dangerous deterioration of the situation in all the Palestinian territories occupied by Israel since 1967, including Jerusalem, and at the violence and rising tension in Israel,

``Taking into consideration the statement by the President of the Security Council on 20 December 1990 concerning the method and approach for a comprehensive, just and lasting peace in the Arab-Israeli conflict;

``Recalling its resolutions 607 (1988), 608 (1988), 636 (1989) and 641 (1989) and alarmed by the decision of the Government of Israel to deport four Palestinians from the occupied territories in contravention of its obligations under the Fourth Geneva Convention,
``1. Expresses its appreciation to the Secretary-General for his report contained in document S/21919;
``2. Expresses its grave concern over the rejection by Israel of Security Council resolutions 672 (1990) and 673 (1990);
``3. Deplores the decision by the Government of Israel, the occupying power, to resume deportations of Palestinian civilians in the occupied territories;

``4. Urges the Government of Israel to accept de jure applicability of the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949, to all the territories occupied by Israel since 1967, and to abide scrupulously by the provisions of the said convention;

``5. Calls on the high contracting parties to the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949 to ensure respect by Israel, the occupying Power, for its obligations under the Fourth Geneva Convention in accordance with article 1;

``6. Requests the Secretary-General in co-operation with the International Committee of the Red Cross to develop further the idea from the report of the Secretary-General (S/21919) of convening a meeting of the high contracting parties to the Fourth Geneva Convention and to discuss possible measures that might be taken by them under the Convention and for this purpose to invite these parties to submit their views on how the idea could contribute to the goals of the Convention as well as on other relevant matters and to report to the Council;

``7. Requests the Secretary-General to monitor and observe the situation regarding Palestinian civilians under Israeli occupation, making new efforts in this regard on an urgent basis, and to utilise and designate or draw upon the United Nations and other personnel and resources present there in the area and elsewhere needed to accomplish this task and to keep the Security Council regularly informed;

``8. Requests further the Secretary-General to submit a first progress report to the Security Council by the first week of March 1991, and every four months thereafter and decides to remain seized of the matter as necessary.''

TALK.START.PARA: —The 700 women from 60 countries who constitute World Women Parliamentarians for Peace are not only parliamentarians and peace activists. All bring a wide range of talent and experience with them and many have actually fought for liberation from colonial and dictatorial regimes. They include women like Joyce Mujure, one of the many Zimbabwean combatants who are now members of Parliament. Joyce, at the age of 19 and close to the delivery of her first baby, a little more than 10 years ago, shot down a helicopter. The late Nora Astorga of Nicaragua, also pregnant when she fled to the hills fearful for her life, joined the freedom fighters and subsequently became a representative of Nicaragua at the United Nations. Begum Rehana Sahar, Pakistani Minister for Women's Development in the Bhutto Government, a highly qualified barrister and public prosecutor, saw her husband murdered and went to gaol for supporting Benazir Bhutto who was then also under threat of her life.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Than of Hanoi was gaoled in South Vietnam for her active support of the nationalist regime. Many Soviet women deputies as teenagers took up arms to defend their country against the Nazis. Japanese women lived with the aftermath of the nuclear bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The lives of African and central American women have been shaped by armed struggle.

For these women the quest for peace is the most basic of political principles. They wholeheartedly support the objectives of our network to promote world peace and disarmament through the unified action of women parliamentarians all over the world. They represent a wide range of political philosophies, religions and traditions. A few take a rigid pacifist position. But all, I believe, agree with 160 member nations who in Nairobi in 1985 endorsed the Forward-looking Strategies, the document of the United Nations End of the Decade for Women conference which canvasses a theme of peace, equality and development and states at paragraph 242:

There exist situations in several regions of the world where the violation of principles of non-use of force, non-intervention, non-interference, nonaggression and the right to self-determination endangers international peace and security and creates massive humanitarian problems which constitute an impediment to the advancement of women and hence to the full implementation of the Forward-looking Strategies. In regard to these situations strict adherence to and respect for the cardinal principles enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations and implementation of relevant resolutions consistent with the principles of the Charter are an imperative requirement with a view to seeking solutions to such problems, thereby ensuring a secure and better future for the people affected, most of whom are invariably women and children.

My knowledge of the women of whom I speak leads me to believe that the majority, while deploring violence and working for peace, are well aware of the fact that at some stage the privilege of being members of societies which are member nations of the United Nations will be matched by the responsibility of a practical contribution to achieving peace, as foreshadowed by Dr Evatt in 1945. I would strongly recommend that among the very fine speeches that have preceded mine Minister Nick Bolkus's speech gives an excellent summary of those days and the position of social democratic societies in relation to those issues.

War, unfortunately, engenders xenophobia and bigotry and this one is no different. Women who are assumed to be Arabian, especially those who wear the veil, as they are fully entitled to do, are being harassed and victimised in a cowardly and vicious fashion in some of our cities and suburbs. Many have lived in Australia for years and have Australian born families. They may be from Lebanon, India, Pakistan, Malaysia, Afghanistan or any one of a dozen other countries where modesty of dress is required and the wearing of a headscarf, called the hijab, is traditional. Many are political refugees like my friend, Tajwar, an Afghanistan former freedom fighter who now lives in Western Australia. Thus identified, they are being refused service, abused, and the scarves torn from their heads. Their children are bullied and their husbands provoked.

I call upon all Australians of good will to offer friendship and support to these women particularly. Women themselves can identify with the distress of these possibly Arab women who are far from their close relatives and their motherland, sick with anxiety for their compatriots and relatives. Their final oppression is hostility and insults when they leave their homes. I appeal to Australians, if they know of such families in their neighbourhoods, to make sure that no such victimisation is taking place and offer assistance if it is needed and welcomed, preferably on a community basis. The many fine non-governmental organisations in Australia which pride themselves on community service could well consider how best they can, with sensitivity, extend comfort and encouragement to such families, especially the women who risk being totally isolated in their homes, singled out as they are for abuse and harassment. A society which can set up a very efficient neighbourhood watch system can surely care for the oppressed in its midst. It is worth noting that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has issued a strong statement condemning such acts of racism and that there are Federal and State laws which outlaw behaviour which discriminates against people because of their race.

I noted with interest the description by one of my colleagues, Elaine Darling of the House of Representatives, of war as a social cancer. Despite my disagreement with her conclusions, the analogy is hard to resist. War, like cancer, is malign. It maims, debilitates, invades and destroys creating pain, loss of function, distress and disruption of individuals, families and whole societies as an untreated malignancy does on a more limited scale.

Cancer can be prevented in many cases and so, we hope, can war. Indeed, the United Nations has repeatedly intervened over the years to avert open conflict. But identifying the predisposing causes is a matter of long, hard, social and scientific endeavour. Eliminating the causes through education, persuasion and social progress is costly and time consuming and, above all, requires the cooperation of the parties and community support. In the case of war, that means the 160 strong community of the United Nations.

Cancer can be treated in most cases. In order to stop further invasion and the isolation of the malignancy, the treatment may be very drastic indeed. Reconstruction and rehabilitation can be costly and painful. It is for these very reasons that we must allow the drastic option in the event that other treatment fails. Who now doubts the intransigence and duplicity of Saddam Hussein? There is now on record in Hansard much information about the horrifying abuses of human rights that he has perpetrated over the last years and months and his total refusal to yield to anything but force.

While there are malign forces in the world, the option must remain for timely and appropriate treatment, conservatively when possible, but radically when the balance of informed opinion so determines. The statement made by Perez de Cuellar, and already incorporated this evening, is moving and sincere. They are the words of a leader who has pledged his and the United Nations commitment to continue to work for a peaceful resolution.

The world's need of the United Nations is unarguable. This war is a tragedy, however one views it, for individuals, for the countries of the Middle East, and for the peace loving peoples and nations of the world. A greater tragedy would be to lose the hard won confidence in the United Nations, so important for the security of the many smaller and medium sized nations, nations whose people are dependent upon the United Nations and the greater world community for amelioration of the perennial problems that they cannot resolve on their own-civil wars, abuses of human rights, displacement of whole populations, malnutrition, disease, lack of fuel and clean water, illiteracy, maternal and child mortality-the list goes on.

Being of the generation which lived through the anxious years of the Cold War and the arms build up-and build down subsequently-the proliferation of nuclear weapons et cetera, and agonised over the regular use of the veto in the Security Council, many of us have come to depend heavily on the principles of the instruments of the United Nations, the imperatives that provided the basis for the defence of human rights and human dignity. The United Nations did not previously have the power; there simply was not the consensus to endorse intervention on the scale that we are witnessing in 1991. It is an historical fact.

This is a development, one for which we have waited for a long time. But in many other ways, support has slowly, painstakingly been nurtured for crucial initiatives, both bilaterally and multilaterally. Peacekeeping forces in otherwise war torn countries, nuclear free zones, progress on a chemical weapons ban, even progress on the comprehensive test ban treaty, wide support for new instruments such as the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women and the Convention on the Rights of the Child, the work of the United Nations Human Rights Commission, the High Commission on Refugees, conventions on apartheid, capital punishment, treatment of prisoners of war-these are just a few of the real triumphs of international diplomacy, each success adding to the status and potential of the United Nations to produce a real improvement in living standards and a real possibility of peace sometime in the future.
We support the United Nations for all these and other very good reasons. As I said initially, I have no hesitation in supporting the motion which we are debating tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the world emerged from the smouldering ruins of the Second World War, a conflict which claimed 60 million lives, humanity vowed that such a catastrophe should never happen again. Tired of war, world leaders looked to provide for peace. It was in these circumstances that they came to form the United Nations, vowing to beat their swords into ploughshares, and promising to create a new world order.

SPEECH.PARA: The blueprint for that new world order was embodied in the Charter of the United Nations, which stated certain fundamental principles. Among these were the right of people everywhere to live in peace and happiness, the right of peoples to self-determination, and the right of every sovereign state to exist free from attack within its own borders. These are the principles in which I believe very strongly, and principles which my generation holds dear, even if we do at times take them for granted.

But, Mr Deputy President, the Charter of the United Nations is more than just a statement of principles because it sets out the rules which govern relations between nations. It provides for the General Assembly, for the Security Council and for the International Court of Justice for the pacific settlement of disputes. Here we come to the interesting part, because after fighting for six years against a dictator who was not willing and did not believe in the peaceful settlement of disputes, those world leaders also allowed for the use of force, if all else failed, against those who would not live by the rules.

Unfortunately, the past 45 years have seen too many dictators who would not live by the rules, and the consequence has been the suffering of millions of innocent people under the terror of Stalin, of Mao Tse-Tung, of Deng Xiao-Ping. And on and on the list continues-Tito, Ceaucescu, Khomini, Idi Amin, Gaddafi and, lately, Saddam Hussein. In short, the years following the Second World War largely failed to bring about the new world order which so many people desired.

In 1989, however, an event occurred which had the potential to change all of that-it was the fall of the Berlin Wall-because the collapse of communism has made possible the attainment of that new world order for which we have struggled so long. This is the challenge that my generation readily embraces; this is the challenge we must all embrace, to create not just a better town or state or even a nation, but to create a better world.

It is so ironic, therefore, at a time when peace was more than just a possibility-it was a real chance for the world-that it should be shattered by the brutal Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on 2 August 1990. Let us take this opportunity right here and now to examine why Saddam Hussein chose to make his bloody attack; why he sent his tanks to crush a peaceful nation, and why he chose to plunge the world down the path to war. What was his justification? I will tell you what his justification was: he said that Iraq had an historical claim to Kuwait. But then Hitler said that Germany had an historical claim to Austria; Mussolini said Italy had a claim to Abyssinia, and Stalin alleged that Russia had a title to the Baltic states.

All of these tyrants were wrong. All of them used such lies as a basis for oppression and terror, and all of them should have been stopped in their tracks. Honourable senators, Saddam Hussein should be stopped in his tracks. Hussein's every action in this regard smacks of deceit and treachery. He recognised the Kuwaiti Government, he called those in that Government his brothers in the Arab League, he borrowed billions of dollars from them to finance his war with Iran, and then he sent his troops, his tanks and his guns in the dead of night to take what was not his. That is how Kuwait was crushed, and that is why Kuwait must be set free.

But Saddam Hussein's perversity did not end there. He tried to call his war a holy war, even though he was fighting against his fellow Muslims. He even tried to link Kuwait with Palestine and then launched rockets against Israel, which he knew full well could kill Palestinian and Israeli alike. But the worst, the sickest and the most depraved act of all was to hold innocent people hostage to protect his strategic sites from attack, and to call these people his guests. These actions alone-and one can add to them his brutal reign of terror and his development of weapons of mass destruction-demanded that the world respond.

The world has responded: world leaders have urged Hussein to leave Kuwait; millions of ordinary people have prayed for peace; the United Nations passed resolutions; it imposed sanctions and embargoes, and all to no avail. While we are on the subject of sanctions we should mention the thousands of Australian farmers who are our second front against Saddam Hussein. For five months now, these men and women have had to pay the cost of the sanctions in lost markets for live sheep, for wheat and other grains. The wool industry too, just as it was recovering from its Government imposed crisis, has suffered falls in the amount of wool purchased at auction by the trade. The Government has to realise, therefore, that it has a moral and political obligation to ensure that the cost of the sanctions is borne equally by the community. If that means compensation for lost markets or collapsed prices, then so be it.

The sanctions are the Government's work and I support them. Many would say that the rural recession is in a large part the Government's part too, although of course I do not support that situation. I just take this opportunity therefore to remind the Government at this hour of crisis to look after the people who work the land and to stand up for Australia's farmers just as they are helping to stand up on our behalf to Saddam Hussein.

Unfortunately, while sanctions are an important part of the international effort, they will not do the job on their own. Sanctions have had five months to work and yet Saddam Hussein remains as unrepentant and as intransigent as before. I am well aware that there are people who say we must give the sanctions more time, but we must weigh against this the fact that every single day that passes increases Hussein's stranglehold on Kuwait; every single day that passes increases his opportunity to dig in and to fortify his position; and every single day that passes means that, when the inevitable assault to liberate Kuwait begins, more and more lives of young servicemen from the United States of America and other coalition countries will be lost. More and more lives will be lost in Kuwait as Saddam continues his reign of brutal oppression.

The question I ask, therefore, is how many women have to be raped, how many babies have to be ripped from incubators, and how many innocent people have to be tortured and murdered before we come to learn that a craven peace paid for at a dictator's asking price does not save any lives. It only makes life more unbearable for those who have to suffer the oppression every hour of every day of every week.

This was a question the Security Council had to face when it came to debate resolution 678, and this is why Iraq was given until 15 January to get out of Kuwait or face the consequences. But the diplomacy did not end even then. Secretary of State, James Baker, met with the Iraqi Foreign Minister in Geneva. We saw representations from the Yemenis, the French, the Soviets and others, and all without success. Finally, and perhaps most importantly, the Secretary-General of the United Nations went to Baghdad with hope in his heart and peace on his lips, only to return with despair on his brow.

It is this exhaustion of diplomacy, not by the United Nations but by Saddam Hussein, which has led to the resort to war. That is why, even as we speak, the forces of 28 nations representing the brotherhood of humanity are serving in the Gulf. And these are not heartless killers; these are men and women who love and laugh as we do, men and women who more than anyone else have a vested interest in peace but who are willing to lay down their lives in the hope that their sons and daughters will never have to do so.

What is at stake is more than just oil, and more than just Kuwait; it is the future of the world for the next 50 years. That is why we are involved in conflict. It is because we recognise the importance of principle and the right of people everywhere to live free of terror and intimidation, and instead in the happiness and security of their own homes. For these reasons, the Kuwaiti border is more than just a line scratched in the desert sands. It is a place where praxis and principle have met in an effort to provide for peace.

Allow me to address too the peace movement, which claims so vociferously to believe in peace. To them I say that I too believe in peace, but that peace and freedom are always hard fought and hard come by and often easily lost. For me the importance of peace is that it is an expression of our love for our fellow man. It seems strange to me, therefore, that many of the people who claim to be interested in peace seem to thrive so much on hate. As the Bible so eloquently says:
Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends.
That is why I support the efforts of our service men and women in the Gulf, and that is why I support the actions of the coalition forces.

Let us not forget either that Australia's freedoms were preserved in the Second World War only by the sacrifice of Australian, American and other servicemen who fought the evil tide of Japanese expansionism at the cost of their own lives. This is the legacy which we have inherited and the obligation we owe to other members of the community of nations.

Australia, along with its allies, is embarked upon a struggle intrinsic to the fate of future generations. It is a struggle to secure for them an inheritance as fundamental to mankind as life itself. It is a struggle for freedom. The choice we must take, therefore, is to stand up for freedom, to stand up for peace and to stand up to Saddam Hussein. If we do this, we have made our contribution to the creation of a better world so that whenever tyranny, violence and terror threaten freedom, law and order, no nation shall stand alone, for the whole of the civilised world will be there too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been made clear in the debate that war is a foul instrument and that everybody in this chamber, and I think in the other place, regards it as such. Its aim is to destroy, to kill, to overthrow with violence, to subdue, to conquer. As Pope John Paul II says, `War is an adventure with no return'. Any person with instincts abhors it. Not one person, as I say, in this place or in the other has lightly counselled armed intervention in the Middle East. Conscious of the awful gravity of advice, it has been for all a matter of the most solemn concern.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two sides fighting the present war: Iraq and the United Nations. Australia, as a founding member of that organisation, has given it moral and material support. Many speakers in this debate have pressed cogent reasons for it to do so. Others have argued strongly against the war and our part in it. The Hansards of yesterday and today will contain a permanent record of the comprehensive cases put forward supporting the various courses urged upon us as proper for Australians to take in the present crisis. That record will show strong arguments for and against our present commitment. This being so, whatever view is taken of the war with Iraq, understanding should be given by each side of the community debate to the other, and that is a point that has been made again and again today. At times there is a tendency on the part of both sides to belittle the other, to impugn its integrity and to treat it as delinquent in its civic duty. That is a most unhappy situation.

While robust debate enhances democracy, intolerance, carping, poorly-formed criticism and the false attribution of ill-motives to others do not. Fortunately, the debate over the last two days, and indeed in the community generally, has in the main been informed and reasonable. In this context, the stance that most people in this country have taken towards their brothers and sisters of Arabic background and of the Muslim faith has been quite superb. That is a point again that has been made here. The cruel and bullying actions against them have been roundly condemned by most of their fellow Australians, and so they should.

It is abhorrent to see self-appointed vigilantes attack within the safety and comfort of these shores, men, women and children because of their race, religion or supposed loyalties. Such vigilantes are in no way to be compared to the courageous and dedicated people who, in serving their country, have gone into the dangers of the battle zone. They deserve our highest gratitude and praise.

In this context, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has acted with high principle and great leadership in his rejection of the racism and intolerance shown towards those with an Arabic background and of the Islamic faith. His actions will be written into history.

Pope John Paul II, with others in the spiritual ministry, has counselled peace and turned humbly to God seeking it. I do not know whether people outside Victoria saw the prayer service in St Paul's cathedral in Melbourne on 14 January. It was marvellous. Religious leaders of the Muslim community, of the Jewish congregation and of different Christian denominations gathered together to ask the Almighty for harmony in the world. Tragically, the efforts of those committed people and others throughout the world like them have not prevented war. Hopefully, they can bring justice to the settlement which must come when the armed conflict ceases. Whether or not we believe in God, we must hope that this will happen.

A lot of the debate over the last two days, which has been excellent, has turned on the question of whether or not we ought to go to war in the Middle East. The fact of the matter is that we have done so already-if not in August of last year, certainly in January of this year. So we cannot prevent war but we must not allow a flawed peace to follow. To that end, we should now look for an effective and sensible strategy to resolve the divisive issues in the Middle East. Without this, loss of life and property in the present conflict will be squandered. It is not an effective and sensible strategy to thwart the aggression of Saddam Hussein and do no more.

The Palestinians in Gaza and on the West Bank must be given their due as full members of the human community. The people in Lebanon have rights which during the last decade have been grievously abused-they must be redressed. The Kurds have been most horribly used and their situation must be looked at. What should we do about the most unhappy unease that exists between the Muslim faith and the Western philosophy? Something will have to be done about that. How can we ensure that Israel has safe and secure borders and is allowed to enjoy the peace and harmony that countries like ourselves do? Who do we leave in charge of the oil supplies in the Middle East? What do we do with Kuwait? What are we going to do with Iraq?

It seems to me that these are the questions that we should be answering now so that when the end of hostilities does come, what we put in place is a lot better than what was there before. In my view, that is going to be a very hard task indeed. We certainly will need a lot of goodwill from a lot of people and from a lot of nations. Given the present conflict, that might be very difficult to obtain. Fortunately, in my case the question of whether or not we should have gone to war need not be answered. I remember, early in my career in the law hearing judges and being advised, `If you don't have to answer a question, don't do so'. As I say, most of the debate has been good, but there have been some things put, fairly harshly, that I would like to answer. The Democrats, Senator Vallentine, Manning Clark and those who have advocated peace have been accused by some as being appeasers. The history of the thirties has been pointed out as the lesson that ought to be followed.

As somebody else has pointed out, there are many wars that we can look at to see whether or not peace should have been discussed before actions were taken. Today when some senators accuse others of being appeasers, and of not standing up with armed forces to put aggressors to flight, we ought to look at what we have done today. A motion was put by Senator Hill-I must say that his speech on the debate before us was excellent-in reference to the actions of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania.

In the context of where those who have been striving for peace and advocating discussions have been castigated, I would have thought that there would have been something in Senator Hill's motion stating that if the Soviet troops did not withdraw we were going to take appropriate action through the United Nations, including resort to arms. But as I look through the motion I see that the most it seems to do is protest and continue to protest and call on the Soviet Government to facilitate the peaceful transition to independence of these republics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that not the first stage of negotiation?

—There is nothing in that motion that talks about the armed struggle and the need to stand up to the aggressor. All I say to Senator Walters is that when we condemn others for being, in effect, wimps, appeasers and what have you, we ought to look at what we do. We ought to look at what we have done about Tibet-which used to be an independent country-as far as China is concerned. We should look at what we did when the Russians went into Afghanistan and all the other instances that have been referred to during this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: People have spoken about the abuse of human rights and have quoted material provided by Amnesty International, as evidence of the cruelty which has been perpetrated by the Iraqis in Kuwait. It has been said that such action and the trampling down of human rights ought to evoke an armed response.

There are two things I want to say about that. Firstly, the material that Amnesty International puts out does not contain, as far as I can establish-perhaps somebody in this chamber can tell me where I can find it-any suggestion that in defence of people's rights armed conflict ought to be undertaken. Indeed, what it seems to suggest is that letters be written and that diplomatic pressure be imposed. It seems to me that we ought to be very careful in using the abuse of human rights as a reason for going to war.

On the other hand, it is said that sanctions should be used. The only difficulty that I have with that-again it has been pointed out in this place today-is that the longer we look to sanctions to work the more secure Saddam Hussein becomes in Kuwait. It seems to me that, whereas people may have disagreed on many other matters, what nobody seems to have disagreed upon is the fact that he should not be there and the fact that he should be made to go.

Secondly, I find that many of the reasons put forward to invite our armed intervention, such as the abuse of human rights-dreadful as that might be-and intrusion onto other countries' territory, given the history of the way we have acted in respect of other instances where those sorts of things have occurred, are less compelling than they might have been had we acted consistently throughout. On the other hand, I do not think it can be said that because we have countenanced the abuse of human rights and the invasion of territories in other instances we should not act when it happens in this instance. The United Nations has said sanctioned the use of force. As has been said again and again in this debate, the United Nations determined that we take that particular approach in this instance.

If we accept the United Nations as the proper instrument of some form of world order-no matter how defective it may be-and if we adhere to that and intend to keep doing so, then when it advocates a particular line of action in reference to a particular country and a particular person, that ought to be adopted, unless we want to get out of the United Nations and see it fall into disrepute.

There are many inconsistencies in the actions we take, in that we seem to be courageous in some instances and not in others. We seem to be conscious of people's rights in some areas and not in others. Nevertheless, where we have a particular instrument we look to to institute some sort of world order and world peace and harmony, we should support it.

As one reads through the volumes of material put out by Amnesty International, one sees that the tragedy existing around the world is almost beyond endurance. We have spoken about the babies being thrown from their humidicribs in Kuwait. We should also remember the children that were shot in the streets of Brazil because, according to a sign hung round the neck of one, they `did not study and had no future'. Where those things have occurred we have been selective in our reaction.

I support the motion put forward by the Government. In my view, it is the best that can be done given the situation in which we find ourselves. The world is not perfect. We cannot argue in terms of absolutes. We cannot act as moral superiors to other people, given the disasters and the dreadful abuse of rights of all sorts that have gone unanswered around the world. But it seems to me that when we do get the world together and there is an opportunity, as offered by the United Nations in this instance, to stop a person whose stance nobody has defended, it is an opportunity we must take.

It is well to remember that we are all in need of redemption and that when we do criticise each other, whether for being warmongers on the one hand or appeasers on the other, that hardly creates an atmosphere which will bring forth the new order we all so desperately hope for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to support the motion presently before the Senate-one of the most important motions that has come before the Australian Parliament in many generations. The war to liberate Kuwait in which Australia is now participating has arisen quite simply as the result of the actions and intransigence of only one man. The United States Secretary of State, James Baker, explained it well when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: A dangerous man has committed a blatant act of aggression in a vital region at a critical moment in history.

Honourable senators will know that on 29 November the Security Council of the United Nations passed an extremely grave resolution. That resolution was momentous and in some respects quite unprecedented. Resolution 678 authorised member states of the United Nations from 15 January 1991 to use all necessary means to uphold and implement the Security Council's previous resolutions on the Gulf crisis. Essentially those previous resolutions called on Iraq to withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait and to release all hostages. The resolution also requested all states to provide appropriate support for actions taken under the resolution. The words `all necessary means' carry a clear meaning in this resolution. They encompass the use of armed force to compel compliance with the Security Council's resolutions.

The fact that both superpowers were prepared, with four other nations, to sponsor this resolution shows in the most concrete terms that the nations of the world are overwhelmingly united in their condemnation of Iraq's aggression and in their determination to do whatever it takes to use all necessary means to make sure that Iraq's aggression is not allowed to stand.

The easy option was always to extend the embargo indefinitely to allow matters to drift on and to play into the hands of Saddam Hussein by that process. But, acting properly and capably, the United Nations set about the task of bringing forward, in a responsible way, resolutions to address all that is involved in the Middle East. That culminated in resolution 678 which was in fact sponsored by no fewer than six countries. It is interesting to note that they were the United States of America, Great Britain, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, France, Canada, and Romania under its new administration.

We now know that embargoes and sanctions as such would not have in themselves been effective in liberating Kuwait. Indeed, the Iraqis were effectively toughing out the circumstances, and with varying degrees of success they carried on with their annexation of Kuwait and a number of other horrific activities which have been outlined by a number of senators during this current debate.

As the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said in the other place back in December, this is one of the gravest tests of the international community since 1945. It will certainly affect the nature of international relations and the security of independent states for years to come. That is why Australia cannot do nothing, and why it is correct in the world's interests and in Australia's strategic and economic interests to respond, and to respond in a manifestly correct way.

It has been necessary that we respond to these actions of Saddam Hussein for a variety of very simple reasons, and they are, firstly, that no nation has the right to invade another nation, no matter what the so-called provocation. The second point is that Saddam knows that by controlling oil he can control the economies of the Western world. I ask how long would it have been before he would have been looking with greedy eyes at the oil fields of Saudi Arabia? Let me reiterate that Saddam Hussein never went into Kuwait to resolve the Palestinian question; he went into Kuwait as a blatant act of aggression to ensure greater supplies of oil and thus control the Western world.

Thirdly, just like Kuwait, Australia is a middle power which would rely on the United Nations to come to its aid in times of trouble, and as such we have a responsibility to that union of nations to take action when called upon to protect the rights of others. The fourth point is that the argument to use the Palestinian question is purely disinformation which, I might add, is propagated by many of our so-called peace activists. The fifth point I want to mention is that this man must be stopped before he has the capability to use far greater and more destructive weapons on other nations. I can tell many of the peace activists that this man would think nothing of using those destructive weapons. Saddam Hussein has already used poisonous gas on his own people, so we now know what we are up against. He has executed some of his closest colleagues in the most horrific circumstances, and of course his use of hostages as human shields is totally unacceptable. What did we see in the Australian headlines this morning? We saw this:
Iraq threatens to use POWs as human shields.

I just want to tell all these doubters of the true intentions of this man. He is no great saviour of the Palestinian or Muslim people. He is a ruthless dictator bent on glorifying himself in the annals of Arab history, and at the cost of other lives-the lives he lost in the Iran-Iraq war, the lives he lost when gassing the Kurdish people, the lives lost while defending Kuwait. Mr Don Chipp, who was the Leader of the Australian Democrats in this place for many years, writing in the Sunday Times on 6 January said:
No Middle East observer holds any doubt that Israel would be subjected to a massive attack from Saddam Hussein of poison gas, biological and possibly nuclear weapons within two years.

Yet we hear the Democrats in this place talk about giving him time. Time for what-more murder, torture and terrorism? This is one of the reasons I believe that the right action has been taken in so far as he has to be stopped. We did not want to use appeasement like Neville Chamberlain did in the last World War, and about which Senator Bishop spoke so clearly, distinctly and forcibly here in the Senate this evening.

Saddam Hussein is not a great leader of his nation. A great leader would have known what the world meant when it passed resolution 678. He chooses to ignore this because he thinks he is greater than the rest of the world. I want to tell the Senate that except for the swift action of the United States and the rest of the world it would not have been long at all before he would have been marching into other countries.
I support the decision made by the Australian Government to send our naval contingent, as well as other military and medical personnel, to the Persian Gulf.

I want to make a few comments about the demonstrators for peace to whom the media is so keen to give a lot of publicity and credence. No-one-I repeat, no-one-really wants war. We all want peace, but peace does not always come with the absence of war. This is a point I particularly want to emphasise to the Democrats who seem to think that we will have peace if we let Saddam Hussein have his way and keep Kuwait. This, I believe, is completely wrong.

Senator Powell says, `Let's give peace a chance'. This is what all the folk who have been marching and demonstrating have been saying- `Let's give peace a chance'. I do not believe we want peace at any price. Of course, that is what Neville Chamberlain did during the last war. It is a long time ago, but I can remember back to the days when Neville Chamberlain was trying to appease Germany. I can remember thinking, `Oh, yes, we don't want war. Won't it be lovely if he can stop it'. Sure enough, he stopped it, but it did not last for very long and in another 12 months the war started. In those extra 12 months Germany had been making extra weapons and that country and all the countries that Hitler had annexed were very hard to beat. That is something that we have to remember in the case that we are thinking about here in the Parliament at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has had the last five months.

—As Senator Brownhill reminds us, Saddam Hussein has had an extra five months and he is getting more weapons all the time. This is something that we have to remember. Of course, `Let's have peace' is a message that is undoubtedly appealing to a significant minority of Australians. We have seen and heard a lot from the demonstrators in the last couple of days; a lot of noise and a lot of calls for `Let's have peace'. I have been very dismayed, like a lot of other senators, about the behaviour of so many of the peace people in the Senate yesterday. I believe that if they want to get up and scream and shout, and use words that I do not believe should be used in the Senate-in fact, I do not think they should be used anywhere, let alone in the Senate-let them become senators or members of parliament. Then they can come and say what they want to in this place and we will listen to them, even if we do not agree with them.

SPEECH.PARA: Peace is something which we earn. It does not come automatically. It is something that all people have to defend and be willing to fight for. Peace is not the absence of war. It is the right to freedom, and the right to exercise that freedom. It is the security to know that one has the right and the opportunity to achieve legitimate aims and not be under threat by other powers, whether they are rulers or nations. I want to quote from that greatest of authors, Anonymous, as follows:

War is an ugly thing, but not the ugliest of things. The decayed and degraded state of moral feeling which thinks nothing worth a war is worse . . . a man who has nothing which he cares more about than his self-preservation is a miserable creature who has no chance of being free unless made so and kept so by the existence of better men than himself.

I ask these demonstrators for peace: what about the peace for the people of Kuwait since the invasion in August? Are they not entitled to peace? What about peace for the people of Israel, a country which has chosen to stay out of this conflict, yet one which Saddam Hussein has been using with deliberate obfuscation to try to drag into the war and thus justify his actions in Kuwait? Do the peace marchers think the people of Israel have peace when, every day and night, they carry their gas masks around with them?

These peace marchers we see on the streets appear to be more keen on demonstrating against the United States than actually seeking peace. We have not seen them demonstrating outside the Iraqi Embassy. Why, I ask, when it is Iraq that started this war when it invaded Kuwait? It is Iraq which is the initial aggressor in this conflict.

Finally, let me remind those who are listening that the objectives for this military action in the Persian Gulf are clear. They are not ambiguous; the goals are well defined and familiar. Iraq must be kicked out of Kuwait completely, and Kuwait's legitimate government must be restored. The security and stability of the Persian Gulf must be assured. Citizens abroad must be protected.

These goals are not the goals of any one nation. They have been endorsed by the United Nations Security Council numerous times. Most countries share these concerns for principle, and many have a stake in the stability of the Persian Gulf. This war is not, as Saddam Hussein and others would have it, the United States against Iraq. It is Iraq against the world. Let me quote from President Bush's address to the joint session of Congress in September last year as follows:
We stand at a unique and extraordinary moment. The crisis in the Persian Gulf, as grave as it is, also offers a rare opportunity to move towards an historic period of cooperation.

Out of these troubled times . . . a new world order can emerge: a new era-freer from the threat of terror, stronger in the pursuit of justice, and more secure in the quest for peace. An era in which the nations of the world, east and west, north and south, can prosper and live in harmony.
A hundred generations have searched for this illusive path to peace, while a thousand wars raged across the span of human endeavour.

Today that new world is struggling to be born. A world quite different from the one we've known. A world where the rule of law supplants the rule of the jungle. A world in which nations recognise the shared responsibility for freedom and justice. A world where the strong respect the rights of the weak.

I wish to pay a tribute to our men and women who are serving in our naval forces in the Gulf area. We thank them for the part they are playing with the allied forces as they endeavour to bring peace to our world again. It is important that we remember in our prayers not only those who are in the war area but also their dear ones who are at home, hoping that it will not be long before the war is over and their dear ones return home.

I am happy to support this motion before us this evening. As a member of the National Party of Australia and the coalition I have been glad to have this opportunity of adding my words of support to the motion before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have opposed the war from the start. This is a war that has already wreaked, and will continue to wreak, massive carnage in the Middle East. The question that we must ask ourselves is: is the strategy contained in the motion one that will work? I do not believe it will. I oppose President Bush's dangerous and simplistic rush to war. It will not bring peace or a satisfactory political settlement to the troubled area of the Middle East, in my view. It will not result in a new world order because a new world order cannot be created in a place like the Middle East through the barrel of a gun.

SPEECH.PARA: I add my voice to the 47 1/2 per cent of senators in the United States of America, the 42 per cent of the members of the United States Congress and the cry across the world against the premature use of force. Sanctions were not given time to work. I believe that President Bush will be judged harshly by history for his handling of this issue. However, my criticism of the Bush Administration should not in any way detract from the absolute condemnation that I join with other senators in making of Hussein and the blood thirsty regime he presides over.
I believe that economic sanctions were the effective strategy to follow. As the United States Democrat senator Sam Nunn said of them:
We are playing a winning hand. I see no reason to use military actions.
Max Stauffer, a Middle East expert from the John Hopkins University in the United States of America, said:
We're witnessing one of the few cases in the history where economic sanctions are actually working. Only essential items like food are trickling through the blockade.
The country's economy has been grinding inexorably to a halt.
Iraq is a natural for economic sanctions: its dependence on oil is overwhelming.

Mr Stauffer estimates that petroleum made up 75 per cent of the economy in direct and indirect connections, making it very vulnerable with consumer disposable income cut in half or more during that time. Iraq's oil revenues, which provided 95 per cent, or if one believes the Central Intelligence Agency, 97 per cent, of its foreign exchange were already down, having dropped 20 per cent by July last year.

Not only was Iraq a natural for sanctions but also at the time sanctions were imposed the internal situation in Iraq was such that they had an even greater chance of success. The public sector wages in Iraq were at starvation levels and guest workers were being harassed into leaving the country or accepting deteriorating pay and conditions. The promised liberalisation, both in the political and economic systems, were in limbo under the Hussein regime. It was becoming clear that the Government there had no solutions. United Nations sanctions were imposed on Iraq at a time when it was rich in discontent.

There is no question that Hussein is a rogue presiding over a regime that has been guilty of every human rights abuse. However, I believe that Hussein feared this restive population. He knew that as the months rolled on the sanctions would bite deeply. He preferred war now-and this is the important point-with a relatively united people rather than face sanctions over a period when his regime would be challenged from within.

Unfortunately, President Bush, in escalating the level and the speed of American military involvement, has denied the world the chance of a successful United Nations economic sanctions model. That is a great tragedy. United States Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, when he attacked the Bush Administration for abandoning sanctions in favour of the military option, quoted a string of administration officials who had testified that sanctions were biting. Mitchell said:
Inexplicably however on November 8th Mr Bush had ordered the doubling of US forces in the Gulf.

In effect, the President, without any consultation and without any public debate, changed American policy. He said that the grave decision for war was made prematurely. As I said earlier, I believe that history will judge President Bush harshly, particularly if the war is protracted, and the news tonight is that we face a protracted war.

When President Bush doubled the size of America's military involvement on 8 November, he changed military confrontation from an action of last resort to his preferred option. We remember that up to the United States congressional elections taking place in November last year he said that sanctions were working. Senator Robert Bird summed the situation up perfectly in the New York Times when he said:

. . . a superpower has claws and it has teeth. The superpower, as against this third world power, doesn't have to be impatient or impetuous. A superpower doesn't have to feel rushed. We can afford to be patient and let sanctions work. They say the morale of our soldiers will suffer. Mr President, we should have thought about this before we proceeded to double our forces and terminate the rotation policy in the Middle East.

That is the situation that existed at that time. The hypocrisy of the military solution to the current crisis in the Gulf is further exposed when we look at the attitude of the United States Administration towards Iraq prior to the invasion of Kuwait. Professor Robert Springborg in the Australian Journal of International Affairs, in an article on the origins of the Gulf crisis, points out that the historical records show that from 1988 to 1990 the United States Administration supported Iraq and worked assiduously to head off congressional attempts to chastise Saddam for human rights abuses, violation of bilateral economic agreements and attempts to smuggle weapon technology out of the United States.

The Senate initiative led by Clairbourne Pell and Jesse Helms to impose sanctions on Iraq for using poisonous gas against its Kurdish population was defeated by the Reagan Administration in the House. The United States declined to join 12 other Western nations in demanding a United Nations inquiry into Iraq's treatment of its own population. The United States Administration sacked a voice of an American employee who had presented editorials critical of Iraq's human rights record. President Bush refused to join worldwide appeals for clemency for the British Iranian journalist and alleged spy, Farzad Bazoft.

In the weeks before the invasion, the United States Administration, increasingly under pressure for its pro-Iraq policy, shifted its justification to the position that trade sanctions would hurt American farmers and businessmen without swaying Baghdad in the least.

In July 1990, last year, the Bush Administration-I repeat, the Bush Administration-opposed trade sanctions in the Congress. On 25 July the United States Ambassador to Iraq was instructed to assure Saddam that the United States had no position on this dispute with Kuwait. Most significantly of all, two days before the invasion, the State Department declared that the United States had no obligation to come to Kuwait's aid if it was attacked.

So I find it very strange when people talk about appeasement, as did Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Bishop before her. Mention Chamberlain and it is a bit embarrassing when one considers the hypocrisy of President Bush and, before him, President Reagan's Administration. Because of the great respect for the institution of the American presidency and the fact that we are at war, there is a natural reluctance to criticise President Bush, to subject his actions to critical analysis. But the sordid support for Hussein for years; the supply of arms-of course, that occurred with many other countries-the intelligence during the Iran war and the political support, even up to two days before the invasion, are an indictment of President Bush. That is my position.

I join with all those who have expressed the hope that the United Nations will become a more effective organisation with the end of the Cold War. Senator Giles's speech earlier tonight most eloquently outlined that position that we, in the Australian Labor Party, have long held dear. We have championed the United Nations since its inception.

I respect all those who have the view that they must support this motion because of the United Nations' involvement. I appreciate their sincere belief that this will lead to a strengthening of the United Nations. But when I see the United States using the United Nations as a rallying call today, I cannot help but remember that both the Reagan and the Bush administrations have spent the last 10 years disparaging the United Nations at every opportunity.

In the past the United States has refused to pay its dues and has ignored the ruling of the United Nations International Court of Justice against the United States mining of harbours in Nicaragua. That was not so long ago; perhaps people have selectively forgotten it.

Today we have a completely different situation-we have the exact opposite. Now the United States is the main support for the United Nations, carrying 90 per cent or so of the human and economic burden in this war. The US is the enforcer for the United Nations and, as such, it cannot afford to get tired. This is the point I want to make. If the prolonged ground war which is now being predicted happens, America may get tired. It may get tired if it is a protracted war with heavy US casualties. As has been pointed out in the US media, this could be the last attempt at such a solution if the war drags on because the United States will carry the burden both in human and financial commitment.

My concern is that if the United Nations fails in the Middle East and if volatile public opinion turns against costly involvement in the Middle East, instead of ushering in a new world order we will see the United States in particular retreat to isolation, which previously has been a characteristic in its history.

My criticism of President Bush might cause people to think that I am being anti-American. Nothing could be further from the truth because a great deal of my opposition is based on United States sources. After all, President Bush took a divided Congress into the war. While I appreciate that during the war the criticism will be muted, I believe that that divided country will be very critical in a short time if, as I suspect, this war becomes more protracted than we might have been led to believe at first.

My opposition to the war is also based on a need I feel to articulate a genuine opposition, shared by countless thousands of people in my State, to the war. I have been active in the peace and disarmament movement in my State for over 30 years. For the past 10 years I have been the convener of the Sydney Nuclear Disarmament Coordinating Committee. We have organised each year a Palm Sunday march and rally. Several times during the past decade we have had over 150,000 people march through the streets of Sydney. Several times the number of people who turn out has gone up and down. But I must answer the criticisms made of the peace movement by so many honourable senators in this debate because once again people are marching. They are expressing their basic democratic right to show their concern. Some 10,000 or 20,000 people may be marching in Sydney or Melbourne, and I can assure honourable senators that those numbers will increase.

As a result of my involvement, I regret some of the attacks that have been made. It is pretty easy to pick on young people sitting in the gallery who are inexperienced and who are reacting emotionally because they are very concerned. I think all the pros in this chamber know they are attacking straw people. I think it would be far fairer if people such as Senator Bjelke-Petersen, who just spoke, acknowledged that the peace movement is simply a mass movement of people who are agitated and concerned about the threat of war, instead of criticising these abstract people. This Parliament ignores at its own peril the views of such a broad cross- section of the community which opposes the escalation of war.

I suggest that the priority should be a dialogue between the Government, the Parliament and concerned people. Certainly that is what I will be attempting to do. I believe it is essential that we increase the community's understanding of the complexity of the issues involved, particularly in the Middle East. For example, I for one do not accept that everybody in the peace movement is reacting with little knowledge. They will not get a lot if they are watching television.
