They will not necessarily get both sides of the story watching American television. I think it is essential that we try to have debate in the community.

I praise everybody. I think the debate in this Parliament has been part of that process. I certainly commend it. I think the contributions from all parts of the chamber have been excellent. I have no doubt that the peace movement will organise at a higher and better level in the universities, schools, workplaces and churches and conduct seminars, teach-ins and discussions, which are essential in raising the level of debate. Rather than abuse people, I believe we should all encourage this debate. Abuse on any side of the argument is absolutely destructive and should be rejected.

As a result of the nature of the peace movement, one might forget its many component parts. I would firstly like to mention the present outstanding unity, which I have not seen before, within the religious community-within all the churches and the Muslim faith. People from the various churches and the Muslim faith are actually working together. This is very inspiring. They are participating in the rallies and in the discussions which have taken place. They are concerned about the casualties and the suffering of the war, including the refugees. Many are concerned about the issues I previously mentioned, and particularly whether war was only an action of last resort. They are troubled that the war will not promote a just peace and, with all of us, they are concerned about the environmental, human and psychological damage caused by a war that will last for generations.

I have petitions and letters from officers of some of the largest unions in Australia who have expressed to me their concern and opposition to the war. They have many different views, and that is my point. I feel that I have a responsibility to try to bring their views to the attention of the Parliament and the people. If possible, I have a responsibility finally to get a consensus in order to reach agreement in Australia to encourage the excellent initiative that Prime Minister Hawke announced only this week in trying to work with other world leaders. I commend him for that. It was an initiative which resulted from discussions in the Government party. I believe that sort of thing is very commendable and should happen even more often than it has until now. The views of the people whom I have described and of members of political parties must be taken into consideration; I believe it is absolutely essential that discussion takes place.

There are many other problems. The issue of the Palestinian homeland is a tragedy which must be addressed. If there is one strange thing-and not because of what Saddam Hussein has said-it is that people across the world now recognise that finally the issue of justice for the Palestinians has reached fruition. I commend that at least as one of the positive things to arise from this conflict. For the reasons I have outlined, I cannot support the first two paragraphs of the motion. So, for the only time in my life, I will abstain from voting with the Government.
Wednesday, 23 January

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak in this debate I must pick up one absolutely extraordinary point made in the previous speaker's address. I do not deny Senator Childs's right to hold the position he takes, but his comments in relation to President Bush and Americans must apply equally to all other countries involved in the United Nations' actions. I am saddened that the United States of America was selected so singularly. What he said must also apply, if it is his belief, to the Australian Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We are faced with the serious situation which has developed in the Middle East and a debate on Australia's commitment to the United Nations in terms of the various resolutions carried by that body. I strongly support the motion before us. I strongly support the position adopted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and in particular the leadership of Dr John Hewson in publicly seeking a bipartisan approach to this issue.

When I became a member of this chamber on 1 July last year, the last thing I would have wished to debate this day was the commitment of Australians to a war theatre. Nonetheless, invasion, looting, raping, torture, murder and other atrocities have been committed. I believe they would continue indefinitely if the United Nations did not stand up and say, `No more' and then be prepared to enforce that. It should be noted that these atrocities have been committed against a small, defenceless country. I do not wish to go over all the points that have been made by previous speakers; however, I do wish to emphasise some. In doing so, I wish to state that nobody wants peace more than I and, having listened to all speakers in this debate, I know that all want peace. The difference is how we resolve the issue. Do we have a continuation of the sanctions and diplomacy or direct intervention?

I do not believe claims that the sanctions would have worked. I do not deny that they were inflicting some pain, but who was bearing that pain? It was not President Hussein, not his elite force, not his army or air force but ordinary Iraqis, the people in the street, the remaining people of Kuwait. Unfortunately, diplomacy has clearly failed. The Secretary-General of the United Nations worked overtime. Many countries tried. Saddam Hussein rebuffed and rebuked them all.

Let us look at some indisputable facts: the war started on 2 August, not 17 January; Iraq is the aggressor; Iraq has an enormous and very potent armory; Saddam Hussein would not have been satisfied with just Kuwait; Saddam Hussein has no respect for human life or sovereign boundaries; Saddam Hussein rejected all reasonable and rational approaches for a negotiated settlement-paramount in this was an unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait; Saddam Hussein was producing more horrific arms and digging himself in-not for peace, but war; not to leave Kuwait, but to stay; not to be compassionate to Kuwaitis, but to be cruel. I believe to have waited longer would only have made this situation worse.

In this debate I wish to give notice of a number of flow-on issues that emerge from the Gulf crisis. In doing so I wish to acknowledge and congratulate President Bush of the United States. He is the man who has shown leadership. He has, through strength and not weakness, given us a chance for a new world order. We will have to examine carefully our future role in this new world order.

I raise the issue of our trade with the Middle East. Our exports to the region are worth some $2 billion per annum. Our imports cost some $1.5 billion per annum. The region is of immense importance to Australia and Australia is of enormous importance to the Middle East. Therefore, it is important that the Government develop a strategy to deal with this part of the flow-on effects. It is imperative that the burden in Australia be shared as equitably as possible between industries and individuals. This is a responsibility of the Parliament and should be subject to further debate and discussion. It is essential that at this time of conflict and crisis which requires our utmost attention, we do not neglect other matters of vital importance.

I must comment on the unfortunate bias shown in recent days by the peace movement in and around this building. I will never understand why the United States and Australia are selectively targeted by the protesters-organised, orchestrated protesters. Why has not Iraq been targeted with equal vigour, when it is Iraq which invaded Kuwait on 2 August? Equally, it saddens me that the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine so publicly align themselves with the group which has been here. They in fact encourage the group we have seen behave so badly over the last two days-a group whose selective activities are encouraging Hussein to stay in Kuwait. If they have any moral fibre and consistency, they will also target the perpetrator-the invader, the butcher of Baghdad. I do not deny the protesters' right to freedom of speech. I just plead for fairness and consistency. As I said before, we all want peace. Let us all target the culprit and, hence, end the occupation of Kuwait.

My thoughts and best wishes go to those now living in Australia who originate from the Middle East; to the members of our forces serving in the Middle East; to the families of those serving on our behalf-in fact, to all who have been called to serve under the United Nations Charter. There are many other issues I could pursue. However, they have been well covered by other speakers in a series of excellent speeches.

I conclude by saying that the lessons of the beginning of the Second World War should teach us that we will not win peace by appeasement, by allowing a dictator to walk over a small country and saying `Stop'-because he will walk over another when it suits him. We will only win peace by strength. Hussein will only leave Kuwait when he recognises the United Nations is serious. I hope and pray that is soon and that we have a just and lasting peace in the Middle East. Peace will survive only if we have the fortitude to defend it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to discuss all of the relevant issues in this conflict, but I want just briefly to explain my position. It is easy to support talk of attacking installations; of attacking Saddam Hussein; of pushing him out of Kuwait; of concentrating on the Iraqi leader and his being a dictator and responsible for appalling actions. But such talk avoids the reality that it is people, real Iraqi people, not just their leaders, who are being attacked in our name-young people and old people, innocent and guilty, no matter how one defines innocence and guilt. So I cannot put out of my mind the real victims of this horror: the allied military casualties, the Iraqi military casualties and the even greater innocents-the civilian casualties, the refugees, and the survivors who will continue suffering long after those who are killed.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it impossible to justify killing some people in the hope that that will prevent others being killed or otherwise abused. It is not even as though it is the responsible tyrant who is being made to suffer personally. I have a basic opposition to the use of force. I do not agree that Iraq's violence or anyone's violence justifies violence in return. I condemn the use of force by anyone, and I am appalled by the reported Iraqi abuses of human rights. So in no way can my attitude be construed as pro-Iraq. I deplore the invasion of Kuwait as much as anyone else does.

It is an attitude of preference for avoiding the use of force to solve conflict. I continually ask myself: how does aggression prove that aggression is wrong? Perhaps some indication of my revulsion is that while I have of course heard and read descriptions of the television coverage of this war, I have watched not one minute of that television coverage: I could not bear to do so. I am in a position where I would not go to war myself, so how can I ask others to do so? How could I, in all conscience? I cannot. I have anguished deeply over this problem. I oppose this war and all war. The cost, and the terrible waste involved of humans and of other resources, is abhorrent to me, as I know it is to most people.

I just cannot come to grips with the concept of a just war or a war that is justified. That probably means that I am an absolute pacifist. That I am a pacifist is certain, but that that pacifism is absolute is less certain. I think I can be absolutely certain about that only if I have been continuously a pacifist until I die. I am pleased that most people recognise that one can genuinely hold the pacifist position and that they respect the legitimacy of that position; I trust it is only a minority here who use it as a term of abuse.

What I am doing is not at all easy for me. I think it would be a lot easier to go along with the clear majority in the Government, supporting the motion endorsing our involvement. I could easily justify it on the ground of solidarity. In fact, it pains me at this moment not to be supporting my comrades, including many for whom I have great respect and who have put their support for Australian involvement very powerfully. I cannot possibly list all the twists and turns of my thinking on this issue or the reasoning that has led me to this position, but I think it is clear that I have grappled with my conscience over this matter.

I have consistently accepted, supported and strongly argued for collective decision-making within the Australian Labor Party, and I have consistently observed it rigorously. I never thought I would be in this position of seeking to be excused from supporting a Caucus decision. So it is with a terrible feeling in my guts that I do so and indicate that I intend abstaining from the vote on the motion endorsing the war and our involvement.

There have been previous instances where I have disagreed with the collective decision but then supported it. So why am I treating this one differently? I suppose it is because it is a question of war and peace, of authorising aggression. It is so big that it has pushed me over that line. I am aware of the risk of being accused of grandstanding. I hope that it is obvious that I am not seeking to do that but, having been faced with what I have felt is a terrible dilemma, I have had to decide to which of the conflicting principles I have to give priority.

I will not be going out of my way to add to the inevitable publicity about this. In fact, when I have finished this speech I will have said all I want to say. I would be most unhappy about my position if I thought that other Labor colleagues felt pressed or that I was taking the luxury of a position that others wished also to take but felt unable to take. But I feel reassured that, while some may have wished for some of the wording to have been different, and have gone through a lot of anguish about this issue themselves, those who are supporting the commitment do so not only because of the Caucus decision in which they have participated but, at least on balance, because of their own genuine beliefs, which I understand and respect.

I say now that I will not tolerate criticism of my colleagues for supporting the motion. I sincerely hope that I have not made things more difficult for them. I trust that it is clear how my position differs. All I ask for is the understanding of those of my colleagues who think I am doing the wrong thing.

I should also answer the accusation which could be made that this is a token action on my part and that it is not significant because the overwhelming majority will ensure that the motion is carried and that the Government is not at risk. That point is true, but the action is highly significant to me. I never thought that I would be in this position. I have carefully worked through the issues and with much trepidation reached the position of not supporting the motion.

Of course, there are parts of the motion I could support, but I think I would be kidding myself if I tried to use that as a justification for overlooking the main parts. For instance, I am not critical of the Australian defence forces. In fact, my feeling for them and for their families and friends left behind is as great as for anyone. I do not want to see even one Australian hurt in this operation. This is why I have refused to agree simplistically with calls for immediate withdrawal of the ships, which I assume might put them in even greater danger than they are at present. Of course, I support the United Nations' role for peace.

Furthermore, I am not doing this because of some assessment that the majority of Australians oppose the war. I suspect that at the moment the clear majority of Australians support it, although with various degrees of dissatisfaction. It is a significant number, but a minority, who oppose our involvement. I am speaking from a personal perspective, but it is also true that I am thereby representing many people. I do not think it is necessary for the Parliament to give unanimous support to the motion. If it did, it would be a misrepresentation of the range of views in the community.

I attended the protest meeting in Hobart on Monday of last week and I marched in Hobart on Saturday. I hope it does not have to be said that I am therefore guilty by association with every statement or chant uttered by every other participant. I am not a chanter by nature, anyway. However, I emphasise that there were many highly respected members of the Tasmanian community who last Saturday expressed their opposition to the war.

While I am on the subject of opposition to the war, there is one thing I want to say about the demonstrations in the parliamentary galleries over the past two days. I think it is probably important that someone speaking from the position I have taken should say this. While of course I do not underestimate how strongly people feel, I do wish that those who protested had not taken it on themselves actually to disrupt proceedings. I do not think it was of help to their cause or to my cause. In fact, it was counterproductive. It damn near made me rejoin the fold in solidarity with my comrades, as a greater need for that solidarity had arisen. I suggest that silent protest can be much more powerful and effective. At the same time, I implore those critical of certain demonstrators' behaviour not to generalise from the behaviour they disapprove of by extending blame to all those who march and rally for peace. One cannot blame the whole peace movement.

I make one final point: the 4 December decision is one factor that has weighed heavily with me. I opposed it at the time because I feared the outcome which has now transpired. I should have opposed it more strongly, and perhaps so should a lot of others. I did not, but that does not lead me to conclude that I must therefore automatically go along meekly with the next step.

What I would like to see are new initiatives for negotiations and peace. However, I am terribly pessimistic of there being much chance of success in that direction at the moment. I fear that this war will go on and on, and, even worse, that it will escalate and lead to even more appalling turmoil and destruction in our world. I am deeply troubled by that and I do not want to be on the record as approving it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —No issue is so clear that there is no room for dissent or disagreement, and this is particularly so on this issue, which is probably the most important that any of us in this chamber will be required to determine. But the consequences of the decisions each of us take have to bear examination. The consequences of the decisions to be taken, for example, by the Australian Democrats and by a few members of the Australian Labor Party have to be examined with the same scrutiny through which the actions of those of us who are voting with the Government have been examined and attacked by the Australian Democrats, by the demonstrators, and by those who chose to disturb and disrupt the proceedings of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The same intellectual scrutiny should apply and the same preparedness to recognise the consequences of their actions should be accepted by the people who have so enthusiastically denied the merit of the position that the great bulk of this chamber has taken, the great bulk of parliamentarians in Australia and the great bulk of the Australian people.

The latest polls show that 75 per cent of the Australian population support the concept of military intervention of one kind or another in the Gulf. That is not mentioned by me in order to say, `Look, the majority of people support it; therefore it must necessarily be right'. But it does indicate that when people like Senator Powell come into this chamber and pretend to us that a rowdy minority in that gallery represents the majority opinion of Australians, and when that rowdy minority seeks to disrupt and to influence us here, I think we have to recognise what reality is. When I hear people like Senator Powell posing as the possessor of all wisdom and the right to judge what the majority of Australians really want, then I must say I have the instinctive uneasiness that comes when I hear anyone who claims to have some special access to knowledge, some special understanding which is denied the rest of us.

What strikes me most about the consequences of the course of action taken by those people voting against this motion-this resolution of support for the action taken under the auspices of the United Nations-who are saying that we should give peace a chance, as if those of us supporting this resolution are somehow opposed to peace, is that the consequences of those actions are--

TALK.START.PARA: —You're supporting war.

—I thank Senator Vallentine for that interjection. I will endeavour to demonstrate that one of the greatest factors in Saddam Hussein's disastrous miscalculation in this matter, this miscalculation that the rest of the world would not resist him, emerged from very people like Senator Vallentine, who gave comfort to that view and encouraged him to war. The warmongers, the people who have generated war in this chamber, are far more the Vallentines than anyone else in this chamber. I will go into that matter later. She has, naturally, left the chamber when being attacked. This senator continually interjects, organises disruptions in the gallery, makes a farce of the proceedings in this place, and goes into the House of Representatives and demeans the status of the Senate by interrupting and disrupting debate there; but then, when subject to any attack, walks out.
—There is not one Democrat here.

—Yes, it is interesting to note that there is not one Democrat here. I assume that their interest was simply coming in here to hear Senator Childs and Senator Coates support the position that they were maintaining. I am glad to see Senator Bell here, because I have some regard for some of the points that Senator Bell was making.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to recognise the interests that are being served by those people who oppose this motion. Whose interests are being served? I believe that that ends up with one very simple and uncomplicated answer. The only interest ultimately being served-and I welcome back Senator Vallentine to the chamber-by further delay is the aggressor's best interests. As Mr Isi Leibler, the Vice-President of the World Jewish Congress, said very recently:
Iraq's missile attack on civilian targets in Israel showed what would have happened had Saddam Hussein been given time to develop nuclear weapons.

He said that peace protesters who mindlessly called for an end to conflict in the Gulf did not realise the parallels between Saddam and Hitler. Perhaps we should recognise our debt to the Israelis for having--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the--

—I am interested to hear Senator McLean now starting to interject because I will deal with his contribution shortly. I believe that we have some kind of obligation, and thanks due, to Israel for having knocked out the nuclear reactor facility that--
—What about Israel's reactor facility? What about their 200 nuclear weapons?
—Order! Senator Vallentine!

—Senator Vallentine says, `What about Israel's nuclear facility?'. To my knowledge, Israel has not called for a holy war to destroy other countries in the region. I stress that this holy war called by Saddam Hussein is totally phoney and is not supported at all by the Koran or by the Islamic community. I know that it will interrupt and interfere with the wall of nonsense, of obfuscation, that has descended across Senator Vallentine's intellect. We are only too well aware of what Senator Vallentine's objectives are, because we have seen them clearly in the press release that she put out on 21 January. She said that she will move amendments to the Prime Minister's statement calling for `a denial of information to Israel by Nurrungar which would be crucial for their use of Patriot missiles as such a contribution negates Australia's official policy of even-handedness in the Palestine-Israel conflict'.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought this issue was about whether or not a tyrant had the right to invade Kuwait. I thought the supply of Patriot missiles to Israel had something to do with preventing attacks on Israel, which is not at war.

TALK.START.PARA: —On innocent civilians.

—Preventing attacks on innocent civilians. I thank the honourable senator for the interjection. I thought this but obviously I am wrong because Senator Vallentine knows all. She has special access to a pool of misinformation that swamps her and swamps us when it descends in volumes, orchestrated by Senator Vallentine from the gallery.

SPEECH.PARA: We have this absolute nonsense. We have to recognise what the consequences will be-and that is what I am getting to in each case-of Senator Vallentine's desire not to have Patriot missiles effectively destroying rocket attacks on Israel. The consequences of that are that Israel would retaliate. Senator Vallentine is quite happy to live with those consequences because that would with average luck perhaps lead to the destruction of Israel. One cannot see, in anything that Senator Vallentine has put out, anything else but a desire to destroy Israel. If that is her objective, she is working towards it. There are no other consequences possible from this incredible garbage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to see the destruction of Israel.
—Order! Honourable senators will come to order. Senator Vallentine!

—This woman professes to be a peace lover and here she is objecting to Israel having access to missiles whose purpose is to prevent missiles coming from Iraq to destroy, kill and maim innocent civilians in Israel. What sort of a woman is this who can put out this sort of stuff? What are her motives? This is what I believe we have to look at when we are wondering what are the consequences of people like Senator McLean and Senator Vallentine opposing this motion and putting their opposition in terms, such as Senator Vallentine has done, which can have but one consequence, and that is assisting the interests of the aggressor.

SPEECH.PARA: All the time we hear these people saying, `Ah, yes, if you gave the sanctions a chance-that is what you should be doing'. This is what we have heard from this corner non-stop. They have been saying, `If you gave the sanctions a chance. We're not involved in appeasement. Don't call us appeasers. We're not appeasers'. We heard this from every one of them. They said, `We're not appeasers. We believe in sanctions. We want action to be taken'. We believe in talk, talk, talk, but we must not attack them as appeasers.

I think that what we have to recognise, very simply, is that not one of the people who spoke on this issue said, `Yes, we think that sanctions should have been given a greater go and if in 18 months they had failed, we would then support military action'. Not one of them said it because, in fact-and I guess we can find the answer simply-not one of them believes that in any circumstance military action can be justified. That is the reality. Otherwise, why did one of them not say so? In other words, there is a simple rationalising of their objection to war on any grounds. That is their honest position.

This bit about giving sanctions a chance is a disgraceful and totally dishonest smokescreen. If it was not a smokescreen, why did we not hear one of them say, `Yes, okay, we would have accepted this motion had in fact sanctions been given a greater chance'. And not one of them said it. Why? It is because they are as a group morally bankrupt; because they are not prepared to accept and to admit to this chamber that there is nothing that in their view will justify Australia going to war.

But there is an even more significant and disturbing consequence of their actions, and that is that they, like their colleagues around the rest of the world, have given Saddam Hussein the totally false impression-and I hope it remains totally false-that the rest of the world will stand idly by because deep in the heart of every nation which wants to stand against him there is an overwhelming, growing, significant element which, like the Democrats and Senator Vallentine, would never under any circumstances take action to resist a tyrant.

The reality is that that expectation is exactly the same expectation that Adolf Hitler had when he took the view that the British would not stand up to him-and he was well-informed about that; it is alleged even by the man who was supposed to be the future king. Hitler took exactly the same view and was equally misinformed. The reality is-and it must be evident to anyone-that Saddam Hussein took the view that he could literally get away with murder and pillage. He thought he could get away with it because there was a soft underbelly to the West represented by peaceniks, who in the end in fact become warniks because they bring forward a greater confidence in a tyrant that he can get away with it. This, I believe, is the burden that these sorts of people around the world have to carry on their conscience. They have encouraged a tyrant like Saddam Hussein to take the view that the West would not stand up to him.

If the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine had at one stage, anywhere in this debate, said, `Yes, there may be a time when we would support military intervention, but it is not now', I could not and would not be making this charge against them. They did not because at no stage would they be prepared to do so. What a different party they are from the party under Don Chipp. I hope everyone in this chamber read what Mr Chipp said about `beware of the bleeding hearts' in last Saturday's paper. If that remark is not an indictment by ex-Senator Chipp of his former, and now, I must say, debased, Party, I do not know what is. His is a powerful and reasonable article.
Senator McLean interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean, I think you have interjected enough for a while.

—We have heard some extraordinary rationalising from the Australian Labor Party dissidents about how the United Nations has not given the sort of support for this action which the Prime Minister has suggested.

SPEECH.PARA: Mountains of nonsense was written in the Sydney Morning Herald today. I do not know what the group that is almost a commune that seems to be running the Sydney Morning Herald these days is on about, but the most appalling garbage was written in the Sydney Morning Herald which in lineage far exceeded its reporting of the debate here. If it had read the debate it would have seen that the points that were made and the so-called informed comments were all more than adequately answered and severely dealt with in the debate.

In any event it is quite clear that except for a small number of countries the international community has condemned the invasion and reacted, through what is described in the briefing to us from the Department of the Parliamentary Library research service, as an unprecedented consensus by passing 12 resolutions in the Security Council of the United Nations. Now surely if there is moral support for the position being taken by the Government, which is supported by the Opposition, it is that unprecedented support through the United Nations.

Because time is running out I will move quickly to one of the problems that concerns me seriously, and that is the extent to which the Muslim community in Australia has been quite improperly and disgracefully attacked by some people when the reality of their position is very largely exactly the opposite to the one for which they are being insulted. The great bulk of the Muslim community in fact belongs to and attends mosques and community associations which are heavily funded and subsidised by the Saudi Government with whom we are allied in this matter. One of the reasons those mistaken attacks on the Islamic community here go on is because Saddam Hussein has quite improperly called this war a jihad, a holy war. That of course is absolutely ludicrous. You cannot have a holy war against other believers. A holy war is only against disbelievers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Infidels.

—Infidels, as Senator Tate says. As a result this call as if it were a holy war has confused many people, I believe, and certainly has caused distress within the Muslim community in Australia which regrettably has been divided on a whole lot of different grounds in recent years, and there have been very many bitter disputes. I do not want to exacerbate those disputes, but I must say that there are some religious groups in Australia which are funded by the Iraqis directly. I believe that that funding and those links, and some very pro-Iraqi statements that have come from people in those groups, put a special responsibility on the members of those groups and the spokesmen for those groups to remember that they are now Australians and in Australia, and that that is where their primary allegiance must lie. It is not a question of should lie; it is where their primary allegiance must lie.

SPEECH.PARA: I presume that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) and whoever else is responsible is closely examining the whole question of the terrorist threat which is obviously a matter of some concern around the world. I am not suggesting that members of those communities I have just spoken about are likely candidates, but I would remind the Senate of the ASIO report of only last year. This follows on a recent report in the Sunday Age which says:
Australia's security services fear Iraq will launch an international terror campaign against the member countries of the international coalition in the Gulf.
We have already had a question at question time today about what happened to four entry visas from Nigeria which magically seem to have disappeared, and the people seem to have disappeared.

We do not know whether there is a security threat involved or where the Nigerian entry visas came from. We have the right to expect a very speedy reply to that kind of situation. I remind the Senate that the ASIO report said:

Australia continues to play host to a number of representatives of foreign intelligence services from various countries, whose activities are regarded as hostile to Australia's interests. Over the past year ASIO has discovered a higher level of representation and activity in Australia by some hostile intelligence services than had been previously known or suspected.

. . . the threat from these services has been shown to be significant. The lowering of world tensions over the past year arising from political reforms in some countries has not reduced the level of activity of hostile intelligence services.

When I was dealing with this report I noted this as a matter of great significance because we are in an environment in which the general view is that the detente between the East and the West should lead to a relaxation of our guard. Australia simply cannot afford to lower its guard against the threat of hostile intelligence services operating in this country. I hope that it has not simply taken the present problem to generate that interest.

I shall now return very briefly to the question of whether this can possibly be a jihad and whether the Muslim community around the world is or is not supporting Saddam Hussein. It has been mentioned in this debate that a large number of the 28 nations actively participating in the United Nations supported actions are Islamic nations. One of them, Saudi Arabia, is probably the key nation of all of the Islamic nations, being the centre of the most holy places. On 29 November last Sheikh al-Sabah of Kuwait addressed the United Nations and said:

Our goal is peace. Our Islamic faith advocates peace and enjoins us to work earnestly and sincerely for peace. But, by the same token, true Islam makes it incumbent upon us all to resist aggression and not to yield in submission to the aggressor. Perhaps God the Almighty has defined for us a prescription for fair and just recourse in the face of such an aggression, for God says in the Holy Koran:
If two parties among the believers fall into a quarrel, make ye peace between them:-
`Hear, hear!', we should all say-

but if one of them transgresses beyond bounds against the other, then fight ye (all) against the one that transgresses until it complies with the command of God; but if it complies, then make peace between them with justice, and be fair: for God loves those who are fair (and just).

There is a clear admonition, if you like, in The Holy Koran for an aggressor to be resisted. It is with that confidence that the Saudis and their colleagues are resisting the aggressor, the man who is using and misusing the Islamic faith for political and personal and disgraceful and dishonest reasons. The Koran also states:
True justice accords with Allah's Law.
Follow not men's selfish desires,
But Allah's Will, which was revealed
To Moses and Jesus, and now to Muhammad.
Take not for friends and protectors
Those in whose hearts is a disease-
To whom religion is a mockery
Or a plaything-who worship evil-
what a magnificent description of Saddam Hussein-
Proclaim the Truth of Allah, and be
Not afraid. Eschew their iniquities,
Which were denounced by David
And Jesus. But recognise with justice
Those who are sincere and humble,
Though they may be themselves
Not of your flock, if they witness to Truth.

I guess that is another admonition for the Saudis to bring in people, whom Senator Tate might suggest could otherwise be described as infidels, to be part of the fight for truth, for they witness the truth.

As I said, it is always difficult on a major issue to dismiss the thought that there is no room for dissent. Obviously there is room for dissent. Obviously there is room for disagreement. But let all those who dissent from this motion, who dis-agree with it, recognise the consequences of their actions, that among the major consequences of those actions are that they bolster the aggressor and make the peaceful outcome we all seek so much more difficult.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand to record my support for the motion that is before the chamber. Nearly everything has been said. However, eight senators out of the 76 in the Senate have spoken against the motion and I wish to confine my remarks to Senator Vallentine and the Australian Democrats. The Democrats' view can be summarised as a plea for more time. It reminds me of Samuel Beckett's play, Waiting for Godot. Two days ago a reply came to them from their former leader, Mr Chipp, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are at a time when we should contemplate the devastation, suffering and death that a man . . . can inflict on humankind if their greed and lust are allowed . . . to use delaying tactics.

The Iraqi killers have already been responsible for more than one million deaths, inflicting hideous pain on their own people through chemicals and by terrible acts of torture. In another place this evening my colleague Don Dobie reminded us that 400 officers were executed by the Iraqis when a reverse occurred in the war against Iran and that 167 Iraqi officers were executed when there was a reverse in the war against, and occupation of, Kuwait. Yet the Democrats plead for more time-time to stockpile and manufacture chemical, biological and nuclear weapons. I refer them also to an article by Malcolm Browne which appeared in the New York Times on 18 November last year. He states:
Iraq has amply demonstrated that it intends to build a nuclear arsenal from scratch . . .

A welter of reports and rumours have circulated in recent months that Iraq is close to beginning production of nuclear weapons. One set of speculations centred on some highly enriched uranium fuel salvaged from the breeder reactor after the Israeli attack that was mentioned by Senator Baume. This fuel could be used to make one crude nuclear weapon relatively quickly, although it is regularly inspected by experts from the International Atomic Energy Agency to make sure that it has not been diverted to military use. Several weeks ago Iraq invited the Agency to conduct a new inspection, suggesting that Baghdad has no immediate military plans for the fuel.

Other speculations have been based on seizures by European governments of materials and components bound for Iraq that could be used for the production of nuclear weapons. In March 1990, British Customs officials, acting on information from the United States authorities, seized a shipment of special capacitors consigned to Iraq. That is no speculation. Such devices can store electricity and release it in a millionth of a second as a powerful pulse. Iraq has planned nuclear weapons of this type for many years. As a matter of fact, on 15 July German Customs officials in Frankfurt seized a consignment of Swiss-made machinery which was bound for Iraq. The shipment consisted of items fabricated from high-strength, corrosion-resistant steel essential for the construction of gas centrifuges-advanced devices capable of separating fissionable uranium 235 from its inert isotope, uranium 238.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did Australia sell?

—None. As a matter of fact, it was imported from Brazil, Portugal and Niger, so there was no Australian uranium. Iraq is also exploiting deposits of low-grade uranium in the far north-western part of Iraq. Altogether, 250 tonnes of uranium-bearing mixture has been imported.

SPEECH.PARA: Yellowcake must be subjected to a complex series of processes to produce fissionable uranium 235. Polish engineers who were held briefly as human shields by Iraq have stated that the first chemical steps of that process are already being performed at a large chemical plant at Al Qaim north-west of Baghdad. The end chemical product in this complex chain is uranium hexafluoride, a gas needed for the isotope separation process in which bomb fuel is produced. It is a matter of speculation how quickly a full scale uranium separation plant might eventually be built.

The Simon Wiesenthal Foundation of Los Angeles has circulated a list of more than 200 companies in Europe, Asia and the United States that have supplied Iraq with materials and technologies potentially needed by a nuclear weapons industry. Iraq has three nuclear research laboratories at Mosul, Erbil and Tuwaitha. And the Democrats want to give them more time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not for that.

—Well, time for what, then? Time for a diplomatic solution? It should by now be clear that any conceivable diplomatic solution acceptable to Hussein would be a calamity because it would legitimise the invasion of Kuwait and Iraq's ability to rain mass death on its neighbours and beyond. If massed American military power backed by global political consensus is not allowed to deal decisively with Saddam Hussein's Iraq, then nothing ever will.

SPEECH.PARA: I now want to refer to Senator Vallentine. It is a matter of historical record that 144 nations condemned Iraq at the United Nations. Forty nations agreed to provide or help sustain military forces. Four nations in fact voted against this: Jordan, Cuba, Yemen and North Korea. I would not try to persuade Senator Vallentine. She said, according to yesterday's Hansard, that the world has not agreed to go to war; that only 28 countries had agreed. She and her followers in the gallery yesterday have a similar characteristic, an ability to believe their own rhetoric which for them becomes their truth, a schizoid-type reaction. I have treated many like her and her followers in the past. Senator Vallentine needs the help of myself and another medically qualified person. I would contrast this rabble with the 400 young Australians who yesterday signed up as members of the armed forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the 1,700 young Christians who put an advertisement in the paper saying, `Don't go to war'?

—I also believe that actions speak louder than words. It has been said that parliamentarians are prone to pontificate about committing their citizens to war and do not involve themselves. The Australian medical team in Vietnam was backed by the surgeons of Australia who volunteered for service in that theatre. I wish to record in the Senate that I have already offered my services as a surgeon to the chief of the defence forces should they be required.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, one of the noticeable things about the last two days in this place has been the obvious cooperation and willingness to work together that has existed between the Government and the Opposition. We have seen that when we as a nation are confronted by some serious problem or threat, we are able to forget our differences and work towards a solution for the country.

Perhaps when we meet again in February, we can remember these lessons when we are talking about our economic problems. Why can we not work together to try to solve our economic and resultant social problems in the future? I challenge the Government to this end, as there is time to achieve a common end in the interests of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As much as anybody in the Senate, I have a passion for peace. I am not alone, but I do seek truth, justice and peace. It is a matter of conscience for me and I am sure it is a matter of conscience for other senators. I want to know the evidence; I want to evaluate the evidence; and I want to act on the conclusions reached.

SPEECH.PARA: This passion for peace remains a principal motivation for my being in politics and serving in this Parliament. It is on this foundation that I support completely the motion in its five parts that has been moved by the Government, and supported by the Opposition, in our debate about the Gulf these past two days.

Blessed are the peacemakers is the encouragement of the Sermon on the Mount. Love your enemies, turn the other cheek, do good to those who hurt you, are the personal injunctions of the ethics I accept. Jesus' first words to his disciples following his suffering death and living resurrection were, `Peace be with you'. Peace is much more than the absence of strife. Quiet, alone, is insufficient for peace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would He be saying go to war?
—Senator Vallentine!
—How dare you--
—Senator Vallentine!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Vallentine

TALK.START.PARA: —use Jesus Christ.

INTERJECT.PARA: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT Senator Vallentine, I warn you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Peace is about fullness, health, positive life with coherence and justice and complete development, but not at the expense of others. Peace is positive and secure. But I am not a pacifist, and neither was the one I have quoted-Jesus, the son of David the King. I regard pacifism as an idealist distortion to be rejected. Of course, I respect the handful of Australians who are conscientious pacifists, and there is only one senator in this chamber who is a pacifist. It is my view that taking the pacifist path often frustrates the achievement of genuine peace, and it has always been so.

SPEECH.PARA: Achieving peace requires the resisting of evil. Peace requires the protection of the innocent and the defenceless. Peace requires us to stand between the aggressor and the victim to take the aggressor's blows but, more often, to disarm the aggressor and stop the aggressor. Winning peace requires action to resist evil, but the action is qualified by restraint and is subject to the objective of securing an enduring peace.

The resisting of evil is more often required of a community than of an individual. We support police forces, except where they become corrupt or officious. The resisting of evil is certainly required at a national level. The necessity of a strong defence force is the experience of every nation. The objective of these forces is to secure peace. Only a pacifist would want to abandon any police force or any national defence force. These are the principles I have understood since I was a teenager. They are derived, as for millions of Australians-and for millions of christians in this country-from reading the scriptures, a study of history and open discussion. For example, when I was an undergraduate I studied in detail the rise and fall of Nazi Germany and of Japan, and the lessons of the Second World War period in Europe and in Asia, but my study of history is not confined to these recent episodes. At that time I was directed to Dietrich Bonhoeffer's experience and writings in Germany. Ever since, I have identified with his assessment of war and peace.

I was not surprised, then, that Senator Tate, in his moving speech yesterday, referred to Dietrich Bonhoeffer in underlining conclusions which he personally had reached-conclusions which I share. Senator Tate said:
. . . I find it impossible to maintain that it is never justified to use military force to remove a tyrant.

I have moved to the same painful conclusion as Dietrich Bonhoeffer, the great famous German pastor, who found himself against every previous understanding he had of the claims of the gospel. This great pastor, particularly amongst the youth of Germany, involved himself in the assassination plot against Hitler because he came to the painful, reluctant conclusion that he had to be part of the process of removing a tyrant who was claiming the lives of so many innocent victims.

In 1984 I was a founding member-an original co-convener-of the all-party Parliamentary Peace and Disarmament Group. I am still a member and still a co-convener. I had the encouragement of my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties to do so. Particularly in 1988, the International Year of Peace, the group had a very active program of activities engaging the attention of the super-powers and the other nuclear-armed nations.

We continue within our several parties to work for an initial 50 per cent cut in nuclear weapons and a disarmament which is not unilateral but mutually accepted and verifiable. We work for the total elimination of chemical weapons and the strengthening of the Non-proliferation Treaty, the eventual ban of all nuclear weapons tests and the most stringent safeguards on the use of uranium for the generation of electric energy.

I am a part of the peace movement. I represent the Opposition on the Australian Government's advisory committee on peace and disarmament. I have contributed to the review of the Australian National University Peace Research Centre, successfully urging its greater concentration on strategic international peace issues, including the effectiveness of deterrents and the effectiveness of the joint Australian-American facilities, including Pine Gap and Nurrungar. In 1988, the International Year of Peace, I led the first Liberal Party contingent in the Palm Sunday peace marches, and our banner motto of `peace through strength' boldly expressed the conviction shared by the Australian Defence Force.

I conscientiously believe that the ethics to which I have referred lead in a reasonable and just way to the pursuit of peace through strength. This has been the means to end the Cold War. We would not have the Gorbachev-Bush accord, the new atmosphere in international relations, and the end of the Cold War had not our allies pursued peace through strength. This has been the means to peace. It is also a principle endorsed by the United Nations Charter, by the United Nations decisions since 2 August and the series of 12 resolutions adopted overwhelmingly by the United Nations General Assembly and the United Nations Security Council that were referred to very directly by Senator Brownhill and by Senator Jones.

It is on the basis of peace through strength that I speak and endorse Australia's actions in the Gulf. I appeal to all senators, not least the minority of 11, 12 or 13 senators who dissent, many of whom share the values and explicitly the Christian ethics to which I have referred. I am convinced, for six or seven specific reasons, to which I will briefly and shortly refer, that the Australian defence contingent should be part of the United Nations sanctioned multinational force of some 40 countries now actively engaged in military action against Saddam Hussein and against Iraq.

I want Australians serving in the Gulf to know that we have confidence in them and that we support them, not just out of Australian solidarity but because we believe it is right that they be there. They are acting for us in resisting evil, and they are acting with restraint and in the firm hope of eventually being successful in securing peace. The overwhelming majority of members of this Parliament and of the Australian people support our Navy contingent on the Sydney, Melbourne and Success, and on Westralia which is now heading north-west to relieve Success. We support our defence medical teams, our logistics group, and those 20 or so defence personnel seconded to allied forces serving in the Gulf.

The third part of the motion before the Senate in this debate sets out this confidence in our armed forces and our support for them-support which has been directly referred to admirably by my colleague the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, who said:

I take the opportunity, as the Minister did, to commend the contribution that our armed services make to our security. Those who give a life of service in this way, who know that in the event of hostilities it will be their lives that they commit for our protection, deserve much greater community recognition and support than they usually receive. This commendation includes their families, who make sacrifices simply by being service families but also know that their loved ones might be called upon at any time to make the supreme sacrifice. In commending Australia's forces in the Gulf, I include those who just as easily could be there. The Defence Force must know that we genuinely appreciate and recognise their key contribution to our society and our way of life.

What I have said up to this point is only a foundation for considering the actual elements of the present situation in the Gulf and for determining Australia's response to Iraq's invasion, occupation and destruction of Kuwait. All the evidence needs to be understood and evaluated. Even then, a judgment of whether to commit military force and when to act must be made. My judgment-and that of the Government and the Opposition-is that with the passing of the mid-January deadline that the United Nations had set and with the elapse now of 5 1/2 months of the Iraqi-induced war, the time is right to act by military means, as has happened by the United Nations sanctioned multinational force.

I concede that a minority of honourable senators have made a contrary judgment. I respect their view but I strongly believe they are wrong. Senator Vallentine implies that the time to act in this way is never. Senator McLean said to this question, `I do not know'. Even to my interjection he acknowledged, `Yes. The evil goes on but I do not know'. Senator Spindler and Senator Kernot dissented, implying that military action should not at any time be entered into. At least they urged that military action be avoided, now that we have come to a supposed new enlightenment in the 1990s. They appealed to a nobler solution but did not convince me that there was any hope of it actually working.

Senator Reynolds, as a former Minister of this Government, gave a brave speech confessing to being unconvinced from the beginning that our ships should be in the Gulf. She said that she opposes their military action now. Senator Childs is in another category. I see that he is just entering the chamber. I am sure that we all listened to his careful and sincere speech, but he remains almost alone in his derogatory references to President Bush, in his actual views about Hussein's tactics and in what I see as an overestimation of the bite of sanctions. The great majority of us disagree with his assessments.

In fact, dissent in the debate, being already concluded in the House of Representatives and being almost concluded here in the Senate, stands at less than 20 per cent in the Senate. Judging from those who have spoken, even taking into account my three colleagues who have already indicated their support for the motion in front of us, it may be a low as only a dozen-eight Australian Democrats, Senator Vallentine and two or three Government members. The rest of the Senate genuinely supports the five-part motion moved by the Government and strongly supported by the Opposition. In the House of Representatives the dissent was considerably lower than 10 per cent.

Today's public opinion polls show that 18 per cent have indicated their opposition to the multinational force and perhaps as many as 24 per cent are opposed to Australia's involvement in that multinational force.

The overwhelming majority of the Australian public has been shown, by polling, to support the multinational force's military action in the Gulf this past week and Australia's involvement to the extent that has been decided. While I recognise the genuine judgment of those dozen-some of whom I particularly referred to just a moment ago-it is clear, not only from the numbers but also from the personal genuine statements of support made so variously towards the one end of supporting the five parts of this motion by the great majority of members of Parliament, that there is overwhelming support in this chamber and in the House of Representatives and among the Australian public.

I stand in this debate with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), not slavishly but having independently reached the same conclusion. I stand with my colleagues, Senator Hill and Senator Durack, and with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, and with the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, all of whose speeches yesterday I heard or, in the case of the House of Representatives, I have read. I stand with Senator Newman in her references to the Australian Defence Force, with Senator Campbell in his references to Australian youth and with Senator Reid in her references to some of the Australian media.

I will quote two brief sections from the speeches given by Mr Hawke and Dr Hewson yesterday on this motion. These statements are typical of their sound contributions to the debate yesterday, and they are statements with which I fully agree. I quote the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke:

The decision to commit Australian forces to this war in the Gulf is without historical precedent. Never has Australian military action been undertaken with such global consent and within such a broad alliance. We stand with a coalition of nations the like of which, in its diversity, strength and authority, has never before been assembled. Never have the nations of the world acted in such overwhelming concert to condemn and to reverse an action as they have in these last few months condemned and acted to reverse Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
I quote from Dr Hewson, whose speech I found excellent in all that he said in the House of Representatives yesterday:

Australian interests in the current Gulf crisis are real and they are vital. We cannot expect others to protect them for us. They are interests that go to the heart of our values as a nation and our hopes for a newer and better world. They require us to be clear-eyed about why this war began and about the only way it can be ended. They may well require us to be in for the long haul in what may well be a very difficult campaign. They require us not to lose our nerve. And they also require us not to let rightly expressed differences of opinion among us obscure what is at stake for us as a nation.

I now wish briefly to summarise the six or seven specific factors based on evidence that have led me to the conclusion I have now outlined. I do not ask the Australian public or honourable senators to be moved to this conclusion by considering one or two of these reasons but by considering all six or seven reasons which I will now address. Firstly, I am convinced that sanctions have not been politically effective. Moreover, I believe they had no prospect of being politically effective. They were tested over a period of five months. I am not saying that the sanctions themselves were ineffective because clearly they were an effective net against 95 per cent of items of trade-that is, against items that were otherwise entering or leaving Iraq. However, it had become clear over the five months that the sanctions would in that fashion remain at the 95 per cent net virtually forever without leading to any change of mind, any response or any political change in the decisions of the government of Iraq. They were not politically effective.

Secondly, I believe that the attempts at diplomacy eventually failed. I do not suppose that in a period of four or five months there had ever been seen such intensity by the world through its diplomats, through its presidents, through its foreign ministers, to achieve the withdrawal of Iraq by diplomatic means. The Arab diplomacy had already failed by 2 August. The United Nations diplomacy failed despite stronger and stronger resolutions backed up by negotiation through 12 resolutions that have been referred to over these five months. Ultimately, there was the Secretary-General's, Perez de Cuellar's, tragic singular rejection by Saddam Hussein earlier this month. In particular, even the extraordinary diplomatic measures taken by the United States of America failed. On this point I briefly quote Senator Durack, the shadow Minister for Defence, who is here in the chamber. In his speech yesterday he said:

We in the Opposition would certainly want to emphasise the leading role that the United States has played in putting together that coalition of multinational force over these months. It has been a notable piece of diplomacy and leadership by the United States. But, of course, we must give credit to all those nations who have responded-as the Australian Government has responded, with the support of the Opposition-ever since these events commenced in August.

I agree with those remarks and I agree with all those who have commended the United States for its diplomatic initiatives over the last five months with the support of the Soviet Union, China, France, the United Kingdom and of other nations immediate to the region-Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Syria. But my conclusion is that that diplomacy failed. The end point which was demonstrated abundantly in the first two weeks of this month was a slap in the face to all of them by Iraq and a total rejection, a total defiance, by Saddam Hussein.

The third consideration is the brutality of Iraq which continues unrelenting day by day. I do not need to go over what more than 50 senators have already referred to in Iraq's aggression and its occupation of Kuwait-the murder, rape, looting, killing of children and the destruction of hospitals. Remember the capture of hostages-the thousands of hostages and eventually the 26 Australians-who were held against every international convention, who were held by a criminal Iraq. Now we have the intolerable news today that Iraq is beginning to treat prisoners of war in the same way as those hostages against all of the Geneva conventions. That is a criminal act by the Government of Iraq.

Not only are these offences continuing day by day, but the deception of the people of Iraq, by the Government and by Saddam Hussein in particular, has brutalised the people of Iraq by Hussein's distortion of Islam. Tell me of one imam in Australia who regards Hussein's interpretation of the Koran as orthodox or regards the brutalising of the people of Iraq, the hatred of Saddam Hussein of Israel and the allies in Saudi Arabia, his inciting of a jihad, his whipping up of religion and race as reasons to attack.

Fourthly, I give consideration to the greater threat to Israel and the holocaust to the Middle East that could have eventuated had there not been this intervention by the multinational force earlier this week. We have now seen the Iraqi attack on Israel, born out of Hussein's hatred; not out of any action or policy of Israel, not primarily out of the Palestinian issues. It is my view that Iraq's Scud missile attack on Israel this past week is intolerable; but it is also my view that it was inevitably coming from Iraq whatever happened this month.

The difference since 16 January is that the world can reasonably appeal to Israel not to hit back but to rely upon the multinational force that is in place to eliminate urgently the Scud missile launchers, the chemical weapons apparatus and any other equipment that Iraq is prepared to use in its unilateral attack on Israel.

Should Israel react, the consequences will be an increasing disarray and a new polarisation in the Middle East. Even now there is no assurance that Israel will not be further provoked to respond. However, the actions this week by the multinational force have considerably relieved the danger that would have eventuated had such an attack been made unilaterally on Israel by Iraq without the multinational force being able to respond to eliminate that threat to Israel.

Fifthly, it was time to act to prevent Iraq developing chemical and nuclear weapons and other consolidations of its military equipment. Iraq already has chemical weapons, as we well know; Iraq is developing nuclear weapons. I believe that if more months had gone by we would have seen a greater threat to the countries of the region, indeed to world peace, with an enhanced militarised Iraq-five months of extra military preparation by Iraq.

Sixthly, I consider that it is time to act so that Iraq's hoped for tactic does not succeed. Here I disagree with Senator Childs in his comments on this very point. As I see it, Iraq hoped to call the bluff of the United States, the Soviet Union, the United Kingdom, and even France to pursue the tactic of delay and more delay, and delay until even the people of our countries would hesitate and turn away from the resolve to act at all.

Seventhly and finally, the consideration in my mind is that there was a need for a response to defiance. Saddam Hussein was unquestionably defiant. There was a need to respond to ensure the credibility of the United Nations; to ensure that the multinational force was believable; that the statements made by our allies, indeed by our own country, were believable, that they were not idle threats; to ensure that the post-Cold War pattern of international relations is consolidated and goes in a positive direction; to demonstrate that invasion by an aggressor will in fact be resisted by the whole world; and to ensure that the Middle East is not left to the complete instability and disorder that would have followed.

The motion before us rightly refers to the security of Israel and to the resolution of the Palestinian issues. This is something which I am sure the majority of the Senate supports and is rightly a part of this motion. Senator Hill's remarks were particularly pertinent to these two elements of the instability in the Middle East over the past four decades.

I conclude by urging the Australian Government not only to act on the bases and for the reasons that have been set out by all of us in this Parliament, but to keep an open dialogue with the Australian people; to respond to the Australian people; and to ensure that we have in this Parliament and in the Government of Australia the full confidence of the Australian people. Finally, we pray for all those who are committed in this war, that they will see a successful peace. We pray for the families and the loved ones of those who are serving Australia and all nations in the Gulf, that they may see a speedy end to this war and the return of their loved ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion before the chamber. The chronology of events leading to the situation in which the world finds itself has been well canvassed by other speakers, and I will not repeat it. It is sufficient to say that a small country, Kuwait, was attacked and occupied by a powerful neighbouring country, led by a person who is recognised as being a sadistic killer. Real fear existed that, having taken Kuwait, the next move by Iraq would almost certainly have been into Saudi Arabia, and hence the location of troops in that country and the subsequent sanctions. All forms of diplomacy were used to convince Saddam Hussein to withdraw, and they were all exhausted. The United Nations voted for military intervention if all else failed, and when all else was correctly perceived to have failed, the United States, sanctioned by the United Nations and supported by 40 countries, attacked strategic targets in Kuwait and Iraq.

SPEECH.PARA: No sane person wanted this war. Everyone views with horror the death, injuries and destruction which come with war. To go to war is the most difficult decision any government will ever take. To commit its armed forces to a war zone is one of the most serious and grave decisions that can be taken. The Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, made the point in his address that the easiest way of winning publicity and cheap political points, particularly for an Opposition, would be to exaggerate popular fears and inflame suspicions-an easy option, as Dr Hewson said, but a course of action we in opposition would not pursue. That was the view of every member of the Opposition without-even though Senator McLean implied otherwise-being coerced by anyone. If the Australian Labor Party had been in opposition, I wonder whether it would have adopted such a reasoned approach. I doubt it; in fact, I am sure it would not have done so, and people who sit as Ministers on the other side of the chamber would almost certainly have been leading marches down the streets.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a cheap shot.
—Senator Bolkus may well have been the first cab off the rank.
—Did you hear me today?

—I did hear the self-justification of Senator Bolkus. If his party had been in opposition and we had been in government, I would bet his party would have been leading marches down the streets. Regrettably, the Australian Democrats have chosen to fan the flames of fear and suspicion. Senator McLean said, quite correctly, that war is an obscenity. No-one disagrees with that. The obscenity, however, is the person who started this conflict. That is where the obscenity lies; it lies not with those who decide to say, `Let us draw a line'-and a line must be drawn. Sure, one can argue and debate about the timing of that, but inevitably that time must come. Senator Kernot-and I am pleased that she has remained in the chamber throughout most of this debate, and I congratulate her on that-followed the same theme. She said-and I quote her without any sort of qualification at all:

SPEECH.PARA: I am one of those who believe there is no such thing as either a just war or a justifiable war.

That is a direct quote. What a very foolish statement from Senator Kernot. Apparently, Senator Kernot would have applied the same principle to World War II. It is all very well for the Democrats to be armchair pacifists. I would remind Senator Kernot and the other Democrats that in World War II Darwin-closer to home- was attacked, Townsville was attacked and midget submarines found their way into Sydney Harbour. Senator Kernot might also be aware that a hospital ship, the Centaur, was sunk off Cape Moreton within sight of the City of Brisbane, in which we both live. What effect would a call for sanctions have had on Japan in 1941?

If we were subject to similar attacks, would the Democrats be calling for sanctions and be leading the so-called peace movement? If the same thing happened again, would Senator Kernot be saying, `There is no such thing as a just war'? That is what she said: `There is no such thing ever as a just war'-without qualification. Or would she be calling for our allies, and particularly the United States (US), to come to our aid, as we did in World War II? If the US had not responded in the Battle of the Coral Sea, it could well be that the State in which both Senator Kernot and I live would have been occupied.
Senator Spindler referred to his own experience as a 12-year-old-refugee in Europe at the end of the war--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you think, Senator.

—I will indeed. Just wait for it. Senator Spindler referred to the total horror of the Holocaust. Surely Senator Spindler would agree that if Hitler had been stopped there would not have been a Holocaust; there would probably not have been a Second World War. My own father, a civilian, would probably not have been the first Australian killed in New Guinea by the Japanese in January 1942.
—Millions have learned the lessons of war.

—I am glad for that interjection. One of the reasons that we study history is to learn from history not to repeat the mistakes that occurred in the past. I notice in the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats that they call for an immediate cease-fire. Intentionally or not, they are acting as the apologists for Saddam Hussein. They are really the white feather party. Sanctions were given a chance in Iraq. They had not worked and all they were doing was giving Iraq an opportunity to build up its arsenal of chemical and biological weapons, and possibly a nuclear capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLean interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Interjections are disorderly.

—What Senator McLean has just said by way of interjection, as this Opposition and the Government is fully aware, is totally and utterly dishonest. What he said was that we were supplying uranium to Iraq.
—I did not say uranium at all.

—If the honourable senator did not, I apologise. Last Tuesday, I went down to have a look at a so-called peace rally in King George Square in Brisbane. I use the term `so-called' deliberately as it was not a peace rally. It was yet another anti-American rally. The slogans were the same, the people were the same, the organisations were the same as at every similar meeting I have seen in the past 20 years.
—How many people were there?

—Senator McLean interjects again and asks how many people were there. It is very interesting because we had a write-up in the newspaper. The day I went down there was a Tuesday, so let us not get the day incorrect. There were about 500, with a media write-up of about 1,500 to 2,000, in King George Square. Notwithstanding that, as in the past, there was a sprinkling of genuinely sincere people.
—A sprinkling?
—A sprinkling of genuinely sincere people. When I saw the radical group in the Parliament yesterday, I could not help but think--

SPEECH.PARA: Senate McLean interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes I think Senator McLean thinks he is the Kruschev of the Parliament. The only thing he has not done yet is to take his shoe off and hit it on the desk so that the rest of us cannot hear. When I saw the radical group in the Parliament yesterday-inflamed by certain senators here, quite deliberately for their own self-gratification; not worrying about those young people at all, just their own self-promotion-I could not help but think that they had no realisation that, but for the action of their grandfathers and with the support of United States men and women in times of crisis, particularly in World War II, there is every probability that they would not have been here yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Those people would not have existed. Let us recognise that reality. After that war, the United States did something that had never before been done. These things must be recognised. The United States assisted the vanquished Germany and Japan to get back on their feet. I do not think that such a thing has ever occurred before. After the atrocities, which were still fresh in their minds, and in the emotional aftermath of that war such an act signalled that man was capable of deeds which spelled hope for the future of civilisation. The United States has continued to carry the burden, both in human sacrifice and in economic terms, for the free world. For goodness sake, let us give recognition where it is due.

Yet again the United States is carrying the major burden. The aggressor in this war in the Middle East has been Iraq. Iraq invaded and occupied Kuwait. Iraq rejected all pleas, even those of its own neighbours and of the United Nations. A stand had to be taken. Okay, honourable senators can make a judgment as to when that stand should be taken.
Senator McLean interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator McLean, it is disorderly to be continually interjecting. I ask that Senator Parer be given the same courtesy as others who have contributed.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. A stand had to be taken, otherwise the world ran the risk of a much greater conflict in the future. It should be clearly recognised that, if a halt were not called now, within a year or two young people who are not engaged in a conflict now would probably be engaged in a much greater one, even to the extent of a third world war. Of course, when the Government was making its decision-and I commend the Government for it-it no doubt took that factor into consideration. As I mentioned at the beginning of my address, it is not an easy decision; it is a very tough and grave decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the motion. Along with the majority of Australians, I hope and pray that the conflict is over quickly, with a minimum loss of life. War, by its very nature, must involve a loss of life. That is a fact that does not give me any pleasure. I hope that a lasting peace will be restored to the troubled area and that the Australians engaged in the war zone return safely to their families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume that most of my colleagues who are here tonight are not here to listen to me. They must have realised that I was going to be the last speaker. However, I find that I am the penultimate speaker. I state right at the beginning of my short speech that I too support the motion relating to the Gulf war moved by the Government and supported by the vast majority of members and senators.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the basic principles of a democracy is that majority rules. In this case it is not just a large majority of parliamentarians who support Australia's role in the Gulf. According to yesterday's Australian newspaper, it appears that almost 75 per cent of the Australian people agree with our involvement. That is not to say that the opposing view has not been well aired. Elements of the print and electronic media have certainly promoted the minority view. Indeed, the Sydney Morning Herald and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation seem to have shown a certain bias against the Government's position.

The Australian Democrats have tried to take the high moral ground in their usual muddled way. On the one hand we have them opposing the use of force in the Middle East and, on the other, we have Senator Bell giving a notice of motion advocating that Latvia establish a self-defence force to combat the aggression being perpetrated on the democratically elected government of Latvia by elements of the Soviet Army.
