But do not take just my word for it. The Australian Democrats' position is well summed up by two articles that I read in yesterday's newspapers. One was in the Herald Sun and the other was in the Hobart Mercury.

TALK.START.PARA: —I replied to that today.
—I will just read them for the benefit of those who have not seen Senator McLean's reply. The Hobart Mercury said:

SPEECH.PARA: In their headlong charge to capture the moral high ground, the Australian Democrats have sunk into the mire.
It went on to say:
What is offensive is the hypocrisy being shown by the Australian Democrats in their efforts to emphasise the quality of their morality.
But I think the best quote was from Terry Vine in the Herald Sun.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you read it to the Senate.
—I am going to read some of it-the first few paragraphs anyway. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Ever get the feeling that everyone is out of step except our Democrats?
Talk about keeping the bastards honest! They can't even keep themselves on the right road.

Never has there been a political party in Australia so full of misfits, each going his or her own way, each chasing his or her own star and all of them jumping in to support any issue going as long as it will get their names in the paper.
Obviously, Senator McLean is going to get his name in the paper when he replies to the editorial in the Mercury. Terry Vine went on to say:
When Don Chipp and John Siddons ran the Democrats, they seemed to have some purpose in life and their policy of keeping the major parties honest had real meaning.
Now they have degenerated into a bunch of idealists and most of the time they can't even agree among themselves.

He went on to talk about Janet Powell. Anyway, enough of the Democrats. We have had interjections right through this very long and very serious debate from the Democrats. I did not interject on Senator McLean, but I presume that in the few minutes I have got I will certainly get plenty.

Mr Acting Deputy President, yesterday when I was carrying out a similar duty to yourself as the occupant of the chair, I had the opportunity to hear many fine speeches on this grave situation and to emulate them in the short time I have available to me would be futile. What I would like to do, as one of the final speakers, is to sum up what seems to me to be the major reasons for Australia's position in this crisis.

Firstly, when one is forced into a fight, one's first task is to assess the character of who one is fighting. In this case, the opponent is Saddam Hussein, the butcher of Baghdad, a tyrant and dictator who will stop at nothing to get his own way. This man has no principles, as shown on countless occasions, which I think is agreed by everybody in this place. He has encouraged torture, looting, killing and rape in Kuwait. He has attempted to use hostages as a human shield. In the last few days he has ignored the Geneva convention and used prisoners of war for his own political purposes. He has shown disregard for every convention. He has used poison gas on the Kurdish people, citizens of Iraq-his own people-and no doubt when ready he would resort to the use of nuclear weapons.

The human rights atrocities have been well documented by Amnesty International. I must say that I was very moved by the contribution of Senator Tate, a fellow Tasmanian and a man of high Christian and moral principles, who explained to the Senate why he had wrestled with his pacifist principles to arrive at a position where he could condone Australia being involved in war. No-one could help but be moved by the description of the atrocities conducted on the Kuwaiti people, particularly the unforgivable actions against 300 helpless premature babies. So we know our opponent, a cruel, barbaric tyrant, has to be stopped.

Secondly, I believe it is appropriate that in the Australian Parliament we recognise the selfless efforts of the United Nations Secretary-General, Mr Javier Perez de Cuellar, in his own personal efforts to secure peace in the Middle East. It became apparent towards the end of these efforts that Saddam Hussein was not interested in peace but rather sought to pursue his own political agenda. The United Nations represents the rule of law of the world as we know it, and it should not be forgotten that the Security Council of the United Nations has now passed a total of 12 resolutions which have condemned Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait and called for its withdrawal. In addition, the use of hostages has been condemned and, finally, after the failure of economic sanctions, there was no alternative but to approve the use of force to evict Iraq from the neighbour which it had invaded.

Thirdly, Senator Vallentine and the Australian Democrats have asked for more time to allow sanctions to work. After some 5 1/2 months, it is quite obvious that Saddam Hussein will not withdraw from Kuwait. Senator McMullan and others on that side of the House have explained how Daniel Ortega had stated to Mr Craxi, the former Socialist Prime Minister of Italy, that Saddam would not be convinced to withdraw from Kuwait. I quote:
The one word Saddam Hussein intends not uttering is the word withdrawal.

All opportunities for a peaceful solution have been exhausted. It was interesting to note Senator McMullan's admission that, as one who strongly opposed Australia's involvement in Vietnam, he could now see no alternative but to fight the aggression in Kuwait. It is also interesting to note that one of the leaders of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party, Senator Bolkus, has pleaded with his left wing colleagues and the peace movement to support our presence in the Gulf. This crisis has brought most of the factionalised Labor Party together in support of our armed forces.

The coalition position is quite clear. Dr Hewson, our leader, and every other member of the Federal coalition supports this motion. We are not confused like the Democrats, nor divided like the Labor Party. We know the enemy; we know the consequences of our action; we know, as Senator Short said during the debate, that we are part of a multinational force of 28 nations which has the support of some 140 independent countries of all political views who support United Nations resolution 678.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you have made a warlike interpretation.

—It is true that times of war tend to bring out both the best and the worst in people. We have already heard Senator Newman and Senator Robert Ray criticise the despicable rumours which have been deliberately perpetrated on the subject of conscription and an escalation of Australia's involvement in the Gulf war. These have been spread purely to cause concern and anguish against the families of Australian young people. There is no basis or foundation in any of these rumours and the perpetrators should be held liable for their acts, be they for political or personal gain.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the more scurrilous efforts has come, not surprisingly perhaps, from the Tasmanian Aboriginal activist, Mr Michael Mansell, the so-called national secretary of the so-called Aboriginal provisional government. Senators in this chamber may recall that it was not that long ago that Mr Mansell was in Libya attempting to grovel at the feet of another well known assassin, Colonel Gaddafi. Mr Mansell has recently called for Aboriginals in the armed forces not to fight in the Gulf war but rather to take up arms against the Hawke Government. These comments are nothing short of traitorous, and I trust that if there was ever any doubt about Mr Mansell's intentions his recent outburst has placed them in their proper perspective.

For the first time in my lifetime, we have an opportunity to be part of a new world order-a phrase used by President Bush, our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and many others. Let us hope that if this new world order is allowed to work in the Gulf, then this new world order can be used to stop the blatant abuse by the Soviet Government against the independent Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. For the first time in my lifetime, we have a chance to allow the United Nations to achieve peace-a peace we have been lucky enough to have in our lucky country of Australia; a peace that has been achieved in Australia not by appeasement but earned by our people because they believe that if we are to have peace and we want peace, when all else fails, we have to be prepared to fight for peace. If Australia had not been prepared to fight for peace in the past and support our allies as they have well and truly supported us, then this country would have already in its 200 year history tasted war on our own soil, as Senator Parer said earlier.

If it had not been for our American allies in World War II, Australia would certainly have been involved in war in its own land. How can we expect other countries to help defend us if we do not support other countries in their fight for peace? Finally, we know the enemy, we know the consequences, we know why we are there, and let us hope for a quick solution so that peace can be restored.

I would also like to take this opportunity to extend my concern to the families of three Tasmanian peace activists whose whereabouts are currently unknown, although I did notice tonight that they made contact, I believe, through another source. I refer to Mr Tom Lynch of Lune River, Mr Jack Lomax of Lachlan and Ms Liz Denham of Hobart, who formed part of the Australian contingent of an international peace delegation to the region. I do not condone their actions, which I think have been best described by others as irresponsible and fruitless, but at the same time I trust that they may safely return to Australia.

Lastly, I wish to add my support for our armed forces in the Gulf, my prayers for their safe return and my best wishes and support for their families and friends. On behalf of Tasmanians, we send our support to those Tasmanian sailors serving in the Gulf. To our Telecom technicians working in Saudi Arabia, we hope that they and their families are safe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a particularly sad time for us all-that is, of course, except the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine-as we are discussing what in effect is a commitment of our fine Australian service men and women to a world war. I am the last of 58 speakers-there are 76 senators-to contribute to this debate. This debate has been particularly significant inasmuch as in the six years that I have been here I do not think anything as critical as this matter has been debated as thoroughly. But some of the lunacy contributed by a very few honourable senators has been disturbing.

SPEECH.PARA: I except the expression of sadness from the Democrats in this debate, and I also except that of Senator Vallentine for a very special reason. They are delighted to have this issue as something through which they can attempt to attract a minority of people to vote for them at the next election and improve their waning support. Their contributions over the last two days have simply reinforced that position. Their short-sighted view is of course purely anti-American; no more, no less. This typifies their lack of understanding of Hussein's atrocities and thereby virtually condones his actions.

If they saw the news tonight and saw the state of those hostages, I cannot believe that they would continue with the sanctimonious claptrap that they have gone on with now for two days in this place, let alone the amount of time they have spent outside the Senate. The way Senator Powell and her Democrat flunkeys and Senator Vallentine have engineered such appalling behaviour from so-called peace-loving people is a monumental disgrace. If the way in which the demonstrators have conducted themselves over the last few weeks is meant to be indicative of peace, they are clearly barking up the wrong tree.

It has been like sitting in a bird cage for the last two days, with Senator Powell rabbiting on and Senator Kernot rabbiting on. But, of course, Senator Vallentine has not necessarily contributed much because, as my colleague Senator Campbell highlighted just after 8 o'clock, at that stage she had been in the chamber for only two out of 14 hours. At this stage I think she has only been in the chamber for certainly not much more than four out of more than 20 hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —She spends a lot of time in the other chamber.

—That is right. I will acknowledge the interjection of Senator Campbell because Senator Vallentine has made a disgrace of parliamentarians in the past day when she deliberately and willingly not only disrupted the Senate but also went over to the House of Representatives to interject on a speech being made by the Prime Minister of this country, Mr Hawke, a speech to the nation which is probably the most important speech a Prime Minister could ever give to his country.

SPEECH.PARA: The difference between us and them a la the Democrats and Senator Vallentine is that we first of all consider what is right and proper for the welfare of all Australians and the world at large. For Senator Powell to acknowledge, as she did at Question Time today, an unruly protester as it was escorted out of the gallery shows Australia the contempt in which she holds the institution of the Parliament. On the subject of contempt for the institution of Parliament, Senator Vallentine has the ability to equal, if not better, Senator Powell. Yesterday Senator Vallentine actually went up to the gallery and encouraged her supporters to misbehave and to create an unruly scene.

TALK.START.PARA: —Her office signed them in today.

—I understand from what Senator Tambling is saying-and I have had it verified from other sources-that her office actually signed them in through security today. One need only look at their conduct to feel nervous.
—What about the way in which it was not possible to--
—Order! Senator Vallentine.

—Not only did Senator Vallentine organise and egg on her so-called peace group the day before yesterday and yesterday to behave in an unruly manner, but she too went into the senators gallery, as I say, in the House of Representatives. Of course, all who know her would be well aware that she was seeking to get thrown out-again-and to obtain more publicity. However, the fact remains that she behaved, and continues to behave, in a manner now considered highly inappropriate by the public for members of parliament. Foul language and inciting people to misbehave is hardly becoming of a senator or any other member of parliament. Senator Vallentine is guilty on both counts and Senator Powell certainly on the latter.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not question the right of people to express their views, but why not do it courteously and within the law? We have seen members of the Australian Labor Party say that they are going to abstain from the vote on this resolution. We have not tried, and will not try, to score cheap political points, because we believe that this issue is a very important one. We have no doubt that if the boot were on the other foot we would probably have it poked down our throats at a rate of knots.

I think that it is important that we are seen to be unified on this issue, and that is why we have gone along with the motion in its entirety. Why also should the truth not be told? Why is it that Senators Powell and Vallentine choose to keep promoting the lie that they are speaking for 50 per cent of Australians? Not only do all polls conducted in Australia-and around the world, for that matter-not go above 25 per cent opposition to the war, but these two senators also use the figures for people who have marched against the Government's and the Opposition's decision.
Australian Democrat senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, you can see what I mean about spending your life in an aviary with this mob.
—Order! It is late in the evening. It has been a very productive and positive debate. I will not stand for any future interjections. The last speaker will be heard in silence.

—Thank you. If one adds all the marchers together, at best they represent one per cent of Australia's population. For those Australian Democrat and independent senators-I do not include Senator Harradine of course-to claim that they are representing over 50 per cent is just absolute rot. Also, it must not be forgotten that most of those in favour of the decision are just too busy earning a living to go on the streets and show their support.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that has staggered me over the Democrats position is their total and unequivocal ditching of their founder and former leader, Don Chipp. How he must wish that he could keep the bastards honest now. The only difference is that it is a different set of bastards. Mr Chipp has written and said that Hussein deserves this fight, and I would like to quote from two articles written by Mr Chipp. They are as follows:
If we are to talk about the probity, or lack of it, of using force against Hussein, surely the first question to be determined is do we have the right to defend ourselves?
I believe I have the right to defend myself and my loved ones by reasonably violent means if we are being physically attacked.
Consider the Iraqi dictator in this context.

He climbed to his position of power through murder, torture and terrorism. In September, 1980, he revoked a border treaty with Iran and began an eight-year war which was to account for more than a million people being killed.
He went on to say:
If such a man is allowed to hijack the worldwide Islamic renaissance, a global holocaust of breathtaking proportions would be inevitable.
The founder of the Australian Democrats wrote that-quite clearly, quite succinctly-yet Senator Powell takes them off down another track. In another article Mr Chipp also wrote:
It would be intolerable for any Arab or Muslim to be allowed to support publicly Hussein's cause with impunity.
Such a person should not only be liable to criticism by the Australian media, but should be charged and, if found guilty of sedition or treason, put away for the duration.
Would that not be gorgeous? I have certain people in mind, of course. He continued:
We are at a time when we should contemplate the devastation, suffering and death that man, assisted by a few fanatics, can inflict on humankind if their greed and lust are allowed to go unchecked.
The Iraqi killers have already been responsible for more than a million deaths, inflicting hideous pain through chemicals and by terrible acts of torture on their own people.
Now they imperil the economic and political stability of the entire world.
They have jeopardised the hopes and happiness of hundreds of millions of people in newly emerging eastern European economies who have not known financial security for 50 years.
If the 28-nation task force in the Gulf succeeds, it will certainly begin a new era in world politics where it can be proven that the United Nations can provide peace and safety for small nations.

Of course, Senator Powell has taken over the leadership of the Australian Democrats, and she has not only taken them to the left, but to the left right out position of the Parliament, and at least through this issue has had a greater opportunity to show Australians exactly what she is like and what a bunch of lunatics she represents. It must be cause for great concern for their founder, seeing just what a monster he created.

No-one wants this war, and I find it singularly offensive for Senator Powell and Senator Vallentine in particular to claim that they have a mortgage on the desire for peace. Those of us who are supporting the motion before the Senate this morning actually do care about peace and are prepared to make the hard decisions in an attempt to achieve it. Those supporting this motion are also prepared to put politics aside and act in the national and global interest. I wish I could say the same for the Democrats and Senator Vallentine.

The Australians who are serving their country overseas and their families deserve our support and our gratitude. Let us not diminish that and have it overwhelmed by groups or individuals who simply seek cheap publicity for their own ends and not for the security of Australia and the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I rise to make a somewhat unusual personal explanation because I speak as a doctor. I refer to remarks made earlier this evening by a fellow doctor, Senator Herron, when he appeared to make both a diagnosis and an offer of treatment of Senator Vallentine. If his remarks were made in a flippant manner--

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. On the basis on which Senator Coulter has introduced this subject, this cannot be a personal explanation. It is a comment on what other honourable senators have said.
—You have not heard it yet.
—Well, if Senator Coulter claims to have been misrepresented and is making a personal explanation, at the beginning he must state what the misrepresentation is. I do not think he has done very well.
—Order! Senator Coulter, you must confine yourself to where you have personally been misrepresented in this debate.
—Mr President, I did not mention Senator Coulter.
—How can you misrepresent him if you did not mention him?
—You have never been helpful, nor are you on this occasion.
—Order! I was not here for the contribution but I will listen to Senator Coulter.

— Thank you, Mr President. I am speaking as a doctor and I am making the point that if Senator Herron's remarks were meant in a flippant manner-although that is not the point I am making here-I regard the remarks as unparliamentary.
—There is no claim to have been misrepresented. There is no class action here in the Senate in relation to misrepresentation.
—I call Senator Vallentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. I was not actually going to mention Senator Herron but, as the question has been raised, he talked in very disparaging terms about a medical diagnosis and said that I needed a second opinion. I think it was most unparliamentary. I really wanted to talk earlier about Senator Schacht, who early this morning misrepresented a statement that I made when I quoted Martin Luther King. Senator Schacht suggested that I did not understand Martin Luther King saying that there was no recognition of evil or no need to resist evil. Senator Schacht completely misunderstands the meaning of active resistance. I have never advocated passive resistance, which is what Senator Schacht claimed. He misrepresented my position, which is one not of passive resistance but of active non-violent resistance. Martin Luther King advocated that as well.
— Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Vallentine is debating the point.
—Order! I think that Senator Vallentine is really debating the point. Say where you personally have been misrepresented, Senator Vallentine.

—I have been personally misrepresented many times during the day. I will not go through all of them, honourable senators will be pleased to know, because of the hour. Earlier Senator Campbell said that I personally conspired to disrupt the Parliament by going upstairs. Senator Knowles repeated the allegation. It is not true. When I went up to the gallery yesterday, I was quite surprised that there was a round of applause from the gallery. I did not know that people were up there at that point. This was very early on, Mr President, as you may remember. I went up there after you had cautioned people for applauding from the gallery. I went up to the people in the gallery and said, `You will be thrown out of here if you make noise. You have to remain silent in the gallery. If you want to listen to the debate you must be quiet and you must not applaud. If you interject you will be thrown out'.

SPEECH.PARA: It was important that people had that reaffirmed. They did not take much notice of me, mind you, but that is exactly what I went up there and said. I have never conspired with anybody else for the disruption of this Parliament. I disclaim that statement that was made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is now clearly becoming a debate. I doubt whether it was a personal explanation in the first instance, but it cannot be sustained as one at the moment. I therefore suggest that you inform the Senator of that and that we proceed to the votes that we have to deal with.
—Senator Vallentine, you are speaking to the point of order.
—Mr President, that is one of the things that was said-that I had conspired. It is not true so I have to disclaim it. Senator Baume said--
—Oh, Mr President.
—Order! Senator Hill, I really think Senator Vallentine is making a personal explanation.

—Senator Baume said, among many other things, that I was anti-Israeli. This is not true. I challenge Senator Baume to look in the Hansard and find anything which I have said which is anti-Israeli. I commend the Israelis for their restraint in the last week in the face of Iraq's attacks, which I deplore. I do not believe that Israel is blameless in the long term in this whole issue. Over many years the rights of Palestinians have been denied. But I reject totally the allegation that I am anti-Israeli. I believe in the right of Israel to exist and the right of other nations to co-exist with Israel with their own rights intact. That is not the situation in the Middle East.

SPEECH.PARA: Numerous senators have claimed that I have said that Iraq should stay in Kuwait. That, also, is untrue, Mr President. I have never said that Iraq has any right to stay in Kuwait. What I have said consistently in this debate is that we should not be going to war to eject Iraq from Kuwait and that sanctions should have been given time to work. I reject totally any suggestion that I have said that Iraq should stay in Kuwait.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is not possible to continue the debate when the debate has been concluded, under the guise of making a personal explanation on the grounds that this particular senator has been misrepresented.
—Senator Vallentine has claimed to have been misrepresented. I must remind her that she cannot turn this into a debate and comment on every speech that senators have made.

—Mr President, I do not intend to do that. There have been 58 speeches and I am commenting on just a few of them. Just a few moments ago, Senator Knowles accused me of using foul language. I challenge her to demonstrate that. I have not used foul language in this place; I would never do that and I have not done it. She is not speaking the truth. There have been many comments about interjections that I have made--
—Order! That is not a personal explanation. Resume your seat.

—by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. As in Senator Vallentine's case, there are probably many instances that I could cite, but most recently Senator Knowles said that under my leadership I had turned the Australian Democrats into a monster. I have done no such thing. While I do not claim to have turned the Democrats into anything, at this point the Democrats are the only opposition in this country.
—Order! Senator Powell, you know that is not a personal explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to close the debate in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLean interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —You get violent. You are as big a fraud as she is.
—Order! Senator McKiernan, all interjections are disorderly, but if you make them at least you ought to be in your proper seat.
—I apologise, but I am in my proper seat.
—It is a long time since you have been there.

—I rise to close the debate. The first thing I intended to say was that many of the 58 speeches that were made-I have not heard them all, of course, but I have listened to a number of them-have been a credit to the Senate on the whole. One may find that unbelievable after the last 20 minutes, sadly--
—Oh!

—Including Senator Powell's performance. It is unbelievable to be able to say that, but the fact of the matter is that, during the two days the Parliament has been sitting, that has been so. Of course, the issue should have been debated seriously because it was one of the most difficult issues to come before this Parliament as it involves the commitment of Australian armed forces to military action in the Gulf authorised by the United Nations.

SPEECH.PARA: I express my thanks to those senators who have taken part in the debate, regardless of their party or affiliation. I must say that I think I have to do that regardless of their views, a number of which I do not share personally. Each of us has different views and different points of emphasis in considering the enormous issues which are associated with this commitment by the United Nations and the commitment of Australian forces to that effort.

There has been a fair degree of realism and a shared concern for the best interests of Australia, even across party lines and even across differences of opinion which have emerged in the course of the debate. I am very pleased that this motion will be passed with a significant majority, because it is important that we as a parliament carry out our responsibilities in the shared spirit of commitment to Australia's national interest that has characterised this debate.

It is also important that we send a strong message to a number of people who normally might not take much notice of this Parliament's deliberations. I think it is important that we send a message to those serving personnel on the three ships in the Gulf and to our allies in the coalition whose parliaments have had similar debates. That message involves condemnation of Iraq's attack on Israel and the original occupation of Kuwait. To that extent, it involves an expression of sympathy with the people of Kuwait and more recently with the people of Israel.

The message also underlines this Parliament's concern that once this crisis is over, there will be intensified efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, something which is overlooked and ignored on a day by day basis in the political debate in this country. It is important that commitment is there in the motion which is hopefully about to be adopted.

It is important that Australians understand the facts of the situation, however confusing some of the arguments may have been. Although there have been differences of opinion about the facts, I think that the debates which have taken place and which I understand have been widely listened to in the Australian community, will ensure a better understanding of the issues and of the concerns of the majority in the Senate and the majority in the House of Representatives to establish a degree of commitment to what is happening in the Gulf and a commitment to our allies in that operation.

The Government takes the view that we have made the right decision on behalf of the Australian people. It is important that all those who are carrying out that decision in terms of their personal commitment, whether they be in the Gulf or elsewhere in the Middle East, understand the commitment and support of the Australian Parliament. Accordingly, I commend the motion to the Senate.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Reid

TALK.START.PARA: —I merely ask that it be recorded that Senator Lewis is not present and has not voted. He would have voted with the Opposition and the Government but he had to return to Melbourne for personal reasons.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the motion (Senator Button's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button)-by leave-agreed to:
That the order of the Senate of 23 August 1990 relating to the presentation of committee reports when the Senate is adjourned have effect till the next day of sitting.
Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:
That leave of absence be granted to every member of the Senate from the termination of the sitting this day to the day on which the Senate next meets.
Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:

That the Senate, at its rising, adjourn till Tuesday, 12 February 1991, at 2 p.m., or such other time as may be fixed by the President or, in the event of the President being unavailable, by the Deputy-President, and that the time of meeting so determined shall be notified to each senator.
Senate adjourned at 2.50 a.m. (Wednesday), until 2 p.m. on Tuesday, 12 February 1991, unless otherwise called together in accordance with the resolution agreed to this day.
